question: When considering an Application for Listing, what actions may the Regulator take regarding admission of Securities to the Official List, and how does the authority under section 52(1)(b) of the FSMR relate to the circumstance-based power described in subsection (2)?
expected_answer: The Regulator has power to manage outcomes at the listing stage by either declining the Application for Listing or controlling the terms on which Securities are admitted to the Official List through conditions or restrictions, including later changing or removing those conditions or restrictions. [#TGT:764bd3fc-ac8b-451f-b8bb-aa931a00c48b] In addition, section 52(1)(b) of the FSMR specifically supports the Regulator’s ability to impose conditions or restrictions on admission to the Official List and to vary or withdraw them, which aligns with (and is reflected in) the same set of actions described for admission decisions in the listing context. [#SRC:790f04b5-f8da-46cb-9014-cff27cdb7226] The circumstance-based framing in the listing provision means these actions (refusal, or the imposition/variation/withdrawal of conditions or restrictions) are exercisable in the circumstances identified in subsection (2), rather than as an unqualified discretion. [#TGT:764bd3fc-ac8b-451f-b8bb-aa931a00c48b] Practically, this links the FSMR section 52(1)(b) authority over admission conditions to the listing decision pathway that also includes the option to refuse the Application for Listing, with both sets of actions operating within the subsection (2) circumstances. [#SRC:790f04b5-f8da-46cb-9014-cff27cdb7226] [#TGT:764bd3fc-ac8b-451f-b8bb-aa931a00c48b]

question: If the Regulator is looking at an Application for Listing, what can it do (including refusing the application), and how does section 52(1)(b) of the FSMR fit with the rule that these actions are only available in the circumstances in subsection (2)?
expected_answer: For an Application for Listing, the Regulator can choose to refuse the Application for Listing, or it can allow admission of Securities to the Official List but attach conditions or restrictions to that admission. [#TGT:764bd3fc-ac8b-451f-b8bb-aa931a00c48b] If conditions or restrictions are used, the Regulator can also later change them or remove them entirely (vary or withdraw them). [#TGT:764bd3fc-ac8b-451f-b8bb-aa931a00c48b] Section 52(1)(b) of the FSMR provides the underlying authority for the admission-related part of this: it expressly allows the Regulator to impose conditions or restrictions on admission of Securities to the Official List and to vary or withdraw those conditions or restrictions. [#SRC:790f04b5-f8da-46cb-9014-cff27cdb7226] The listing provision adds an important boundary: the Regulator’s ability to refuse the application or to impose/vary/withdraw admission conditions is stated to apply in the circumstances specified in subsection (2). [#TGT:764bd3fc-ac8b-451f-b8bb-aa931a00c48b] Taken together, section 52(1)(b) explains the scope of the admission-condition tools, while the listing provision ties both refusal and those tools to the subsection (2) circumstances. [#SRC:790f04b5-f8da-46cb-9014-cff27cdb7226] [#TGT:764bd3fc-ac8b-451f-b8bb-aa931a00c48b]

question: For a Reporting Entity, how do the section 82 FSMR obligation to appoint an auditor and the requirement that the auditor be appointed in accordance with Part 15 and any Rules made for that Part operate together when making the appointment?
expected_answer: A Reporting Entity must ensure it has an auditor and that the appointment is made through the specific framework referenced for auditor appointments. [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb] The baseline obligation is that the Reporting Entity is required to appoint an auditor under section 82 of the FSMR, so the entity cannot omit making an appointment. [#SRC:0b00ca08-6924-419e-b76d-dd66e5575a33] In addition, the appointment is not merely a general designation; it must be carried out in accordance with Part 15 and any Rules made for the purposes of that Part, meaning the Reporting Entity must follow that Part 15/Rules pathway when appointing the auditor. [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb] Read together, section 82 establishes the duty to appoint, while the Part 15 and related Rules condition specifies the required method or procedural basis for how the auditor is appointed. [#SRC:0b00ca08-6924-419e-b76d-dd66e5575a33] [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb] Accordingly, compliance requires both (i) making an auditor appointment and (ii) ensuring that appointment is made under the Part 15 and Rules framework, rather than outside it. [#SRC:0b00ca08-6924-419e-b76d-dd66e5575a33] [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb]

expected_answer: A Reporting Entity must both appoint an auditor and make that appointment using the specific appointment framework referenced for financial reports. [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb] Section 82 of the FSMR creates the requirement for a Reporting Entity to appoint an auditor, so the entity has a clear duty to make an appointment rather than leaving the role unfilled. [#SRC:0b00ca08-6924-419e-b76d-dd66e5575a33] The financial reports provision adds that the Reporting Entity must have an auditor appointed in accordance with Part 15 and any Rules made for the purposes of that Part, so the appointment must be done through that Part 15 and Rules route. [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb] Putting these together, the “what” is appointing an auditor (the obligation), and the “how” is that the appointment must be made in line with Part 15 and any Rules made for that Part (the required basis for the appointment). [#SRC:0b00ca08-6924-419e-b76d-dd66e5575a33] [#TGT:74fee9ec-688d-43df-99e1-bc5b4f83f0fb] This means a Reporting Entity should treat Part 15 and its Rules as the governing process for fulfilling the section 82 appointment duty. question: Where an Applicant/Authorised Person seeks FSRA approval for its FSP to cover a Regulated Activity in relation to both conventional assets (e.g., Securities or Derivatives) and Spot Commodities, how should the fee outcome be determined if the Regulator considers it fair and reasonable to reduce, waive or refund fees in that particular case?
expected_answer: If an Applicant/Authorised Person will undertake a Regulated Activity involving conventional assets in addition to Spot Commodities, it must seek approval from the FSRA for its FSP to permit it to carry out its Regulated Activity in relation to both asset types. [#SRC:e801f4a4-1a6e-4c91-92d6-724eec350cc0] In that dual-asset scenario, the fee outcome is not automatically cumulative across the conventional and Spot Commodity-related Regulated Activities where the FSRA exercises discretion to reduce or waive a fee, taking into account the high fees already imposed on Applicants/Authorised Persons conducting Regulated Activities using Spot Commodities. [#SRC:e801f4a4-1a6e-4c91-92d6-724eec350cc0] This aligns with the Regulator’s broader power to reduce, waive, or refund all or part of any fee (including supplementary or late payment fees) at any time, provided it considers that doing so would be fair and reasonable in the circumstances of the particular case. [#TGT:0caa9f08-40e5-42b7-9cef-4148ae1dc036] Accordingly, when the Regulator reaches a fairness-and-reasonableness view for the specific case, it may implement that relief in a way that prevents fees from stacking cumulatively across the two asset types, rather than charging full fees for both without adjustment. [#SRC:e801f4a4-1a6e-4c91-92d6-724eec350cc0] [#TGT:0caa9f08-40e5-42b7-9cef-4148ae1dc036]

question: When deciding whether to revoke a Recognition Order, how does the Regulator distinguish between using its power to give directions to secure compliance with the Recognition Requirements (including directions that may require premises access or suspension of activities) and proceeding to revocation, and what specific circumstances trigger the revocation approach?
expected_answer: The Regulator may use directions to require a Recognised Body to take specified steps to secure compliance with the Recognition Requirements, but it will usually consider revoking a Recognition Order where a direction is not suitable or the Recognised Body’s position warrants revocation. [#TGT:83e95cf0-0fcf-4cb3-ab07-0404f8736500] In particular, revocation is typically considered if the Recognised Body is failing or has failed to meet one or more Recognition Requirements and that failure has or will have serious consequences. [#SRC:45239250-1e38-4dc5-ac39-f213f5fe4a6a] Revocation is also the usual approach where it would not be possible for the Recognised Body to comply with a direction given under the Regulator’s direction power, or where (for another reason) it would not be appropriate for the Regulator to give such a direction. [#SRC:45239250-1e38-4dc5-ac39-f213f5fe4a6a] By contrast, where directions are used, the specified steps can include granting the Regulator access to the Recognised Body’s premises to inspect the premises or documents there, and requiring suspension of the carrying on of any activity for the period stated in the direction. [#TGT:83e95cf0-0fcf-4cb3-ab07-0404f8736500] Separately, revocation is usually considered if the Recognised Body has not carried on the business of a Recognised Body during the 12 months starting on the day the Recognition Order took effect, or has not carried on that business at any time during the six months ending on the day the Recognition Order is revoked. [#SRC:45239250-1e38-4dc5-ac39-f213f5fe4a6a]

question: Where an Issuer makes an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM and has published a Prospectus, what must the Issuer (or the person responsible for the issue of the Prospectus) do if, after the Prospectus is issued, a significant change occurs or a material mistake/inaccuracy or significant new matter arises, and what baseline prospectus requirement anchors this obligation?
expected_answer: In this scenario, the Issuer’s baseline obligation is to publish a Prospectus when it wishes to make an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM. [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd] Once that Prospectus has been issued, if at any time afterward there is a significant change in information, a material mistake or inaccuracy affecting a matter in the Prospectus, or a significant new matter arises, the Issuer or the person responsible for issuing the Prospectus must issue a supplementary prospectus. [#TGT:570827ee-e3f5-499b-8451-bbc5bdb6d80c] The supplementary prospectus must (i) set out details of the relevant change, mistake, inaccuracy, or new matter, and (ii) meet the requirements referenced in section 62(1). [#TGT:570827ee-e3f5-499b-8451-bbc5bdb6d80c] The timing trigger is explicitly “after the issue of a Prospectus” and applies whenever the specified events occur, meaning the duty is ongoing for the period after issuance rather than limited to a single update point. [#TGT:570827ee-e3f5-499b-8451-bbc5bdb6d80c] This supplementary-prospectus duty is therefore an extension of the initial prospectus publication requirement that applies to Offers of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM. [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd]

question: If an Issuer is offering Securities to the public in or from ADGM and has already put out a Prospectus, what should happen if something important changes or a big error is found after the Prospectus is issued, and how does this connect to the original need to publish a Prospectus?
expected_answer: For an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM, the Issuer is expected to publish a Prospectus as part of the applicable requirements for such offers. [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd] After that Prospectus has been issued, the rules then require an additional step if certain events occur: if at any time there is a significant change, or a material mistake or inaccuracy affecting something in the Prospectus, or a significant new matter arises, the Issuer (or the person responsible for issuing the Prospectus) must produce a supplementary prospectus. [#TGT:570827ee-e3f5-499b-8451-bbc5bdb6d80c] That supplementary prospectus has two core content/compliance elements: it must describe the relevant change, mistake, inaccuracy, or new matter, and it must comply with the requirements in section 62(1). [#TGT:570827ee-e3f5-499b-8451-bbc5bdb6d80c] The link between the two texts is that the supplementary prospectus obligation only makes sense once the Issuer has already met the initial prospectus publication requirement for the public offer in or from ADGM. [#SRC:d7598df9-aeea-4b2d-b1ef-e4e98bea49dd] The trigger is explicitly tied to the period after the Prospectus is issued, and it applies whenever the specified kinds of developments occur. [#TGT:570827ee-e3f5-499b-8451-bbc5bdb6d80c]

question: When a Petroleum Reporting Entity has new material estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves that have not previously been disclosed, what is the required disclosure timing and what specific content elements must be included in that disclosure (including how it should address prior disclosures)?
expected_answer: A Petroleum Reporting Entity must make an immediate disclosure when it has new material estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves that have not previously been disclosed. [#TGT:1d41da19-7d47-42e7-baf3-28af0f6c1c12] When making that disclosure under Rule 12.6.1, it must also ensure the disclosure includes specific supporting information that explains the basis for the new estimates and how they differ from what was previously reported. [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] In practice, the disclosure should cover all of the following elements: - Identify the types of permits or licences the Petroleum Reporting Entity holds that relate to the estimates being disclosed. [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] - Explain the new data and information that underpins the new material estimates. [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] - Explain how that new data and information has affected the estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Resources (including Petroleum Reserves). [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] - Describe any changes or additions to information previously disclosed for Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources, and Petroleum Reserves by reference to the specified prior-disclosure categories. [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] This combines the timing trigger (immediate disclosure of new material estimates) with the minimum content needed to make that disclosure complete. [#TGT:1d41da19-7d47-42e7-baf3-28af0f6c1c12] [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704]

debug_context.source_text: A Petroleum Reporting Entity making a disclosure under Rule 12.6.1 must ensure the disclosure contains: (1) the types of permits or licences held by the Petroleum Reporting Entity relating to the estimates; (2) an explanation of the new data and information; (3) an explanation of how the new data and information has affected the estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Resources; and (4) any changes or additions to the information previously disclosed relating to: (a) Prospective Resources under Rules 12.8.1(1) to 12.8.1(4); (b) Contingent Resources under Rules 12.10.1(1) to 12.10.1(5); and (c) Petroleum Reserves under Rules 12.12.1(1) to 12.12.1(7).

question: If a Petroleum Reporting Entity comes up with new material estimates for Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources, or Petroleum Reserves that it has never disclosed before, how fast does it need to disclose them, and what details must it include about licences, the new data, and what changed compared with earlier disclosures?
expected_answer: The Petroleum Reporting Entity must disclose the new material estimates immediately when they have not previously been disclosed. [#TGT:1d41da19-7d47-42e7-baf3-28af0f6c1c12] When it makes that disclosure under Rule 12.6.1, it must also include enough detail to show what the estimates relate to and why they changed. [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] The disclosure needs to include, at a minimum: - The types of permits or licences the Petroleum Reporting Entity holds that relate to the estimates. [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] - A clear explanation of the new data and information. [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] - An explanation of how the new data and information affected the estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources, or Petroleum Resources (which includes Petroleum Reserves). [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] - Any changes or additions to what it previously disclosed for Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources, and Petroleum Reserves, using the listed prior-disclosure groupings. [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] So the rule is both “disclose right away” and “include the specified supporting explanations and updates to earlier information.” [#TGT:1d41da19-7d47-42e7-baf3-28af0f6c1c12] [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704]

question: For a Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity preparing its quarterly report, what information must the report contain (including any consolidated-basis requirement and the 12‑month reserves/resources disclosure cross-reference), and by when after quarter-end must the report required by Rule 12.13.1 be disclosed?
expected_answer: A Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity must both (i) include specified content in its quarterly report for each quarter of its financial year and (ii) disclose the Rule 12.13.1 report within a defined post‑quarter deadline. [#TGT:ab93bfec-289e-42d2-b653-975f44d08c62] [#SRC:380ff25a-7805-4020-9f40-da991f91eab1] The quarterly report must cover the Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity and all controlled entities, prepared on a consolidated basis where applicable. question: When the Listing Authority concludes, after an enquiry into a complaint or allegation, that the information is accurate, constitutes Inside Information, and is not covered by the Rule 7.2.2 disclosure exemption, how should the Listing Authority proceed under Rule 7.2.1, and what specific confirmations and timing details would an ‘aware letter’ typically require from the Reporting Entity if the information should have been Disclosed earlier?
expected_answer: Where the Listing Authority’s enquiry leads it to decide the information is accurate, is Inside Information, and does not fall within the Rule 7.2.2 exemption from disclosure, it will require the Reporting Entity to make a Disclosure about the matter under Rule 7.2.1. [#SRC:6f969623-b272-436b-9bad-c57a00efd944] If the Listing Authority considers the information should have been Disclosed earlier, it may issue an ‘aware letter’ as a follow-on step. [#SRC:6f969623-b272-436b-9bad-c57a00efd944] In that aware letter, the Listing Authority would typically (a) identify the information at issue and state the relevant date it was Disclosed, and then (b) ask the Reporting Entity to address whether it considers the information to be Inside Information, using the reasonable-person/price-effect framing described in the template. [#TGT:f221a729-4fb2-4eca-bb45-6c892c667a28] If the Reporting Entity answers that it is Inside Information, the letter generally seeks timing and context: when the Reporting Entity first became aware of it, including the time and circumstances of becoming aware of the key contents. [#TGT:f221a729-4fb2-4eca-bb45-6c892c667a28] It also asks why the Reporting Entity did not Disclose earlier or request a Trading Halt or Suspension earlier, with specific commentary on Rule 7.2.1, and requests confirmation of compliance with the Markets Rules, particularly Rule 7.2.1. [#TGT:f221a729-4fb2-4eca-bb45-6c892c667a28]

question: Where the Regulator considers a name issue under Section 117 of FSMR, how does the Regulator’s power to make a direction apply across (i) a Fund, (ii) a Sub-Fund, and (iii) a class of Units in a Fund, and what specific action may the Regulator require and from whom when the name is undesirable, misleading, or conflicts with another name?
expected_answer: If the Regulator forms the view that a relevant name is undesirable, misleading, or conflicts with a name used by another product, the Regulator has power to issue a direction under Section 117 of FSMR covering not only a Fund and a Sub-Fund but also a class of Units in a Fund. [#SRC:bdb691fd-fde8-4cef-b9ca-5c2166f72295] When exercising that power in relation to a Fund or a Sub Fund, the Regulator may require a concrete remedial step: it may direct the Fund Manager to change the name of the Fund or the Sub Fund. [#TGT:3ec1d30f-39dd-4b93-86ed-4f8e25d7d0ff] The triggering conditions align across both passages: the Regulator’s assessment (including where the name conflicts with another Fund/Sub-Fund name, or is undesirable or misleading) is the basis for intervention. [#TGT:3ec1d30f-39dd-4b93-86ed-4f8e25d7d0ff] The scope of what can be assessed for undesirability, misleading character, or conflict is broader in that it expressly includes a class of Units in a Fund in addition to Funds and Sub-Funds. [#SRC:bdb691fd-fde8-4cef-b9ca-5c2166f72295] Accordingly, compliance planning should treat the Fund Manager as the directed party for Fund/Sub Fund name changes, while recognizing that the Regulator’s naming-direction power extends to class-of-Units naming issues as well. [#TGT:3ec1d30f-39dd-4b93-86ed-4f8e25d7d0ff] [#SRC:bdb691fd-fde8-4cef-b9ca-5c2166f72295]

question: For a Third Party Provider entering into a Governing Contract with a Customer, what information must be included in the Governing Contract (absent a written agreement otherwise), and by what point must that Rule 20.2.2 information be provided so the Customer is not bound before receiving it?
expected_answer: A Third Party Provider must ensure the Customer receives the information specified in Rule 20.2.2 before the Customer becomes bound by the Governing Contract. [#SRC:3ac84a75-f9ab-498e-9ca1-cf7af2ebe1b8] Unless the Third Party Provider and their Customer have otherwise agreed in writing, that Rule 20.2.2 information is the set of items that the Governing Contract itself is required to contain. [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] In practice, this means the contract must include, at a minimum, identifying and regulatory details about the Third Party Provider (including its name, ADGM office contact details, and the name of its Regulator and Financial Service Permission details), and operational details about the Third Party Services (including service characteristics, what customer information/identifier is needed for a Third Party Transaction, consent process, time of receipt of a Third Party Transaction, maximum service time, and any usage limits). [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] It must also cover charges and (where relevant) exchange rates and Reference Exchange Rates mechanics, agreed communication methods and frequencies (including what Customer information is transferred to the Customer’s Financial Institution), safeguards/corrective measures (including notification periods for unauthorised or incorrect Third Party Transactions and relevant liability/refund conditions), change/termination terms, and redress provisions. [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] The timing requirement is that this information must be provided before the Customer is bound, even if information may also be provided during the period of the Governing Contract. [#SRC:3ac84a75-f9ab-498e-9ca1-cf7af2ebe1b8]

(b) about the Third Party Services: (i) a description of the main characteristics of the Third Party Services to be provided; (ii) the information or unique identifier that must be provided by the Customer in order for a Third Party Transaction to occur; (iii) the form and procedure for giving consent to a Third Party Transaction; (iv) the time of receipt of a Third Party Transaction; (v) the maximum time taken for the Third Party Services to be provided; and (vi) any limits for the use of the Third Party Services; (c) about charges and exchange rates: (i) details of all charges payable by the Customer to the Third Party Provider, including those connected to information which is provided or made available and, where applicable, a breakdown of the amounts of all charges; (ii) where relevant, details of the exchange rates to be applied or, if Reference Exchange Rates are to be used, the method of calculating the relevant date for determining such Reference Exchange Rates; (iii) where relevant and if agreed, the application of changes in Reference Exchange Rates and information requirements relating to any such changes; (d) about communication: (i) the means of communication agreed between the parties for the transmission of information or notifications including, where relevant, any technical requirements for the Customer’s equipment and software for receipt of the information or notifications; (ii) the manner in which and frequency with which information under this Chapter is to be provided or made available; (iii) what information relating to the Customer will be transferred to the Customer’s Financial Institution as part of a Third Party Transaction; (ii) the secure procedure by which the Third Party Provider will contact the Customer in the event of suspected or actual fraud or security threats; (iii) where relevant, the conditions under which the Third Party Provider proposes to reserve the right to stop or prevent a Third Party Transaction from being executed; (iv) the Customer’s liability under Rule 20.12.6 including details of any limits on such liability; (v) the Third Party Provider’s liability for unauthorised Third Party Transactions under Rule 20.12.5; (ii) the duration of the Governing Contract; (iii) where relevant, the right of the Customer to terminate the Governing Contract and any agreements relating to termination in accordance with Rule 20.2.6. (g) about redress: (i) any contractual clauses on the law applicable to the Governing Contract and the competent courts; and (ii) the availability of any alternative dispute resolution procedures, if applicable, for the Customer and the methods for having access to them.

question: If a Third Party Provider is about to sign a Governing Contract with a Customer, what details have to be in the contract (unless they both agree something else in writing), and when does the Customer need to get that information so they are not bound too early?

[#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] Even though information can be provided during the period of the Governing Contract, the key timing point is that the Customer must receive it before being bound. [#SRC:3ac84a75-f9ab-498e-9ca1-cf7af2ebe1b8]

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity makes a disclosure that does not follow a non-mandatory requirement in a Mining Reporting Standard (for example, a non-mandatory item in Table 1 of the JORC Code or SAMREC Code), what must the Mining Reporting Entity include in the disclosure, and how does this relate to the Regulator’s expectation of compliance under Rule 11.2.1(1) and the explanation approach referenced in Rule 11.2.2?
expected_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity is expected to comply fully with non-mandatory requirements in a Mining Reporting Standard, but if it does not, it must transparently explain the departure within the disclosure itself. [#SRC:b8235755-7447-4ae5-b3dc-8cb14109c124] Specifically, where a disclosure does not meet a non-mandatory requirement in the relevant Mining Reporting Standard, the Mining Reporting Entity must include a statement in that disclosure describing both how the disclosure differs and why it differs from the non-mandatory requirement. [#TGT:211edfe0-af57-41c8-84ca-814e1af3de0f] This disclosure-level statement operationalizes the Regulator’s expectation that non-mandatory requirements are followed unless the entity explains non-compliance, including in relation to non-mandatory items such as those found in Table 1 of the JORC Code or SAMREC Code. [#SRC:b8235755-7447-4ae5-b3dc-8cb14109c124] In practical terms, the Mining Reporting Entity should (i) identify the specific non-mandatory requirement it did not meet, (ii) describe the nature of the difference, and (iii) provide the reason for that difference, all within the disclosure. [#TGT:211edfe0-af57-41c8-84ca-814e1af3de0f] This approach aligns with the referenced expectation to explain non-compliance in accordance with Rule 11.2.2 when non-mandatory requirements are not followed. question: For a Listed Entity that has only partially adopted the best practice standards in APP 4, what specific disclosures must appear in its annual financial report, and how does that annual reporting obligation align with the Regulator’s expectation for disclosure in the Prospectus and thereafter under Rule 9.2.10, including the consequence of inaccurate or false representations?
expected_answer: A Listed Entity that has only partially adopted APP 4 must make a structured set of disclosures in its annual financial report, and those disclosures should be consistent with the Regulator’s expectation that the same type of explanation and alternative measures be disclosed in the Prospectus and then continued thereafter under Rule 9.2.10. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] [#SRC:ff5bac8d-3dc7-46dd-a9ce-b0c32a42422e] Specifically, the annual financial report must (i) state whether the APP 4 best practice standards (the Corporate Governance Principles) have been adopted, and (ii) where adoption is partial, explain why full adoption did not occur and describe what actions (if any) were taken to achieve compliance to the extent of the gap. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] In addition, Directors must provide an opinion on whether the Listed Entity’s Corporate Governance framework is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, supported by information and assumptions and including qualifications if needed. question: For an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business, how should the Resolution Pack requirement to include the master list of all Client Accounts be satisfied in terms of the specific data fields that must appear on that master list?
expected_answer: To satisfy the Resolution Pack requirement for an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business, the master list of all Client Accounts must be included in the Resolution Pack and must be maintained with the specific account details prescribed for that master list. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] [#TGT:47678f27-9e0b-4782-949a-f38e84a7442d] The Resolution Pack scope expressly includes the master lists of all Client Accounts in relation to Client Money and Client investments, so the pack should contain the master list(s) that the Authorised Person maintains for those Client Accounts. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] In maintaining that master list, the Authorised Person must ensure it details, for each Client Account, the account name, account number, and where the account is located. [#TGT:47678f27-9e0b-4782-949a-f38e84a7442d] It must also identify the bank and include the bank’s address and contact information, and it must record the account’s terms and conditions. [#TGT:47678f27-9e0b-4782-949a-f38e84a7442d] Finally, the master list must show whether each account is open or closed and the date it was opened or closed, so that the Resolution Pack contains a complete and status-aware inventory of Client Accounts. [#TGT:47678f27-9e0b-4782-949a-f38e84a7442d]

question: When the Regulator issues a written collateral notice to a Captive Insurer requiring assets to be made available, how is the maximum value of those assets capped by reference to the “lower of” test, and how is the Rule 10.3.2(4) amount determined for (i) a Captive Cell of a Captive Insurer which is a Cell Company and (ii) a Captive Insurer that is not a Cell Company?
expected_answer: A collateral notice can require a Captive Insurer to make available assets, but the value of assets that can be required is capped at the lower of (1) any amount stated in the notice and (2) the amount calculated under Rule 10.3.2(4), with the asset value determined under Chapter 6. [#TGT:5e621133-6c3b-411a-8ce1-0064086fd0e7] To apply that cap, the Rule 10.3.2(4) amount depends on the Captive Insurer’s structure and the relevant business segment. [#SRC:9585f95e-ae97-44a1-966f-ec94cc458c39] For the Rule 10.3.2(4) limb of the “lower of” test: - For a Captive Cell of a Captive Insurer which is a Cell Company, the amount is the sum of (i) the Insurance Liabilities attributable to that Captive Cell and (ii) the Minimum Cellular Capital Requirement applicable to that Captive Cell. [#SRC:9585f95e-ae97-44a1-966f-ec94cc458c39] - For a Captive Insurer that is not a Cell Company, the amount is the sum of (i) the Captive Insurer’s Insurance Liabilities and (ii) the Captive Insurer’s minimum capital requirement as provided for in Rule 2.2. [#SRC:9585f95e-ae97-44a1-966f-ec94cc458c39] Accordingly, the collateral notice cannot require assets (valued under Chapter 6) above whichever is lower: the notice-stated amount (if any) or the applicable Rule 10.3.2(4) calculation for the relevant case. [#TGT:5e621133-6c3b-411a-8ce1-0064086fd0e7]

debug_context.source_text: The amount referred to in Rule ‎10.3.2(1)(b) is calculated as follows: (a) in the case of a Captive Cell of a Captive Insurer which is a Cell Company, the sum of the following two amounts: (i) the Insurance Liabilities attributable to that Captive Cell; and (ii) the Minimum Cellular Capital Requirement applicable to that Captive Cell. (b) in the case of a Long-Term Insurance Fund, subject to Rules ‎10.3.2(4)(c) and ‎10.3.2(4)(d), the sum of the following two amounts: (i) the Insurance Liabilities attributable to that Long-Term Insurance Fund; and (ii) the Minimum Fund Capital Requirement applicable to that Long-Term Insurance Fund; (c) in the case of a Captive Insurer that is not a Cell Company, the sum of the following two amounts: (i) the Captive Insurer's Insurance Liabilities; and (ii) the Captive Insurer's minimum capital requirement as provided for in Rule 2.2. (d) in the case of a Captive Insurer to which Rules ‎10.3.2(4)(a) and ‎10.3.2(4)(c) both apply, the amount set out in ‎10.3.2(4)(a); and (e) in the case of a Captive Insurer to which Rules ‎10.3.2(4)(c) and ‎10.3.2(4)(d) both apply, the amount set out in Rule ‎10.3.2(4)(d).
debug_context.target_text: The Regulator may, by written notice (referred to in this Chapter as a 'collateral notice'), require a Captive Insurer to make available assets: (a) of a type and in a manner described in Rule ‎10.3.2(5); and (b) having a value, determined in accordance with the provisions of Chapter 6, of the lower of: (i) the amount, if any, specified in the notice; and (ii) the amount determined in accordance with Rule ‎10.3.2(4).

question: If the Regulator sends a collateral notice to a Captive Insurer, what is the limit on how much asset value can be required, and how do you work out that limit for a Long-Term Insurance Fund using the Rule 10.3.2(4) calculation?
expected_answer: A collateral notice can require a Captive Insurer to make assets available, but the required asset value (as valued under Chapter 6) is limited to the lower of (i) any amount written into the notice and (ii) the amount calculated under Rule 10.3.2(4). [#TGT:5e621133-6c3b-411a-8ce1-0064086fd0e7] This means you must compute the Rule 10.3.2(4) amount for the relevant case and then compare it to any figure specified in the notice to identify the binding cap. [#SRC:9585f95e-ae97-44a1-966f-ec94cc458c39] Once that sum is determined, it becomes the Rule 10.3.2(4) comparator in the “lower of” test used to cap the collateral notice requirement. [#TGT:5e621133-6c3b-411a-8ce1-0064086fd0e7] In practice, the maximum asset value that can be required is whichever is lower: the notice amount (if any) or the Long-Term Insurance Fund sum described above. [#TGT:5e621133-6c3b-411a-8ce1-0064086fd0e7]

question: When a Prospectus has been filed with the Regulator and is intended to be treated as an “Approved Prospectus” for the purposes of subsection (1), what specific approval action must the Regulator take, and how does that action apply where the Prospectus comprises multiple documents under the Rules-based approval concept?
expected_answer: A filed Prospectus is treated as an “Approved Prospectus” only when the Regulator has taken an affirmative approval step, not merely because it has been filed. Under the Regulations’ framing, a Prospectus qualifies as an Approved Prospectus if it is approved by the Regulator in line with the requirements prescribed in the Rules, and references to a Prospectus in the Regulations are generally to an Approved Prospectus unless context indicates otherwise. [#TGT:caf92348-9f78-4a22-b449-0824165b55e1] In addition, for the filing to result in an Approved Prospectus for the stated statutory purpose, the Regulator must issue the Applicant a notice that states the Regulator’s approval. [#SRC:85f98644-465b-43a9-bb47-cedcdbaaf60e] That notice must cover the Prospectus (or, where applicable, the Supplementary Prospectus). [#SRC:85f98644-465b-43a9-bb47-cedcdbaaf60e] Where the Prospectus consists of multiple documents, the notice must expressly approve all of those multiple documents, aligning the practical evidence of approval (the notice) with the Rules-based approval concept used to define an Approved Prospectus. [#SRC:85f98644-465b-43a9-bb47-cedcdbaaf60e] [#TGT:caf92348-9f78-4a22-b449-0824165b55e1]

debug_context.source_text: A Prospectus filed with the Regulator is not an Approved Prospectus for the purposes of section 61(2)(a) of the FSMR unless the Regulator has issued to the Applicant a notice stating its approval: (a) of the Prospectus or the Supplementary Prospectus as the case may be; and (b) in the case of a Prospectus in (a) comprising multiple documents, of all the multiple documents.

[#SRC:85f98644-465b-43a9-bb47-cedcdbaaf60e] Separately, the Regulations explain that a Prospectus is an Approved Prospectus when it is approved by the Regulator in accordance with the requirements prescribed in the Rules, and that when the Regulations refer to a “Prospectus” they generally mean an Approved Prospectus unless the context requires otherwise. [#TGT:caf92348-9f78-4a22-b449-0824165b55e1] If the Prospectus is made up of multiple documents, the Regulator’s notice must cover approval of all the multiple documents, not just one part, so that the approval aligns with how the Prospectus is constituted. [#SRC:85f98644-465b-43a9-bb47-cedcdbaaf60e]

question: When an Authorised Person is establishing and maintaining systems and controls to deter/prevent and report suspected fraud and other Financial Crimes, how should it reflect best practices given the evolving nature of Financial Crime, and what concrete measures are indicated as examples for those systems and controls?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must have effective systems and controls that both (i) deter and prevent suspected fraud and other Financial Crimes against the Authorised Person and its Customers and (ii) enable reporting of suspected fraud and other Financial Crimes to the relevant authorities. [#TGT:d277a5cf-34ce-41bb-9ee6-6fce18484596] In establishing the systems and controls required for this purpose, the Authorised Person should also observe best practices, explicitly recognizing that Financial Crime evolves and that controls should be designed with that changing risk in mind. [#SRC:c57d295b-e1d8-48c1-a630-f8f2646578c7] Practically, this means the required fraud/Financial Crime framework should be implemented and maintained in a way that can support both prevention/deterrence and reporting outcomes, while incorporating concrete control features that are identified as examples of best practice. [#TGT:d277a5cf-34ce-41bb-9ee6-6fce18484596] [#SRC:c57d295b-e1d8-48c1-a630-f8f2646578c7] Examples of such best-practice measures include using secure authentication, deploying biometrics, and monitoring customer behaviour metrics within anti-fraud and anti-Financial Crime systems and controls. [#SRC:c57d295b-e1d8-48c1-a630-f8f2646578c7] Taken together, the obligation to establish and maintain effective systems and controls is met not only by having controls in place for deterrence/prevention and reporting, but by building them using these kinds of evolving best-practice techniques. [#TGT:d277a5cf-34ce-41bb-9ee6-6fce18484596] [#SRC:c57d295b-e1d8-48c1-a630-f8f2646578c7]

question: If an Authorised Person needs controls to stop fraud and other Financial Crimes and to report suspected cases, what best-practice features should it consider adding to those controls because Financial Crime keeps changing?
expected_answer: The Authorised Person is required to set up and keep effective systems and controls that do two things: help deter and prevent suspected fraud and other Financial Crimes against the Authorised Person and its Customers, and support reporting suspected fraud and other Financial Crimes to the relevant authorities. [#TGT:d277a5cf-34ce-41bb-9ee6-6fce18484596] When putting those systems and controls in place, the Authorised Person should also follow best practices, specifically because Financial Crime is evolving and controls should be designed with that changing threat in mind. [#SRC:c57d295b-e1d8-48c1-a630-f8f2646578c7] In other words, the required fraud/Financial Crime controls should not be static; they should be built and maintained in a way that supports prevention/deterrence and reporting while using practical techniques that are identified as best-practice examples. [#TGT:d277a5cf-34ce-41bb-9ee6-6fce18484596] [#SRC:c57d295b-e1d8-48c1-a630-f8f2646578c7] The examples given of such best-practice techniques are incorporating secure authentication, using biometrics, and monitoring customer behaviour metrics as part of anti-fraud and anti-Financial Crime systems and controls. [#SRC:c57d295b-e1d8-48c1-a630-f8f2646578c7] Using these features helps align the way the controls are established with the obligation to maintain effective controls for both stopping suspected misconduct and reporting it. [#TGT:d277a5cf-34ce-41bb-9ee6-6fce18484596] [#SRC:c57d295b-e1d8-48c1-a630-f8f2646578c7]

question: For an Authorised Person acting as Investment Manager of an ADGM Green Portfolio, how should the Green Portfolio Attestation Requirement be applied across different portions of Eligible Green Portfolio Assets when some assets are aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy under Rule 3.8.4(a) and other assets are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark under Rule 3.8.4(b)?

question: When a person is making an Offer of a Unit, how do the Chapter-level non-application provisions interact with the Rulebook’s chapter 4 Prospectus content and structure requirements for Prospectuses relating to Units of Funds, and where are the applicable Prospectus requirements instead located?
expected_answer: For an Offer involving Units, the combined effect is that the Chapter’s provisions (and Rules made for that Chapter) do not apply to the person making the Offer, and the Rulebook’s chapter 4 Prospectus content and structure requirements are also not applicable to Prospectuses relating to Units of Funds. question: When an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT and is measuring E for a pre settlement Counterparty Exposure, how should the firm determine which collateral-recognition approach is permitted, including the distinction between exposures determined under Rule 4.9.15 and whether the SFT sits in the Trading Book or Non Trading Book?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person may recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral for an SFT only in the circumstances and using the methods specified for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures, and the permitted method depends on both how the exposure is determined and which book the SFT is in. [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778] Where the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure for an SFT is determined in accordance with Rule 4.9.15 and the Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral, the firm may recognise the effect of that collateral by applying the framework set out in Rules 4.9.17 to 4.9.20. [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778] In addition, for any SFT in the Non Trading Book, the firm must choose either the FCSA or the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral, apply that single chosen approach consistently across the entire Non Trading Book, and avoid mixing the two approaches. [#TGT:cf88cf6e-8083-4aed-8468-eed8d367f412] By contrast, for a pre settlement Counterparty Exposure arising from an SFT in the Trading Book, the firm is restricted to using only the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral. [#TGT:cf88cf6e-8083-4aed-8468-eed8d367f412]

debug_context.source_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for any SFT where the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined in accordance with Rule 4.9.15 may recognise the effect of such Collateral in accordance with Rules 4.9.17 to 4.9.20.
debug_context.target_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person must use either the FCSA or the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral for any SFT in the Non Trading Book. The Authorised Person must apply the chosen approach consistently to the entire Non Trading Book and must not use a combination of both approaches. For a pre settlement Counterparty Exposure arising from any SFT in the Trading Book, an Authorised Person must only use the FCCA to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral.

question: When an Authorised Person chooses to reduce the value of its Exposures using one or more of the credit risk mitigation methods listed for this Section, what policy documentation is required specifically in relation to using exclusions in Rule 4.15.12, and how does that documentation obligation relate to the discretionary nature of those exposure reductions?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person that elects to reduce the value of its Exposures using the credit risk mitigation recognition options in this Section must also have documented policy coverage for its use of any exclusions in Rule 4.15.12. [#SRC:5a4ad383-0e7b-476f-84ee-d6bce45b2270] This documentation requirement applies in addition to (and is not replaced by) the fact that the Section allows the Authorised Person, at its discretion, to reduce Exposure values using one or more specified methods. [#TGT:9ae2763f-2e1a-4afb-ac8e-f57ce03a81c3] In practice, this means: - The Authorised Person may choose whether to reduce Exposures and may do so via specific provisions, netting (if Section 4.13 conditions are met), eligible Collateral (meeting Section 4.13 requirements), eligible guarantees (as permitted under Section 4.13.9), qualifying Credit Derivatives (included in Rule 4.13.11 and meeting that Section’s conditions), or securitisation transfers (if Section 4.14 conditions are met). [#TGT:9ae2763f-2e1a-4afb-ac8e-f57ce03a81c3] - Separately, it must document its policy for using any exclusions in Rule 4.15.12, so that any reliance on those exclusions is governed by an established internal policy. [#SRC:5a4ad383-0e7b-476f-84ee-d6bce45b2270] Accordingly, discretion to apply the listed reduction techniques does not remove the need for a documented exclusions policy where Rule 4.15.12 exclusions are used. [#SRC:5a4ad383-0e7b-476f-84ee-d6bce45b2270] [#TGT:9ae2763f-2e1a-4afb-ac8e-f57ce03a81c3]

debug_context.source_text: Recognition of Credit Risk mitigations. An Authorised Person must document its policy for the use of any of the exclusions in Rule 4.15.12.
debug_context.target_text: Recognition of Credit Risk mitigations. For the purposes of this Section, an Authorised Person may reduce the value of its Exposures, at its discretion, by any one or more of the following: (a) the amount of any specific provision made, where the provision relates to the risk of a credit loss occurring on that Exposure and is not held as part of a general provision or reserve against its Credit Risks; (b) Netting its claims on and liabilities to a Counterparty, provided that the conditions in Section 4.13 of CRM are met; (c) the amount of Collateral held against its Exposures, where that Collateral is of a type listed based on the FCSA and FCCA approaches and meeting the requirements under Section 4.13; (d) the amount of any eligible guarantees as permitted under Section 4.13.9; (e) the value of a Credit Derivative, where the Credit Derivative is an instrument included in Rule 4.13.11 and the transaction meets the conditions set out in that Section; and (f) the effects of transactions transferring Credit Risks from the Authorised Person to another party through securitisation, provided that the conditions in Section 4.14 are met.

question: When a Fund Manager appoints an auditor to audit a Fund’s financial statements under IAASB standards, what specific statements must the Fund Manager ensure the Auditor includes in the resulting Fund Auditor’s Report, including any points that apply at Fund or Sub-Fund level for the annual accounting period?
expected_answer: A Fund Manager must both (i) formally instruct its auditor in writing to perform the audit under the relevant IAASB standards and to produce a Fund Auditor’s Report, and (ii) when procuring that report, ensure the Auditor’s report contains the required set of statements about the financial statements and related matters. [#SRC:8949f938-33e5-4393-a256-021917125579] Specifically, the Fund Manager must ensure the Auditor states whether the financial statements were properly prepared using the financial reporting standards the Fund has adopted under FUNDS, and whether they present a true and fair view of the Fund’s financial position. [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce] That true-and-fair assessment must cover net income and net gains or losses of the Fund Property (or, where relevant, the Fund Property attributable to the Sub-Fund) for the annual accounting period, and the financial position of the Fund or Sub-Fund at the end of that period. [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce] The report must also address whether proper accounting records have not been kept or whether the statements fail to agree with records/returns or fail to comply with applicable reporting standards, confirm whether the Auditor received all necessary information and explanations, and state whether the Directors’ report or Fund Manager’s report is consistent with the financial statements, plus any other matter required by FUNDS. [#TGT:8a39a0f2-3ac3-4f8c-bf98-2752b5310cce]

debug_context.target_text: Fund Auditor's Report. A Fund Manager must, in procuring the production of a Fund Auditor's Report, ensure that an Auditor states: (1) whether the financial statements have been properly prepared in accordance with the financial reporting standards adopted by the Fund in accordance with FUNDS; (2) whether the financial statements give a true and fair view of the financial position of the Fund, including the net income and the net gains or losses of the Fund Property, or, as the case may be, the Fund Property attributable to the Sub-Fund for the annual accounting period in question and the financial position of the Fund or Sub-Fund as at the end of the annual accounting period; (3) whether proper accounting records for the Fund, or as the case may be, Sub-Fund, have not been kept, or that the financial statements are not in agreement with the accounting records and returns, or that the financial statements do not comply with the applicable financial reporting standards; (4) whether it has been given all the information and explanations which, to the best of its knowledge and belief, are necessary for the purposes of its audit; (5) whether the information given in the report of the Directors or in the report of the Fund Manager for that period is consistent with the financial statements; and (6) any other matter or opinion required by FUNDS.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity makes a disclosure under Rule 11.9.1 that includes forecast financial information, how should it handle material economic assumptions it considers commercially sensitive, and what additional disclosure is required about the Production Target—particularly in light of the caution about when it is difficult to justify commercial sensitivity?
expected_answer: In a Rule 11.9.1 disclosure containing forecast financial information, a Mining Reporting Entity must provide all material economic assumptions it used, and it must also disclose any other material assumptions applied. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] If the Mining Reporting Entity treats the material economic assumptions as commercially sensitive, it still must include a clear statement that it considers them commercially sensitive and explain the methodology it used to determine those material economic assumptions. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] That sensitivity position should be taken carefully: it is specifically cautioned that where the Mining Reporting Entity has not yet entered into commercially sensitive contracts underpinning assumptions such as commodity price, capital expenditure, or operational expenditure, it would be difficult to conclude that information about those assumptions is commercially sensitive. question: When applying Rules A4.7.3 to A4.7.6 to a reverse repurchase agreement, how should the firm determine the exposure amount (E) using the reverse repo formula, and what methodology must it use to calculate the market value (MV) inputs for both the Securities and any Collateral?
expected_answer: For a reverse repurchase agreement assessed under Rules A4.7.3 to A4.7.6, the exposure amount (E) is determined by taking the amount paid (or Collateral given) and subtracting the market value (MV) of the Securities received. [#TGT:4262e773-aad2-4422-b6b3-fea38fd9d619] To apply that formula correctly, the MV of Securities and the value of Collateral used as inputs must be calculated using the credit risk mitigation (CRM) provisions specified in Section 4.13, because Rules A4.7.3 to A4.7.6 require those MV and collateral values to be computed in accordance with that CRM methodology. [#SRC:379a83c2-96da-4b2a-acea-f8779444878d] In practice, this means the firm should (i) identify the relevant reverse repurchase agreement components (amount paid or Collateral given, and the Securities received), (ii) compute the MV of the Securities received using the Section 4.13 CRM approach, and (iii) compute the value of any Collateral (including Collateral given, where relevant to the reverse repo inputs) using the same Section 4.13 CRM approach, before inserting those values into the E calculation. [#SRC:379a83c2-96da-4b2a-acea-f8779444878d] This linkage ensures the reverse repo exposure formula uses MV and collateral values that are consistent with the required CRM calculation basis for Rules A4.7.3 to A4.7.6. [#TGT:4262e773-aad2-4422-b6b3-fea38fd9d619]

debug_context.target_text: For reverse repurchase agreements: E = Amount paid or Collateral given MV of the Securities received.

[#SRC:379a83c2-96da-4b2a-acea-f8779444878d] Instead, the MV of Securities and the value of Collateral that feed into the reverse repo E formula must be calculated using the CRM provisions in Section 4.13, because Rules A4.7.3 to A4.7.6 specify that those values should be calculated in accordance with that Section 4.13 CRM framework. question: How would the Regulator assess whether a trader’s conduct in a crude oil contract—rapidly accumulating more than 90% of the physical inventory, not offering to lend it back at a reasonable commercial rate, and then unwinding in the final settlement window at rapidly increasing prices—amounts to Behaviour that secures an abnormal or artificial price level, given the requirement that the transactions or orders be otherwise than for legitimate reasons and in conformity with Accepted Market Practices?
expected_answer: The described crude oil scenario can be assessed as potentially abusive where the trading strategy both creates an abnormal price outcome and is carried out through transactions or orders that are not for legitimate reasons and not in line with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market. [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f] In the example, the trader rapidly amasses more than 90% of the physical inventory underlying the crude oil contract, does not offer to lend the crude oil back at a reasonable commercial rate, and then exits the position during the Exchange’s final settlement window at rapidly increasing prices, with the effect of cornering/squeezing the market. [#SRC:350b6237-da6f-47c6-b04c-10caf56bf9d7] That conduct is described as causing an abnormal movement in the price of crude oil contracts for forward month delivery, which aligns with the concept of securing the price at an abnormal or artificial level. [#SRC:350b6237-da6f-47c6-b04c-10caf56bf9d7] The “fusion” point is that the abnormal movement is achieved through the trader’s execution pattern (building the dominant inventory position and unwinding in the final settlement window), which is the type of transaction/order behaviour the rule targets when it is not undertaken for legitimate reasons and in conformity with Accepted Market Practices. [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f] On these facts, the Regulator’s example supports treating the strategy as an abusive squeeze that may contravene the relevant prohibition, while the rule frames the key test as abnormal/artificial price impact coupled with lack of legitimate/accepted-market-practice justification. [#SRC:350b6237-da6f-47c6-b04c-10caf56bf9d7] [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f]

debug_context.source_text: Abusive squeezes. The following are specific examples of an abusive squeeze that, in the Regulator's view, may contravene section 92 (4)(b): (a) during the course of a trading day on a Commodity Derivative Exchange, a trader rapidly builds up a position of more than 90% of the physical inventory underlying a crude oil contract. The trader fails to Offer to lend the crude oil back to other market participants at a reasonable commercial rate. The trader then unwinds his position in the Exchange's final settlement window at rapidly increasing prices, thereby cornering/squeezing the crude oil market. His conduct causes an abnormal movement in the price of crude oil contracts for forward month delivery; and (b) a trader with a long position in bond futures, buys or borrows a large amount of the bonds and either refuses to re-lend these bonds or will only lend them to parties he believes will not re-lend to the market. His purpose is to position the price at which persons with short positions have to deliver to satisfy their obligations at a materially higher level, making him a profit on his position.
debug_context.target_text: The third is where the Behaviour consists of effecting transactions or orders to trade (otherwise than for legitimate reasons and in conformity with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market) which— (a) give, or are likely to give, a false or misleading impression as to the supply of, or demand for, or as to the price of, one or more Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities; or (b) secure the price of one or more such instruments at an abnormal or artificial level.

question: If a trader in bond futures buys or borrows a large amount of the bonds and then refuses to re-lend them (or only lends to people they think won’t re-lend), how does that connect to the rule about placing orders or doing trades that can mislead the market or keep prices at an abnormal level when it’s not for legitimate reasons and not in line with Accepted Market Practices?
expected_answer: This bond-futures pattern can fit the rule’s concern where the trader’s transactions or orders are used to influence market conditions in a way that produces a distorted price outcome, and the activity is not for legitimate reasons and not consistent with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market. [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f] In the example, the trader holds a long position in bond futures, acquires a large quantity of the deliverable bonds by buying or borrowing, and then restricts re-lending (either refusing to re-lend or lending only to parties the trader believes will not re-lend to the market). [#SRC:350b6237-da6f-47c6-b04c-10caf56bf9d7] The stated purpose is to push the delivery price faced by short-position holders to a materially higher level, allowing the trader to profit on the long position. [#SRC:350b6237-da6f-47c6-b04c-10caf56bf9d7] That purpose-and-effect linkage is the “fusion” with the rule: using trading and related actions to secure the price of a Financial Instrument at an abnormal or artificial level is explicitly captured, provided the conduct is otherwise than for legitimate reasons and in conformity with Accepted Market Practices. [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f] Put simply, the example supplies the concrete mechanism (restricting bond availability to raise the delivery price), and the rule supplies the legal characterization test (abnormal/artificial price secured through non-legitimate, non-accepted-market-practice transactions or orders). [#SRC:350b6237-da6f-47c6-b04c-10caf56bf9d7] [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f]

question: For an Authorised Person using the FCCA, how should eligible financial Collateral be determined when the proposed Collateral is an instrument listed in Rule 4.13.5 but is a T1 Capital instrument or T2 Capital instrument issued by an entity in the Financial Group of the Authorised Person and held as Collateral by the Authorised Person or any of its Financial Group entities?
expected_answer: Eligible financial Collateral for an Authorised Person using the FCCA is defined to include instruments listed in Rule 4.13.5, but that inclusion is narrowed by a specific exclusion for certain intra-Group capital instruments. [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85] In practice, even if the proposed Collateral falls within the category of instruments listed in Rule 4.13.5, it must be treated as ineligible if it is a T1 Capital instrument or a T2 Capital instrument issued by any entity in the Financial Group of the Authorised Person and it is held as Collateral by the Authorised Person or any of its Financial Group entities. [#SRC:a3e095b2-569f-4475-9c44-3652864cf685] Accordingly, the Authorised Person should apply a two-step determination: first confirm the instrument is within the FCCA-eligible set (including Rule 4.13.5 instruments), and then screen out any T1/T2 Capital instruments issued by a Financial Group entity when the Collateral is held within the Authorised Person’s Financial Group. [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85] [#SRC:a3e095b2-569f-4475-9c44-3652864cf685] This ensures the FCCA eligibility assessment does not inadvertently treat intra-Group capital instruments as eligible merely because they appear on the Rule 4.13.5 list. [#SRC:a3e095b2-569f-4475-9c44-3652864cf685]

debug_context.source_text: For the purposes of Rule 4.13.5 and 4.13.6, eligible financial Collateral excludes any T1 Capital instrument or T2 Capital instrument issued by any entity in the Financial Group of the Authorised Person, which is held by the Authorised Person or any of its Financial Group entities as Collateral.
debug_context.target_text: For an Authorised Person using the FCCA, eligible financial Collateral comprises: (a) any instrument listed in Rule 4.13.5; (b) any equity Security (including a convertible bond) that is traded on a regulated exchange; and (c) any Unit in a Collective Investment Fund which invests in equity Securities referred to in (b), where: (i) a price for the Units is publicly quoted daily; and (ii) at least 90% of the deposited property of the Fund is invested in instruments listed in this Rule and Rule 4.13.5.

question: If an Authorised Person using the FCCA wants to take a Unit in a Collective Investment Fund as eligible financial Collateral, what extra checks apply to the Fund, and does the rule about excluding certain T1/T2 Capital instruments issued within the Financial Group affect what the Fund can hold to meet the 90% investment test?
expected_answer: A Unit in a Collective Investment Fund can count as eligible financial Collateral for an Authorised Person using the FCCA only if the Fund is an equity-focused fund meeting specific conditions, and the Fund’s holdings must be assessed against what is treated as eligible under the relevant rules. [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85] The Fund-related checks are: the Units must have a price that is publicly quoted daily, and at least 90% of the Fund’s deposited property must be invested in instruments that are listed in the FCCA-eligible rule set (this Rule and Rule 4.13.5). [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85] When applying that 90% test, instruments that are excluded from eligible financial Collateral must not be treated as qualifying investments for this purpose; specifically, any T1 Capital instrument or T2 Capital instrument issued by an entity in the Financial Group of the Authorised Person is excluded where it is held as Collateral by the Authorised Person or any of its Financial Group entities. [#SRC:a3e095b2-569f-4475-9c44-3652864cf685] Therefore, the Authorised Person should verify both the Fund’s daily public pricing and the 90% investment composition, while ensuring the composition is not satisfied by relying on excluded intra-Group T1/T2 capital instruments. [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85] [#SRC:a3e095b2-569f-4475-9c44-3652864cf685]

question: How should an Authorised Person classify itself if its Financial Services Permission includes Accepting Deposits and also includes Providing Credit and Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal), and what determinative authorisation and “absence of authorisation” tests must be applied across Categories 1 and 2?
expected_answer: The Authorised Person must assess Category 1 and Category 2 by applying each category’s determinative authorisation test and the stated “does not meet Category 5” condition, and then determine which category’s criteria it satisfies. [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66] For Category 1, the determinative factor is whether its Financial Services Permission authorises Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu, and it must also not meet the criteria of Category 5. [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66] For Category 2, the relevant authorisations are Providing Credit and/or Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal), and the firm must not meet the criteria of Categories 1 or 5; additionally, its dealing activities must not be limited in scope as described in Rule 1.3.3(1)(a)(i). [#SRC:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f] In applying the Category 2 guidance, the analysis also turns on the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rule 1.3.1 when determining Category 2 status. [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66] Accordingly, because Category 2 expressly excludes firms that meet Category 1, the firm must first confirm whether it meets Category 1 based on Accepting Deposits/PSIAu authorisation before concluding it can be Category 2. [#SRC:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f] [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66]

question: If a firm’s dealing is only as Matched Principal, but it also has permission for Providing Credit, how do you decide whether it fits Category 2 or instead falls into Category 3A, and what extra Category 2 conditions must you check?

question: When an Authorised Person seeks to recognise the effects of CRM for the types of Collateral referenced in Rules 4.13.5 to 4.13.7, what specific pre-recognition conditions must it have in place under the requirements that must be complied with before recognition, including any constraints on eligible securities and any custodian-related safeguards?
expected_answer: To recognise the effects of CRM for the types of Collateral referenced in Rules 4.13.5 to 4.13.7, an Authorised Person may do so only if it ensures the relevant requirements in Rule 4.13.8 are complied with, because compliance with those requirements is a condition for recognition. [#SRC:c36bf3cf-160f-43ab-bb40-9d7f5ceec7b8] Before recognition, the Authorised Person must ensure that the legal arrangement for pledging, assigning, or transferring the Collateral gives it a timely right to liquidate or take legal possession upon the Counterparty’s default/insolvency/bankruptcy (or other defined credit events in the transaction documentation), and where applicable also upon such events affecting the custodian holding the Collateral. [#TGT:cb37e5c4-ed71-4523-8fb8-da4fbc7eecf1] It must also take all steps needed under the applicable law to obtain and maintain an enforceable security interest (including registration where required) or to exercise netting/set-off rights for title transfer Collateral. [#TGT:cb37e5c4-ed71-4523-8fb8-da4fbc7eecf1] In addition, it must avoid Collateral where the Counterparty’s credit quality and Collateral value are materially positively correlated, and it must treat securities issued by the Counterparty or any Closely Related Counterparty as ineligible. [#TGT:cb37e5c4-ed71-4523-8fb8-da4fbc7eecf1] Operationally, it must have procedures enabling prompt liquidation while observing legal conditions for declaring default, and if a custodian holds the Collateral, it must take reasonable steps to ensure segregation from the custodian’s own assets. [#TGT:cb37e5c4-ed71-4523-8fb8-da4fbc7eecf1]

question: If an Authorised Person wants to count the risk-reduction effect of CRM using Collateral (the types mentioned in Rules 4.13.5 to 4.13.7), what must it check and set up first under the “Requirements for Recognition of Collateral,” especially about being able to sell/take the Collateral quickly and what happens when a custodian holds it?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person can only recognise the effects of CRM for the types of Collateral referred to in Rules 4.13.5 to 4.13.7 if it ensures the relevant requirements in Rule 4.13.8 are met, because those requirements are the gateway conditions for recognition. [#SRC:c36bf3cf-160f-43ab-bb40-9d7f5ceec7b8] Practically, before recognising CRM, it must confirm that the legal method used to pledge, assign, or transfer the Collateral gives it a right to liquidate or take legal possession in a timely way if the Counterparty defaults or becomes insolvent/bankrupt (or if other defined credit events in the transaction documents occur), and this also extends to the custodian’s default/insolvency/bankruptcy where applicable. [#TGT:cb37e5c4-ed71-4523-8fb8-da4fbc7eecf1] It must also have taken all steps needed under the law governing its interest in the Collateral to obtain and keep an enforceable security interest (including registration where required) or to exercise net/set-off rights for title transfer Collateral. [#TGT:cb37e5c4-ed71-4523-8fb8-da4fbc7eecf1] In addition, it must have procedures that allow prompt liquidation while observing any legal conditions for declaring the Counterparty in default, and if a custodian holds the Collateral, it must take reasonable steps to ensure the custodian keeps the Collateral separate from the custodian’s own assets. [#TGT:cb37e5c4-ed71-4523-8fb8-da4fbc7eecf1]

question: When a Reporting Entity requests a Trading Halt or Suspension from the Listing Authority to obtain time to prepare and release a Disclosure of Inside Information, what information will the Listing Authority usually require the Reporting Entity to provide, and in what types of Disclosure-management circumstances might a Trading Halt or Suspension be considered necessary (including how the RIE’s trading status affects that assessment)?
expected_answer: A Reporting Entity seeking a Trading Halt or Suspension to gain time to prepare and release a Disclosure of Inside Information should expect the Listing Authority to require specific contextual details, and the Listing Authority will then decide whether the situation justifies the halt/suspension. [#SRC:22a51628-c5c0-43b8-b062-2c8145b3a2c6] In practice, the Listing Authority will usually ask the Reporting Entity to outline: the nature of the Inside Information, why the Trading Halt or Suspension is being requested, what event is expected to end it, and the intended scope and timing for releasing the Disclosure. [#SRC:22a51628-c5c0-43b8-b062-2c8145b3a2c6] Those inputs are assessed against circumstances where a Trading Halt or Suspension may be necessary to manage Disclosure issues, including where confidentiality appears to have been lost ahead of Disclosure and the information is having (or, if the RIE is not yet open, is likely to have when it opens) a significant price effect. [#TGT:4bdd6d36-6949-4aeb-9161-1eead5b4cfb9] It may also be necessary if the Listing Authority has asked the Reporting Entity to correct or prevent a false market, or if the Inside Information is particularly significant and likely to move the price materially (with examples such as a significant capital raising, a board decision to appoint an administrator, or winning approval for a one-off contract that substantially changes scale and activities). [#TGT:4bdd6d36-6949-4aeb-9161-1eead5b4cfb9] The RIE’s status matters: if the market is open and the Reporting Entity cannot disclose immediately, or if the market is not open and the Reporting Entity cannot disclose before the RIE opens, that timing constraint supports the need for a halt/suspension. [#TGT:4bdd6d36-6949-4aeb-9161-1eead5b4cfb9]

question: If a Reporting Entity asks the Listing Authority for a Trading Halt or Suspension because it needs time to get a Disclosure of Inside Information ready, what details does it usually have to explain, and what situations (like lost confidentiality or the RIE being open/closed) can make a Trading Halt or Suspension necessary?

question: When the Regulator receives the notice referred to in Rule 3.2.2 and would otherwise be required to notify Host Regulator(s) within five Business Days of its intent to use the passporting procedures, in what circumstances must the Regulator refrain from transmitting the notice under Rule 3.2.4(a), and how does that affect the downstream steps tied to Host Regulator confirmation and completion of registration on the Register of Passported Funds?
expected_answer: The Regulator is required to withhold transmitting the notice under Rule 3.2.4(a) if it forms certain compliance- or objectives-based views, even though the passporting workflow otherwise contemplates a five-Business-Day notification to Host Regulator(s) after receiving the Rule 3.2.2 notice. [#TGT:3c548ffe-2bd8-478f-8ddc-d55a1eb83d6e] Specifically, the Regulator must not transmit that notice if it considers the Fund Manager or the Public Fund is not complying with applicable legislation (including these Rules), or if it has reasonable grounds to determine that the Fund Manager or the Public Fund may not comply in the future. [#SRC:02c6d009-e171-41d6-adac-aaaaf2b66e5a] It must also refrain where it considers doing so is necessary and appropriate to meet its objectives. [#SRC:02c6d009-e171-41d6-adac-aaaaf2b66e5a] Because the subsequent steps in the passporting sequence are expressly tied to Host Regulator involvement and confirmation, withholding the Rule 3.2.4(a) notice prevents the Regulator from proceeding along that path: the Regulator’s obligation to provide notice of intent to use the passporting procedures to the Host Regulator(s) within five Business Days is framed as part of the process that is “subject to Rule 3.2.5.” [#TGT:3c548ffe-2bd8-478f-8ddc-d55a1eb83d6e] Likewise, publication on the Register of Passported Funds and notification to the Fund Manager that registration is complete occur only after confirmation from the relevant Host Regulator that its Register has been updated. [#TGT:3c548ffe-2bd8-478f-8ddc-d55a1eb83d6e]

debug_context.source_text: The Regulator shall not transmit a notice under Rule 3.2.4‎(a): (a) if it considers that the Fund Manager or the Public Fund does not comply with, or it has reasonable grounds for determining that the Fund Manager or the Public Fund may in the future not comply with, applicable legislation, including these Rules; or (b) if it considers that it is necessary and appropriate to refrain from doing so in order to meet its objectives.
debug_context.target_text: The Regulator shall: (a) Within five Business Days of receipt of the notice set out in Rule 3.2.2, and subject to Rule 3.2.5, provide notice of the intent to use the passporting procedures under these Rules to the Host Regulator(s) in the relevant Host Jurisdiction(s) where the Passported Fund is intended to be Promoted; and (b) promptly following confirmation from the relevant Host Regulator that its respective Register of Passported Funds has been updated to include the details of the Passported Fund: (i) publish the details of the Passported Fund on the Register of Passported Funds; and (ii) notify the Fund Manager that registration on the Register of Passported Funds is complete.

question: For an Authorised Person conducting periodic stress tests on securitisation activities and off balance sheet Exposures (including testing future ability to transact securitisation as a means of CRM or for liquidity purposes), how must it determine the appropriate frequency and extent of those stress tests?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must run stress tests periodically for its securitisation activities and its off balance sheet Exposures, and those tests must include an assessment of the Authorised Person’s future ability to transact securitisation as a means of CRM or for liquidity purposes. [#TGT:d430637c-0076-42dd-b3ff-ff739c34e3aa] The appropriate frequency and the extent (i.e., how often and how wide-ranging/deep) of the stress testing are not fixed; instead, they must be set by reference to the materiality of the Authorised Person’s securitisation volumes and its off balance sheet Exposures. [#SRC:053ecf47-4501-4027-a994-9ada059b5e73] In practice, this means the Authorised Person should calibrate its periodic stress-testing programme so that more material securitisation volumes and/or more material off balance sheet Exposures drive a higher frequency and/or greater extent of testing, while less material activity supports a lower frequency and/or narrower extent—provided the programme still covers both securitisation activities and off balance sheet Exposures and includes the forward-looking ability-to-transact element for CRM or liquidity purposes. [#TGT:d430637c-0076-42dd-b3ff-ff739c34e3aa] [#SRC:053ecf47-4501-4027-a994-9ada059b5e73]
