question: For an Authorised Person, how do the criteria in Rule 2.2.1 (which trigger application of the Appendix) connect to the specific quantitative and intent-based tests for when it must have a Trading Book, including the normal and look-back thresholds?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person is within scope of the Appendix only if it meets the criteria in Rule 2.2.1, and that status is what makes it required to have a Trading Book under the Appendix framework. [#SRC:80bc7597-4d36-479b-a3e3-7c1f24dda06d] To determine whether the Authorised Person must have a Trading Book, apply the Trading Book tests that specify both the nature of positions and quantitative thresholds. [#TGT:222ece21-d4dd-4842-a942-cc4312301ea0] In practice, the Authorised Person must have a Trading Book when it has positions that are required to be included in a Trading Book under Section A2.1 of App2, and those positions are held with trading intent as described in Rule A2.1.5. [#TGT:222ece21-d4dd-4842-a942-cc4312301ea0] In addition, the total value of positions eligible for inclusion (based on those inclusion and intent conditions) must meet one of the specified size tests: either it normally exceeds $15 million or 5% of combined on- and off-balance sheet positions, or it exceeded $20 million or 6% at any time during the preceding 12-month period. [#TGT:222ece21-d4dd-4842-a942-cc4312301ea0] Read together, the Appendix’s applicability hinge (meeting Rule 2.2.1) provides the scope, while the Trading Book requirement is operationalized by the position-type, trading-intent, and threshold tests. [#SRC:80bc7597-4d36-479b-a3e3-7c1f24dda06d] [#TGT:222ece21-d4dd-4842-a942-cc4312301ea0]

debug_context.target_text: An Authorised Person must have a Trading Book if: (a) it has positions that must be included in a Trading Book in accordance with Section A2.1 of App2; (b) those positions are held with trading intent in accordance with Rule A2.1.5; and (c) the total value of the positions eligible for inclusion in the Trading Book pursuant to (a) and (b): (i) normally exceeds $15 million or 5% of its combined on and off balance sheet positions; or (ii) has exceeded $20 million or 6% of its combined on- and off balance sheet positions at any time in the preceding 12 month period.

question: If an Authorised Person is one that meets the criteria in Rule 2.2.1 (so the Appendix applies), what exact checks does it use to decide whether it must have a Trading Book, including the dollar/percentage limits and the 12‑month look-back?
expected_answer: If the Authorised Person meets the criteria in Rule 2.2.1, the Appendix applies to it and, on that basis, it is required to have a Trading Book when the Trading Book conditions are met. [#SRC:80bc7597-4d36-479b-a3e3-7c1f24dda06d] The decision is not based on a single factor; it requires checking the type of positions, the intent for holding them, and the size of the eligible positions. [#TGT:222ece21-d4dd-4842-a942-cc4312301ea0] Specifically, the Authorised Person must have a Trading Book if it has positions that must be included in a Trading Book under Section A2.1 of App2, and those positions are held with trading intent under Rule A2.1.5. [#TGT:222ece21-d4dd-4842-a942-cc4312301ea0] Then it must assess the total value of the positions that are eligible for inclusion based on those two conditions: the requirement is triggered if that total normally exceeds $15 million or 5% of its combined on- and off-balance sheet positions, or if it exceeded $20 million or 6% at any time in the preceding 12 months. [#TGT:222ece21-d4dd-4842-a942-cc4312301ea0] The Appendix scope condition (meeting Rule 2.2.1) and the Trading Book tests together determine whether the Trading Book requirement applies in the Authorised Person’s case. [#SRC:80bc7597-4d36-479b-a3e3-7c1f24dda06d] [#TGT:222ece21-d4dd-4842-a942-cc4312301ea0]

question: Where the Regulator issues a written notice directing an Authorised Person to submit returns in a different form, manner, or frequency than prescribed in Rule 2.3.2, how must the Authorised Person reconcile that direction with the obligation to prepare returns under the Chapter/PRU/EPRS requirements (including EPRS submission frequency) and to submit via EPRS, and for how long does the modified approach apply?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must treat the Regulator’s written notice as an operative instruction that changes the form, manner, or frequency of submission away from what would otherwise apply under Rule 2.3.2, while still meeting the baseline requirement to prepare returns under the Chapter framework and to submit them to the Regulator using EPRS. [#SRC:ceb0fc5a-9013-4a01-bf0c-a672333fcb3b] [#TGT:d384c02a-97aa-458d-9961-3b9b406ec6f9] In practice, this means the Authorised Person should (i) continue preparing returns in line with the Rules in the Chapter, the instructional guidelines in PRU and elsewhere, and the EPRS requirements (including the frequency of submission described in EPRS), and (ii) submit those returns through EPRS, except to the extent the written notice specifically directs a different form, manner, or frequency than Rule 2.3.2 would prescribe. [#TGT:d384c02a-97aa-458d-9961-3b9b406ec6f9] [#SRC:ceb0fc5a-9013-4a01-bf0c-a672333fcb3b] The modified approach is not temporary by default: the Authorised Person must keep submitting returns in accordance with the Regulator’s direction until the Regulator issues a further written notice directing otherwise. [#SRC:ceb0fc5a-9013-4a01-bf0c-a672333fcb3b] This creates a clear control point: EPRS-based preparation and submission remains the standard operating method, but a written notice can override the Rule 2.3.2 baseline on form/manner/frequency for as long as that notice remains in effect. [#TGT:d384c02a-97aa-458d-9961-3b9b406ec6f9] [#SRC:ceb0fc5a-9013-4a01-bf0c-a672333fcb3b]

debug_context.source_text: The Regulator may by way of a written notice direct an Authorised Person to submit its returns in a form, manner or frequency other than as prescribed in Rule 2.3.2. An Authorised Person must continue to submit its returns in accordance with this direction until the Regulator by way of written notice directs otherwise.
debug_context.target_text: An Authorised Person must, subject to Rule 2.3.3: (a) prepare its returns in accordance with the Rules in this Chapter, the instructional guidelines in PRU and elsewhere, and the requirements of the Electronic Prudential Reporting System (EPRS) of the Regulator including the frequency of submission detailed therein; and (b) submit the returns to the Regulator using EPRS.

question: If the Regulator sends a written notice telling an Authorised Person to file returns in a different way or on a different schedule than Rule 2.3.2, does the Authorised Person still have to use EPRS and follow the Chapter/PRU/EPRS preparation requirements, and when can it stop following the notice?
expected_answer: Yes: the Authorised Person must still prepare its returns under the Rules in the Chapter, the instructional guidelines in PRU and elsewhere, and the Regulator’s EPRS requirements (including the submission frequency described in EPRS), and it must submit the returns to the Regulator using EPRS. [#TGT:d384c02a-97aa-458d-9961-3b9b406ec6f9] At the same time, if the Regulator issues a written notice directing a different form, manner, or frequency of submission than Rule 2.3.2 would otherwise require, the Authorised Person must follow that direction for those aspects. [#SRC:ceb0fc5a-9013-4a01-bf0c-a672333fcb3b] The practical reconciliation is that EPRS-based preparation and submission remains the default operating channel and standards, but the written notice can change how the returns are submitted (form/manner) or how often they are submitted (frequency) compared with the Rule 2.3.2 baseline. [#TGT:d384c02a-97aa-458d-9961-3b9b406ec6f9] [#SRC:ceb0fc5a-9013-4a01-bf0c-a672333fcb3b] The Authorised Person cannot decide on its own when to revert: it must continue submitting returns in accordance with the Regulator’s direction until the Regulator issues another written notice telling it to do otherwise. [#SRC:ceb0fc5a-9013-4a01-bf0c-a672333fcb3b] This means the “stop” point is controlled by a further written notice, not by the passage of time or internal preference. [#SRC:ceb0fc5a-9013-4a01-bf0c-a672333fcb3b]

question: When the Regulator is considering disclosure under the permissions referenced in paragraphs (1)(b)(i)–(iv), (vi) and 1(c), what specific consent and purpose limitations apply if the information is (a) Confidential Information that originated in another governmental or regulatory authority, or (b) CRD Information as defined by reference to receipt from an EEA Competent Authority?
expected_answer: The Regulator may only disclose Confidential Information under the permissions referenced in paragraphs (1)(b)(i)–(iv), (vi) and 1(c) if the relevant consent conditions are satisfied, and those conditions differ depending on whether the information originated with another authority or is CRD Information. [#TGT:3c8ef7e5-1e03-4523-abe0-9bd8451cee4c] For Confidential Information that originates (in whole or in part) in another governmental or regulatory authority (whether within the Abu Dhabi Global Market or elsewhere), the Regulator must obtain that originating authority’s prior written consent before making the disclosure. [#TGT:3c8ef7e5-1e03-4523-abe0-9bd8451cee4c] If the information is CRD Information, the Regulator must treat it as Confidential Information received or obtained from an EEA Competent Authority by virtue of the Capital Requirements Directive, and therefore must obtain the prior written consent of the EEA Competent Authority that provided it. [#SRC:dc3f77a8-19bb-49c7-a2f8-f257642a9321] [#TGT:3c8ef7e5-1e03-4523-abe0-9bd8451cee4c] In addition, where the EEA Competent Authority’s consent is granted for a particular purpose, the Regulator’s disclosure must be limited strictly to that purpose. [#TGT:3c8ef7e5-1e03-4523-abe0-9bd8451cee4c] This CRD-focused consent framework aligns with the section 199(2) provisions that address information exchange and professional secrecy in the Capital Requirements Directive context. [#SRC:dc3f77a8-19bb-49c7-a2f8-f257642a9321]

debug_context.source_text: The exceptions under section 199(1) of FSMR. The provisions in section 199(2) relate specifically to Confidential Information originating in another governmental or regulatory authority, or Confidential Information that is CRD Information, and provide for and are consistent with the exchange of information and professional secrecy requirements in the European Unions Capital Requirements Directive. For the purposes of section 199(2): (a) CRD Information is defined as Confidential Information received or obtained by the Regulator from the EEA Competent Authority by virtue of the Capital Requirements Directive; and (b) EEA Competent Authority means a public authority or body officially recognised by national law of a jurisdiction within the EEA and empowered by that national law to supervise institutions as part of the supervisory system.
debug_context.target_text: Paragraphs (1)(b)(i), (ii), (iii), (iv), (vi) and 1(c) do not permit the Regulator to disclose Confidential Information unless the conditions in paragraphs (a) and (b) are met – (a) where the Confidential Information (in whole or in part) originates in another governmental or regulatory authority, whether in the Abu Dhabi Global Market or otherwise, the authority that has disclosed the Confidential Information to the Regulator has given its prior written consent to the disclosure; and (b) where the Confidential Information is CRD Information – (i) EEA Competent Authority that has disclosed the Confidential Information to the Regulator has given its prior written consent to the disclosure; and (ii) if such consent was given for a particular purpose, the disclosure by the Regulator is solely for that purpose.

question: If the Regulator wants to share Confidential Information using the permissions listed in paragraphs (1)(b)(i)–(iv), (vi) and 1(c), what does it need to do first when (1) the information came from another authority, and (2) the information is CRD Information received from an EEA Competent Authority under the Capital Requirements Directive?
expected_answer: Before the Regulator can disclose Confidential Information under the permissions in paragraphs (1)(b)(i)–(iv), (vi) and 1(c), it must check which consent rule applies based on where the information came from. [#TGT:3c8ef7e5-1e03-4523-abe0-9bd8451cee4c] If the Confidential Information (all or part) originated with another governmental or regulatory authority (inside the Abu Dhabi Global Market or elsewhere), the Regulator cannot disclose it unless that authority has provided prior written consent. [#TGT:3c8ef7e5-1e03-4523-abe0-9bd8451cee4c] If the information is CRD Information, it is a specific type of Confidential Information: it is received or obtained by the Regulator from the EEA Competent Authority by virtue of the Capital Requirements Directive. [#SRC:dc3f77a8-19bb-49c7-a2f8-f257642a9321] In that CRD case, the Regulator must obtain prior written consent from the EEA Competent Authority that supplied the information. [#TGT:3c8ef7e5-1e03-4523-abe0-9bd8451cee4c] Also, if the EEA Competent Authority’s consent is limited to a particular purpose, the Regulator may disclose the CRD Information only for that purpose and not for any other use. [#TGT:3c8ef7e5-1e03-4523-abe0-9bd8451cee4c] These steps reflect the section 199(2) focus on handling CRD-related confidential material in a way consistent with information exchange and professional secrecy expectations under the Capital Requirements Directive. [#SRC:dc3f77a8-19bb-49c7-a2f8-f257642a9321]

question: How does the exclusion in Rule 6.8.1(b)(iv) affect an Authorised Person’s duty to take reasonable steps to make and retain recordings of voice and electronic communications under Rule 6.8.1(a), particularly for communications involving Clients or other Persons in relation to a Transaction and made on equipment provided or permitted by the Authorised Person?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person’s obligation to take reasonable steps to make and retain recordings under Rule 6.8.1(a) applies only to the extent it is not carved out by Rule 6.8.1(b)(iv). [#SRC:42726734-2dda-41b2-bba0-84f238f4e0c5] In scope, the recording duty covers voice and electronic communications with a Client or with another Person where the communication is in relation to a Transaction, including communications about receiving, executing, or arranging execution of Client orders and passing related instructions. [#TGT:b67e7e61-b8d6-4ede-8736-73c331997df8] It also applies only where the communication is made with, sent from, or received on equipment that the Authorised Person provided to an Employee or contractor, or equipment whose use the Authorised Person has sanctioned or permitted. [#TGT:b67e7e61-b8d6-4ede-8736-73c331997df8] However, the effect of Rule 6.8.1(b)(iv) is that conversations or communications made by Investment Analysts, retail financial advisers, and persons carrying on back office functions are excluded from Rule 6.8.1(a), even if they would otherwise fall within the Transaction/Client-related and equipment-based conditions described above. [#SRC:42726734-2dda-41b2-bba0-84f238f4e0c5] Accordingly, when assessing whether a particular communication must be recorded and retained, the Authorised Person must evaluate both the communication’s subject matter/equipment nexus and whether the communicator falls within the excluded categories. [#TGT:b67e7e61-b8d6-4ede-8736-73c331997df8] [#SRC:42726734-2dda-41b2-bba0-84f238f4e0c5]

question: If an Employee uses equipment the Authorised Person provided (or allowed) to talk with a Client about a Transaction, when does the Authorised Person have to record and keep that call, and when is it not required because of the Rule 6.8.1(b)(iv) exclusion?
expected_answer: The Authorised Person must take reasonable steps to make and retain recordings of voice and electronic communications when the communication is with a Client (or another Person) in relation to a Transaction, including messages about receiving, executing, or arranging execution of Client orders and passing related instructions. [#TGT:b67e7e61-b8d6-4ede-8736-73c331997df8] This duty is framed as being subject to Rule 6.8.1(b), and it applies where the communication is made with, sent from, or received on equipment the Authorised Person provided to an Employee or contractor, or equipment whose use the Authorised Person has sanctioned or permitted. [#TGT:b67e7e61-b8d6-4ede-8736-73c331997df8] Even if those conditions are met, the effect of Rule 6.8.1(b)(iv) is that conversations or communications made by Investment Analysts, retail financial advisers, and persons carrying on back office functions are excluded from Rule 6.8.1(a). [#SRC:42726734-2dda-41b2-bba0-84f238f4e0c5] So, to decide whether recording is required, you need both checks: (1) does the communication match the Client/Transaction and equipment conditions, and (2) is the person making the communication outside the excluded categories. question: In assessing whether Behaviour involving effecting transactions or orders to trade that may create a false or misleading impression or secure an abnormal/artificial price is caught by the described category, how does the ability to establish that the conduct was for legitimate reasons and in conformity with an Accepted Market Practice affect the analysis?
expected_answer: Where the Behaviour consists of effecting transactions or orders to trade that give, or are likely to give, a false or misleading impression about supply, demand, or price, or that secure the price at an abnormal or artificial level, the described category is framed to apply when those transactions or orders are done other than for legitimate reasons and in conformity with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market. [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f] In that context, if a person can establish that they carried out the conduct or practice for legitimate reasons and in conformance with an Accepted Market Practice, that established showing aligns with the stated carve-out condition and therefore addresses the “otherwise than for legitimate reasons and in conformity” element embedded in the category description. [#SRC:277b5e91-5efc-4b1d-a2b2-790aa0039f73] Practically, the analysis turns on two linked components: (i) whether the transactions/orders have (or are likely to have) the misleading/price-securing effects described, and (ii) whether the person can demonstrate legitimate reasons and conformity with an Accepted Market Practice, which is the specific basis identified for treating the conduct as market practice rather than falling within the “otherwise than” framing. [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f] [#SRC:277b5e91-5efc-4b1d-a2b2-790aa0039f73]

debug_context.source_text: Market Practice. If a person establishes that they carried out the conduct or practice for legitimate reasons and in conformance with an Accepted Market Practice (see section 92(4)).
debug_context.target_text: The third is where the Behaviour consists of effecting transactions or orders to trade (otherwise than for legitimate reasons and in conformity with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market) which— (a) give, or are likely to give, a false or misleading impression as to the supply of, or demand for, or as to the price of, one or more Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities; or (b) secure the price of one or more such instruments at an abnormal or artificial level.

question: When calculating Additional Tier 1Capital (AT1 Capital), how should the firm reconcile the SOURCE statement that AT1 Capital is the sum of AT1 Capital elements in Rule 3.11.2 subject to later deductions, with the TARGET specification of which capital elements make up that sum (including any related accounts)?
expected_answer: AT1 Capital should be determined by first identifying the capital elements that are included in the “sum” and then applying any deductions that the relevant Section requires later. [#SRC:07d97e4e-0f4e-4883-abf4-12a3890129f9] Concretely, the capital elements that make up AT1 Capital include (a) capital instruments that satisfy the eligibility criteria in Rule 3.11.3 and (b) the share premium accounts that relate to those eligible instruments. [#TGT:1cb9d22d-5506-40d1-92ea-7f84d5e4d10b] The SOURCE frames this as a sum of AT1 Capital elements referenced in Rule 3.11.2, but it also makes clear that the resulting amount is not final until the deductions specified later in the same Section are taken into account. [#SRC:07d97e4e-0f4e-4883-abf4-12a3890129f9] Accordingly, a compliant calculation approach is: (1) include the eligible capital instruments and their related share premium accounts as the component elements of AT1 Capital, and (2) treat that subtotal as subject to reduction by the deductions stipulated later in the Section. [#TGT:1cb9d22d-5506-40d1-92ea-7f84d5e4d10b] [#SRC:07d97e4e-0f4e-4883-abf4-12a3890129f9]

question: Under Section 92(2), when an Insider has Inside Information relating to a Financial Instrument, how should the prohibition on dealing be applied to a "Related Instrument", and where is the definition of "Related Instrument" located?
expected_answer: Section 92(2) prohibits an Insider from dealing or attempting to deal not only in the Financial Instrument (and, where relevant, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity) to which the Inside Information relates, but also in any Related Instrument connected to that Inside Information. [#SRC:4d6d9fa5-5edd-4280-9d7b-90fca017f5d7] For purposes of applying that prohibition, a Related Instrument is treated as within scope where, in relation to a Financial Instrument, it is an investment whose price or value depends on the price or value of the Financial Instrument. [#TGT:701dd6f2-183c-4150-a7ab-58ab24fc3f8f] This means the compliance analysis must extend beyond the instrument that is the direct subject of the Inside Information to any dependent-value investment, such as a derivative linked to the Financial Instruments of the relevant Issuer. [#TGT:701dd6f2-183c-4150-a7ab-58ab24fc3f8f] It can also include another Financial Instrument in a member of the Issuer’s Group, provided that the price or value of that other Financial Instrument depends (in whole or in part) on the price or value of the Issuer’s Financial Instruments. [#TGT:701dd6f2-183c-4150-a7ab-58ab24fc3f8f] The formal definition of “Related Instrument” is located at paragraph 1(9) of the CMC, which should be used as the reference point when determining whether a particular investment falls within Section 92(2)’s dealing prohibition. [#SRC:4d6d9fa5-5edd-4280-9d7b-90fca017f5d7]

debug_context.source_text: Related Instruments. Section 92(2) prohibits an Insider from dealing or attempting to deal in relation to either the Financial Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity (i.e. to which the Inside Information relates) or a Related Instrument. The definition of a "Related Instrument" is set out at paragraph 1(9) of the CMC.
debug_context.target_text: Application to Financial Instruments and Related Instruments. Section 92(2) (Insider Dealing) also applies to a "Related Instrument", which is defined as meaning: "…in relation to a Financial Instrument, an investment whose price or value depends on the price or value of the Financial Instrument." For example, if an Insider has Inside Information relating to an Issuer, A, of Financial Instruments, then a "Related Instrument" could include a Derivative relating to the Financial Instruments of A or another Financial Instrument in a member of A's Group, if the price or value of that other Financial Instrument depends, in whole or in part, on the price or value of Financial Instruments of A.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity makes a subsequent disclosure of forecast financial information derived from a Production Target after having already disclosed under Rule 11.9.1, under what conditions may it omit the assumption and Production Target information otherwise required in the initial Rule 11.9.1 disclosure, and what specific content must have been included in that earlier Rule 11.9.1 disclosure for the cross-reference to be valid?
expected_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity may omit the Rule 11.9.2 information in a subsequent disclosure of forecast financial information derived from a Production Target only if the subsequent disclosure is explicitly anchored to an earlier Rule 11.9.1 disclosure that itself contained the required assumption and Production Target content, and the subsequent disclosure includes the specified confirmations and warnings. [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4] For the earlier Rule 11.9.1 disclosure to be a valid reference point, it must have included all material economic assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information, any commercially sensitive statement (if applicable) together with an explanation of the methodology used to determine those material economic assumptions, and all other material assumptions utilised, as well as the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3). [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] In the subsequent disclosure, the Mining Reporting Entity must (i) reference that earlier compliant disclosure, and (ii) confirm that all material assumptions from the initial disclosure continue to apply and have not materially changed. [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4] Additionally, if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, or is based in part on an Exploration Target, the subsequent disclosure must include an at least equally prominent and proximate statement about the forecast financial information corresponding to the relevant statement specified in Rule 11.8.3(5)(d) or Rule 11.8.3(7)(b), respectively. [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4]

debug_context.source_text: If a Mining Reporting Entity has made a disclosure under Rule 11.9.1, then any subsequent disclosure in relation to forecast financial information derived from a Production Target need not include the information in Rule 11.9.2 where the subsequent disclosure: (1) references the earlier disclosure that was in compliance with Rule 11.9.2; (2) contains a statement confirming that all the material assumptions in the initial disclosure upon which the forecast financial information derived from a Production Target is based continue to apply and have not materially changed; (3) if the Production Target upon which the forecast financial information is derived is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, includes an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement about the disclosed forecast financial information to the effect of the statement set out in Rule 11.8.3(5)(d); and (4) if the Production Target upon which the forecast financial information is derived is based in part upon an Exploration Target, includes an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement about the disclosed forecast financial information to the effect of the statement set out in Rule 11.8.3(7)(b).
debug_context.target_text: A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include: (1) in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information: (a) all material economic assumptions employed; (b) if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and Guidance A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure. (c) all other material assumptions utilised. (2) the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).

expected_answer: A later disclosure about forecast financial information derived from a Production Target can leave out the Rule 11.9.2 information only when it is built on an earlier Rule 11.9.1 disclosure and includes the required confirmations and any required cautionary statements tied to the basis of the Production Target. question: Where an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, how do the restrictions on actions pending calculation and notification apply to specific CET1 Capital-related transactions such as cash dividends, bonus Shares, and redemptions or purchases of its own Shares, and what procedural steps must be completed before those actions may be undertaken?
expected_answer: If an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it is restricted from carrying out certain actions, including distributions connected with CET1 Capital, until it completes specified procedural steps. [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e] In this context, a “distribution in connection with CET1 Capital” includes, among other items, paying cash dividends, issuing fully or partly paid bonus Shares or other capital instruments, redeeming or purchasing its own Shares or other capital instruments, repaying amounts paid up in connection with capital, and distributing other items that are eligible for inclusion as CET1 Capital. [#SRC:34155950-25e6-40a4-b984-3b9ddd253f26] Accordingly, when the Combined Buffer Requirement is not met, the Authorised Person must first calculate the maximum distributable amount in accordance with Rule 3.19.6. [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e] It must also refrain from undertaking any CET1 Capital distribution (including the specific forms listed above) until it has both calculated that maximum distributable amount and notified the Regulator under Rule 3.19.7. [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e] This linkage means that the enumerated CET1-related transactions—such as cash dividends, bonus Shares, and buybacks/redemptions—are treated as restricted “distributions” for the period before calculation and notification are completed. [#SRC:34155950-25e6-40a4-b984-3b9ddd253f26] [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e]

debug_context.source_text: Restrictions on distributions. For the purposes of Rule 3.19.3(b)(i), a distribution in connection with CET1 Capital includes any of the following: (a) payment of cash dividends; (b) distribution of fully or partly paid bonus Shares or other capital instruments; (c) a redemption or purchase by an institution of its own Shares or other capital instruments; (d) a repayment of amounts paid up in connection with capital; or (e) a distribution of other items referred to in Section 3.10 as eligible for inclusion as CET1 Capital.
debug_context.target_text: Restrictions on distributions. Where an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must: (a) calculate the maximum distributable amount in accordance with Rule 3.19.6; and (b) ensure that it does not undertake any of the following actions until such time as it has calculated the maximum distributable amount and notified the Regulator under Rule 3.19.7: (i) make a distribution in connection with CET1 Capital, or create an obligation to pay variable remuneration or discretionary pension benefits, or pay variable remuneration if the obligation to pay was created at a time when the institution failed to meet its Combined Buffer Requirement; or (ii) make payments on AT1 and T2 Capital instruments.

question: If an Authorised Person does not meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, can it repay paid-up capital or buy back its own Shares right away, and what must it do first before taking those steps?
expected_answer: No. When an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must not make a distribution in connection with CET1 Capital until it has completed the required calculation and notification steps. [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e] The types of actions treated as a CET1 Capital distribution include repaying amounts paid up in connection with capital and redeeming or purchasing the institution’s own Shares or other capital instruments. [#SRC:34155950-25e6-40a4-b984-3b9ddd253f26] Because those transactions fall within the defined set of CET1 Capital distributions, they are among the actions the Authorised Person must hold off on during the restricted period triggered by failing the Combined Buffer Requirement. [#SRC:34155950-25e6-40a4-b984-3b9ddd253f26] [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e] Before it can undertake those actions, the Authorised Person must calculate the maximum distributable amount in accordance with Rule 3.19.6. [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e] It must also ensure it does not undertake the distribution until it has both calculated that amount and notified the Regulator under Rule 3.19.7. [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e] In practical terms, the repayment of paid-up capital and a buyback/redemption of own Shares are treated the same as other CET1-related distributions (such as cash dividends or bonus Shares) for purposes of the “wait until calculation and notification” restriction. [#SRC:34155950-25e6-40a4-b984-3b9ddd253f26] [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e]

question: For an Authorised Person that (i) has a Financial Services Permission to carry on either one or both of the Regulated Activities of Effecting Contracts of Insurance or Carrying Out Contracts of Insurance as Principal, and (ii) operates as a Cell Company under Rule 3.11.2 or Rule 3.11.4, what annual supervision fees must be paid to the Regulator, and how does the number of Cells affect the total amount?
expected_answer: The Authorised Person must pay the annual supervision fee applicable to the insurance Regulated Activities and, in addition, the separate annual supervision fees that apply because it operates as a Cell Company, with the Cell Company component increasing based on the number of Cells. [#TGT:6fc382ee-caf4-4abd-b571-718512a89e96] Specifically, where the Authorised Person has a Financial Services Permission to carry on either one or both of the Regulated Activities of Effecting Contracts of Insurance or Carrying Out Contracts of Insurance as Principal, it must pay the Regulator $50,000 per year for either or both of those Regulated Activities (i.e., the same $50,000 amount applies whether it carries on one or both). [#TGT:6fc382ee-caf4-4abd-b571-718512a89e96] Separately, if that same Authorised Person operates as a Cell Company under Rule 3.11.2 or Rule 3.11.4, it must also pay an additional $8,000 annual supervision fee for the Cell Company itself, plus $1,000 for each Cell. [#SRC:3256d044-7e1a-46ff-82d5-db50175eae7b] Accordingly, the total annual supervision fees payable to the Regulator equal $50,000 plus $8,000 plus $1,000 multiplied by the number of Cells. question: For an Authorised Person that is authorised to Manage a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu, how should the firm treat T2 Capital under the Part 4 capital resources framework when the Profit Equalisation Reserve and Investment Risk Reserve together exceed the Displaced Commercial Risk Capital Requirement calculated under the IFR rules?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person that is authorised to Manage a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu is subject to Part 4 for calculating capital resources, but it benefits from a specific carve-out affecting how T2 Capital is determined for that activity. [#SRC:daf2ec63-a8a3-4cd4-b0e3-450154245ed4] In applying that carve-out, the firm must remove from its T2 Capital the portion of reserves that sits above the relevant displaced commercial risk measure: specifically, it must exclude any amount by which the combined total of the Profit Equalisation Reserve and the Investment Risk Reserve is greater than the Displaced Commercial Risk Capital Requirement (as calculated under the IFR rules). [#TGT:db2f1888-b83e-45c9-99f7-dfc2058f61c2] This means the exclusion is not a blanket removal of those reserves; it is a threshold-based adjustment that only applies to the excess over the displaced commercial risk capital requirement. [#TGT:db2f1888-b83e-45c9-99f7-dfc2058f61c2] Operationally, the firm should (i) identify whether it is authorised to Manage a PSIAu and therefore within the Part 4 exemption context, and (ii) compute the excess of the two reserves over the displaced commercial risk capital requirement and exclude that excess from T2 Capital when calculating capital resources. [#SRC:daf2ec63-a8a3-4cd4-b0e3-450154245ed4] [#TGT:db2f1888-b83e-45c9-99f7-dfc2058f61c2]

question: Where the Listing Authority is dealing with a time-critical continuous disclosure issue under Rule 7.2.1, what specific contactability and internal-authority arrangements should a Reporting Entity maintain to reduce the risk that the Listing Authority will Suspend the Listed Entity’s Securities because it cannot promptly reach or obtain effective engagement from the Reporting Entity?
expected_answer: A Reporting Entity should structure its contact arrangements and internal decision-making so the Listing Authority can reach the Reporting Entity quickly and obtain prompt, effective action on sensitive, time-critical continuous disclosure matters, thereby reducing the risk of a Suspension being imposed due to failed or ineffective contact. [#SRC:8fbe10b4-f49e-4b93-b470-a3c663f2ab94] In practice, this means the Reporting Entity should be readily contactable by phone and available to discuss pressing Disclosure issues during the normal trading hours of the relevant RIE and for at least one hour before and after those hours each Business Day. [#TGT:40f90ce3-56d4-440a-abf9-2ab4b8249d8e] It also means ensuring that the relevant Officers responsible for communication with the Listing Authority have both the organisational knowledge to hold meaningful discussions on Rule matters and the authority to request a Trading Halt or Suspension and to make a Disclosure when required. [#TGT:40f90ce3-56d4-440a-abf9-2ab4b8249d8e] These measures directly address the risk scenario where the Listing Authority cannot contact the Reporting Entity’s designated contact points, or those contacts lack the knowledge or authority to resolve the matter promptly, in which case the Listing Authority may Suspend the Listed Entity’s Securities until the issue is properly resolved. [#SRC:8fbe10b4-f49e-4b93-b470-a3c663f2ab94]

question: For an Authorised Person, how does the obligation to maintain the required buffer amount as CET1 Capital at all times interact with the requirement to calculate a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital, including the specific calculation components and rule cross-references that determine the amount that must be maintained?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must ensure that the required buffer amount is continuously held in the form of CET1 Capital, and the Countercyclical Capital Buffer calculation is one mechanism that determines a CET1 Capital buffer amount that must be maintained. [#SRC:97faadb3-289b-44a9-9f5c-3ea5c35e39cf] Specifically, the Authorised Person is required to calculate a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital by taking its Total Risk Exposure Amount and multiplying it by a weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates applicable to certain exposures. [#TGT:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c] The Total Risk Exposure Amount used in that calculation must be determined under Rule 3.5.7, and the weighted average of the buffer rates must be computed under Rules 3.18.5 to 3.18.8, based on the jurisdictions where the Authorised Person’s private sector credit exposures are located. [#TGT:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c] Separately, the requirement to maintain the required buffer amount “at all times” applies to the buffer amount as calculated in accordance with Rule 3.18.4, meaning the Authorised Person must keep that CET1 Capital buffer continuously available rather than only at a point-in-time calculation date. [#SRC:97faadb3-289b-44a9-9f5c-3ea5c35e39cf]

question: If an Authorised Person has private sector credit exposures in different jurisdictions, what do they have to do to work out the Countercyclical Capital Buffer and how does that connect to the rule that says they must keep the required buffer amount as CET1 Capital at all times?
expected_answer: The Authorised Person must both (1) compute a Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital using a jurisdiction-based formula and (2) continuously hold the required buffer amount as CET1 Capital. [#TGT:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c] For the calculation, the Countercyclical Capital Buffer must equal the Authorised Person’s Total Risk Exposure Amount multiplied by the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates that apply to exposures in the jurisdictions where its private sector credit exposures are located. [#TGT:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c] The Total Risk Exposure Amount used in that multiplication must be calculated under Rule 3.5.7, and the weighted average of the jurisdictional buffer rates must be calculated under Rules 3.18.5 to 3.18.8. [#TGT:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c] Separately, the Authorised Person must maintain the required buffer amount as CET1 Capital at all times, and that required buffer amount is determined using the calculation approach in Rule 3.18.4. [#SRC:97faadb3-289b-44a9-9f5c-3ea5c35e39cf] Taken together, the rules mean the Authorised Person cannot treat the buffer as a one-off computation; it must be held continuously in CET1 Capital while being calculated using the specified rule-based methods. question: When an Issuer proposes to offer Securities for subscription or sale under an Approved Prospectus, how does the requirement that the Prospectus be a current Prospectus interact with the Regulator’s prescribed categories of Exempt Securities (for example, a rights issue where a document is made available describing the number and nature of the Securities and the reasons for and details of the Offer)?
expected_answer: An offer for subscription or sale of Securities under an Approved Prospectus is not permitted unless the Prospectus is a current Prospectus, except where an exemption under Rule 4.3.1 or 4.4.1 applies. [#SRC:b98b8be4-d9f5-4369-b2d0-00885f78cf38] Separately, the Regulator has prescribed specific types of Securities as Exempt Securities for the purposes of section 61(3)(b) of the FSMR, including Securities offered, allotted or to be allotted in connection with a rights issue where (i) the Securities are of the same class as Securities already admitted to trading on the same Recognised Investment Exchange and (ii) a document is made available with information on the number and nature of the Securities and the reasons for and details of the Offer. [#TGT:16a48ee7-becd-40f8-8af0-17dbcd09dfc0] In practical compliance terms, you must first determine whether the contemplated Securities fall within one of the Regulator’s Exempt Securities categories (such as the rights issue category with its same-class and document-availability conditions). [#TGT:16a48ee7-becd-40f8-8af0-17dbcd09dfc0] If the offer is proceeding “under an Approved Prospectus,” the baseline rule remains that the Prospectus must be current unless the relevant exemption under Rule 4.3.1 or 4.4.1 is available and applies to the transaction. [#SRC:b98b8be4-d9f5-4369-b2d0-00885f78cf38] Accordingly, the Exempt Securities analysis and the “current Prospectus” condition must be assessed together to confirm whether the offer can proceed as structured. [#SRC:b98b8be4-d9f5-4369-b2d0-00885f78cf38] [#TGT:16a48ee7-becd-40f8-8af0-17dbcd09dfc0]

or (9) Securities already admitted to trading on another Recognised Investment Exchange or Regulated Exchange (the "Other Market"), where: (a) the Securities, or Securities of the same class, have been admitted to trading and continuously traded on the Other Market for more than 18 months; (b) the on-going obligations for trading on that Other Market have been complied with; and (c) the Person requesting the admission to trading of the Securities under this exemption makes a summary document in the English language which is approved by the Regulator in accordance with the requirements in section 4.6 and published: (i) containing the information set out in Rule 4.5.2(1)(b); (ii) stating where the most recent and current Prospectus, if any, can be obtained; and (iii) specifying where the financial information disclosed by the Issuer pursuant to its on-going disclosure obligations of the Other Market is available. (10) Securities offered in connection with any issue of Securities under Rules 9.7.1 or 9.7.4, where the Securities are of the same class already admitted to trading on the same Recognised Investment Exchange.

question: For the purposes of Rule 2.5.5, what must a Recognised Body have in place, and what standard of effort must it apply, to ensure its commercial interests (including profitability) do not adversely affect the performance of its Regulatory Functions?
expected_answer: A Recognised Body must both implement an internal control framework and actively apply a reasonableness standard to prevent its commercial interests from harming the performance of its Regulatory Functions. [#SRC:0a71e314-db1c-4038-aea2-9ce748ddbfd8] Specifically, for the purposes of Rule 2.5.5, it must maintain adequate systems and controls, including documented policies and procedures, designed so that pursuing commercial interests (expressly including profitability) does not negatively impact how it carries out its Regulatory Functions. [#SRC:0a71e314-db1c-4038-aea2-9ce748ddbfd8] In addition to having those arrangements, it must take all reasonable steps to ensure that the performance of its Regulatory Functions is not adversely affected by its commercial interests, which sets an ongoing conduct expectation rather than a one-time design requirement. [#TGT:74bba2cd-f78a-4308-96b7-5431d4be50d5] Read together, the obligation is not satisfied merely by having policies on paper; the Recognised Body must also act reasonably in practice to keep commercial drivers from impairing regulatory performance. [#SRC:0a71e314-db1c-4038-aea2-9ce748ddbfd8][#TGT:74bba2cd-f78a-4308-96b7-5431d4be50d5]

question: In a Takeover or Merger where a Listed Entity seeks the Regulator’s prior written consent to release a holding lock on Restricted Securities, what written agreements and acceptance thresholds must be in place (including where the transaction is an offer versus a scheme), and how does this interact with the requirement to obtain and submit a holding-lock undertaking within two Business Days after issue?
expected_answer: To obtain the Regulator’s prior written consent to release a holding lock on Restricted Securities, the Listed Entity must align the release request with both the post-issue holding-lock undertaking framework and the specific consent preconditions for a Takeover or Merger. The holding lock is expected to be put in place through an undertaking obtained from an appropriate intermediary (for example, a bank, trustee, custodian, Recognised Body, CSD, or another entity the Regulator considers suitable) and submitted to the Regulator within two Business Days after the Restricted Securities are issued; that undertaking must also commit not to release the lock without the Regulator’s prior written consent. [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76] For consent in a Takeover or Merger, the Regulator will not consent unless the applicable transaction-structure conditions are met. If there is an offer, it must cover all Ordinary Securities (or, if the Restricted Securities are not Ordinary Securities, all Securities in the same class), and holders of at least half of the non-Restricted Securities to which the offer relates must have accepted. [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd] If the offer is conditional, the offeror and the Security Holder must agree in writing that the holding lock is immediately re-imposed for any Securities not acquired under the offer. [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd] If conducted by scheme, the Security Holders and the Listed Entity must agree in writing to immediate re-imposition if the Takeover does not take effect. [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd]

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses forecast financial information that is derived from a Production Target in relation to either its Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or its material Mining Project(s), what specific content must be included about (i) the assumptions used and (ii) the Production Target itself?
expected_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity that discloses forecast financial information derived from a Production Target—whether the disclosure is made in relation to its Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or its material Mining Project(s)—must include both assumption-related content and Production Target-related content in the disclosure. [#TGT:3b6fe7a5-ba91-4bcf-b1f3-f46b7164fe1d] For the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information, the disclosure must cover all material economic assumptions employed and also include all other material assumptions utilised. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] If the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, it must state that they are commercially sensitive and explain the methodology used to determine those material economic assumptions. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] In addition, because the forecast financial information is derived from a Production Target, the disclosure must include the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, and it must include all the information that is required to be contained in that Production Target under Rule 11.8.3. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] This combined content expectation applies regardless of whether the Production Target-based forecast is presented against holdings or against material project(s). [#TGT:3b6fe7a5-ba91-4bcf-b1f3-f46b7164fe1d]

(c) all other material assumptions utilised. (2) the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).

expected_answer: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses forecast financial information that comes from a Production Target, it can be presented in relation to either the entity’s Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or its material Mining Project(s), but the disclosure still has to include specific items about assumptions and the Production Target. [#TGT:3b6fe7a5-ba91-4bcf-b1f3-f46b7164fe1d] On assumptions, the disclosure must include all material economic assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information, plus any other material assumptions used. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] If the Mining Reporting Entity thinks the material economic assumptions are commercially sensitive, it must say they are commercially sensitive and describe the methodology it used to determine those material economic assumptions. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] On the Production Target, the disclosure must identify the Production Target that the forecast financial information is based on, and it must include all the information that Rule 11.8.3 requires to be included with that Production Target. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] These content requirements apply whichever of the two contexts (holdings or material project(s)) the entity uses for the Production Target-based forecast disclosure. question: For documents that must be submitted in final form to the Regulator before 9:00am on the day the Regulator is to consider an application, who must sign the documents required by Rule 2.4.5, and which specific documents are required (including when a pricing statement is required)?
expected_answer: On the day the Regulator is to consider the application, the Applicant must both (i) submit specified documents to the Regulator by 9:00am in final form and (ii) ensure that the documents required by Rule 2.4.5 are properly signed by the correct signatory. [#TGT:dc66c345-5fd8-4956-8ee4-f839e841bd7c] [#SRC:0dd551f7-727e-4872-9782-b54e37104017] The submission obligation applies to documents that must be provided on the day, and it sets a firm deadline: before 9:00am on the day the Regulator will consider the application. [#TGT:dc66c345-5fd8-4956-8ee4-f839e841bd7c] The documents that must be submitted in final form are: (1) a completed Shareholder statement; and (2) a completed pricing statement where the application involves a placing, open Offer or Offer for subscription. [#TGT:dc66c345-5fd8-4956-8ee4-f839e841bd7c] Separately, the Applicant must ensure that the documents required by Rule 2.4.5 are signed either by its Sponsor (if a Sponsor has been appointed) or by a duly authorised officer of the Applicant. [#SRC:0dd551f7-727e-4872-9782-b54e37104017] Accordingly, for the day-of submission package, the Applicant should confirm both timely delivery to the Regulator and that the relevant Rule 2.4.5 documents bear the required signature authority. question: When an Authorised Person has Counterparty Risk Exposures arising from an SFT that are included in the Trading Book, under what conditions may it treat those Exposures as collateralised, and what scope of eligible financial Collateral may it recognise for those Exposures?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person may treat Exposures as collateralised only if it satisfies the conditions set out in Rules 4.13.5 to 4.13.8 (which are identified as relating to CRM). [#SRC:558596ee-af40-4c07-8067-9c5c25eebaa5] Where the Exposures are Counterparty Risk Exposures described in Rules 4.13.5 and 4.13.6 and they arise from an SFT that is included in the Trading Book, the scope of eligible financial Collateral is broad: it includes all instruments that the Authorised Person may include in its Trading Book. [#TGT:cacd95d6-558b-4d84-93f1-e1d5664a1d01] In practical terms, the Trading Book inclusion and SFT origin determine the collateral eligibility set, but the ability to treat the Exposure as collateralised still depends on meeting the CRM conditions across Rules 4.13.5 through 4.13.8. [#SRC:558596ee-af40-4c07-8067-9c5c25eebaa5] [#TGT:cacd95d6-558b-4d84-93f1-e1d5664a1d01] This means the Authorised Person must first confirm the Exposure falls within the relevant Counterparty Risk Exposures in Rules 4.13.5 and 4.13.6 and is from an SFT in the Trading Book, and then apply the CRM conditions to determine whether it can recognise collateralisation for that Exposure. [#TGT:cacd95d6-558b-4d84-93f1-e1d5664a1d01] [#SRC:558596ee-af40-4c07-8067-9c5c25eebaa5]

question: When calculating and paying an initial annual fee that is payable on an annual basis, how must the proration for the remainder of the calendar year be determined, and by when must the prorated amount be paid in full to the Regulator?
expected_answer: For an initial annual fee payable on an annual basis, the amount due must be prorated by reference to the portion of the year remaining, and the resulting prorated fee must then be paid in full to the Regulator within the specified payment window. [#TGT:b8f50488-8fd2-4f32-a6c6-d841b3c60c37] The proration methodology is that the portion due is calculated based on the number of months remaining until the end of the calendar year, so the remaining-month count drives the reduced amount for the rest of that year. [#SRC:94b3f85d-c033-41a3-a884-c873899c049f] Once the fee becomes due, the initial annual fee (as prorated for the remainder of the calendar year using that remaining-month approach) must be paid in full to the Regulator within twenty days of the due date. [#TGT:b8f50488-8fd2-4f32-a6c6-d841b3c60c37] In practical terms, compliance requires (i) identifying how many months are left to the calendar year-end to compute the portion due, and (ii) ensuring the full prorated amount reaches the Regulator no later than the twentieth day after the fee becomes due. [#SRC:94b3f85d-c033-41a3-a884-c873899c049f] [#TGT:b8f50488-8fd2-4f32-a6c6-d841b3c60c37]

question: When the Regulator is considering whether to refuse to recognise a Foreign Resolution Action (in whole or in part) while also proposing to take Resolution Action in relation to an ADGM Branch pursuant to section 78(5), how do the preconditions for taking Resolution Action in respect of an ADGM Branch interact with the refusal ground that the Resolution Conditions have not been met?
expected_answer: If the Regulator proposes to take Resolution Action in relation to an ADGM Branch pursuant to section 78(5), it may refuse to recognise a Foreign Resolution Action (in whole or in part) where it is satisfied that the Resolution Conditions have not been met for the relevant entity. [#TGT:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba] For an ADGM Branch, those Resolution Conditions include that the Regulator is satisfied the branch is failing or likely to fail, that (considering timing and other relevant circumstances) it is not reasonably likely that other action by or in respect of the ADGM Branch or the Non-ADGM Institution will prevent that failure or likely failure, and that applying a Resolution Tool is in the public interest. [#SRC:f586c998-e0a5-470f-a8d5-ae1669514726] In addition, the Regulator must be satisfied about the Non-ADGM Institution’s status regarding Foreign Resolution Action or Non-ADGM Insolvency Proceedings—either it is not subject (and not likely within a reasonable timeframe to become subject) to such measures, or it is subject to Foreign Resolution Action and a specified circumstance applies. [#SRC:f586c998-e0a5-470f-a8d5-ae1669514726] Accordingly, if any of these ADGM-Branch-specific conditions are not met, that shortfall can support refusal of recognition under the ground tied to unmet Resolution Conditions in the section 78(5) context. [#TGT:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba]

debug_context.target_text: The Regulator may refuse to recognise a Foreign Resolution Action in whole or in part if it is satisfied that one or more of the following conditions are met— (a) recognition would have an adverse effect on financial stability in the ADGM; (b) the Resolution Conditions have not been met in relation to the entity listed in section 2 with respect to which the Regulator proposes to take Resolution Action pursuant to section 78(5); (c) the taking of Resolution Action by the Regulator in relation to an ADGM Branch pursuant to section 78(5) is not necessary to achieve one or more of the Resolution Objectives; (d) under the Foreign Resolution Action, creditors located or payable in the ADGM would not, by reason of being located in the ADGM, receive the same treatment, and have similar legal rights, as creditors (including depositors) who are located or payable in the non-ADGM jurisdiction concerned; or (e) recognition of, and taking action in support of, the Foreign Resolution Action (or the relevant part) would have material fiscal implications for the UAE or the ADGM.

question: In a case involving an ADGM Branch where the Non-ADGM Institution is subject to a Foreign Resolution Action, what combination of (i) the conditions that must be satisfied before a Resolution Action may be taken in respect of the ADGM Branch and (ii) the Regulator’s discretion to refuse recognition based on unequal treatment of ADGM creditors, determines whether the Regulator can both proceed with ADGM Branch Resolution Action and decline recognition of the foreign action?
expected_answer: Where the Non-ADGM Institution is subject to a Foreign Resolution Action, a Resolution Action may still be taken in respect of an ADGM Branch only if the Regulator is satisfied that the branch is failing or likely to fail, that (given timing and other relevant circumstances) it is not reasonably likely that other action will prevent the failure or likely failure, and that use of a Resolution Tool is in the public interest. [#SRC:f586c998-e0a5-470f-a8d5-ae1669514726] In that same scenario, the Regulator must also be satisfied that, although the Non-ADGM Institution is subject to Foreign Resolution Action, one of the specified circumstances applies in respect of the Non-ADGM Institution. [#SRC:f586c998-e0a5-470f-a8d5-ae1669514726] Separately, even if the Regulator is considering recognition of the Foreign Resolution Action, it may refuse to recognise it (in whole or in part) if it is satisfied that, under the foreign action, creditors located or payable in the ADGM would not receive the same treatment and similar legal rights as creditors (including depositors) located or payable in the relevant non-ADGM jurisdiction, where the difference arises because the creditors are located in the ADGM. [#TGT:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba] Therefore, the Regulator can proceed with ADGM Branch Resolution Action only if the ADGM-Branch conditions are met, while it can simultaneously decline recognition if the foreign action would disadvantage ADGM creditors compared with non-ADGM creditors. [#SRC:f586c998-e0a5-470f-a8d5-ae1669514726] [#TGT:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba]

question: When an Authorised Person is a clearing member with Trade Exposure to a Non-QCCP (including acting as an intermediary between a client and the Non-QCCP), how should it determine the applicable calculation approach for exposure and the risk-weighting treatment, taking into account the SA-CCR requirement for derivatives and long settlement transactions and the corporate asset class CRW requirement for the Non-QCCP?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person that acts as a clearing member and has Trade Exposure to a Non-QCCP must (i) calculate the relevant exposure measure using the required counterparty credit risk approach for derivatives/long settlement transactions, and (ii) apply the specified corporate-asset-class risk weight for the Non-QCCP when determining Credit RWA. [#SRC:d16634fb-97c2-470f-9bd9-a92049293eba] Specifically, for Derivative transactions (whether OTC or exchange-traded) and for long settlement transactions, the exposure at default (EAD) must be calculated under the Standardised Approach to Counterparty Credit Risk (SA-CCR), unless the Authorised Person has permission from the Regulator to use an internal model instead. [#TGT:05fe705c-077c-46d7-8bf8-8ff6d49dfcff] In parallel, where the Authorised Person is acting as a clearing member either for its own purposes or as an intermediary between a client and a Non-QCCP, it must calculate Credit RWA for its Trade Exposure to that Non-QCCP in accordance with Rule A4.6.14 and apply an appropriate CRW based on the corporate asset class of the Non-QCCP as set out in Rule 4.12.13. [#SRC:d16634fb-97c2-470f-9bd9-a92049293eba] Accordingly, the EAD methodology (SA-CCR unless internal-model permission) informs the exposure component, while the corporate-asset-class CRW requirement governs the risk-weighting applied to that Non-QCCP exposure for Credit RWA purposes. [#TGT:05fe705c-077c-46d7-8bf8-8ff6d49dfcff] [#SRC:d16634fb-97c2-470f-9bd9-a92049293eba]

expected_answer: For a clearing member’s Trade Exposure to a Non-QCCP, the Authorised Person needs to combine the exposure-calculation rule for derivatives/long settlement transactions with the risk-weighting rule for the Non-QCCP. [#SRC:d16634fb-97c2-470f-9bd9-a92049293eba] For Derivative transactions (OTC and exchange-traded) and long settlement transactions, the exposure at default (EAD) must be calculated using the Standardised Approach to Counterparty Credit Risk (SA-CCR), unless the Regulator has granted the Authorised Person permission to use an internal model. [#TGT:05fe705c-077c-46d7-8bf8-8ff6d49dfcff] Once the exposure is being treated as a Trade Exposure to a Non-QCCP in the clearing-member context (including where the Authorised Person acts as an intermediary between a client and the Non-QCCP), the Authorised Person must calculate Credit RWA for that Trade Exposure in accordance with Rule A4.6.14. [#SRC:d16634fb-97c2-470f-9bd9-a92049293eba] It must also apply an appropriate CRW that corresponds to the corporate asset class of the Non-QCCP, as set out in Rule 4.12.13. [#SRC:d16634fb-97c2-470f-9bd9-a92049293eba] In short, SA-CCR (or an approved internal model) determines EAD, and the corporate-asset-class CRW determines the risk weight used in the Credit RWA calculation for the Non-QCCP exposure. [#TGT:05fe705c-077c-46d7-8bf8-8ff6d49dfcff] [#SRC:d16634fb-97c2-470f-9bd9-a92049293eba]

question: When an Authorised Person proposes to conduct a Regulated Activity in relation to a product it describes as a “Spot Commodity,” how should it frame its submission so the Regulator can determine whether the product is an Accepted Spot Commodity, including how the product’s defining features (e.g., prompt delivery and not being a Financial Instrument) connect to the Regulator’s assessment factors (e.g., sustainable sourcing standards and market fundamentals)?
expected_answer: The Authorised Person should present the product in a way that allows the Regulator to confirm it is a “Spot Commodity” and then assess whether it is an “Accepted Spot Commodity” for the intended Regulated Activity. [#TGT:2a87b251-49cc-4d23-b88b-e73df61b7338] First, the submission should explain how the product fits the FSRA’s characteristics of a Spot Commodity, including that it is a good sold for cash with prompt delivery on settlement, and that it is not a future-dated delivery contract beyond the market’s standard delivery period. [#SRC:34ccda9d-76c5-45f3-af56-56834f25f068] It should also clarify that the product is not a Financial Instrument involving conventional assets (such as Securities or Derivatives) and is not a service or other non-good/intangible item (such as currencies or rights in real estate). [#SRC:34ccda9d-76c5-45f3-af56-56834f25f068] Building on that classification, the Authorised Person should provide information relevant to the Regulator’s acceptance assessment, including its responsible and sustainable sourcing requirements and standards (including adherence to internationally recognised certification standards where applicable), and market fundamentals such as market practice, liquidity, participant base, transparency, and fair and orderly operation. [#TGT:2a87b251-49cc-4d23-b88b-e73df61b7338] Finally, it should address any other factors the Regulator may consider in deciding whether the Spot Commodity is appropriate for the Authorised Person’s proposed Regulated Activity. [#TGT:2a87b251-49cc-4d23-b88b-e73df61b7338]

expected_answer: To support the Regulator’s decision, the Authorised Person needs to cover both (1) why the item qualifies as a Spot Commodity and (2) why it should be treated as an Accepted Spot Commodity for the intended Regulated Activity. [#TGT:2a87b251-49cc-4d23-b88b-e73df61b7338] It should also be prepared to address any other factors the Regulator considers relevant to whether the Spot Commodity is appropriate for that activity. question: When the Regulator is considering whether to impose a supplementary fee on a Person, how do the circumstances of a particularly complex or novel waiver/modification request interact with the broader cost/effort-based triggers tied to handling an application, authorisation, filing, or on-going supervision?
expected_answer: The Regulator may require a Person to pay a supplementary fee where the matter it is dealing with is expected to drive substantial additional cost or effort, and a particularly complex or novel waiver or modification request is an example of a circumstance that can support that outcome. [#TGT:64a0df5a-e946-4496-9fd3-244340c2a080] In particular, if the Regulator forms the view that a request for a waiver or modification is especially complex or novel, it has discretion to require the Person to pay a supplementary fee for that request. [#SRC:ef45697b-2b10-450b-bacc-b9d501e87404] This waiver/modification-specific trigger should be understood within the broader set of situations where the Regulator anticipates substantial additional costs or substantial additional effort in dealing with regulatory matters, including an application, authorisation, filing, or the conduct of on-going supervision. [#TGT:64a0df5a-e946-4496-9fd3-244340c2a080] Accordingly, in practice the Regulator’s decision can be framed as: (i) identifying the type of matter it is handling (including a waiver/modification request), and (ii) determining whether the circumstances—such as complexity or novelty—mean it expects to incur substantial additional costs or expend substantial additional effort, in which case it may require the supplementary fee to be paid to the Regulator. [#SRC:ef45697b-2b10-450b-bacc-b9d501e87404] [#TGT:64a0df5a-e946-4496-9fd3-244340c2a080]

expected_answer: The Regulator can require a Person to pay a supplementary fee when it expects the work will involve substantial extra cost or substantial extra effort, and a waiver or modification request that is particularly complex or novel is a specific situation where it may do so. [#SRC:ef45697b-2b10-450b-bacc-b9d501e87404] Beyond waiver/modification requests, the same supplementary-fee approach can apply when the Regulator is dealing with an application, an authorisation, a filing, or when it is conducting on-going supervision, provided it expects substantial additional costs or effort in those circumstances. question: Where a Framework Contract permits the Payment Service Provider to implement proposed changes unilaterally unless the Payment Service User objects before the changes take effect, what combined pre-notification content and timing must the Payment Service Provider meet when communicating those proposed changes (including any deemed-acceptance and termination-right messaging)?
expected_answer: In this scenario, the Payment Service Provider must both (i) deliver the proposed changes within the required advance timeframe and (ii) include specific information to ensure the Payment Service User understands the consequences of not objecting and the available exit right. The proposed changes to the existing terms of the Framework Contract (and any changes to the information specified in Rule 19.2.1) must be provided to the Payment Service User no later than two months before the date the changes are intended to take effect (subject to Rule 19.2.7). [#TGT:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5] In addition, where the Framework Contract allows unilateral implementation unless the Payment Service User notifies the Payment Service Provider to the contrary before the proposed entry-into-force date, the Payment Service Provider must inform the Payment Service User that the user will be treated as having accepted the changes communicated under Rule 19.2.4 if the user does not object in time. [#SRC:3f0b9767-ce03-4986-bf5f-630548e2a5e1] The Payment Service Provider must also inform the Payment Service User that the user may terminate the Framework Contract without charge at any time before the proposed date the changes enter into force. [#SRC:3f0b9767-ce03-4986-bf5f-630548e2a5e1] Together, these requirements mean the two-month notice must be paired with clear deemed-acceptance and no-fee pre-effective-date termination messaging for unilateral-change mechanisms. [#TGT:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5] [#SRC:3f0b9767-ce03-4986-bf5f-630548e2a5e1]

question: If the Framework Contract says the Payment Service Provider can change things unless the Payment Service User objects before the change starts, what does the Payment Service Provider have to tell the user, and how early must the proposed changes be sent?
expected_answer: The Payment Service Provider must do two things: send the proposed changes early enough, and include specific explanations about what happens if the Payment Service User stays silent and what the user can do before the change date. For timing, proposed changes to the existing terms of the Framework Contract (or to the information specified in Rule 19.2.1) must be provided to the Payment Service User at least two months before the date the changes are meant to take effect (subject to Rule 19.2.7). [#TGT:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5] For content, when the Framework Contract allows unilateral changes unless the Payment Service User notifies the Payment Service Provider to the contrary before the proposed entry-into-force date, the Payment Service Provider must tell the Payment Service User that the user will be treated as having accepted the changes that were communicated under Rule 19.2.4. [#SRC:3f0b9767-ce03-4986-bf5f-630548e2a5e1] The Payment Service Provider must also tell the Payment Service User that the user can end the Framework Contract without paying a charge at any time before the proposed date the changes start. [#SRC:3f0b9767-ce03-4986-bf5f-630548e2a5e1] In practice, the two-month advance delivery and these two messages must be combined for this type of “silence means acceptance” change process. [#TGT:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5] [#SRC:3f0b9767-ce03-4986-bf5f-630548e2a5e1]

question: Where the Regulator issues a written notice directing an Authorised Person to submit returns in a different form, manner, or frequency than the Electronic Prudential Reporting System (EPRS) requirements (including the frequency of submission detailed in EPRS), what submission method and ongoing compliance approach must the Authorised Person follow, and when may it revert to the Rule 2.3.2 approach?
expected_answer: If the Regulator issues a written notice directing an Authorised Person to submit returns in a different form, manner, or frequency than the baseline prescribed approach, the Authorised Person must follow that direction rather than the default EPRS-based parameters. [#TGT:ceb0fc5a-9013-4a01-bf0c-a672333fcb3b] Under the baseline rule, the Authorised Person is required to prepare returns in line with the Rules in the Chapter, relevant instructional guidelines in PRU and elsewhere, and the requirements of the Regulator’s Electronic Prudential Reporting System (EPRS), including the submission frequency specified in EPRS, and to submit those returns to the Regulator using EPRS. [#SRC:d384c02a-97aa-458d-9961-3b9b406ec6f9] However, the written notice mechanism allows the Regulator to override the prescribed form, manner, or frequency that would otherwise apply under Rule 2.3.2 (including what EPRS would otherwise require). question: Where Confidential Information is held by the Regulator (or its employees or agents) and is also in the hands of a primary recipient (or someone who obtained it from that primary recipient), whose prior consent is required before any disclosure can be made, and how do the two texts differ in describing the second consenting person when that person is not the original source?
expected_answer: Disclosure is prohibited unless prior consent is obtained from two categories of persons, and this applies both to the Regulator-side holders and to primary-recipient-side holders. [#SRC:fbbdae87-6f42-49d9-81a9-e75a30466d8a] Specifically, the discloser must obtain consent from (a) the person from whom the Confidential Information was obtained (described in the primary-recipient context as the person from whom the primary recipient obtained the information). [#SRC:fbbdae87-6f42-49d9-81a9-e75a30466d8a] [#TGT:db8084a6-8fbb-4197-9e29-8bd14a43f866] In addition, if that person is different, a second consent is required; the SOURCE frames this as the person to whom the duty of confidentiality is owed, while the TARGET frames it as the person to whom the information relates. [#SRC:fbbdae87-6f42-49d9-81a9-e75a30466d8a] [#TGT:db8084a6-8fbb-4197-9e29-8bd14a43f866] The scope of who is restricted also differs in expression but is complementary: the SOURCE expressly covers the Regulator, its employees, agents, and any person who comes into possession of Confidential Information, whereas the TARGET expressly covers a primary recipient and any person obtaining the information directly or indirectly from a primary recipient. [#SRC:fbbdae87-6f42-49d9-81a9-e75a30466d8a] [#TGT:db8084a6-8fbb-4197-9e29-8bd14a43f866]

debug_context.source_text: With prior consent under section 198(1) of FSMR.
