question: When an Authorised Person is calculating CET1 Capital and must deduct defined benefit pension fund assets, in what circumstances may the amount of that deduction be reduced, and what additional treatment applies to any assets used to reduce the deduction?
expected_answer: In calculating CET1 Capital, an Authorised Person is required to deduct its defined benefit pension fund assets from CET1 Capital, but the amount of that specific deduction may be reduced in limited, specified cases. [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd] For the defined benefit pension fund asset deduction, the Authorised Person may reduce the deduction by (i) any associated deferred tax liability that could be eliminated if the pension assets were impaired or derecognised under the International Financial Reporting Standards, and (ii) the amount of pension fund assets that the Authorised Person has an unrestricted ability to use, provided it has given adequate advance notification to the Regulator of its intention to use those assets. [#SRC:b0259e6e-b58e-4055-96ec-75e630bdaada] Any pension fund assets used to reduce the amount deducted are not ignored for prudential purposes; instead, those assets must be assigned a risk weight in accordance with Chapter 4 of these Rules. [#SRC:b0259e6e-b58e-4055-96ec-75e630bdaada] This reduction mechanism operates within the broader CET1 deduction framework that includes, among other items, goodwill and other intangible assets and certain deferred tax assets, but the reduction described here is specific to the defined benefit pension fund asset deduction. [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd]

debug_context.source_text: CET1 Deductions - defined benefit pension fund assets. For the purposes of Rule 3.10.7(d), the amount of defined benefit pension fund assets to be deducted from CET1 Capital must be reduced by the following: (a) the amount of any associated deferred tax liability which could be extinguished if the assets became impaired or were derecognised under the International Financial Reporting Standards; and (b) the amount of assets in the defined benefit pension fund which the Authorised Person has an unrestricted ability to use where the Authorised Person has provided adequate advance notification of its intention to use those assets to the Regulator. Those assets used to reduce the amount to be deducted must receive a risk weight in accordance with Chapter 4 of these Rules.
debug_context.target_text: CET1 Deductions. Subject to the following Rules in this Section, an Authorised Person must deduct the following from the calculation of its CET1 Capital: (a) losses for the current financial year; (b) goodwill and other intangible assets as defined in the International Financial Reporting Standards; (c) deferred tax assets that rely on future profitability; (d) defined benefit pension fund assets of the Authorised Person; (e) the applicable amount, by reference to Rule 3.10.12, of direct and indirect holdings by an Authorised Person of its own CET1 Capital instruments including instruments under which an Authorised Person is under an actual or contingent obligation to effect a purchase by virtue of an existing contractual obligation; (f) holdings of the CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities where those entities have a reciprocal cross holding with the Authorised Person which have the effect of artificially inflating the Capital Resources of the Authorised Person; (g) the applicable amount, by reference to Rule 3.10.13, of direct and indirect holdings by the Authorised Person of CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities where the Authorised Person does not have a significant investment in those entities; (h) the applicable amount, by reference to Rules 3.10.13 and 3.10.18, of direct and indirect holdings by the Authorised Person of the CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities where the Authorised Person has a significant investment in those entities; (i) the amount of items required to be deducted from the calculation of AT1 Capital in accordance with the relevant Rules under Section 3.11, that exceeds the AT1 Capital of the Authorised Person; (j) the Exposure amount of the following items which qualify for a risk weight of 1000%, where the Authorised Person deducts that Exposure amount from CET1 Capital as an alternative to applying a risk weight of 1000%: (i) Qualifying Holdings; (ii) securitisation positions, in accordance with relevant Rules in Chapter 4; and (iii) free deliveries, in accordance with the Rules in Section A4.6; and (k) for an Authorised Person which is a Partnership, the amount by which the aggregate of the amounts withdrawn by its Partners or members exceeds the profits of that firm.

question: Where an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business intends to use a Client’s Safe Custody Assets for its own purpose or that of another Person, what specific permissions, controls, and record types must it have in place, and which of those records must be included in the Resolution Pack (including any related reconciliations)?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person in this situation must both (i) operate the required systems and controls around the use of a Client’s Safe Custody Assets and (ii) ensure the relevant evidence is captured within its Resolution Pack. The systems and controls must ensure the Client’s prior written permission is obtained, adequate records are maintained to protect the Safe Custody Assets when used (including as collateral or for stock lending), equivalent assets are returned to the Client’s Client Account, and the Client is not disadvantaged by the use. [#TGT:82a79456-0923-48f0-8521-17b43774e939] In addition, the Resolution Pack must include records evidencing adequate records and the Client’s written permission regarding the use of Client Investments, which aligns with documenting the permission and recordkeeping elements required when using Safe Custody Assets. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] The Resolution Pack must also include the most recent reconciliations of Client Investments, supporting oversight of the Client’s holdings and the return of equivalent assets to the relevant Client Account. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] Together, these requirements mean the Authorised Person should be able to demonstrate both operational compliance (permission, protection, return, and no disadvantage) and that the key permission/record and reconciliation materials are packaged for resolution readiness. [#TGT:82a79456-0923-48f0-8521-17b43774e939] [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]

debug_context.source_text: The following records must be included in the Resolution Pack of an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business: (a) Rules ‎2.7.1 and ‎3.7.1(d) (records of Client classification and Client agreements); (b) Rules 14.6.2 and ‎15.4.3 (master lists of all Client Accounts in relation to Client Money and Client investments); (c) Rule ‎15.4.4 and Rule ‎15.4.5 (adequate records and Client's written permission re use of Client Investments); (d) Rules 14.7.1 and 14.7.4 (assessment of appropriateness of Third-Party Agent and acknowledgement by Third-Party agent in respect of Client Money); and (e) Rule ‎15.5.1 and 15.6.1 (assessment of appropriateness of Third Party Agent and acknowledgement by Third-Party Agent in respect of Client Investments); and (f) Rule 14.11.1 and ‎15.9.1 (most recent reconciliations of Client Money and Client Investments).

question: When the Regulator is considering disqualifying an auditor or actuary for a contravention, how should it determine both whether to disqualify and the scope of the disqualification (e.g., across any Authorised Person, Recognised Body or Reporting Entity or a particular class), and what case-specific factors must be weighed?
expected_answer: Where the Regulator considers an auditor or actuary has contravened these Regulations, it has discretion to disqualify that person from acting for any Authorised Person, Recognised Body or Reporting Entity, or for a particular class of them; the scope decision is therefore part of the same assessment as whether to disqualify at all. [#TGT:5cca9150-8e16-41b4-a5ef-74950916d06e] In deciding whether to exercise the disqualification power and what the scope of any disqualification will be, the Regulator must evaluate all the circumstances of the case, rather than relying on a single trigger. [#SRC:89e542d2-0dfe-4eb9-8b8b-5f006c089e22] The factors to be weighed include the nature and seriousness of the contravention and its effects, and whether the contravention (or any failure to disclose information to the Regulator) has resulted in or is likely to result in customer loss, reputational damage to the ADGM, or increased financial-crime risk involving a firm, Recognised Body, or Reporting Entity. [#SRC:89e542d2-0dfe-4eb9-8b8b-5f006c089e22] The Regulator should also consider remedial actions taken by the auditor or actuary, any professional-body disciplinary action (and whether it adequately addresses the contravention), and the auditor’s or actuary’s prior compliance record including relevant prior sanctions. [#SRC:89e542d2-0dfe-4eb9-8b8b-5f006c089e22]

debug_context.source_text: In deciding whether to exercise our power to disqualify an auditor or actuary under section 233(3) of FSMR, and what the scope of any disqualification will be, we will take into account all the circumstances of the case, including: (a) the nature and seriousness of any contravention of FSMR or Rules and the effect of that contravention; (b) whether any contravention of FSMR or Rules, or any failure to disclose information to us, has resulted in or is likely to result in: (i) loss to customers; (ii) damage to the reputation of the ADGM; or (iii) an increased risk that a firm, Recognised Body or Reporting Entity may be used for the purposes of financial crime; (c) any action taken by the auditor or actuary to remedy the contravention; (d) any disciplinary action taken (or to be taken) against the auditor or actuary by a relevant professional body, and whether that action adequately addresses the particular contravention; and (e) the previous compliance record of the auditor or actuary concerned, and whether the relevant regulatory body or professional body has imposed any previous disciplinary sanctions that may be relevant.
debug_context.target_text: If the Regulator considers that an auditor or actuary has committed a contravention of these Regulations, it may disqualify the auditor or actuary from being the auditor of, or (as the case may be), from acting as an actuary for, any Authorised Person, Recognised Body or Reporting Entity or any particular class thereof.

question: Where an application concerns activities relating to Spot Commodities that will be carried on by a Recognised Body (whether a Recognised Investment Exchange or Recognised Clearing House), how should the applicant determine the applicable application fee when the applicant is also an Applicant for a Financial Services Permission to carry on the Regulated Activity of Dealing in Investments as Principal (but not as a Matched Principal)?
expected_answer: If the application is framed as one concerning activities relating to Spot Commodities to be carried on by a Recognised Body (either a Recognised Investment Exchange or a Recognised Clearing House), the fee basis is the one identified as applying under Section 4.1 for that type of application. question: Where a Relevant Person is maintaining the record categories listed for CDD/due diligence, transaction reconstruction, suspicious activity notifications/reports, FIU communications, and other required matters for the stated retention period, may those records be kept electronically, and what accessibility standard applies when the Regulator requests information?
expected_answer: A Relevant Person may keep the records it is required to maintain—including CDD/due diligence materials, transaction and account records, suspicious activity notifications and reports, FIU communications, and other expressly required matters—in electronic format, but only if the electronic records are readily accessible and can be produced promptly when the Regulator asks for information. [#SRC:54721870-44ed-4aad-a842-fe0cd9ded618] The scope of what must be maintained (where relevant) includes: copies of documents and information obtained for initial and ongoing CDD or due diligence on business partners; original documents or certified copies for the customer business relationship (including business correspondence, transaction records sufficient to reconstruct individual transactions, and internal findings/analysis for unusual or suspicious activity whether or not a Suspicious Activity/Transaction Report is filed); internal notifications to its MLRO; Suspicious Activity/Transaction Reports with supporting materials; communications with the FIU; the documents in Rule 4.6.1; and any other matter expressly required to be recorded under the Rules. [#TGT:2bb23374-a3ae-4dd1-af3e-7222ecda1e98] Those records must be kept for at least six years, measured from the latest of: the date a notification or report was made, the end of the business relationship, or completion of the Transaction. [#TGT:2bb23374-a3ae-4dd1-af3e-7222ecda1e98] The electronic-format permission does not remove the obligation to ensure rapid responsiveness to Regulator information requests. [#SRC:54721870-44ed-4aad-a842-fe0cd9ded618]

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity makes a subsequent disclosure that refers back to previously disclosed Exploration Results or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, what must it include to rely on the “first time only” application of Rule 11.12.1, and how does that interact with the Competent Person statement elements required in a disclosure containing those items?
expected_answer: To rely on Rule 11.12.1 applying only to the first disclosure, the Mining Reporting Entity’s later disclosure must (i) point readers to the earlier disclosure that complied with Rule 11.12.1 and (ii) include a confirmation that the entity is not aware of any new information or data that materially affects what was included previously; for Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves estimates, it must also confirm that the material assumptions and technical parameters underpinning those estimates still apply and have not materially changed. [#SRC:9819bc20-c088-4225-b398-fd241c8b322d] In addition, where the later disclosure itself contains Exploration Results or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves (or Exploration Targets), it must include a Competent Person statement that the disclosure is based on and fairly represents information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s). [#TGT:1133d38f-067b-4a0a-b325-b5c7b2512203] That statement must also specify, for each Competent Person, whether they are an employee of the Mining Reporting Entity or a Related Party, and if not, identify the Competent Person’s employer. [#TGT:1133d38f-067b-4a0a-b325-b5c7b2512203] Finally, it must name the professional organisation of which each Competent Person is a member. [#TGT:1133d38f-067b-4a0a-b325-b5c7b2512203] Together, the cross-reference/confirmation conditions support the “first time only” treatment, while the Competent Person statement elements govern what must be stated in any disclosure that contains the relevant technical content. [#SRC:9819bc20-c088-4225-b398-fd241c8b322d] [#TGT:1133d38f-067b-4a0a-b325-b5c7b2512203]

question: When the Fund Manager of a Passported Fund (or the governing body or trustee) notifies the Regulator of a material event—such as an amended Prospectus or the commencement of winding-up—what subsequent notification must the Regulator make, and what timing standard applies to that onward notification, given the Regulator’s duty upon receiving a notification described in Rule 6.6.2?
expected_answer: Where the Fund Manager of a Passported Fund (or the governing body or trustee) gives the Regulator a notification of a material event of the kind specified (including, for example, an amended or replaced Prospectus or the commencement of winding-up), the Regulator is then required to pass that change on to the relevant Host Regulator. [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898] The timing standard for the Regulator’s onward step is that, upon receiving a notification described in Rule 6.6.2, it must notify the relevant Host Regulator “without undue delay.” [#SRC:f1c064bd-93c8-459f-b7fa-fd9ed79b4669] In practice, this creates a two-stage notification chain: - First, the Fund Manager (or the governing body or trustee) must notify the Regulator as soon as practicable of material events, and for the listed events must do so as soon as practicable and no later than seven days after becoming aware. [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898] - Second, once the Regulator receives such a notification (as described in Rule 6.6.2), it must notify the relevant Host Regulator without undue delay of the changes. [#SRC:f1c064bd-93c8-459f-b7fa-fd9ed79b4669] Accordingly, the Fund Manager’s “as soon as practicable” (and, for specified events, seven-day) deadline governs the initial report to the Regulator, while the Regulator’s obligation is an immediate onward notification standard framed as “without undue delay.” [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898] [#SRC:f1c064bd-93c8-459f-b7fa-fd9ed79b4669]

debug_context.source_text: Upon receiving such a notification as described in Rule 6.6.2, the Regulator shall without undue delay notify the relevant Host Regulator of such changes.
debug_context.target_text: The Fund Manager of a Passported Fund must notify the Regulator as soon as practicable of any material events, in accordance with applicable ADGM legislation. In particular (but without limitation), a Fund Manager or the governing body or trustee of a Passported Fund must notify the Regulator as soon as practicable (and in any case no later than seven days after it becomes aware) of any of the following events: (a) the Fund Manager intends to retire as manager of the Passported Fund; (b) it is proposed that a successor manager will be appointed in relation to the Passported Fund; (c) the Fund Manager has been removed or replaced as manager of the Passported Fund; (d) any material service provider to the Passported Fund (including, without limitation, any custodian) or an Agent or Licensed Person resigns, is appointed, is removed, or is replaced; (e) the Prospectus relating to the Passported Fund has been amended or replaced; (f) winding-up of the Passported Fund has commenced; or (g) the Fund Manager intends to vary or revoke its Financial Service Permission (or any conditions contained in that Financial Service Permission).

question: If a Passported Fund’s Fund Manager becomes aware that a custodian or other material service provider has resigned (or been appointed/removed/replaced) and tells the Regulator within the required timeframe, what does the Regulator have to do next, and how quickly must it do it?
expected_answer: If a material service provider to a Passported Fund (including a custodian) resigns, is appointed, is removed, or is replaced, the Fund Manager (or the governing body or trustee) must notify the Regulator as soon as practicable and, for this listed type of event, no later than seven days after it becomes aware. [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898] Once the Regulator receives a notification of the kind described in Rule 6.6.2, the Regulator must then notify the relevant Host Regulator of the changes, and it must do so without undue delay. [#SRC:f1c064bd-93c8-459f-b7fa-fd9ed79b4669] This means the compliance sequence is: - Identify whether the service-provider change is within the specified events (it is, where the service provider is material, including a custodian). [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898] - Ensure the Regulator is notified as soon as practicable and within seven days of awareness for that specified event. [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898] - Expect the Regulator, after receiving the relevant notification, to inform the Host Regulator without undue delay. [#SRC:f1c064bd-93c8-459f-b7fa-fd9ed79b4669] So the Fund Manager’s deadline is tied to practicability and a seven-day backstop for the listed events, while the Regulator’s onward notification is governed by the “without undue delay” standard. [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898] [#SRC:f1c064bd-93c8-459f-b7fa-fd9ed79b4669]

question: When a Third Party Provider is required to make dispute resolution service details available to the Customer in a clear, comprehensive and easily accessible form, through which specific channels must that information be made available, given the Rule 20.13.3 availability locations?
expected_answer: A Third Party Provider must provide the Customer with details of the dispute resolution services that can handle disputes about rights and obligations arising under this Chapter, and it must do so in a manner that is clear, comprehensive, and easily accessible. [#TGT:08650621-06b8-481f-8650-2c5ebdb06be0] To meet the required accessibility standard using the specified availability locations, the information must be made available through all of the following channels: on the Third Party Provider’s website, at the Third Party Provider’s main office and any branches, and within the general terms and conditions of the Governing Contract. [#SRC:055fc91a-22c6-4511-9508-b90212a4d414] In practice, this means the Third Party Provider should ensure the same dispute resolution service details are presented to the Customer across each of these locations so the Customer can readily find and use them. [#TGT:08650621-06b8-481f-8650-2c5ebdb06be0] [#SRC:055fc91a-22c6-4511-9508-b90212a4d414] The obligation is framed as a “must” requirement on the Third Party Provider, and it is specifically tied to disputes concerning rights and obligations arising under this Chapter, rather than unrelated complaints. [#TGT:08650621-06b8-481f-8650-2c5ebdb06be0]

question: For an SFT in which both the Exposure and the Collateral are Securities issued by central governments, when may an Authorised Person set HE, HC and HS to zero, and how does the required risk-weighting for a CR Exposure in the central government and central bank asset class (including the Credit Quality Grade 1 outcome) support that determination?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person may set HE, HC and HS to zero for an SFT only where (i) both the Exposure and the Collateral are Securities issued by central governments, (ii) the banking regulator in the relevant jurisdiction has prescribed a value of zero for that treatment, and (iii) Exposures to that jurisdiction’s central government have a Credit Quality Grade of 1 under the referenced table. [#SRC:ed63c9d6-51da-4984-9431-9a2ca8dc0d03] The Credit Quality Grade condition is reinforced by the central government and central bank asset class risk-weight table, which assigns a 0% risk weight to Credit Quality Grade 1 exposures (and higher risk weights to lower grades and unrated exposures). [#TGT:f3576eb9-2d51-4fbe-bf30-26823907def6] Practically, the Authorised Person should confirm that the exposure being considered is to the relevant central government and that it qualifies as Credit Quality Grade 1, because the zero-HE/HC/HS option is explicitly tied to that grade rather than to other grades or unrated status. [#SRC:ed63c9d6-51da-4984-9431-9a2ca8dc0d03][#TGT:f3576eb9-2d51-4fbe-bf30-26823907def6] If the exposure is not Credit Quality Grade 1 (or is unrated), the risk-weight table indicates it would not receive the 0% outcome, and the SFT would not meet the stated condition for applying zero to HE, HC and HS. [#SRC:ed63c9d6-51da-4984-9431-9a2ca8dc0d03][#TGT:f3576eb9-2d51-4fbe-bf30-26823907def6]

question: If an Authorised Person has an SFT where both the Exposure and the Collateral are central government Securities, what exact conditions must be true to use zero for HE, HC and HS, and what does the central government/central bank risk-weight table say about Credit Quality Grade 1 that links to that choice?
expected_answer: Zero can be used for HE, HC and HS in this SFT scenario only when all of the following are met: the Exposure and the Collateral are both Securities issued by central governments; the banking regulator of that jurisdiction has prescribed a value of zero for that case; and Exposures to that jurisdiction’s central government are Credit Quality Grade 1 under the relevant table. [#SRC:ed63c9d6-51da-4984-9431-9a2ca8dc0d03] The link to Credit Quality Grade 1 is meaningful because the central government and central bank asset class table assigns a 0% risk weight to Credit Quality Grade 1 exposures, while other grades and unrated exposures receive higher risk weights (including 20%, 50%, 100%, 150%, or 100% for unrated). [#TGT:f3576eb9-2d51-4fbe-bf30-26823907def6] In other words, the SFT zero-HE/HC/HS option is not a general rule for all central government exposures; it is specifically tied to the jurisdictional “zero prescribed” condition and to the exposure being Credit Quality Grade 1, which aligns with the 0% risk-weight outcome shown in the table. question: Where a Payment Service Provider proposes to change a Framework Contract item that is required to be included in the contract (for example, the Payment Service Provider’s office address and contact details in ADGM), what must the Payment Service Provider provide to the Payment Service User and by when, and how does the “unless otherwise agreed in writing” carve-out for a Payment Service User which is not a Natural Person affect what information is in scope of that change process?
expected_answer: If a Payment Service Provider proposes to change either (i) the existing terms of the Framework Contract or (ii) any of the information that the Framework Contract is required to include, the Payment Service Provider must give the proposed changes to the Payment Service User at least two months before the date the changes are intended to start applying. [#SRC:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5] The information that can fall within this “information specified” category includes, for example, the Payment Service Provider’s name, its ADGM office address and contact details, and the name of its Regulator and Financial Service Permission details, because those items are listed as required inclusions in a Framework Contract. [#TGT:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b] The “unless otherwise agreed in writing” concept matters for scoping: where the Payment Service Provider and a Payment Service User which is not a Natural Person have agreed in writing to vary the otherwise-required contract information, the set of “information” that is required to be in the Framework Contract (and therefore the set of information whose changes would be captured as changes to required information) is determined by that written agreement. [#TGT:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b] Regardless of whether the change concerns a contract term or a required information item (as applicable), the two-month advance delivery obligation applies to the proposed change before it takes effect. [#SRC:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5]

(ii) the address and contact details of the Payment Service Provider’s office in ADGM; (iii) the name of the Regulator of the Payment Service Provider, and details of the Payment Service Provider’s Financial Service Permission; (b) about the Payment Service: (i) a description of the main characteristics of the Payment Service to be provided; (ii) the information or unique identifier that must be provided by the Payment Service User in order for a Payment Order to be properly initiated and executed; (v) the maximum execution time for the Payment Services to be provided; and (vi) any spending limits for the use of a Payment Instrument as agreed in accordance with Rule 19.10.2(1); (c) about charges and exchange rates: (i) details of all charges payable by the Payment Service User to the Payment Service Provider, including those connected to information which is provided or made available and, where applicable, a breakdown of the amounts of all charges; question: If a Payment Service Provider intends to amend the Framework Contract’s disclosure of charges payable by the Payment Service User (including any breakdown of amounts), what is the minimum advance notice period for providing that proposed amendment to the Payment Service User, and why does that charges disclosure qualify as information whose change triggers the notice requirement?
expected_answer: A proposed amendment to the Framework Contract’s charges disclosure must be provided by the Payment Service Provider to the Payment Service User no later than two months before the date the amendment is intended to take effect. [#SRC:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5] This timing applies because the notice rule covers proposed changes to both the existing terms of the Framework Contract and the information that is specified as required contract content. [#SRC:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5] The charges disclosure qualifies as such specified information because a Framework Contract must include details of all charges payable by the Payment Service User to the Payment Service Provider, including charges connected to information that is provided or made available, and (where applicable) a breakdown of the amounts of all charges. [#TGT:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b] The operational compliance outcome is that the Payment Service Provider should plan the effective date of any revised charges (and any revised breakdown) to allow at least a two-month lead time for delivering the proposed change to the Payment Service User. [#SRC:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5]

question: When a Petroleum Reporting Entity makes a disclosure under Rule 12.6.1 that includes new, previously undisclosed material estimates of Contingent Resources, what specific content must be included to address both (i) the Rule 12.6.1 “new data/information” impact explanation and (ii) the additional Contingent Resources disclosure elements (including any technology-under-development or Unconventional Petroleum Resources details, if applicable)?
expected_answer: The Petroleum Reporting Entity must prepare a single disclosure that satisfies both the Rule 12.6.1 “new data/information” update requirements and the specific content required for first-time, material Contingent Resources estimates. [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] [#TGT:cd78e857-9a44-49d6-932d-db3b31f20dec] The disclosure must identify the types of permits or licences held that relate to the estimates (and, for the Contingent Resources component, those relevant to the disclosed Contingent Resources estimates). [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] [#TGT:cd78e857-9a44-49d6-932d-db3b31f20dec] It must explain the new data and information and describe how that new data and information affected the estimates (including Contingent Resources). [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] For the previously undisclosed material Contingent Resources, it must also state the basis for confirming a significant quantity of potentially moveable Petroleum and the determination of a discovery, and describe the estimation method, the key contingencies supporting Contingent Resources classification, and any further appraisal drilling/evaluation work to progress the project. [#TGT:cd78e857-9a44-49d6-932d-db3b31f20dec] If the estimates are contingent on technology under development, it must explain the technology’s demonstrated (or not yet demonstrated) commercial viability status and ensure Unrecoverable quantities are not included as Contingent Resources. [#TGT:cd78e857-9a44-49d6-932d-db3b31f20dec] If they relate to Unconventional Petroleum Resources, it must add the specified Unconventional details (type, land area, number of wells, and specialised extraction technology). [#TGT:cd78e857-9a44-49d6-932d-db3b31f20dec] Finally, it must include any changes or additions to previously disclosed information for Contingent Resources as referenced in Rule 12.10.1(1) to 12.10.1(5). [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704]

debug_context.source_text: A Petroleum Reporting Entity making a disclosure under Rule 12.6.1 must ensure the disclosure contains: (1) the types of permits or licences held by the Petroleum Reporting Entity relating to the estimates; (2) an explanation of the new data and information; (3) an explanation of how the new data and information has affected the estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Resources; and (4) any changes or additions to the information previously disclosed relating to: (a) Prospective Resources under Rules 12.8.1(1) to 12.8.1(4); (b) Contingent Resources under Rules 12.10.1(1) to 12.10.1(5); and (c) Petroleum Reserves under Rules 12.12.1(1) to 12.12.1(7).
debug_context.target_text: A Petroleum Reporting Entity disclosing estimates of Contingent Resources that are material, and that have not previously been disclosed by the Petroleum Reporting Entity, must ensure the disclosure contains: (1) the types of permits or licences held by the Petroleum Reporting Entity relevant to the disclosed estimates of Contingent Resources; (2) the basis for, confirming the existence of a significant quantity of potentially moveable Petroleum, and the determination of a discovery; (3) a description of: (a) the method of estimation; (b) the key contingencies that resulted in the estimates being classified as Contingent Resources; (c) any further appraisal drilling and evaluation work to be undertaken to assess the potential for commercial recovery, and to progress the relevant project; (4) if the disclosed estimates of Contingent Resources are contingent on technology under development, to ensure that Unrecoverable quantities are not classified as part of the Contingent Resources, an explanation of whether the technology has: (a) been demonstrated to be commercially viable in analogous reservoirs; (b) been demonstrated to be commercially viable in other reservoirs that are not analogous, and that a pilot project, which is planned and budgeted, will be necessary to demonstrate commerciality for this reservoir; or (c) not been demonstrated to be commercially viable, but is currently under active development, and there is sufficient evidence to indicate that the technology may reasonably be expected to be available for commercial application within five years; and (5) if the disclosed estimates of Contingent Resources relate to Unconventional Petroleum Resources, the: (a) type(s) of Unconventional Contingent Resource; (b) land area; (c) number of wells; and (d) specialised extraction technology proposed to be utilised.

question: If a Petroleum Reporting Entity is updating estimates because it has new data (a Rule 12.6.1 disclosure) and the update includes material Contingent Resources that it has never disclosed before, what information has to be in the disclosure, including what to add if the Contingent Resources depend on new technology or are Unconventional Petroleum Resources?
expected_answer: It must include all items required for a Rule 12.6.1 update and, at the same time, all items required for first-time disclosure of material Contingent Resources. [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] [#TGT:cd78e857-9a44-49d6-932d-db3b31f20dec] For the update aspect, the disclosure must state the types of permits or licences held relating to the estimates, explain the new data and information, explain how that new data and information changed the estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Resources, and describe any changes or additions to previously disclosed information for Contingent Resources by reference to Rules 12.10.1(1) to 12.10.1(5). [#SRC:a9ffc27d-5147-4066-826f-22c25cd1e704] For the first-time material Contingent Resources aspect, it must also include the permits or licences relevant to the disclosed Contingent Resources, the basis for confirming a significant quantity of potentially moveable Petroleum and determining a discovery, and a description covering the estimation method, the key contingencies for Contingent Resources classification, and any further appraisal drilling and evaluation work planned to assess commercial recovery and progress the project. [#TGT:cd78e857-9a44-49d6-932d-db3b31f20dec] If the Contingent Resources depend on technology under development, it must explain the technology’s commercial-viability status in the specified categories and ensure Unrecoverable quantities are not included in Contingent Resources. [#TGT:cd78e857-9a44-49d6-932d-db3b31f20dec] If they relate to Unconventional Petroleum Resources, it must add the type(s), land area, number of wells, and specialised extraction technology proposed. question: When a Recognised Clearing House determines whether it holds capital at least equal to the required sum of risk-based components, how must it source and treat the operational-expense figures used for (i) the six months’ gross operational expenses element and (ii) the minimum floor tied to annual gross operational expenses for business risk?
expected_answer: A Recognised Clearing House must ensure its total capital is at least the sum of the specified risk components, including an amount for winding down or restructuring equal to six months’ gross operational expenses and a business-risk amount that cannot be below 25% of its annual gross operational expenses. [#TGT:fedb7b40-56a0-4cc6-97c6-fef115fc6c1b] To populate the operational-expense figures used in both of those components, it must use the most recent audited information from its annual financial statement. [#SRC:6d70e8b6-10a0-4b13-b3be-912e662e25b0] In addition, when identifying and treating operational expenses for these calculations, it must consider operational expenses in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS), so that the expense base used for the six-month measure and the annual-expense minimum floor is determined on an IFRS basis. [#SRC:6d70e8b6-10a0-4b13-b3be-912e662e25b0] Separately, for business risk it must submit its own estimate of capital needed to cover losses from business risk to the Regulator for approval, and the resulting capital requirement equals that approved estimate but remains subject to the 25% annual gross operational-expense minimum. [#TGT:fedb7b40-56a0-4cc6-97c6-fef115fc6c1b]

debug_context.source_text: For the purposes of Rule ‎4.2.1, Recognised Clearing Houses shall use the most recent audited information from their annual financial statement and operational expenses shall be considered in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS).
debug_context.target_text: A Recognised Clearing House shall hold capital more than or equal to the sum of capital calculated in respect of the following risks. (a) Winding down or restructuring activities. Six months' gross operational expenses. (b) Operational risks. A Recognised Clearing House shall calculate its capital requirement for operational risks using either the Basic Indicator Approach or, with prior authorisation from the Regulator, the Standardised Approach or the Alternative Standardised Approach, both as provided specifically in Appendix 7.3 and generally in Appendix 7 of PRU. (c) Credit, counterparty credit and market risks. A Recognised Clearing House shall calculate its capital requirements as the sum of 10% of its risk-weighted exposure amounts for credit and counterparty credit risk and its capital requirements for market risk calculated in accordance with Appendix 6 of PRU, subject to the following. (i) For the calculation of the risk-weighted exposure amounts for credit risk and counterparty credit risk, a Recognised Clearing House shall apply the Credit Risk Capital Requirement (CRCOM) method in section 4.8 of PRU. (ii) Where a Recognised Clearing House does not use its own resources, the Recognised Clearing House shall apply a risk weight of 250% to its exposure stemming from any contributions to the default fund of another Clearing house and a risk weight of 2% to any trade exposures with another Clearing house. (d) Business risk. A Recognised Clearing House shall submit to the Regulator for approval its own estimate of the capital necessary to cover losses resulting from business risk based on reasonably foreseeable adverse scenarios relevant to its business model. The capital requirement for business risk shall be equal to the approved estimate and shall be subject to a minimum amount of 25% of its annual gross operational expenses.

question: In calculating the capital sum a Recognised Clearing House must hold, how do the operational-expense inputs used for the winding-down/restructuring component interact with the business-risk minimum, and what specific source and accounting basis must be applied to those operational-expense inputs?
expected_answer: The capital a Recognised Clearing House must hold must be no less than the sum of capital calculated for multiple risks, including (i) winding down or restructuring activities measured as six months’ gross operational expenses and (ii) business risk, where the capital requirement equals the Regulator-approved estimate but is subject to a minimum of 25% of annual gross operational expenses. [#TGT:fedb7b40-56a0-4cc6-97c6-fef115fc6c1b] Because both components depend directly on operational-expense amounts (six months of gross operational expenses and a percentage of annual gross operational expenses), the Recognised Clearing House must ensure those operational-expense inputs are derived consistently from the most recent audited information in its annual financial statement. [#SRC:6d70e8b6-10a0-4b13-b3be-912e662e25b0] It must also treat operational expenses in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS), meaning the operational-expense base used to compute both the six-month amount and the annual-expense minimum floor is determined on an IFRS basis. [#SRC:6d70e8b6-10a0-4b13-b3be-912e662e25b0] This linkage ensures that the operational-expense figures feeding into the required capital sum are both audited and IFRS-consistent while still meeting the distinct quantitative requirements for winding down/restructuring and the business-risk minimum. [#TGT:fedb7b40-56a0-4cc6-97c6-fef115fc6c1b]

question: When a reconciliation is carried out under Rule 15.9.1 and then reviewed by a suitably senior member of the Authorised Person, what written confirmation is required from the individual referred to in Rule 15.9.4, and what does that confirmation need to cover in relation to the reconciliation and its review?
expected_answer: For a reconciliation that is performed under Rule 15.9.1 and therefore must be reviewed by a member of the Authorised Person with adequate seniority, the individual referred to in Rule 15.9.4 is required to produce a written statement. [#TGT:60712e89-ce53-445d-81a8-f2d744fc8851] That statement must confirm that the reconciliation has been carried out in line with the requirements of the relevant section (i.e., it is not merely an informal acknowledgement but an explicit confirmation of compliance with the section’s requirements). [#SRC:bcd90aa9-d7d1-47be-b4cb-45b877ddba30] In practical terms, the reconciliation is within scope when it is one “performed in accordance with Rule 15.9.1,” which triggers the review expectation by an adequately senior member of the Authorised Person. [#TGT:60712e89-ce53-445d-81a8-f2d744fc8851] Separately, the written statement obligation attaches to the individual identified in Rule 15.9.4 and focuses on confirming that the reconciliation itself was undertaken in accordance with the section’s requirements. [#SRC:bcd90aa9-d7d1-47be-b4cb-45b877ddba30] The two requirements operate together: the reconciliation must be reviewed by an appropriately senior reviewer, and the specified individual must document, in writing, that the reconciliation was undertaken as required. question: How should the Board of a Listed Entity reconcile its duty to ensure equality of treatment for holders of Securities of a particular class or type with a proposal to allot, issue or grant Shares with Weighted Voting Rights that alters equality and proportionality of Shareholder voting power and equity interest, and what approval condition applies?
expected_answer: A Listed Entity can proceed with Shares with Weighted Voting Rights only if it both (i) satisfies the specific approval condition for creating such rights and (ii) manages the resulting rights structure in a way that is consistent with the Board’s equality-of-treatment duty as it applies within each class or type of Securities. [#SRC:12f21edd-7868-4706-b1f4-3b2e9af8d6aa] The Board’s baseline obligation is to ensure equal treatment of all holders of Securities within the same class or type for all rights that attach to that class or type. [#TGT:194cf07e-3ce5-429a-9d01-6e1c25bef4ae] At the same time, the Listed Entity is expressly permitted, with the Regulator’s approval, to allot, issue or grant Shares with Weighted Voting Rights, which by design changes the equality and proportionality of Shareholder voting power and equity interest (as established in Rule 9.3.3). [#SRC:12f21edd-7868-4706-b1f4-3b2e9af8d6aa] In applying these together, the Board should treat the weighted voting feature as a rights attribute of the relevant Shares and then ensure that all holders of Securities of that particular class or type are treated equally in respect of the rights attaching to that class or type, while recognizing that the rules contemplate departures from equality and proportionality in voting power/equity interest when Weighted Voting Rights are issued with approval. [#TGT:194cf07e-3ce5-429a-9d01-6e1c25bef4ae] [#SRC:12f21edd-7868-4706-b1f4-3b2e9af8d6aa]

question: When an Authorised Person is considering recognising the effects of CRM for a guarantee provided by an MDB, what condition must be met for the guarantee to be eligible for CRM recognition, and how must the Authorised Person risk-weight any CR Exposure to a qualifying MDB such as the Asian Development Bank (ADB)?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person may only treat a guarantee as eligible CRM where the guarantor falls within the permitted categories for recognising the effects of CRM of a guarantee, which expressly includes an MDB (as referenced in the relevant MDB rule cross-reference). [#SRC:281505d3-a15a-449a-9095-dc247d0e2e5d] Separately, for credit risk purposes, the Authorised Person is required to apply a 0% risk weight to any CR Exposure to a qualifying MDB listed in the MDB asset class provision, and that list includes the Asian Development Bank (ADB). [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4] In practice, this means the CRM-recognition question for a guarantee turns on whether the guarantor is an eligible entity type (here, an MDB), while the exposure risk-weighting question turns on whether the MDB is one of the specifically enumerated qualifying institutions (such as ADB). [#SRC:281505d3-a15a-449a-9095-dc247d0e2e5d] [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4]

debug_context.source_text: An Authorised Person may recognise the effects of CRM of a guarantee only if it is provided by any of the following entities: (a) central government or central bank; (b) MDB referred to in Rule 4.12.8; (c) International Organisations referred to in Rule 4.12.9; (d) PSE; (e) banks and Securities firms which qualify for inclusion in bank asset class; or (f) any other entity that has an external credit assessment from a recognised credit rating agency that maps to a Credit Quality Grade 3 or better.

question: If a guarantee is provided by a member of The World Bank Group, how should an Authorised Person determine (i) whether the guarantee’s CRM effects may be recognised and (ii) whether a 0% risk weight applies to a CR Exposure to that institution, taking into account that The World Bank Group includes IBRD, MIGA, and IFC?
expected_answer: For CRM purposes, an Authorised Person may recognise the effects of CRM of a guarantee only where the guarantor is one of the specified eligible entity types, which include an MDB (as referenced in the MDB rule cross-reference). [#SRC:281505d3-a15a-449a-9095-dc247d0e2e5d] For risk-weighting of exposures, the Authorised Person must apply a 0% risk weight to any CR Exposure to the qualifying MDBs listed in the MDB asset class provision. [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4] The World Bank Group is explicitly identified as a qualifying MDB for this purpose, and it is defined there as comprising the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD), the Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA), and the International Finance Corporation (IFC). [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4] Accordingly, if the guarantor is IBRD, MIGA, or IFC, the guarantee can be assessed for CRM recognition under the eligible-guarantor categories (including MDBs), and any CR Exposure to that institution must be assigned a 0% risk weight because it is within the listed qualifying MDB set. question: Where a Recognised Investment Exchange’s Recognition Order includes a stipulation permitting it to operate an MTF, how should the Recognised Investment Exchange determine which rulebook applies to (i) the MTF function when it is operated using Virtual Assets and (ii) the remainder of its operations, given that COBS applies to the MTF/OTF function only?
expected_answer: If a Recognised Investment Exchange’s Recognition Order contains the required stipulation, it may carry on the Regulated Activity of operating an MTF (and, where relevant, an OTF), but the applicable requirements must be allocated by function. [#TGT:8e498a69-8f0c-44c3-970c-58d870656388] For the MTF function specifically, the Recognised Investment Exchange must apply the specific rules on MTFs and OTFs in COBS to that function, and only to that function. [#TGT:8e498a69-8f0c-44c3-970c-58d870656388] Where the stipulation relates to operating an MTF using Virtual Assets, the Recognised Investment Exchange must also meet the requirements of the Virtual Asset Framework in relation to operating that MTF (using Virtual Assets). [#SRC:54b67759-66a7-4cbd-a335-1a40ee4894bb] In parallel, the remainder of the Recognised Investment Exchange’s operations (i.e., activities outside the MTF function) must continue to be operated in compliance with the MIR Rules. [#SRC:54b67759-66a7-4cbd-a335-1a40ee4894bb] Accordingly, the compliance approach is to (1) confirm the Recognition Order stipulation permitting operation of the MTF, (2) treat the MTF function as the scope for COBS MTF/OTF rules, and (3) where Virtual Assets are used in operating the MTF, apply the Virtual Asset Framework to that MTF operation while maintaining MIR Rules compliance for all other operations. [#TGT:8e498a69-8f0c-44c3-970c-58d870656388] [#SRC:54b67759-66a7-4cbd-a335-1a40ee4894bb]

MIR Rule 3.4.2 requires that where such a stipulation is granted to a Recognised Investment Exchange, the Recognised Investment Exchange must meet the requirements of the Virtual Asset Framework in relation to operation of an MTF (using Virtual Assets) while the remainder of its operations must be operated in compliance with the MIR Rules.

expected_answer: When a Recognised Investment Exchange’s Recognition Order includes a stipulation permitting it to operate an MTF (and potentially an OTF), it may carry on that regulated function, but it must separate which requirements apply to which part of its business. [#TGT:8e498a69-8f0c-44c3-970c-58d870656388] For the MTF function itself, the specific COBS rules on MTFs and OTFs apply, and they apply only to that function rather than to the Recognised Investment Exchange’s other activities. question: Before publishing a financing proposal for a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, what due diligence must a PFP Operator carry out to support the disclosure requirements, and what records of that due diligence and related materials must the PFP Operator retain (and for how long)?
expected_answer: A PFP Operator must complete due diligence on the PFP Prospect before it publishes a financing proposal on a Private Financing Platform, and it must then retain records evidencing both the disclosures and the due diligence for at least six years. [#TGT:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce] [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7] The precondition for the due diligence is that the PFP Operator is about to publish a financing proposal in relation to a PFP Prospect; the purpose is to enable the PFP Operator to meet the disclosure requirements imposed on it by Rule 18.5.1. [#TGT:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce] The due diligence must include (and is not limited to) reviewing information provided by the PFP Prospect covering: management details and background (including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers), the PFP Prospect’s background (including financial soundness, good standing and regulatory status if relevant), and the financing proposal itself to ensure that, to the best of the PFP Operator’s knowledge, the content is adequate, clear, fair and not misleading. [#TGT:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce] For record-keeping, the PFP Operator must maintain and keep, for a minimum of six years, records of all disclosures made under Rules 18.5.1 and 18.5.2 and the due diligence undertaken under Rule 18.4.1, as well as documentation between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect. [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7]

debug_context.source_text: A PFP Operator must, for a minimum of six years, maintain and keep a record of: (a) all disclosures made in accordance with Rules 18.5.1 and 18.5.2; (b) all documentation between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect; and (c) the due diligence undertaken in accordance with Rule 18.4.1.
debug_context.target_text: Prior to publishing a financing proposal in relation to a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, the PFP Operator must perform due diligence upon the PFP Prospect, in order to satisfy the disclosure requirements imposed on it by Rule 18.5.1. Such due diligence must include, but not be limited to, a review of the following information to be provided by the PFP Prospect: (a) details and background of management, including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers; (b) background of the PFP Prospect, including its financial soundness, good standing and regulatory status, if relevant; and (c) the financing proposal, in order to ensure that, to the best of the PFP Operator’s knowledge, its content is adequate, clear, fair and not misleading.

question: If a PFP Operator is about to post a financing proposal for a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, what checks must it do on the PFP Prospect, and what related records does it have to keep for six years (including any documents involving a Body Corporate it set up for the transaction)?
expected_answer: Before a PFP Operator publishes a financing proposal about a PFP Prospect on a Private Financing Platform, it must first carry out due diligence on the PFP Prospect to help it meet the disclosure requirements placed on it by Rule 18.5.1. [#TGT:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce] That due diligence must include reviewing information the PFP Prospect provides about: (a) management details and background, including fitness and propriety assessments of directors and key officers; (b) the PFP Prospect’s background, including financial soundness, good standing, and (if relevant) regulatory status; and (c) the financing proposal, so that to the best of the PFP Operator’s knowledge the proposal is adequate, clear, fair, and not misleading. [#TGT:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce] After doing this work (and making the related disclosures), the PFP Operator must keep records for at least six years. [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7] The six-year record set must cover: all disclosures made under Rules 18.5.1 and 18.5.2, all documentation between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect, and the due diligence undertaken under Rule 18.4.1. [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7] Taken together, this means the PFP Operator should be able to show both what it reviewed before publication and what it disclosed, and preserve that evidence for the required retention period. question: For an Authorised Person engaged in Investment Business whose Financial Service Permission entitles them to hold Client Money, what must be submitted to the Regulator annually, and what specific statements must the Auditor include in that report as at the date of the Authorised Person's audited statement of financial position?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person engaged in Investment Business whose Financial Service Permission entitles them to hold Client Money must arrange for a Client Money Auditor's Report to be submitted to the Regulator on an annual basis. [#SRC:c42abaa9-4c93-4d5b-b989-aa4ec57cf600] In procuring the production of that Client Money Auditor's Report, the Authorised Person must ensure the Auditor makes specified statements as at the date on which the Authorised Person’s audited statement of financial position was prepared. [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17] The report must cover both quantitative and qualitative matters, including: - The amount of Client Money the Authorised Person was holding and controlling in accordance with COBS Chapter 14 as at that date. [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17] - Whether, throughout the year, the Authorised Person maintained systems and controls to comply with the relevant provisions of COBS Chapter 14 and whether those controls keep Client Money identifiable and secure at all times. [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17] - Whether any COBS Chapter 14 requirements were not met, and whether Client Money was pooled in a single client Account or segregated in Client Accounts for individual Clients in accordance with COBS Chapter 14. [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17] - Whether the Auditor received all necessary information and explanations for preparing the report to the Regulator, and (if applicable) whether there were material discrepancies in Client Money reconciliation. [#TGT:5a4a5e76-893c-4b13-b6a4-95ac2157cf17]

debug_context.source_text: An Authorised Person engaged in Investment Business whose Financial Service Permission entitles them to hold Client Money must also arrange for a Client Money Auditor's Report to be submitted to the Regulator on an annual basis in accordance with GEN 6.6.6.

question: For an Authorised Person Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets, which MIR Chapter 5 rules must be complied with, and how does COBS Rule 17.7.4 affect the application of those MIR notification and information requirements to MTFs using Virtual Assets (including the linkage to paragraph 29 of the Guidance on additional Accepted Virtual Assets)?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person that is Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets is required to comply with specified MIR Chapter 5 requirements, and COBS Rule 17.7.4 clarifies that certain Recognised Investment Exchange-style notification and information requirements apply to MTFs using Virtual Assets as additional requirements. [#TGT:7404ef72-3a2f-4c07-a166-0dfd8a480e8d] [#SRC:f1ec727b-52fd-409e-a8e4-bf9149a68fe8] Concretely, the MIR Chapter 5 obligations for such an Authorised Person include compliance with Rules 5.1–5.3 and Rule 5.4.1, but only in the circumstances identified in the listed Items (including Items 19, 20, 24(a) and (b), 27, 28, 32, 33, 35, 37–41, 43, 45–50, 52–55, and 57–62). [#TGT:7404ef72-3a2f-4c07-a166-0dfd8a480e8d] In addition, COBS Rule 17.7.4 specifies that certain notification requirements that are applicable to Recognised Investment Exchanges under MIR Rules 5.1 and 5.3, and certain information requirements under MIR Rule 5.4.1, also apply to MTFs (using Virtual Assets), and it characterises these as additional requirements for MTFs using Virtual Assets. [#SRC:f1ec727b-52fd-409e-a8e4-bf9149a68fe8] Finally, beyond those COBS-applied requirements, MTFs using Virtual Assets must also comply with any other applicable notification requirements, including those described in paragraph 29 of the Guidance regarding the use of additional Accepted Virtual Assets. [#SRC:f1ec727b-52fd-409e-a8e4-bf9149a68fe8]

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity makes a disclosure under Rule 11.9.1 that includes forecast financial information derived from a Production Target, how should it structure the required assumptions and Production Target content so that the overall disclosure also meets the “fair and balanced” representation expectation for information drawn from a separate report annexed under Rule 11.6.2, without attempting to summarise the entire annexure?
expected_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity should present the Rule 11.9.1 forecast-financial-information package (assumptions plus the underlying Production Target) in a way that remains fair and balanced when read alongside the separate report that must be annexed, while avoiding an unnecessary full summary of that annexure. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] [#TGT:b8cb4fdb-f627-43ae-90bf-801a549f8d63] Specifically, the disclosure must include all material economic assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information, and it must also include all other material assumptions used. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] If the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions commercially sensitive, it must say so and explain the methodology used to determine those material economic assumptions. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] In addition, the disclosure must include the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, including all information required by Rule 11.8.3. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] To align this with the Rule 11.6.1 “fair and balanced” expectation, the information included in the disclosure should fairly reflect the information in the separate report prepared under Rule 11.6.2 (annexed to the disclosure), but the FSRA expects only material information needed to understand the estimates of Mineral Resources in that separate report—where that material information is not already in the body of the disclosure—to be included, rather than a comprehensive summary. [#TGT:b8cb4fdb-f627-43ae-90bf-801a549f8d63]

debug_context.source_text: A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include: (1) in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information: (a) all material economic assumptions employed; (b) if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and Guidance A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure. (c) all other material assumptions utilised. (2) the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
debug_context.target_text: ORE RESERVES . Pursuant to Rule 11.6.1, the information included in the disclosure must be a fair and balanced representation of the information contained in the separate report prepared in accordance with Rule 11.6.2 (which must be included as an annexure to the disclosure). In complying with this obligation, the FSRA does not expect a Mining Reporting Entity to prepare a summary of all the information contained in the separate report. Instead, it is expected that that only information which is material to understanding the estimates of Mineral Resources contained in the separate report, that is not otherwise included in the body of the disclosure, be included.

question: When the Prospectus relating to a Passported Fund has been amended or replaced, what must the Fund Manager submit to the Regulator in its notification, and what form and timing constraints apply (including any outer deadline once it becomes aware)?
expected_answer: When the Prospectus relating to a Passported Fund is amended or replaced, the Fund Manager must notify the Regulator as soon as practicable, and in any case no later than seven days after it becomes aware of the event. [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898] The notification must be made in the prescribed form that the Regulator may direct from time to time. [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f] At a minimum, the notification must include reasonable detail describing the event. [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f] In addition, where the Prospectus has been amended or replaced, the notification must be accompanied by a copy of the new Prospectus, so the Regulator receives the updated disclosure document alongside the event description. [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f] This Prospectus-change trigger is expressly listed as a notifiable material event for a Passported Fund, and the seven-day outer limit applies once the Fund Manager becomes aware. [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898] Accordingly, compliance requires both meeting the timing requirement for Passported Fund material events and ensuring the submission package satisfies the minimum content and form requirements for the notification. [#TGT:7a51b100-c0e6-41bd-809c-d2ae395a9898] [#SRC:a293c037-9b5d-4128-8318-f840f0264d1f]

debug_context.source_text: The notification referred to in Rule 6.6.2 must be in such prescribed form as the Regulator may direct from time to time. At a minimum, the notification must be accompanied by reasonable detail of the event and (where the Prospectus has been amended or replaced) a copy of the new Prospectus.
debug_context.target_text: The Fund Manager of a Passported Fund must notify the Regulator as soon as practicable of any material events, in accordance with applicable ADGM legislation. In particular (but without limitation), a Fund Manager or the governing body or trustee of a Passported Fund must notify the Regulator as soon as practicable (and in any case no later than seven days after it becomes aware) of any of the following events: (a) the Fund Manager intends to retire as manager of the Passported Fund; (b) it is proposed that a successor manager will be appointed in relation to the Passported Fund; (c) the Fund Manager has been removed or replaced as manager of the Passported Fund; (d) any material service provider to the Passported Fund (including, without limitation, any custodian) or an Agent or Licensed Person resigns, is appointed, is removed, or is replaced; (e) the Prospectus relating to the Passported Fund has been amended or replaced; (f) winding-up of the Passported Fund has commenced; or (g) the Fund Manager intends to vary or revoke its Financial Service Permission (or any conditions contained in that Financial Service Permission).

question: Where a Mining Reporting Entity has already made a Rule 11.8.2 disclosure that complied with the detailed content requirements for Production Targets, under what conditions may a later disclosure about the same Production Target omit the Rule 11.8.2 content items (including the required prominent cautionary statements for Inferred Mineral Resources and/or an Exploration Target), and what specific confirmations or cross-references must the later disclosure still include?
expected_answer: A subsequent disclosure about a Production Target can omit the detailed Rule 11.8.2 content (such as the material assumptions, proportion breakdowns, and the specified prominent cautionary statements) only if it is explicitly tied back to an earlier Rule 11.8.2 disclosure that already contained those required items and was compliant. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] To rely on that streamlined approach, the later disclosure must (i) point readers to the earlier compliant disclosure, and (ii) include a confirmation that the material assumptions used in the initial disclosure continue to apply and have not materially changed. [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] In addition, the later disclosure must still include an at least equally prominent and proximate cautionary statement if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, aligned to the specific statement required for that scenario in the Rule 11.8.2 content list. [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] Similarly, if the Production Target is based in part on an Exploration Target, the later disclosure must still include an at least equally prominent and proximate cautionary statement aligned to the Exploration Target warning specified in the Rule 11.8.2 requirements. [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]

debug_context.source_text: If a Mining Reporting Entity made a disclosure under Rule 11.8.2, then any subsequent disclosure in relation to a Production Target need not include the information required to be disclosed by Rule 11.8.3 where the subsequent disclosure: (1) references the earlier disclosure that was in compliance with Rule 11.8.3; (2) contains a statement confirming that all the material assumptions in the initial disclosure, upon which the Production Target is based continue to apply and have not materially changed; (3) if the Production Target is wholly based upon Inferred Mineral Resources, includes an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement about the disclosed Production Target to the effect of the statement set out in Rule 11.8.3(5)(d); and (4) if the Production Target is based in part upon an Exploration Target, includes an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement about the disclosed Production Target to the effect of the statement set out in Rule 11.8.3(7)(b).
debug_context.target_text: A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2 must include: (1) in relation to the assumptions used to determine the Production Target: (a) all material economic assumptions employed; or (b) if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and Guidance A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure. (c) all other material assumptions utilised. (2) if forecast commodity prices have been used in the determination of the Production Target, a statement that such forecast commodity pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds. (3) the proportions of the Production Target based on: (a) Probable Ore Reserves and Proved Ore Reserves; (b) Indicated Mineral Resources and Measured Mineral Resources; (c) Inferred Mineral Resources; and (d) an Exploration Target. (4) a statement that the respective proportions of Inferred Mineral Resources and the Exploration Target (if applicable) are not the determining factors in the viability of the Production Target and do not feature as a significant proportion in the early mine plan; (5) if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources: (a) an explanation as to why the Mining Reporting Entity believes it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources; (b) the level of confidence in relation to which the Inferred Mineral Resources are estimated and the basis for that level of confidence; (c) a Technical Study of a sufficient level of confidence to support the Production Target, prepared by, or under the supervision of, a named independent Competent Person(s); and (d) an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that: “The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. Though further evaluation and/or exploration work is required to establish sufficient confidence that the production target will be met, there is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised. The mining reporting entity’s production target is based on its current expectation of future results or events, and should not be solely relied upon by investors when making investment decisions.” Guidance Any statement about a Production Target will be deemed to be misleading unless the person making the statement has reasonable grounds for making the statement. The Regulator considers that it is only under exceptional circumstances that a Mining Reporting Entity might form a view that it has reasonable grounds for a Production Target to be wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources. (6) if the Production Target is in part based on Inferred Mineral Resources, an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that: “The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. There is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.” (7) if the Production Target is in part based on an Exploration Target: (a) a statement of the factors that lead the Mining Reporting Entity to believe that it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target based, in part, on an Exploration Target; and (b) an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that: “The potential quantity and grade of an Exploration Target is only conceptual in nature. There has been insufficient exploration to determine a Mineral Resource and there is no certainty that further exploration work will result in the determination of Mineral Resources or that the Production Target itself will be realised.”

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity already made a full Rule 11.8.2 Production Target disclosure, when can it make a later update without repeating all the details (like the assumptions and the split between Ore Reserves/Mineral Resources/Exploration Target), and what must it still say if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources or partly based on an Exploration Target?
expected_answer: A later disclosure about a Production Target does not have to repeat all the detailed Rule 11.8.2 information (for example, the material economic assumptions and other material assumptions, whether forecast commodity prices were used on reasonable grounds, and the proportions sourced from Ore Reserves, Mineral Resources, Inferred Mineral Resources, and any Exploration Target) if it properly relies on an earlier Rule 11.8.2 disclosure that already included those items and was compliant. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] To do that, the later disclosure must refer back to the earlier compliant disclosure and must also confirm that the material assumptions from the initial disclosure still apply and have not materially changed. [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] Even when the later disclosure is streamlined, it still needs to include specific prominent warnings in certain cases: if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, the later disclosure must include an at least equally prominent and proximate statement matching the required Inferred Mineral Resources warning for that scenario. [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] If the Production Target is based in part on an Exploration Target, the later disclosure must include an at least equally prominent and proximate statement matching the required Exploration Target warning. [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]

There is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.” (7) if the Production Target is in part based on an Exploration Target: (a) a statement of the factors that lead the Mining Reporting Entity to believe that it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target based, in part, on an Exploration Target; and (b) an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that: “The potential quantity and grade of an Exploration Target is only conceptual in nature. There has been insufficient exploration to determine a Mineral Resource and there is no certainty that further exploration work will result in the determination of Mineral Resources or that the Production Target itself will be realised.”

question: When applying the Chapter’s requirement to recognise and measure an Insurer’s assets and liabilities using the basis of accounting referenced in Rule 5.3.2, which accounting standards must the Insurer adopt for the purposes of Rule 5.3.1, and how does that differ for a Takaful Insurer versus any other Insurer?
expected_answer: An Insurer must recognise and measure its assets and liabilities using the basis of accounting specified in Rule 5.3.2, unless the Chapter itself states an alternative approach. [#TGT:35397bd0-0c01-4dec-8eba-1b904df8b4d4] For the purposes of Rule 5.3.1, the Insurer’s adopted basis of accounting depends on whether it is a Takaful Insurer or not. [#SRC:3c51cc32-3de9-4282-b9f4-4f06c1c659b0] Specifically, if the Insurer is a Takaful Insurer, it must use the standards issued by the Accounting and Auditing Organisation for Islamic Financial Institutions as its basis of accounting. [#SRC:3c51cc32-3de9-4282-b9f4-4f06c1c659b0] If the Insurer is not a Takaful Insurer, it must instead use International Financial Reporting Standards as its basis of accounting. [#SRC:3c51cc32-3de9-4282-b9f4-4f06c1c659b0] In practical compliance terms, the Chapter’s recognition and measurement requirement operates by tying the accounting treatment of assets and liabilities to the Rule 5.3.2 basis, while Rule 5.3.1 clarifies which accounting framework the Insurer must adopt depending on its type. [#TGT:35397bd0-0c01-4dec-8eba-1b904df8b4d4] [#SRC:3c51cc32-3de9-4282-b9f4-4f06c1c659b0]

debug_context.source_text: The basis of accounting adopted by an Insurer for the purposes of Rule ‎5.3.1 must be: (a) in the case of a Takaful Insurer, the standards of the Accounting and Auditing Organisation for Islamic Financial Institutions; or (b) in any other case, International Financial Reporting Standards.
