question: When an Authorised Person prepares or publishes Investment Research and identifies an actual or potential conflict of interest, what form and level of detail must any conflict disclosure have so that the relevant Client can make an informed decision in the context of the service?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person that prepares or publishes Investment Research must have adequate procedures and controls for that activity, and this sits alongside its obligation to take reasonable steps to identify actual or potential conflicts of interest and then prevent or manage them. [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759] Where the Authorised Person makes a conflicts disclosure under Rule 3.3.23 in connection with the service in which the conflict arises, that disclosure must be delivered in a durable medium and must contain enough information for the Client to make an informed decision. [#TGT:448d19a7-728b-491f-9eb2-284dc92112e9] In practice, this means the Authorised Person should (i) identify the conflict as part of its conflicts process and address it through prevention or management measures, and (ii) if disclosure is used, ensure the disclosure is appropriately communicated and sufficiently detailed for the particular Client. [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759] The required level of detail is not fixed; it must be assessed by reference to the nature of the Client and must be framed so the Client can decide, on an informed basis, whether to proceed with the relevant service notwithstanding the conflict. [#TGT:448d19a7-728b-491f-9eb2-284dc92112e9]

question: Where an Offer in or from the ADGM is structured so that different tranches rely on different prescribed Exempt Offer circumstances (e.g., one tranche directed at no more than 50 Persons in a 12-month period and another tranche meeting a $100,000 minimum consideration threshold), under what condition can the Offer still be treated as an Exempt Offer notwithstanding that it falls partly within more than one circumstance?
expected_answer: An Offer can continue to be treated as an Exempt Offer even if it is split across multiple prescribed Exempt Offer circumstances, provided that every part of the Offer is covered by at least one of those circumstances. [#SRC:93a2a61f-b4c9-4b29-bec3-d7bdd00541c0] In applying that principle, the relevant “circumstances” are those prescribed by the Regulator for section 61(3)(a) of the FSMR, including (among others) an Offer in or from the ADGM directed at no more than 50 Persons in any 12-month period (with specified exclusions for certain Professional Clients), and an Offer where the total consideration paid by a Person is at least $100,000 (or equivalent). [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] Practically, this means you may rely on different prescribed circumstances for different portions of the same overall Offer (for example, a limited-number-of-persons limb for one portion and a minimum-consideration limb for another), but you must check that there is no residual portion that falls outside all prescribed circumstances. [#SRC:93a2a61f-b4c9-4b29-bec3-d7bdd00541c0] If any part of the Offer is not within at least one prescribed circumstance, the condition for maintaining Exempt Offer status is not met. [#SRC:93a2a61f-b4c9-4b29-bec3-d7bdd00541c0]

(4) an Offer where the Securities are denominated in amounts of at least $100,000, or an equivalent amount in another currency; (5) an Offer where the total aggregate consideration for the Securities offered is less than $100,000, or an equivalent amount in another currency, calculated over a period of 12 months; question: If an Offer is made partly to or directed at only Professional Clients and partly through a Private Financing Platform to no more than 200 Persons that are not Professional Clients or Market Counterparties, how should Exempt Offer status be assessed when the Offer falls within more than one prescribed circumstance?
expected_answer: You assess Exempt Offer status by confirming that, although the Offer may fall in whole or in part within more than one prescribed circumstance, all parts of the Offer are covered by at least one prescribed circumstance. [#SRC:93a2a61f-b4c9-4b29-bec3-d7bdd00541c0] The prescribed circumstances include an Offer made to or directed at only Professional Clients, and (other than in relation to Debentures and Sukuk) an Offer in or from the ADGM directed at no more than 200 Persons that are not Professional Clients or Market Counterparties where the Securities are, or have been, offered within a Private Financing Platform or via a Multilateral Trading Facility. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] Accordingly, it is permissible for one portion of the Offer to rely on the “only Professional Clients” circumstance while another portion relies on the “Private Financing Platform/MTF with up to 200 non-Professional Clients/non-Market Counterparties” circumstance, so long as there is no portion of the Offer that is outside all prescribed circumstances. [#SRC:93a2a61f-b4c9-4b29-bec3-d7bdd00541c0] This requires mapping each tranche or distribution channel to at least one prescribed circumstance and ensuring the platform-based limb is not used for Debentures or Sukuk. [#TGT:aebfec36-985e-4d75-a783-f582fed8fafc] If every part is covered, the Offer remains an Exempt Offer despite the overlap. [#SRC:93a2a61f-b4c9-4b29-bec3-d7bdd00541c0]

question: Where an MTF admits to trading Securities offered by way of an Exempt Offer under MKT Rule 4.3.1 (13), how should the operator align its platform-specific systems and controls (including identifying offerees and limiting non-Professional Client participation) with the broader Rule 3.9.1 admission-to-trading framework that requires clear, transparent Business Rules and fair, orderly and efficient trading?
expected_answer: An MTF admitting Securities from an Exempt Offer under MKT Rule 4.3.1 (13) must implement platform-level systems and controls that both (i) enforce the Exempt Offer-specific constraints and (ii) support compliance with the admission-to-trading requirements referenced through Rule 3.9.1. [#SRC:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66] Concretely, the MTF must ensure it admits only Securities from Exempt Offers made on its own platform, can identify the Persons to whom the Exempt Offer was made, and restrict trading so that no more than 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients can trade those Securities. [#SRC:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66] In parallel, because the MTF must comply with MIR rule 3.9.1 (Admission to trading) as applicable for the relevant Securities, the admission approach should be reflected in clear and transparent Business Rules and should ensure the admitted instruments are capable of being traded in a fair, orderly and efficient manner. [#TGT:a9b5571e-2d13-4cb0-b58f-9c251e6bd215] Operationally, this means the Exempt Offer gating (platform-only admission, offeree identification, and the 200-person non-Professional Client cap) should be embedded into the admission process and rule set used to meet Rule 3.9.1 expectations on transparency and orderly trading. [#SRC:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66] [#TGT:a9b5571e-2d13-4cb0-b58f-9c251e6bd215]

(b) The Business Rules must ensure that all Financial Instruments admitted to trading on any market operated by the Recognised Investment Exchange are capable of being traded in a fair, orderly and efficient manner. (c) The Business Rules must ensure that: (i) all Financial Instruments other than Derivatives admitted to trading on a market operated by the Recognised Investment Exchange are freely negotiable; and (ii) all contracts for Derivatives admitted to trading on a regulated market operated by the Recognised Investment Exchange are designed so as to allow for their orderly pricing as well as for the existence of effective settlement conditions. question: For Securities admitted to trading on an MTF under an Exempt Offer, what combined arrangements are required to ensure users can access information (including Offer documents and Inside Information) while also meeting the Recognised Investment Exchange obligation to assist users in obtaining access to information made public under disclosure obligations?
expected_answer: When Securities from an Exempt Offer are admitted to trading on an MTF, the operator must put in place information-access arrangements that satisfy both the Exempt Offer-specific requirement to provide market users with relevant inside and offer-related materials and the broader obligation to help users access information made public under disclosure obligations. [#SRC:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66] [#TGT:a9b5571e-2d13-4cb0-b58f-9c251e6bd215] On the Exempt Offer side, the MTF must have effective systems and controls that allow users of its market to obtain Inside Information, and this expressly includes any Offer documents prepared under MKT Rule 4.3.5 that are relevant to the Securities. [#SRC:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66] Separately, the Recognised Investment Exchange framework for admission to trading requires maintaining arrangements to assist users of a market it operates to obtain access to information that is made public under its disclosure obligations. question: For a Third Party Provider’s Governing Contract, how should the contract’s required exchange-rate disclosures and any agreed approach to changing exchange rates be structured so that the provider can apply exchange-rate changes immediately and without notice only in the permitted cases?
expected_answer: A Third Party Provider should draft the Governing Contract so that (i) it includes the required baseline disclosures on exchange rates and (ii) it only permits immediate, no-notice exchange-rate changes in the limited situations allowed. The contract must, where relevant, state the exchange rates to be applied or, if Reference Exchange Rates are used, explain how the relevant date is determined for those Reference Exchange Rates. [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] Where relevant and if agreed, it must also address how changes in Reference Exchange Rates will be applied and what information will be provided in relation to those changes. [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] Against that disclosure framework, immediate application without notice is only appropriate where the Governing Contract expressly grants that right and the exchange-rate changes are based on Reference Exchange Rate information that has already been provided to the Customer in accordance with Rule 20.2.2, or where the change is more favourable to the Customer. [#SRC:3f6b7da4-2d83-4094-a143-a0901d3bbbf2] In practice, this means the contract’s “changes” provisions should be aligned with its exchange-rate/Reference Exchange Rate disclosures so the no-notice mechanism is not broader than these two permitted cases. [#SRC:3f6b7da4-2d83-4094-a143-a0901d3bbbf2] [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]

(ii) where relevant, details of the exchange rates to be applied or, if Reference Exchange Rates are to be used, the method of calculating the relevant date for determining such Reference Exchange Rates; question: If a Third Party Provider wants to change exchange rates right away without telling the Customer first, what must be written into the Governing Contract about exchange rates and Reference Exchange Rates, and when is the “no notice” change allowed?
expected_answer: The Governing Contract should both explain the exchange-rate basis up front and narrowly define when an exchange-rate change can happen immediately without notice. [#SRC:3f6b7da4-2d83-4094-a143-a0901d3bbbf2] So the contract needs both the required exchange-rate/Reference Exchange Rate information and a tightly scoped “immediate change” clause that matches these permitted triggers. question: How do the Regulations’ general prohibition on making an Offer of Securities in the Abu Dhabi Global Market (and on having Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange) interact with the Regulator’s power under section 59(c) of the FSMR to prescribe certain communications as Exempt Communications, and what is the compliance consequence for those prescribed communications?
expected_answer: Communications that the Regulator prescribes as Exempt Communications are treated as outside the regulatory concept that triggers the general prohibition on making an Offer of Securities in the Abu Dhabi Global Market or having Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange. [#SRC:0c1f16b4-30eb-4cf6-845f-2ecc45f1337f] The Regulations state that a person must not make an Offer of Securities in the Abu Dhabi Global Market and must not have Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, unless an exception applies under the Regulations. [#TGT:67094ff0-5048-4e6e-87e4-bb61836c324a] Under section 59(c) of the FSMR, the Regulator can designate certain communications as Exempt Communications, and those communications are not subject to the prohibition in section 58(1) of the FSMR because they fall outside the definition of an “Offer of Securities” in section 59 of the FSMR. [#SRC:0c1f16b4-30eb-4cf6-845f-2ecc45f1337f] As a result, where a communication has been prescribed by the Regulator as an Exempt Communication, it does not constitute an Offer of Securities for these purposes, so the Regulations’ prohibition framed around making an “Offer of Securities” in the Abu Dhabi Global Market is not engaged by that communication. [#SRC:0c1f16b4-30eb-4cf6-845f-2ecc45f1337f] [#TGT:67094ff0-5048-4e6e-87e4-bb61836c324a]

question: When an Authorised Person calculates its Leverage Ratio using the prescribed methodology, what specific components must be included in the Capital Measure, and how does that Capital Measure relate to the Exposure Measure in the ratio?
expected_answer: In calculating the Leverage Ratio, an Authorised Person must use a Capital Measure that is its Tier 1 Capital, and that Tier 1 Capital must be built up as the sum of two specified components. [#SRC:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b] Specifically, Tier 1 capital is determined by adding together Common Equity Tier 1 capital (CET1 Capital) and Additional Tier 1 capital (AT1 Capital). [#TGT:a2ce8a2e-9188-4d44-8582-42abbadc4f11] The Leverage Ratio itself is then computed by dividing this Capital Measure (i.e., Tier 1 Capital as just described) by the Exposure Measure. [#SRC:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b] The Exposure Measure is not a capital component; it is the value of the Authorised Person’s Exposures, and it must be calculated under the specified exposure rules referenced for that purpose. [#SRC:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b] Accordingly, the numerator of the ratio is Tier 1 Capital (CET1 Capital plus AT1 Capital), while the denominator is the Exposure Measure derived from the Authorised Person’s Exposures. [#SRC:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b] [#TGT:a2ce8a2e-9188-4d44-8582-42abbadc4f11]

debug_context.source_text: An Authorised Person must calculate its Leverage Ratio in accordance with the following methodology: Leverage Ratio = Capital Measure ÷ Exposure Measure where: (a) "Capital Measure" represents the Tier 1 Capital of the Authorised Person calculated in accordance with Rule 3.9.1; and (b) "Exposure Measure" represents the value of Exposures of the Authorised Person calculated in accordance with Rules 3.21.5 and 3.21.6.
debug_context.target_text: Tier 1 capital must be calculated as the total of its Common Equity Tier 1 capital (referred to in these Rules as CET1 Capital) and its Additional Tier 1 capital (referred to in these Rules as AT1 Capital).

expected_answer: To calculate an Authorised Person’s Leverage Ratio, you start by identifying the Capital Measure and the Exposure Measure and then apply the required division. [#SRC:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b] The Capital Measure is the Authorised Person’s Tier 1 Capital, and Tier 1 capital must be calculated as the total of Common Equity Tier 1 capital (CET1 Capital) plus Additional Tier 1 capital (AT1 Capital). [#TGT:a2ce8a2e-9188-4d44-8582-42abbadc4f11] Once you have that Tier 1 Capital amount, you use it as the numerator in the Leverage Ratio formula. [#SRC:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b] You then divide it by the Exposure Measure, which is defined as the value of the Authorised Person’s Exposures calculated under the specified exposure calculation rules referenced for that purpose. [#SRC:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b] In other words, the ratio is Tier 1 Capital (made up of CET1 Capital and AT1 Capital) divided by the Exposure Measure (the value of Exposures). question: Where a person has failed to comply with a requirement under Part 17 of FSMR and is certified in default, what must the Court of First Instance be satisfied about before it may treat the Defaulter as if in contempt, and who else may be dealt with in that way if the Defaulter is a Body Corporate?
expected_answer: If a person fails to comply with a requirement under Part 17 of FSMR and is certified in default, the Court of First Instance may only proceed to treat the Defaulter as if in contempt once it is satisfied of the relevant non-compliance condition described for that step. [#SRC:852b4e79-2438-4f0f-a95c-16c2f18637bf] Specifically, the Court must be satisfied that the Defaulter failed to comply with the requirement without reasonable excuse before it may deal with the Defaulter as if he were in contempt. [#TGT:91865998-c73a-45ec-8cec-23c36750808a] In addition, when the Defaulter is a Body Corporate, the Court’s contempt-style treatment may extend beyond the entity itself to include any Director or other Officer of that Body Corporate. [#TGT:91865998-c73a-45ec-8cec-23c36750808a] Separately from the Court’s contempt-style handling, the same failure to comply with Part 17 requirements may also expose the person to being found to have committed a contravention of FSMR. [#SRC:852b4e79-2438-4f0f-a95c-16c2f18637bf] These consequences operate on the basis of the failure to comply with the Part 17 requirement and the Court’s satisfaction as to the absence of reasonable excuse for the contempt-style response. [#SRC:852b4e79-2438-4f0f-a95c-16c2f18637bf] [#TGT:91865998-c73a-45ec-8cec-23c36750808a]

A person that fails to comply with a requirement under Part 17 of FSMR can be certified in default and, in the event the Court of First Instance is satisfied, dealt with as if they were in contempt of court pursuant to section 214(1)-(2) of FSMR. For failing to comply with such requirements, such a person may also be found to have committed a contravention of FSMR pursuant to section 218.

question: For a Petroleum Reporting Entity preparing a Summary of Reserves and Resources, when must it include the MKT Form 12-1 table and what is the relevant “as of” date constraint, and how does this change if the entity is required to file SEC compliant Forms 10-K and 20-F Reports annually with the SEC?
expected_answer: A Petroleum Reporting Entity generally must include, within its Summary of Reserves and Resources, a table using the MKT Form 12-1 format, and that table must be prepared “as of” a date that is no earlier than one month before the Summary of Reserves and Resources is disclosed. [#SRC:cd137cde-9ef8-4ed1-a401-6bf47f8ccb04] However, if the Petroleum Reporting Entity is required to file SEC compliant Forms 10-K and 20-F Reports annually with the SEC, it is not required to comply with Rule 12.14.1, which is the rule that imposes the MKT Form 12-1 table requirement and its timing condition. [#TGT:b249219a-57ec-4b15-be46-58475357c6c1] In practical terms, the compliance outcome depends on whether the entity falls into that SEC annual filing category: if it does not, it must include the MKT Form 12-1 table and ensure the “as of” date is within the one-month window before disclosure; if it does, the entity is exempt from the Rule 12.14.1 obligation and therefore does not have to meet that table-inclusion requirement or its associated “as of” date constraint under that rule. question: When the Regulator receives a request from a Host Regulator to conduct an on-site inspection relating to a Passported Fund, how should the Regulator determine whether it must permit and accompany the inspection versus when it may refuse to cooperate, particularly where enforcement action or judicial proceedings exist for the same conduct and the same Persons?
expected_answer: The Regulator’s default position, when it receives a Host Regulator request to carry out an on-site inspection connected to a Passported Fund, is to allow the inspection to proceed and to accompany the Host Regulator during the on-site visit. [#SRC:4b0be867-2636-45f5-aced-e11dd90b21c6] However, the Regulator may decline to act on a Host Regulator’s cooperation request for an inspection if specific parallel actions already exist concerning the same conduct and the same Persons. [#TGT:cfff46fb-8811-4ce9-a5a9-a4f42576ca0c] In practice, the Regulator should (i) confirm that the request is for an on-site inspection and that it is in relation to a Passported Fund, because that is the trigger for the permit-and-accompany approach; and then (ii) assess whether either refusal circumstance applies. [#SRC:4b0be867-2636-45f5-aced-e11dd90b21c6] The refusal circumstances are limited to cases where the Regulator has already started or finished enforcement action about the same conduct and the same Persons, or where judicial proceedings have already been started or finished about the same conduct and the same Persons. [#TGT:cfff46fb-8811-4ce9-a5a9-a4f42576ca0c] If neither of those circumstances applies, the Regulator should permit the inspection and accompany it during the on-site inspection. [#SRC:4b0be867-2636-45f5-aced-e11dd90b21c6]

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses forecast financial information under Rule 11.9.1 and treats its material economic assumptions as commercially sensitive, what specific statements and explanatory content must it provide, and how does that disclosure need to connect to the Production Target from which the forecast is derived (including the Rule 11.8.3 information)?
expected_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity that discloses forecast financial information under Rule 11.9.1 must still provide a complete, investor-understandable explanation of how its forecast is built, even if it treats material economic assumptions as commercially sensitive. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] In that scenario, it must (i) identify all material economic assumptions used, and (ii) if it considers those assumptions commercially sensitive, include an explicit statement that they are commercially sensitive and explain the methodology used to determine them. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] Where it relies on the relevant guidance, it must also explain why the information is considered a trade secret or commercially sensitive and disclose enough information—potentially using narrative rather than numbers—to allow investors to understand the methodology used to determine the factors and assumptions and the basis for reporting estimates of Ore Reserves. [#TGT:6435d936-1f1e-44c9-a788-2a4f4de44b80] Separately, the Rule 11.9.1 disclosure must identify the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived and include all information required by Rule 11.8.3 for that Production Target. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] The commercially sensitive treatment does not remove the need to provide sufficient methodological context for investors, including the basis for Ore Reserves estimates. [#TGT:6435d936-1f1e-44c9-a788-2a4f4de44b80]

(c) all other material assumptions utilised. (2) the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
debug_context.target_text: ORE RESERVES. In such cases, however, where a Mining Reporting Entity relies on the guidance set out in Rule 11.6.1(1)(a), it: a) must make a statement to the effect that its material economic assumptions are commercially sensitive; b) should explain why the information is considered a trade secret or commercially sensitive; and c) must disclose sufficient information (possibly in narrative rather than numerical form, where the numbers are commercially sensitive) in order for investors to understand the methodology it has used to determine these factors and assumptions, and the basis on which it is reporting the estimates of Ore Reserves.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity is sharing forecast financial information and says its key economic assumptions are commercially sensitive, what does it still have to tell investors, and what Production Target details must it include with the forecast?
expected_answer: Even if a Mining Reporting Entity says its key economic assumptions are commercially sensitive, it still has to give investors enough information to understand how it built the forecast and what it is based on. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] For the forecast disclosure, it must cover the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information, including all material economic assumptions and any other material assumptions. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] In the commercially sensitive case described for Ore Reserves reporting, it should also explain why the information is considered a trade secret or commercially sensitive and must still disclose sufficient information (which may be narrative rather than numerical) so investors can understand the methodology used to determine the relevant factors and assumptions and the basis for reporting estimates of Ore Reserves. [#TGT:6435d936-1f1e-44c9-a788-2a4f4de44b80] In addition, the forecast disclosure must state the Production Target from which the forecast is derived and include all the information that Rule 11.8.3 requires for that Production Target. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]

question: When an Applicant is seeking admission of Shares to the Official List, how should the Applicant frame its demonstration to the Regulator that it (and any Subsidiaries) has sufficient working capital for its present requirements, including the relevant time horizon the Regulator uses for assessing those present requirements and what must be addressed if working capital is not sufficient?
expected_answer: An Applicant seeking admission of Shares to the Official List must be prepared to satisfy the Regulator that it and any Subsidiaries have enough working capital available for its present requirements, and the Regulator’s benchmark for what counts as “present requirements” is that they are sufficient to support projected normal operations for 12 months starting from the date of admission to the Official List. [#TGT:c5ff4069-f284-4bb2-a504-11cf3694aa2e] [#SRC:b6eba295-6fe5-41d7-9392-46287b03796c] In practice, this means the Applicant’s working-capital case should be framed around a 12-month forward-looking period measured from admission, rather than an undefined or shorter interval. [#SRC:b6eba295-6fe5-41d7-9392-46287b03796c] The Applicant must cover both the Applicant itself and any Subsidiaries in that sufficiency assessment. [#TGT:c5ff4069-f284-4bb2-a504-11cf3694aa2e] If the Applicant cannot demonstrate sufficient working capital for those present requirements, it must instead explain to the Regulator how it proposes to provide the additional working capital needed, which necessarily ties back to meeting the 12-month projected normal operations horizon from admission. [#TGT:c5ff4069-f284-4bb2-a504-11cf3694aa2e] [#SRC:b6eba295-6fe5-41d7-9392-46287b03796c]

expected_answer: For an Applicant seeking admission of Shares to the Official List, the core requirement is to satisfy the Regulator that the Applicant and any Subsidiaries have sufficient working capital available for the Applicant’s present requirements. [#SRC:b6eba295-6fe5-41d7-9392-46287b03796c] Put together, the Applicant’s working-capital showing should be aligned to that 12-month-from-admission horizon and should cover both the Applicant and any Subsidiaries. question: Where a person is prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus, and an investor who acquired Securities suffers loss from an untrue or misleading statement or a material omission in that Prospectus, what publication-related steps (and timing relative to acquisition) can prevent that person from incurring liability for the loss, including the case where the issue is that an Expert was not competent or did not consent?
expected_answer: A person who is prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus can be liable to pay compensation to an acquirer of the relevant Securities for loss or damage caused by an untrue or misleading statement in the Prospectus, or by omitting a material matter that was required to be included. [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac] However, that person does not incur liability for loss in respect of the Securities if, before the Securities were acquired, either (i) a correction was published in a way intended to reach persons likely to acquire those Securities, or (ii) where the statement is of the type attributed to an Expert, the fact that the Expert was not competent or had not consented to inclusion of the attributed statement was published in that same attention-getting manner. [#SRC:70f8f138-3355-432a-88a1-3c58dd25b19b] Alternatively, liability is avoided if the person took all steps that it was reasonable to take to secure that publication and, on reasonable grounds, believed the publication had occurred before the Securities were acquired. [#SRC:70f8f138-3355-432a-88a1-3c58dd25b19b] The key linkage is that the compensation exposure tied to untrue/misleading statements or material omissions is addressed by timely, appropriately targeted publication (or reasonable efforts and belief of publication) occurring before acquisition. [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac] [#SRC:70f8f138-3355-432a-88a1-3c58dd25b19b]

debug_context.source_text: Without prejudice to (2) and (3), a Person does not incur any liability under section 70(1) of the FSMR for any loss in respect of any Securities caused by any statement or omission as is mentioned in that Article if: (a) before the Securities were acquired by any Person, a correction or, where the statement was such as is mentioned in (2)(c), the fact that the Expert was not competent or had not consented to the inclusion of the statement attributed to that Expert in the Prospectus had been published in a manner designed to bring to the attention of Persons likely to acquire the Securities in question; or (b) he took all such steps as it was reasonable for him to take to secure such publication and believed on reasonable grounds that such a publication had taken place before the Securities were acquired.
debug_context.target_text: Any person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus is liable to pay compensation to another person who has acquired Securities to which the Prospectus relates and who has suffered loss or damage arising from any untrue or misleading statement in the Prospectus or the omission from it of any material matter required to have been included in the Prospectus by or under these Regulations.

question: If someone is on the list in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus, and a buyer of the Securities loses money because the Prospectus had a misleading statement or left out a required material matter, what can that liable person do (and by when) to avoid liability—especially if the problem is about an Expert’s competence or consent?
expected_answer: If a person is prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus, that person can have to pay compensation to someone who acquired the Securities covered by the Prospectus and suffered loss or damage because the Prospectus contained an untrue or misleading statement or omitted a material matter that was required to be included. [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac] Even in that setting, the person avoids incurring liability for the loss if, before the Securities were acquired, a correction is published in a way meant to bring it to the attention of people likely to buy those Securities. [#SRC:70f8f138-3355-432a-88a1-3c58dd25b19b] If the issue is a statement attributed to an Expert, the same timing and publication approach can be used by publishing that the Expert was not competent or did not consent to having the attributed statement included in the Prospectus. [#SRC:70f8f138-3355-432a-88a1-3c58dd25b19b] A second route is available: the person can avoid liability if they took all steps that were reasonable to secure that publication and reasonably believed it had happened before the Securities were acquired. [#SRC:70f8f138-3355-432a-88a1-3c58dd25b19b] In short, the compensation risk tied to misleading statements or required omissions is addressed by timely publication (or reasonable efforts and belief of publication) before acquisition. [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac] [#SRC:70f8f138-3355-432a-88a1-3c58dd25b19b]

question: For a Mining Production Reporting Entity preparing its quarterly report, how should it satisfy the requirement to provide the Summary of Reserves and Resources at least once every 12 months, and what date constraint applies to the MKT Form 11-1 table included in that Summary when it is disclosed (including when the Summary is instead included in the annual report)?
expected_answer: A Mining Production Reporting Entity must ensure that, across its quarterly reporting cycle, it provides the Summary of Reserves and Resources at least once in every 12-month period, unless that Summary is instead provided in the Mining Reporting Entity’s annual report. [#SRC:a24b4f51-4c48-4846-bd22-d5f98dbad55b] When the Summary of Reserves and Resources is disclosed (whether via a quarterly report to meet the 12‑month cadence or via inclusion in the annual report), the Mining Reporting Entity’s Summary must contain a table in the format of MKT Form 11-1. [#TGT:dca099e1-1fc2-460e-8853-332c309ad9bd] The table must be prepared “as of” a date that is not earlier than one month before the disclosure date of the Summary of Reserves and Resources, meaning the table’s effective date must fall within the month leading up to the Summary’s disclosure. [#TGT:dca099e1-1fc2-460e-8853-332c309ad9bd] In addition, the quarterly report must state when the prior disclosure of this 12‑monthly Summary occurred and when the next such disclosure is expected to occur, so readers can track the timing of the required Summary disclosures. [#SRC:a24b4f51-4c48-4846-bd22-d5f98dbad55b]

question: Where a Mining Reporting Entity has already made a disclosure that complied with Rule 11.9.2 and later makes a subsequent disclosure of forecast financial information derived from a Production Target, under what conditions may the subsequent disclosure omit the Rule 11.9.2 information, and what specific “at least equally prominent, and proximate” cautionary statement(s) must be included if the underlying Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources or is based in part on an Exploration Target?
expected_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity may leave out the Rule 11.9.2 content in a later disclosure of forecast financial information derived from a Production Target only if the later disclosure (i) points back to an earlier disclosure that itself complied with Rule 11.9.2 and (ii) confirms that the material assumptions from that initial disclosure still apply and have not materially changed. [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4] In addition, the later disclosure must include specific cautionary language, presented at least equally prominently and close to the forecast financial information, when certain Production Target bases apply. [#SRC:05f73fd5-8864-472c-bb5f-16a24a80dae4] If the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, the required proximate cautionary statement is the one set out for that scenario, warning that geological confidence is low, further work is needed, there is no certainty the Production Target will be met or realised, and that investors should not rely solely on the Production Target when making investment decisions. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] If the Production Target is based in part on an Exploration Target, the required proximate cautionary statement is the one explaining that the Exploration Target is conceptual, exploration is insufficient to determine a Mineral Resource, and there is no certainty further work will result in Mineral Resources or that the Production Target will be realised. question: When considering whether to withdraw an Approval for a Controlled Function on the basis that the person is not fit and proper, what specific factors must the Regulator take into account, and how do those factors connect to the particular Controlled Function and the firm’s markets?
expected_answer: If the Regulator is considering withdrawing an Approval given under section 45 because it considers the person is not a fit and proper person to perform the Controlled Function in question, it should ground that assessment in the broader set of relevant matters it uses when deciding whether to exercise its power under section 46 of FSMR. [#TGT:3770f510-3010-431b-9ccf-af63b6825554] In practice, this means the fit-and-proper conclusion for the specific Controlled Function should be informed by multiple, case-specific considerations rather than a single indicator. [#SRC:ca8110b0-dfaa-415f-9b47-4366ee85db7c] In forming its view, the Regulator will have regard to all relevant matters, including: (i) the criteria for assessing the fitness and propriety of an Approved Person (as referenced in GEN 5.2.9 and section 2.3 of GPM); (ii) any offences or findings involving dishonesty, fraud, or a financial crime by the Approved Person; and (iii) whether enforcement action should be taken, or has already been taken, against the Approved Person by the Regulator or other enforcement agencies. [#SRC:ca8110b0-dfaa-415f-9b47-4366ee85db7c] It will also consider contextual factors that link directly to the withdrawal decision for the Controlled Function in question, including the particular Controlled Function the Approved Person is or was performing, the nature and activities of the firm concerned, the markets in which the firm operates, and the severity of the risk the individual poses to consumers and to confidence in the ADGM financial system. [#SRC:ca8110b0-dfaa-415f-9b47-4366ee85db7c] These factors collectively support whether the person should continue to hold the section 45 Approval for that Controlled Function. [#TGT:3770f510-3010-431b-9ccf-af63b6825554]

question: When designing the strategy’s system for controlling Liquidity Risk that enables the Authorised Person to implement the requirements in Rule 9.2.6, what specific capabilities and governance/approval features must that system include for the Authorised Person’s Governing Body and senior management, including in relation to limits set under Rule 9.2.7 and operating procedures?

question: When an Authorised Person is determining the amount of minority interests of a Subsidiary that is eligible for inclusion in consolidated CET1 Capital, how does the 6.0% CET1 Capital requirement tied to the Subsidiary’s Total Risk Exposure Amount connect to the way Total Risk Exposure Amount must be calculated (including any specified components and adjustments)?
expected_answer: In determining eligible minority interests for inclusion in consolidated CET1 Capital, the Authorised Person must apply a subtraction mechanism that depends on a 6.0% CET1 Capital requirement calculated by reference to the Subsidiary’s Total Risk Exposure Amount, so the Total Risk Exposure Amount must be computed using the required component-sum approach before it can be used in that 6.0% test. [#SRC:dc108b2b-6b01-433d-9e1b-09159c329ab0] Specifically, the eligible amount is derived by taking the minority interests of the Subsidiary and subtracting an amount equal to: (i) a defined CET1 Capital “excess/shortfall” measure for the Subsidiary (CET1 Capital of the Subsidiary minus the lesser of two alternative required CET1 amounts, each built from a 6.0% CET1 requirement plus the Combined Buffer Requirement), multiplied by (ii) the minority-interest percentage of all CET1 instruments plus related retained earnings and share premium accounts. [#SRC:dc108b2b-6b01-433d-9e1b-09159c329ab0] To supply the Total Risk Exposure Amount input to the 6.0% requirement referenced in that minority-interest calculation, the Authorised Person must calculate Total Risk Exposure Amount (after taking into account Rule 3.5.8) as the sum of Credit RWA, and the risk exposure amounts associated with Market Risk, Operational Risk, CVA Risk, and (where applicable) Displaced Commercial Risk (calculated in accordance with IFR Rule 5.4.5). [#TGT:25b7dc85-4ef9-4582-864d-fcfc50e1578e]

question: How must an Authorised Person determine the risk weight for (i) a corporate-asset-class CR Exposure that is unrated (no external credit assessment by a recognised external credit rating agency) and (ii) an unrated short term CR Exposure to a corporate where another short term issue-specific external credit assessment for that corporate attracts a 50% or 100% risk weight, taking into account the corporate risk-weight table and the higher-of comparison to the central government risk weight?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must apply the corporate-asset-class risk-weight table as the baseline method for corporate exposures, including the table’s unrated category, but must also apply the specific higher-of and floor rules that override that baseline in the circumstances described. [#TGT:ee286214-80b1-480f-8be1-055c442795e4] For a corporate CR Exposure that has no external credit assessment by a recognised external credit rating agency, the risk weight is the higher of (i) the risk weight determined under the table referenced for such exposures and (ii) the risk weight applicable to a CR Exposure to the central government of the jurisdiction where the corporate is incorporated or established. [#SRC:f80ad0a8-f280-43e0-a71b-74b00c8175ad] Separately, where there is a short term corporate exposure with an issue-specific external credit assessment that results in a 50% or 100% risk weight, any unrated short term CR Exposure to the same corporate must not be assigned a risk weight below 100%, even if the table’s unrated row would otherwise be used as the starting point. [#SRC:f80ad0a8-f280-43e0-a71b-74b00c8175ad] In practice, this means the table’s unrated risk weight (100%) will typically align with the minimum required for those unrated short term exposures, while the higher-of test can still require a higher figure if the relevant central government risk weight is higher. [#TGT:ee286214-80b1-480f-8be1-055c442795e4] [#SRC:f80ad0a8-f280-43e0-a71b-74b00c8175ad]

If a short term CR Exposure in the corporate asset class with an issue specific external credit assessment: (a) attracts a risk weight of 50% or 100%, then the Authorised Person must apply a risk weight of not lower than 100% to any unrated short term CR Exposure to the same corporate; or (b) attracts a risk weight of 150%, then the Authorised Person must apply a risk weight of 150% to any unrated CR Exposure (whether long term or short term) to the same corporate.

question: For an Authorised Person exposed to the risk of foreign currencies and gold under any Islamic Contract, when is it not required to calculate its Foreign Exchange Risk Capital Requirement, and what specific quantitative tests and definitions must be applied to determine that outcome?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person that is exposed to the risk of foreign currencies and gold under any Islamic Contract is generally required to calculate its Foreign Exchange Risk Capital Requirement in accordance with PRU Rule 5.6.2, but it is not required to perform that calculation if it meets both exemption conditions stated for when the requirement does not apply. [#SRC:6a51fe1f-d0d3-42f6-b369-4e9345775696] To determine whether the exemption is available, the Authorised Person must apply two quantitative tests that are each measured against Capital Resources (as defined in Chapter 3). [#TGT:79d3cd2f-93a5-4f25-af68-c67e7fd4cb97] First, it must compute its “Foreign Currency business” as the greater of (i) the sum of its gross long positions and (ii) the sum of its gross short positions across all Foreign Currencies, and confirm that this amount does not exceed 100% of its Capital Resources. [#TGT:79d3cd2f-93a5-4f25-af68-c67e7fd4cb97] Second, it must confirm that its overall net open position (as defined in Rule A6.4.4) does not exceed 2% of its Capital Resources. [#TGT:79d3cd2f-93a5-4f25-af68-c67e7fd4cb97] If either threshold is exceeded, the Authorised Person must proceed to calculate the Foreign Exchange Risk Capital Requirement under PRU Rule 5.6.2 for the relevant exposure under the Islamic Contract. [#SRC:6a51fe1f-d0d3-42f6-b369-4e9345775696]

question: When an Authorised Person chooses to reduce the value of its Exposures using Collateral, how must it determine the Collateral amount to recognise if the Collateral’s value under a stress scenario is below the value otherwise applied under Rule 4.15.12 for purposes of this Section?
expected_answer: When an Authorised Person elects to reduce the value of its Exposures by recognising Collateral for purposes of this Section, it must ensure the recognised Collateral amount reflects the stress-scenario constraint described for Collateral valuation. [#TGT:9ae2763f-2e1a-4afb-ac8e-f57ce03a81c3] Specifically, if the Collateral’s value under the stress scenario is lower than the value that would otherwise be applied under Rule 4.15.12, the Authorised Person must use the lower stress-scenario value when determining the Exposure value for this Section. [#SRC:50586097-115d-49d1-9dd6-462b2d08e3f3] This linkage matters because the TARGET provision permits discretionary exposure reduction by “the amount of Collateral held against its Exposures” (subject to the Collateral being of a listed type under the FCSA and FCCA approaches and meeting Section 4.13 requirements), but the SOURCE provision constrains the valuation input used in the Exposure value calculation when stress-scenario Collateral values are lower. [#TGT:9ae2763f-2e1a-4afb-ac8e-f57ce03a81c3] Accordingly, even where Collateral is otherwise eligible to be recognised as a credit risk mitigation under this Section, the amount that effectively reduces the Exposure value must be based on the lower of the stress-scenario Collateral value and the value applied under Rule 4.15.12. [#SRC:50586097-115d-49d1-9dd6-462b2d08e3f3]

For the purposes of this Section, an Authorised Person may reduce the value of its Exposures, at its discretion, by any one or more of the following: (a) the amount of any specific provision made, where the provision relates to the risk of a credit loss occurring on that Exposure and is not held as part of a general provision or reserve against its Credit Risks; (b) Netting its claims on and liabilities to a Counterparty, provided that the conditions in Section 4.13 of CRM are met; (c) the amount of Collateral held against its Exposures, where that Collateral is of a type listed based on the FCSA and FCCA approaches and meeting the requirements under Section 4.13; (d) the amount of any eligible guarantees as permitted under Section 4.13.9; (e) the value of a Credit Derivative, where the Credit Derivative is an instrument included in Rule 4.13.11 and the transaction meets the conditions set out in that Section; and (f) the effects of transactions transferring Credit Risks from the Authorised Person to another party through securitisation, provided that the conditions in Section 4.14 are met.

question: How must an Authorised Person align its systems-and-controls responsibilities for operating and monitoring a Spot Commodity Auction Platform with the participant safeguards that require transparent rules, transaction recording, information availability, and measures against Market Abuse or Financial Crime?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must combine operational capability and risk/monitoring controls with participant-facing safeguards so that the Spot Commodity Auction Platform is both technically well-run and conducted in an orderly manner that protects participants. [#SRC:4056cfbb-4512-4279-a074-7577632f9653] [#TGT:1970af23-583d-4eee-8691-1db4637d6329] In practice, this means the Authorised Person’s arrangements must demonstrate it can operate the platform, manage risks, and monitor participant bids and transactions, while also ensuring the business conducted on the platform is orderly and protective through specified safeguards. [#SRC:4056cfbb-4512-4279-a074-7577632f9653] [#TGT:1970af23-583d-4eee-8691-1db4637d6329] The required alignment includes: (i) operating and being responsible for the full technical operation (including contingency arrangements for disruption) in a way that supports fair and orderly auctions under transparent rules and procedures; (ii) monitoring bids and transactions alongside arrangements for recording executed transactions; (iii) managing platform risks while adopting measures that reduce use of the facilities for purposes connected with Market Abuse or Financial Crime and facilitate detection/monitoring of their influence; and (iv) ensuring arrangements exist for relevant information to be made available to participants, consistent with the Authorised Person’s overall responsibility for platform operation. [#SRC:4056cfbb-4512-4279-a074-7577632f9653] [#TGT:1970af23-583d-4eee-8691-1db4637d6329]

question: If an Authorised Person submits a Regulatory Filing after it becomes due, what are the compliance consequences, including the specific late payment fee amount and any additional regulatory response beyond the fee?
expected_answer: Submitting a Regulatory Filing after the date it is due results in a breach by the Authorised Person, and it also triggers a mandatory late payment fee payable to the Regulator. [#SRC:2932ae57-5946-46b4-8ac2-e41d4d145bcc] Specifically, when the filing is submitted after the due date, the Authorised Person must pay the Regulator $500 as a late payment fee relating to that Regulatory Filing. [#TGT:44e2c477-1fbd-46c4-9391-046045a5b105] In addition to that fee (which is imposed under Rule 1.2.7), the Regulator is not limited to charging the fee and may take further action in response to the late submission. [#SRC:2932ae57-5946-46b4-8ac2-e41d4d145bcc] The key precondition for both outcomes is the same timing condition: the Regulatory Filing is submitted after the due date (i.e., after it becomes due). [#SRC:2932ae57-5946-46b4-8ac2-e41d4d145bcc] [#TGT:44e2c477-1fbd-46c4-9391-046045a5b105]

For Designated Non-Financial Businesses or Professions, Rule 1.2.7 relates to the AML Return, as required by Rule 4.6.1 in the Anti-Money Laundering and Sanctions Rules and Guidance Rulebook.

question: For an Authorised Person that is both (i) Managing a PSIA that is an Unrestricted PSIA and (ii) incurring Large Exposures in its Non Trading Book (and, where relevant, Trading Book), what is the maximum percentage limit that applies in each regime, and how does the applicable capital base differ between the Large Exposures limit and the PSIA Exposure limit (including the financing conditions that change the PSIA percentage)?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must apply two distinct percentage caps that are triggered by different exposure concepts and measured against different capital bases. For Large Exposures, the Authorised Person is prohibited from incurring any Large Exposures in its Non Trading Book (and, subject to the stated Trading Book condition) that, after reflecting any eligible CRM, exceed 25% of its Tier 1. [#SRC:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f] Separately, when the Authorised Person is Managing a PSIA that is an Unrestricted PSIA, it must ensure its Exposure to a Counterparty (including Connected Counterparty groupings and groups of Closely Related Counterparties) does not exceed specified percentages of its Capital Resources, with the applicable percentage depending on how the exposure is financed. [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f] In practice: - The Large Exposures cap is 25% and is measured against Tier 1, after eligible CRM is taken into account. [#SRC:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f] - The Unrestricted PSIA exposure cap is measured against Capital Resources and is 25% where the exposure is financed by the Authorised Person’s Capital Resources or Unrestricted PSIAs. [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f] - The Unrestricted PSIA exposure cap increases to 40% where the exposure is financed by an aggregate of the Authorised Person’s own Capital Resources and Unrestricted PSIAs. [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f] Accordingly, compliance requires tracking both the Tier 1-based Large Exposures ceiling and the Capital Resources-based PSIA exposure ceilings, applying the correct financing condition for the PSIA limit. [#SRC:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f] [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f]

question: If an Authorised Person is Managing a PSIA that is an Unrestricted PSIA, and it also has a Large Exposure in its Non Trading Book (or Trading Book), what percentage limits apply, and what do those limits get measured against (Tier 1 vs Capital Resources) including when the PSIA limit can be 25% or 40%?
expected_answer: Two different limits can apply, and they use different measurement bases. For Large Exposures, an Authorised Person must not incur a Large Exposure in its Non Trading Book (and, under the stated Trading Book condition) that exceeds 25% of its Tier 1 once the effect of any eligible CRM has been included. [#SRC:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f] For exposures arising when the Authorised Person is Managing a PSIA that is an Unrestricted PSIA, the Authorised Person must keep its Exposure to a Counterparty (including Connected Counterparty and closely related/connected groupings) within set percentages of its Capital Resources, and the percentage depends on how the exposure is financed. [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f] Specifically: - Large Exposures are capped at 25% of Tier 1, calculated after eligible CRM is taken into account. [#SRC:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f] - For Unrestricted PSIA exposures, the cap is 25% of Capital Resources if the exposure is financed by the Authorised Person’s Capital Resources or Unrestricted PSIAs. [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f] - The Unrestricted PSIA cap becomes 40% of Capital Resources if the exposure is financed by a combined pool (an aggregate) of the Authorised Person’s own Capital Resources and Unrestricted PSIAs. [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f] So, you must check both: the Tier 1-based 25% Large Exposures ceiling (after eligible CRM) and the Capital Resources-based PSIA exposure ceiling (25% or 40% depending on financing). [#SRC:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f] [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f]

question: Where the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, how may the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider contractually modify the rule on withdrawal of consent for an individual Payment Transaction, and how does that modification interact with the point in time tied to revocation under Rule 19.14.3?
expected_answer: If the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider can, by written agreement, disapply the specified withdrawal-of-consent provisions (Rule 19.10.1 (3) and (4)). [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] In that case, the default position described for consent withdrawal—namely that the Payer may withdraw consent to an individual Payment Transaction up to the point when the Payment Order is no longer capable of being revoked under Rule 19.14.3—would not apply to the extent it depends on those disapplied provisions. question: Where a Fund Manager identifies a material change, error, or omission after making the notification under Rule 3.1.2 but before Promotion begins in a Host Jurisdiction, what are the Fund Manager’s immediate notification duties, what must the Regulator do with that information, and how can that same type of issue lead to the Regulator taking measures up to de-registration if it results in non-compliance?
expected_answer: Between the notification under Rule 3.1.2 and the start of Promotion in a Host Jurisdiction, the Fund Manager must notify the Regulator in writing without delay if it becomes aware of any material change, error, or omission that is reasonably likely to be relevant to that notification. [#TGT:001f1eee-febb-4f75-97f2-429cb0f2fdd6] After receiving that notice, the Regulator must promptly pass all relevant details of the material change, error, or omission to the relevant Host Regulator. [#TGT:001f1eee-febb-4f75-97f2-429cb0f2fdd6] Separately, if a material change, error, or omission of the type referred to in Rule 3.1.9 results in the Fund Manager no longer complying with applicable legislation (including these Rules), the Regulator is required to take all due measures. [#SRC:05992880-f8db-4ec8-8e02-79ab08521207] Those measures can include, where necessary, de-registering the Private Fund from the Register of Passported Funds in accordance with these Rules, and the Regulator may also act where it otherwise considers action necessary and appropriate in the circumstances. [#SRC:05992880-f8db-4ec8-8e02-79ab08521207] In practice, the Fund Manager’s prompt written notice during the pre-Promotion window enables the Regulator’s onward communication to the Host Regulator while also informing whether the issue triggers due measures for non-compliance, potentially up to de-registration. [#TGT:001f1eee-febb-4f75-97f2-429cb0f2fdd6] [#SRC:05992880-f8db-4ec8-8e02-79ab08521207]

question: Where Confidential Information is sought for use as evidence in civil litigation by a party other than a governmental or regulatory authority, what consents are required before the Regulator may permit disclosure, and how do those consents align with the consent requirements imposed on a primary recipient (and downstream recipients) before any disclosure can occur?
expected_answer: In the civil-litigation scenario described—where Confidential Information is requested by a party that is not a governmental or regulatory authority—the Regulator should only permit disclosure if the required prior consents are obtained, and those consents mirror the consent gate that applies to a primary recipient and anyone receiving the information from them. [#SRC:d5f06cc2-641f-47b8-979d-9a02192e7343] Specifically, the Regulator requires prior consent from (a) the person from whom the Confidential Information was obtained and (b) where different, the person to whom the duty of confidentiality is owed. [#SRC:d5f06cc2-641f-47b8-979d-9a02192e7343] In parallel, the disclosure prohibition applicable to a primary recipient (and any person who obtains the information directly or indirectly from that primary recipient) is lifted only with prior consent from (a) the person from whom the primary recipient obtained the information and (b) if different, the person to whom the information relates. [#TGT:db8084a6-8fbb-4197-9e29-8bd14a43f866] Practically, this means the compliance check is two-pronged in both passages: identify the original source of the information and identify the separate person who is protected by the confidentiality obligation/relationship to the information, and secure both consents before any disclosure is allowed. [#SRC:d5f06cc2-641f-47b8-979d-9a02192e7343] [#TGT:db8084a6-8fbb-4197-9e29-8bd14a43f866]

debug_context.source_text: In other circumstances, such as where Confidential Information is sought by a party other than a governmental or regulatory authority, such as, for example, as evidence for use in civil litigation, the Regulator will require prior consent of— (a) the person from whom the Confidential Information was obtained; and, (b) if different, the person to whom the duty of confidentiality is owed (paragraphs 198(1)(a) and (b)), consistent with its general duty of confidentiality, as contemplated by section 198(1) of the FSMR.
debug_context.target_text: Confidential Information must not be disclosed by a primary recipient, or by any person obtaining the information directly or indirectly from a primary recipient, without the prior consent of— (a) the person from whom the primary recipient obtained the information; and (b) if different, the person to whom it relates.

expected_answer: For a request connected to civil litigation made by a party that is not a governmental or regulatory authority, the Regulator will only allow the Confidential Information to be used or shared if it first gets the required consents. [#SRC:d5f06cc2-641f-47b8-979d-9a02192e7343] Those consents must come from two places: (a) the person from whom the Confidential Information was obtained and (b) if that is a different person, the person to whom the duty of confidentiality is owed. [#SRC:d5f06cc2-641f-47b8-979d-9a02192e7343] The same two-step consent structure also governs disclosure by a primary recipient and by anyone who receives the information from a primary recipient (whether directly or indirectly): they must not disclose unless they have prior consent from (a) the person from whom the primary recipient obtained the information and (b) if different, the person to whom the information relates. [#TGT:db8084a6-8fbb-4197-9e29-8bd14a43f866] So, in both settings, you must identify the original provider of the information and also identify the separate person protected by the confidentiality duty/relationship to the information, and obtain both consents before disclosure. [#SRC:d5f06cc2-641f-47b8-979d-9a02192e7343] [#TGT:db8084a6-8fbb-4197-9e29-8bd14a43f866]

question: How should a PFP Operator align its six-year record-retention duties with its obligation to publish due-diligence-related information to PFP Clients on the Private Financing Platform, particularly where the due diligence is undertaken under Rule 18.4.1?
expected_answer: A PFP Operator must both (i) keep specified records for at least six years and (ii) publish specified due-diligence information for PFP Clients on the Private Financing Platform it operates; the two obligations should be implemented together so the published due-diligence description is supportable by retained evidence. [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7] [#TGT:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f] The record-keeping duty applies to the due diligence undertaken in accordance with Rule 18.4.1, as well as to all disclosures made under Rules 18.5.1 and 18.5.2 and documentation exchanged between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect. [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7] Separately, the publication duty includes making available to PFP Clients the methodology of, and limitations to, the due diligence undertaken by the PFP Operator concerning each PFP Prospect identified on the platform, in accordance with Rule 18.4.1. [#TGT:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f] Practically, the PFP Operator should retain, for the six-year minimum, the underlying due-diligence work and related communications so it can substantiate the published methodology/limitations and keep a consistent compliance trail across what is disclosed/published and what is documented. [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7] [#TGT:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f]

question: When a PFP Operator uses a Body Corporate as an intermediary between a PFP Client and a PFP Prospect, what combined requirements apply to (i) publishing governance/operational arrangements and (ii) retaining transaction-related documentation, and what is the minimum retention period?
expected_answer: Where a PFP Operator uses a Body Corporate as an intermediary, it must address both transparency to PFP Clients via platform publication and documentary retention for a defined period. [#TGT:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f] [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7] On the publication side, the PFP Operator must ensure information available to PFP Clients is published on the Private Financing Platform, including the governance and operational arrangements of any Body Corporate used as an intermediary between a PFP Client and any PFP Prospect. [#TGT:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f] On the record-retention side, the PFP Operator must maintain and keep, for a minimum of six years, all documentation between PFP Client(s), any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator to facilitate a transaction, and the PFP Prospect. [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7] Read together, this means the PFP Operator should (i) publish the Body Corporate’s governance/operational arrangements for PFP Clients to review and (ii) preserve the related transaction documentation involving that Body Corporate for at least six years, so the intermediary structure described to clients is supported by a retained record of how the intermediary was used in practice. question: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation and relies on the carve-out from Rule 11.2.1(1), what specific disclosures must it include in its Summary of Reserves and Resources if it has previously disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates under Rule 11.7.3 that have not later been disclosed as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard, including the additional disclosures triggered after three years from first disclosure under Rule 11.7.4?
expected_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity that discloses material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation may avoid complying with Rule 11.2.1(1) only if it instead complies with Rules 11.7.2, 11.7.3, 11.7.4, and 11.7.6. [#SRC:ec29aad6-3d7b-4466-a6ab-0022accf5f26] Where the entity has previously disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates in compliance with Rule 11.7.3 and those estimates have not subsequently been disclosed as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard, it must include specified information in its Summary of Reserves and Resources. [#TGT:18d4dbe3-8555-4fe0-94e6-91c8b92b5907] Specifically, it must disclose the steps taken to evaluate the previously disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates, the status of any further evaluation and/or exploration work needed to verify and disclose them as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves under the Mining Reporting Standard, and the status of the proposed source of funding for that evaluation and/or exploration work (including the funding status referenced to Rule 11.7.6(1)(b)). [#TGT:18d4dbe3-8555-4fe0-94e6-91c8b92b5907] In addition, if more than three years have passed since the first disclosure of the Non-Equivalent Estimates under Rule 11.7.4 and they still have not been verified and disclosed as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves under a Mining Reporting Standard, the Summary must also explain why verification and disclosure have not occurred and state the entity’s intention, proposed timetable, and proposed source of funding for verifying and disclosing them. [#TGT:18d4dbe3-8555-4fe0-94e6-91c8b92b5907]

question: Under what conditions may a letter of credit be treated as a qualifying letter of credit and included as eligible capital, and what specific characteristics must the instrument and issuing bank have to satisfy the referenced Rule 3.1.4(2) requirements?
expected_answer: A letter of credit may be treated as a qualifying letter of credit only if two conditions are met: it must satisfy the detailed requirements in Rule 3.1.4(2), and the Regulator must allow it to be included as eligible capital under Rule 2(2)(a). [#SRC:09531ba6-44f7-4113-bdf4-943582ecc05c] To meet Rule 3.1.4(2), the letter of credit must be unconditional and irrevocable, must not include any subordination clause, and must be legally enforceable in ADGM or another jurisdiction the Regulator approves for this purpose. [#TGT:27f296e6-bc33-466d-b0c3-d6ff38a741d3] It also must not be cancellable or amendable without the consent of all parties, must be for a fixed amount, and must be renewable annually. question: When an Authorised Person conducts a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets, how must references to “Client Investments” in GEN be interpreted, and what is the practical compliance effect of that interpretation on the scope of FSRA Rulebook provisions (including any specific COBS chapters identified) that use the term “Client Investments”?
expected_answer: For an Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets, any reference to “Client Investments” in GEN must be treated as including “Virtual Asset” or “Virtual Assets”, as applicable. [#TGT:8a2c66a4-0927-4dc2-ab8b-2b5985961c3d] The practical compliance effect is that rules across the FSRA Rulebooks that rely on the term “Client Investments” are expanded so they also apply to Virtual Assets, because COBS Rule 17.1.3 operates to read “Client Investments” in GEN as including Virtual Assets in this context. [#SRC:e2ff5c54-c76a-4e57-b74c-a8458fc98a54] As a result, the regulated firm should treat Virtual Assets as within the scope of the various rules that use “Client Investments” throughout the FSRA Rulebooks, rather than limiting those rules to non-virtual asset holdings. [#SRC:e2ff5c54-c76a-4e57-b74c-a8458fc98a54] This expansion is highlighted as capturing Virtual Assets in particular within the rules contained in Chapters 3 and 6 of COBS, meaning those COBS chapter requirements that are triggered by “Client Investments” should be applied on the basis that Virtual Assets are included. [#SRC:e2ff5c54-c76a-4e57-b74c-a8458fc98a54] In short, the GEN term-mapping for “Client Investments” to Virtual Assets is mandatory for the Authorised Person’s virtual-asset regulated activity, and it drives broader rule applicability across the FSRA Rulebooks, including the specified COBS chapters. [#TGT:8a2c66a4-0927-4dc2-ab8b-2b5985961c3d] [#SRC:e2ff5c54-c76a-4e57-b74c-a8458fc98a54]

question: When a Third Party Provider proposes to change the information that the Governing Contract must contain about communication—specifically the Customer’s right to receive revised terms and other information—what must the Third Party Provider do, and by when, before the change takes effect?
expected_answer: If the Third Party Provider proposes to change information that is required to be included in the Governing Contract—such as the communication-related item describing the Customer’s right to receive revised terms of the Governing Contract and other information in accordance with Rule 20.2.5—this is treated as a proposed change to information that the contract must contain. [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] In that case, the Third Party Provider must provide the proposed change to the Customer no later than two months before the date the change is intended to take effect. [#SRC:29dd8b53-d149-4830-a218-06218e05b53f] This timing obligation applies both where the change is to the existing terms of the Governing Contract and where it is to the specified contractual information that must be included in the contract. [#SRC:29dd8b53-d149-4830-a218-06218e05b53f] Accordingly, for a change affecting the contract’s communication section (including the Customer’s stated right to receive revised terms and other information), the compliance action is to deliver the proposed revised information to the Customer at least two months in advance of the effective date. [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] [#SRC:29dd8b53-d149-4830-a218-06218e05b53f]

Subject to Rule 20.2.7, any proposed changes to: (a) the existing terms of the Governing Contract; or (b) the information specified in Rule 20.2.2, must be provided by the Third Party Provider to the Customer no later than two months before the date on which they are to take effect.
debug_context.target_text: Unless otherwise agreed in writing between a Third Party Provider and their Customer, the Governing Contract between the Third Party Provider and their Customers must contain the following information – (a) about the Third Party Provider: (i) the name of the Third Party Provider; (ii) the address and contact details of the Third Party Provider’s office in ADGM; (iii) the name of the Regulator of the Third Party Provider, and details of the Third Party Provider’s Financial Service Permission; (b) about the Third Party Services: (i) a description of the main characteristics of the Third Party Services to be provided; (ii) the information or unique identifier that must be provided by the Customer in order for a Third Party Transaction to occur; (iii) the form and procedure for giving consent to a Third Party Transaction; (iv) the time of receipt of a Third Party Transaction; (v) the maximum time taken for the Third Party Services to be provided; and (vi) any limits for the use of the Third Party Services; (c) about charges and exchange rates: (i) details of all charges payable by the Customer to the Third Party Provider, including those connected to information which is provided or made available and, where applicable, a breakdown of the amounts of all charges; (ii) where relevant, details of the exchange rates to be applied or, if Reference Exchange Rates are to be used, the method of calculating the relevant date for determining such Reference Exchange Rates; (iii) where relevant and if agreed, the application of changes in Reference Exchange Rates and information requirements relating to any such changes; (d) about communication: (i) the means of communication agreed between the parties for the transmission of information or notifications including, where relevant, any technical requirements for the Customer’s equipment and software for receipt of the information or notifications; (ii) the manner in which and frequency with which information under this Chapter is to be provided or made available; (iii) what information relating to the Customer will be transferred to the Customer’s Financial Institution as part of a Third Party Transaction; (iv) the Customer’s right to receive the revised terms of the Governing Contract and any other information in accordance with Rule 20.2.5; (e) about safeguards and corrective measures: (i) how and within what period of time the Customer must notify the Third Party Provider of any unauthorised or incorrectly executed Third Party Transaction; (ii) the secure procedure by which the Third Party Provider will contact the Customer in the event of suspected or actual fraud or security threats; (iii) where relevant, the conditions under which the Third Party Provider proposes to reserve the right to stop or prevent a Third Party Transaction from being executed; (iv) the Customer’s liability under Rule 20.12.6 including details of any limits on such liability; (v) the Third Party Provider’s liability for unauthorised Third Party Transactions under Rule 20.12.5; (vi) the conditions for the payment of any refund to the Customer under this Chapter (f) about changes to and termination of the contractual arrangement: (i) where relevant, the proposed terms under which the Customer will be deemed to have accepted changes to the Governing Contract in accordance with Rule 20.2.6, unless they notify the Third Party Provider that they do not accept such changes before the proposed date of their entry into force; (ii) the duration of the Governing Contract; (iii) where relevant, the right of the Customer to terminate the Governing Contract and any agreements relating to termination in accordance with Rule 20.2.6. (g) about redress: (i) any contractual clauses on the law applicable to the Governing Contract and the competent courts; and (ii) the availability of any alternative dispute resolution procedures, if applicable, for the Customer and the methods for having access to them.
