question: When an Authorised Person is applying the arrears-day thresholds for classifying Exposures (special mention, substandard, doubtful, loss), how must the Authorised Person ensure that any Evergreening exercise involving refinancing of past due credits does not inappropriately improve the classification category, including for impaired credits?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person should classify Exposures using the stated arrears-day bands for the four categories and, when considering Evergreening treatment, must ensure refinancing does not lead to an upgrade in classification. [#SRC:2dd83781-93a2-4d56-a3fc-bf4665f983d5] Specifically, the classification framework contemplates that loans contractually in arrears for at least 30, 60, 90–120, and 120–180 days are treated as special mention, substandard, doubtful, and loss, respectively, and the Authorised Person is expected to apply those thresholds when determining the category. [#SRC:2dd83781-93a2-4d56-a3fc-bf4665f983d5] In parallel, where the Authorised Person undertakes an Evergreening exercise that involves refinancing past due credits, that refinancing must not cause the credits to be placed into a higher (i.e., better) classification category than would otherwise apply under the arrears-based approach. [#TGT:fc4bcf60-fc4a-4cd8-9848-a2bbcaaef228] This constraint is particularly strict for impaired credits: they cannot be refinanced for the purpose of reclassifying them as standard or special mention credits. [#TGT:fc4bcf60-fc4a-4cd8-9848-a2bbcaaef228] Accordingly, the Authorised Person should apply the arrears-day classification and then check that any refinancing done as Evergreening does not override that outcome by producing an upward reclassification, including any attempt to move impaired credits into standard or special mention. [#SRC:2dd83781-93a2-4d56-a3fc-bf4665f983d5] [#TGT:fc4bcf60-fc4a-4cd8-9848-a2bbcaaef228]

debug_context.source_text: With respect to the ratings above, Authorised Persons should consider the following Exposures as being classified: (i) special mention; (ii) substandard; (iii) doubtful; and (iv) loss where the loans are contractually in arrears for a minimum number of days of 30, 60, 90 – 120 and 120 – 180 days respectively. Authorised Persons should also consider the treatments as set out in Rule 4.5.7 (Evergreening).
debug_context.target_text: Any Evergreening exercise involving refinancing of past due credits must not result in their being classified as a higher category. In particular, impaired credits cannot be refinanced with the aim of classifying them as standard or special mention credits.

question: If a loan is past due and you are classifying it based on how many days it is in arrears (30, 60, 90–120, 120–180), what should you do if the credit is refinanced as part of an Evergreening exercise—can that refinancing move it into a better category, especially if it is impaired?
expected_answer: You should first classify the Exposure using the arrears-day thresholds and then ensure that any Evergreening refinancing does not improve that classification. [#SRC:2dd83781-93a2-4d56-a3fc-bf4665f983d5] The arrears-based approach indicates that loans contractually in arrears for at least 30 days fall into special mention, at least 60 days into substandard, 90–120 days into doubtful, and 120–180 days into loss, and Authorised Persons are expected to use these bands when classifying Exposures. [#SRC:2dd83781-93a2-4d56-a3fc-bf4665f983d5] If the past due credit is refinanced as part of an Evergreening exercise, that refinancing is not allowed to result in the credit being classified in a higher (better) category than it would otherwise be in. [#TGT:fc4bcf60-fc4a-4cd8-9848-a2bbcaaef228] There is also a clear prohibition for impaired credits: they cannot be refinanced with the goal of reclassifying them as standard or special mention credits. [#TGT:fc4bcf60-fc4a-4cd8-9848-a2bbcaaef228] In practice, this means refinancing cannot be used to “reset” the arrears-driven classification outcome, and any attempt to use Evergreening to upgrade an impaired credit into standard or special mention would be inconsistent with the stated restriction. [#SRC:2dd83781-93a2-4d56-a3fc-bf4665f983d5] [#TGT:fc4bcf60-fc4a-4cd8-9848-a2bbcaaef228]

question: When a Relevant Person conducts business entirely in an NFTF manner and uses eKYC, how should its risk assessment and AML/TFS control framework be structured so that it both mitigates the distinct NFTF/eKYC risks and meets the requirement for regular risk assessments of AML/TFS systems and controls?
expected_answer: A Relevant Person should integrate its NFTF/eKYC-specific risk assessment into its broader AML/TFS systems and controls so that the assessment both identifies concrete mitigation actions for NFTF business (including eKYC) and also tests whether the overall AML/TFS framework remains adequate over time. [#SRC:c24c6dfe-b5fa-4802-81ab-5894795d4362] [#TGT:f0c3d08f-8696-42f8-b449-86c97c8f6d4d] The risk assessment should explicitly address that risks can differ when business is conducted entirely in an NFTF manner versus a relationship that mixes face-to-face and NFTF interactions, and it should set out actions to mitigate those NFTF and eKYC risks. [#SRC:c24c6dfe-b5fa-4802-81ab-5894795d4362] In parallel, the Relevant Person must establish and maintain effective policies, procedures, systems and controls to prevent opportunities for money laundering in relation to the Relevant Person and its activities, and it must ensure regular risk assessments are carried out on the adequacy of those AML/TFS systems and controls so they continue to enable identification, assessment, monitoring and management of money laundering risk in a comprehensive and proportionate way. [#TGT:f0c3d08f-8696-42f8-b449-86c97c8f6d4d] To make the NFTF/eKYC assessment actionable within that framework, it should reference risk mitigation measures recommended by the Regulator, a competent authority of the U.A.E., FATF, and other relevant bodies. [#SRC:c24c6dfe-b5fa-4802-81ab-5894795d4362]

The assessment should make reference to risk mitigation measures recommended by the Regulator, a competent authority of the U.A.E., FATF, and other relevant bodies.

question: When the Regulator is satisfied that action is in the interest(s) of the ADGM/Abu Dhabi Global Market, what directions may it give to a Reporting Entity, and what additional power (beyond directing disclosure or other steps) may it exercise, including how it may frame those requirements?
expected_answer: If the Regulator is satisfied that it is in the interest of the ADGM/Abu Dhabi Global Market, it may issue a direction to a Reporting Entity requiring disclosure of specified information or requiring the Reporting Entity to take other steps the Regulator considers appropriate. [#SRC:b83c251c-65fd-4f1c-9225-20fa42145c35] [#TGT:5ed7d470-9d48-4676-936b-d27b5c945a94] The TARGET clarifies that the disclosure direction can be framed as disclosure “to the market,” and it also confirms that the Regulator’s direction power is not limited to disclosure/steps: it may additionally impose extra continuing obligations on the Reporting Entity. [#TGT:5ed7d470-9d48-4676-936b-d27b5c945a94] In exercising these powers, the Regulator may set the terms and conditions it determines for the direction or the additional continuing obligations. [#TGT:5ed7d470-9d48-4676-936b-d27b5c945a94] The SOURCE provides the statutory basis that the Regulator’s power is triggered by its satisfaction that acting is in the interest of the ADGM and that the direction can require disclosure of specified information or other steps the Regulator considers appropriate. [#SRC:b83c251c-65fd-4f1c-9225-20fa42145c35] Taken together, the passages indicate that, once the Regulator reaches the relevant “interest” satisfaction, it can (i) direct disclosure of specified information (including to the market) or other steps, and (ii) separately impose additional continuing obligations, each potentially subject to Regulator-determined terms and conditions. [#SRC:b83c251c-65fd-4f1c-9225-20fa42145c35] [#TGT:5ed7d470-9d48-4676-936b-d27b5c945a94]

question: When the Regulator is considering whether to give a direction to a Recognised Body in matters relating to its Controllers to advance one or more operational objectives, what information and factors must the Regulator take into account in deciding whether it is appropriate to exercise its direction-giving powers under Rule 6.6.1 or Rule 6.7.2?
expected_answer: Where the Regulator is contemplating giving a direction to a Recognised Body on matters relating to its Controllers, it may do so if it considers the direction desirable to advance one or more of its operational objectives. [#TGT:1c3cd986-8007-416b-9fb1-e4600d1b1c81] In deciding whether it would be appropriate to exercise its powers to issue directions under Rule 6.6.1 or Rule 6.7.2 in that context, the Regulator must assess all relevant information and factors, rather than relying on a single consideration. [#SRC:c6a75fa0-e9f4-459e-972a-a06f6236f8c6] Specifically, its assessment includes considering the Rules contained in MIR, the results of its routine supervision of the Recognised Body concerned, and how far any failure or likely failure to satisfy one or more Recognition Requirements may affect the Regulator’s objectives. [#SRC:c6a75fa0-e9f4-459e-972a-a06f6236f8c6] This means the operational-objectives rationale for a Controllers-related direction should be evaluated alongside the MIR rule framework and supervisory findings, and with attention to the potential impact of (actual or likely) non-compliance with Recognition Requirements on the Regulator’s objectives. [#TGT:1c3cd986-8007-416b-9fb1-e4600d1b1c81] [#SRC:c6a75fa0-e9f4-459e-972a-a06f6236f8c6]

question: For an Authorised Person Operating a Multilateral Trading Facility in relation to Virtual Assets, how must GEN Rule 5.2.14 be applied and interpreted, and how does that interpretation fit within the broader set of rulebooks and additional requirements that the Authorised Person must comply with (including the scenario where it is also Providing Custody in relation to Virtual Assets)?

[#SRC:24637efb-9ce5-40ee-bec4-7e5066d40d24] If the same Authorised Person is also Providing Custody in relation to Virtual Assets, it must additionally comply with Rule 17.8, alongside the GEN Rule 5.2.14 interpretation described above. [#SRC:24637efb-9ce5-40ee-bec4-7e5066d40d24]

question: For a Mining Reporting Entity that is considering whether commercially sensitive information (such as pricing or volumes under long-term contractual commitments) should be disclosed, how should it assess whether that information meets the “would, if generally available, be likely to have a significant effect on the price” threshold by applying the definition of Inside Information, and what does the SOURCE say about the FSRA’s expectation regarding disclosure of such commercially sensitive information under the ore reserves Rule obligation?
expected_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity should not assume that commercially sensitive information is automatically required to be disclosed for the ore reserves Rule obligation; the FSRA indicates it does not expect disclosure of commercially sensitive details (for example, pricing or volumes under long-term contractual commitments) solely to satisfy that specific Rule obligation. [#SRC:8597f744-9885-4eb3-9d70-e86ac02e5856] However, the entity should still evaluate whether the same information could fall within disclosure regimes that turn on price sensitivity, by testing it against the definition of Inside Information and the related “significant effect on price” concept referenced in the SOURCE. [#SRC:8597f744-9885-4eb3-9d70-e86ac02e5856] Under the TARGET definition, information is Inside Information only if it is of a precise nature, is not generally available, relates directly or indirectly to one or more Reporting Entities or Issuers (or to the relevant instruments), and would be likely to have a significant effect on price if it became generally available. [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977] Practically, the Mining Reporting Entity should: (i) determine whether the pricing/volume terms are “precise” and currently not generally available; (ii) confirm the information relates to the Reporting Entity/Issuer or the Financial Instruments; and (iii) assess whether general availability would likely move the price, aligning with the SOURCE’s reference to disclosure triggers based on significant price effect. [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977] [#SRC:8597f744-9885-4eb3-9d70-e86ac02e5856]

question: When an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for a CR Exposure and is using the FCSA, how must it reflect that collateral in the RWA(CR) calculation—specifically, how are E and CRW determined for the collateralised and uncollateralised portions under the general RWA(CR) = E x CRW approach?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person that has taken eligible financial Collateral for a CR Exposure and is using the FCSA may reflect the collateral as a CRM effect by splitting the CR Exposure into two parts and then applying the standard RWA(CR) computation to each part. [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb] Under the general approach, the firm calculates RWA for CR Exposures by determining an Exposure value (E), determining the applicable risk weight (CRW), and applying the formula RWA(CR) = E x CRW, then summing across exposures. [#TGT:5c99a9f9-b97d-4f45-834a-0562c13cf368] For the collateralised portion, E must be set to the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral, and CRW must be the risk weight applicable to that collateral as if the Authorised Person had a direct Exposure to it. [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb] For the uncollateralised portion, E must be the original E of the CR Exposure reduced by the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral, and CRW must be the risk weight applicable to the obligor. [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb] The resulting RWA(CR) amounts for the two portions are calculated using RWA(CR) = E x CRW and then included in the total RWA by adding the RWA amounts across all CR Exposures. [#TGT:5c99a9f9-b97d-4f45-834a-0562c13cf368]

debug_context.source_text: Recognition of eligible financial Collateral under FCSA. Subject to A4.3.28, an Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for a CR Exposure and is using the FCSA may recognise the effects of CRM of the eligible financial Collateral as follows: (a) break down the Exposure into - (i) a collateralised portion with E equal to the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral; and (ii) an uncollateralised portion with E equal to the E of the CR Exposure less the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral; and (b) for the purposes of calculating the Credit RWA amount pursuant to Rule 4.8.3, use: (i) for the collateralised portion, the CRW that is applicable to the eligible financial Collateral as though the Authorised Person had a direct Exposure to that Collateral; and (ii) for the uncollateralised portion, the CRW that is applicable to the obligor.

To calculate its RWA for CR Exposures, an Authorised Person must: (a) calculate the value of the Exposure (represented as "E") for every on-balance sheet and every off balance sheet asset in accordance with the Exposure measurement methodology specified in Section 4.9 and recognising the effects of any applicable CRM; (b) categorise that Exposure in accordance with the Rules in Section 4.10; (c) allocate an applicable Credit Quality Grade and risk weight for that Exposure in accordance with the Rules in Section 4.11 and 4.12; (d) calculate the RWA amount for that Exposure using the following formula: RWA(CR) = E x CRW where: (i) "RWA(CR)" refers to the risk weighted Exposure amount for that CR Exposure; (ii) "E" refers to the Exposure value or amount, for that CR Exposure; and (iii) "CRW" refers to the applicable risk weight for that CR Exposure determined in accordance with (b) and (c); and (e) add the RWA amounts calculated in accordance with (d) for all its CR Exposures.

question: Before a Relevant Person appoints a service provider to undertake CDD, how should the Relevant Person structure the required initial assurance assessment so that it also supports the assurance expectations applicable when assessing an eKYC System for the purpose of Rule 9.3.1A, and what documentation must be in place at appointment?
expected_answer: A Relevant Person should design the pre-appointment assurance work so it both (i) evaluates whether the service provider is suitable to undertake CDD and (ii) aligns with the assurance approach expected when assessing an eKYC System for the purpose of Rule 9.3.1A. [#TGT:1f815e39-1a9b-4f7d-af18-65b633fed752] [#SRC:611c820f-2988-4e25-9091-4a3b299501b4] In practice, this means the initial assurance assessment conducted before appointment should be scoped to test whether any eKYC System involved is reliable and independent and whether it enables the Relevant Person to comply with all applicable Rules of the Regulator, because those are the assurance outcomes the Relevant Person should seek to establish for Rule 9.3.1A purposes. [#SRC:611c820f-2988-4e25-9091-4a3b299501b4] The Relevant Person should also consider applying relevant assurance standards guidance issued by the Regulator, competent U.A.E. authorities, FATF, and other standard-setting bodies as part of how it conducts and benchmarks that assessment. [#SRC:611c820f-2988-4e25-9091-4a3b299501b4] Separately, as a condition of appointing the service provider, the Relevant Person must ensure the service provider’s obligations are clearly documented in a binding agreement, and this documentation must be in place prior to appointment. question: When the Investigator issues a written notice requiring production of Specified Documents at a Specified time and place, what forms of documents may be demanded and what authority does the Investigator have to keep originals after production?
expected_answer: Where the Investigator uses a written notice to require the Person Under Investigation or any other person to produce Specified Documents (or Documents of a Specified description) at a Specified time and place, the notice-based power establishes the mechanism and logistics for production (including the specified time/place and the scope of documents). [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] In addition, the Investigator’s document-production power includes the ability to require either original documents or copies, so the recipient may be directed to provide originals rather than reproductions (or vice versa) depending on what is required. [#SRC:1bed8582-a440-425c-b19d-c780cdc7aaf3] If originals are produced in response to the notice, the Investigator is permitted to keep possession of any original document for as long as is necessary for the purpose for which it was requested, meaning retention is tied to necessity and purpose rather than a fixed period. [#SRC:1bed8582-a440-425c-b19d-c780cdc7aaf3] Accordingly, compliance should address both (i) meeting the specified time-and-place production requirement in the written notice and (ii) readiness for the Investigator to insist on originals and to retain them when necessary for the stated investigative purpose. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] [#SRC:1bed8582-a440-425c-b19d-c780cdc7aaf3]

[#SRC:1bed8582-a440-425c-b19d-c780cdc7aaf3] Therefore, a person receiving such requirements should be prepared both for on-premises inspection/copying during normal business hours and for compelled production that may involve surrender and temporary retention of originals. question: For a Person seeking one of the listed ADGM green/climate designations, what payments are owed to the Regulator at the application stage and after the designation is granted, including the amount and any proration or calendar-year payment timing?
expected_answer: A Person applying for one of the specified designations must pay a $2,000 application fee to the Regulator at the time of applying, and if the designation is granted, the Person must also pay an annual designation fee of $2,000 to the Regulator, with specific proration and timing rules. [#TGT:a0e78247-fd29-4fda-8fdc-07ce6c83f37b] [#SRC:aa8d419c-7982-47cd-833b-4ae9bd269fbc] At the application stage, the $2,000 fee applies when the Person applies for any of these designations: ADGM Green Fund, ADGM Climate Transition Fund, ADGM Green Portfolio, ADGM Climate Transition Portfolio, ADGM Green Bond, or ADGM Sustainability Linked Bond. [#TGT:a0e78247-fd29-4fda-8fdc-07ce6c83f37b] After the initial granting of the designation, the Person must pay an annual designation fee of $2,000 that is prorated for the remainder of the calendar year in which the designation is first granted. [#SRC:aa8d419c-7982-47cd-833b-4ae9bd269fbc] For each subsequent calendar year commencing 1 January, the annual designation fee is payable in full on or before 31 January of the calendar year to which the fee relates. [#SRC:aa8d419c-7982-47cd-833b-4ae9bd269fbc] Accordingly, the fee framework combines an upfront application payment for the listed designation types with an ongoing annual fee once the designation has been granted, including proration in the first year and a fixed January payment deadline in later years. [#TGT:a0e78247-fd29-4fda-8fdc-07ce6c83f37b] [#SRC:aa8d419c-7982-47cd-833b-4ae9bd269fbc]

question: Where an Issuer seeks to rely on the exemption from the section 61 FSMR prohibition for admission of additional Units representing less than 10% over 12 months, what trading venue requirement applies to all Units in the class (including those specified under Rule 3.3.5), and how does that requirement interact with the exemption being subject to Rule 3.3.6?
expected_answer: An Issuer may treat the section 61 FSMR prohibition as inapplicable for the admission to trading of Units that, over a 12‑month period, represent less than 10% of the number of Units of the same class already admitted to trading on the same Recognised Investment Exchange, but only because that exemption is expressly conditional on compliance with the requirement in Rule 3.3.6. [#TGT:3a7c96c9-65c9-422f-b480-4592229e0ace] In parallel, the venue rule for Exempt Offers in respect of Units requires that all Units in the relevant class of Securities that are admitted to trading—including those Units identified under Rule 3.3.5—must be traded on a Recognised Investment Exchange. [#SRC:8304d78c-757e-45d8-a9b6-fd855e1513ab] Read together, this means the Issuer cannot treat the exemption as a basis to admit Units while allowing any Units in that class (including the Rule 3.3.5 subset) to trade somewhere other than a Recognised Investment Exchange; the class-wide trading location requirement still applies. [#SRC:8304d78c-757e-45d8-a9b6-fd855e1513ab] The exemption’s “subject to Rule 3.3.6” condition operates as an additional gate to using the section 61 carve-out for the admission to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, rather than replacing the obligation that all Units in the class trade on such an exchange. [#TGT:3a7c96c9-65c9-422f-b480-4592229e0ace]

debug_context.target_text: Exempt Offers in respect of Units. The prohibition in section 61 of the FSMR does not apply, subject to the requirement in Rule 3.3.6, to the admission to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange of: (1) Units representing, over a period of 12 months, less than 10% of the number of Units of the same class already admitted to trading on the same Recognised Investment Exchange; (2) Units issued in substitution for Units of the same class already admitted to trading on the same Recognised Investment Exchange, if the issue of Units does not involve any increase in the issued capital; (3) Units offered, allotted or to be allotted to existing Unitholders free of charge, or in respect of dividends paid out in the form of Units of the same class as the Units in respect of which the dividends are paid, if: (a) the Units are of the same class as the Units already admitted to trading on the same Recognised Investment Exchange; and (b) a document is made available containing information on the number and nature of the Units and the reasons for and details of the Offer; or (4) Units already admitted to trading on another Recognised Investment Exchange or Regulated Exchange (the "Other Market"), where: (a) the Units of the same class have been admitted to trading and continuously traded on the Other Market for more than 18 months; (b) the on-going obligations for trading on that Other Market have been complied with; and (c) there is a summary document in the English language approved by the Regulator and published: (i) containing the Key Information required under Rule 4.5.2(1)(b); (ii) stating where the most recent and current Prospectus, if any, can be obtained; and (iii) specifying where the financial information published by the Issuer pursuant to its on-going disclosure obligations of the Other Market is available.

question: For Units already admitted to trading on another Recognised Investment Exchange or Regulated Exchange (the Other Market), what specific conditions must be met to use the section 61 FSMR exemption for admission to trading, and what overarching requirement applies to the trading of all Units in the class (including those specified under Rule 3.3.5) once admitted?
expected_answer: To rely on the section 61 FSMR exemption for admitting Units that are already admitted to trading on an Other Market, the Units of the same class must have been admitted to trading and continuously traded on that Other Market for more than 18 months, the on‑going obligations for trading on that Other Market must have been complied with, and an English summary document must be approved by the Regulator and published with specified content (including Key Information required under Rule 4.5.2(1)(b), where the most recent/current Prospectus (if any) can be obtained, and where the Issuer’s financial information published under the Other Market’s on‑going disclosure obligations is available). [#SRC:8304d78c-757e-45d8-a9b6-fd855e1513ab] Accordingly, even where the Other Market pathway conditions and documentation are satisfied for admission, the resulting admitted class must still trade on a Recognised Investment Exchange, and this requirement explicitly extends to the Rule 3.3.5 Units within that class. question: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation and later makes a subsequent disclosure about those same Non-Equivalent Estimates, how can it both (i) rely on the carve-out from Rule 11.2.1(1) and (ii) avoid repeating the information required by Rule 11.7.3 in the later disclosure?
expected_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity can avoid complying with Rule 11.2.1(1) for a disclosure of material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation only if it instead complies with the specified alternative set of rules, which includes Rule 11.7.3. [#SRC:ec29aad6-3d7b-4466-a6ab-0022accf5f26] If the entity has already made a Non-Equivalent Estimates disclosure that complied with Rule 11.7.3, then a later disclosure about those same Non-Equivalent Estimates may omit the information required by Rule 11.7.3, but only if the later disclosure meets all of the conditions tied to that omission. [#TGT:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4] Practically, to achieve both outcomes, the Mining Reporting Entity should: - Ensure the initial disclosure of the material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation is made in a way that satisfies the alternative compliance pathway (including Rule 11.7.2, Rule 11.7.3, Rule 11.7.4, and Rule 11.7.6), so Rule 11.2.1(1) is not required for that disclosure. [#SRC:ec29aad6-3d7b-4466-a6ab-0022accf5f26] - In the subsequent disclosure, reference the earlier Rule 11.7.3-compliant disclosure and confirm both that the earlier Rule 11.7.3 information still applies and that there is no new material information or data affecting reliability/interpretation or the entity’s ability to verify the estimates as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves under a Mining Reporting Standard. [#TGT:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4] - Include an at least equally prominent and proximate statement addressing the matters covered by Rule 11.7.3(1). [#TGT:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4]

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity has already made a compliant disclosure about Non-Equivalent Estimates, what does it need to do in a later update so it doesn’t have to repeat the Rule 11.7.3 information, and how does that fit with the rule that lets it skip Rule 11.2.1(1) for material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation?
expected_answer: For material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation, a Mining Reporting Entity can avoid having to comply with Rule 11.2.1(1) only by complying with the alternative set of rules listed for that situation, which includes Rule 11.7.3. [#TGT:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4] In the later update, the Mining Reporting Entity must: - Point back to the earlier disclosure that complied with Rule 11.7.3. [#TGT:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4] - Confirm that the earlier Rule 11.7.3 information still applies and that there is no new material information or data that affects either (i) the reliability or interpretation of the Non-Equivalent Estimates or (ii) the entity’s ability to verify them as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves under a Mining Reporting Standard. [#TGT:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4] - Add an at least equally prominent and nearby statement that addresses the matters covered by Rule 11.7.3(1). [#TGT:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4] Doing this preserves the initial pathway where Rule 11.2.1(1) is not required because the entity is complying with the specified Rule 11.7 requirements (including Rule 11.7.3). [#SRC:ec29aad6-3d7b-4466-a6ab-0022accf5f26]

question: Where a Recognised Investment Exchange is permitted by the FSRA (and within the scope of its Recognition Order) to operate a separate MTF, OTF and/or MTF using Virtual Assets, what additional market must it also operate, and how do the Recognition Requirements apply in that combined operating model?
expected_answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange that is operating an MTF or an OTF must, in addition, operate a market that meets the Recognition Requirements. [#TGT:85479490-968f-42f7-baaa-2580214b953d] This obligation applies even where the Recognised Investment Exchange is permitted by the FSRA to operate a separate MTF, OTF and/or MTF using Virtual Assets under its Recognition Order (and within the described framework for operating markets relating to the trading of Financial Instruments, including Digital Securities). [#SRC:fa3cde4e-a388-4d88-bb14-8242a2758cc0] In practical terms, the permission to run a separate venue using Virtual Assets does not remove the need to maintain a compliant market alongside the MTF/OTF activity; rather, the Recognised Investment Exchange must ensure that its overall operating model includes (i) the MTF and/or OTF (which may be separate and may involve Virtual Assets where permitted) and (ii) a market that satisfies the Recognition Requirements. [#SRC:fa3cde4e-a388-4d88-bb14-8242a2758cc0] [#TGT:85479490-968f-42f7-baaa-2580214b953d] The key linkage is that the FSRA-permitted operation of a separate MTF/OTF/MTF using Virtual Assets under a Recognition Order sits alongside, and does not substitute for, the requirement to operate a Recognition Requirements-compliant market when operating an MTF or OTF. [#SRC:fa3cde4e-a388-4d88-bb14-8242a2758cc0] [#TGT:85479490-968f-42f7-baaa-2580214b953d]

question: If a Recognised Investment Exchange is allowed by the FSRA to run a separate MTF/OTF that uses Virtual Assets under its Recognition Order, does it still need to run another market, and what standard must that market meet?
expected_answer: Yes. When a Recognised Investment Exchange operates an MTF or an OTF, it must also operate a market that complies with the Recognition Requirements. [#TGT:85479490-968f-42f7-baaa-2580214b953d] This remains true even if the Recognised Investment Exchange is permitted by the FSRA to operate a separate MTF, OTF and/or MTF using Virtual Assets under its Recognition Order, alongside its markets for trading Financial Instruments (including Digital Securities). [#SRC:fa3cde4e-a388-4d88-bb14-8242a2758cc0] Put simply, the ability to run a separate venue involving Virtual Assets is an additional capability under the Recognition Order, not a replacement for the requirement to have a Recognition Requirements-compliant market in place when running an MTF or OTF. [#SRC:fa3cde4e-a388-4d88-bb14-8242a2758cc0] [#TGT:85479490-968f-42f7-baaa-2580214b953d] Therefore, the Recognised Investment Exchange should structure its operations so that (1) it can run the separate MTF/OTF/MTF using Virtual Assets where permitted, and (2) it continues to operate a market that meets the Recognition Requirements as required for MTF/OTF operators. [#SRC:fa3cde4e-a388-4d88-bb14-8242a2758cc0] [#TGT:85479490-968f-42f7-baaa-2580214b953d]

question: Before an Authorised Person opens a trading account that enables a Retail Client to buy and sell OTC Leveraged Products, what onboarding steps must the Authorised Person complete regarding the risk disclosure statement and the Retail Client’s acknowledgement, and what specific warnings and risk statements must that risk disclosure statement contain (including any stop-loss explanation conditions)?
expected_answer: Before opening a trading account that allows a Retail Client to trade OTC Leveraged Products, the Authorised Person must complete onboarding actions tied to both delivery of a compliant risk disclosure statement and documented client acknowledgement. [#SRC:3af19a86-294a-44cc-9abc-df79783033e8] The Authorised Person must provide a separate risk disclosure statement as part of onboarding in sufficient time before it carries on any business for that Retail Client, obtain a documented acknowledgement that the Retail Client received and reviewed the statement and understands and accepts the risks, give the Retail Client a duplicate copy of that acknowledgement, and keep a record of the acknowledgement in line with applicable record-keeping requirements. [#SRC:3af19a86-294a-44cc-9abc-df79783033e8] The risk disclosure statement used for this onboarding must include a prominent warning that the Retail Client may lose substantially more than the initial margin posted and must also state, among other points, that it may not cover all risks, that the Retail Client may lose all capital outlay and any unredeemed profits, that losses can accumulate rapidly, that leverage amplifies losses, that loss-mitigation systems (including stop-loss limits) may fail, that slippage can occur, and that most Retail Clients lose money. [#TGT:0987d811-ce0e-4ab8-93b8-90149e88b955] Where stop-loss orders are relevant, the statement must explain them and clearly indicate whether a stop-loss is “guaranteed,” and if not, that it may not limit losses during highly volatile conditions. [#TGT:0987d811-ce0e-4ab8-93b8-90149e88b955]

debug_context.target_text: A risk disclosure statement provided by an Authorised Person to a Retail Client in accordance with Rule 23.4.1 must include a prominent warning that investing in OTC Leveraged Products involves the risk of losing substantially more than the initial margin posted by the Retail Client, and further state that: (a) the risk disclosure statement may not identify or address all risks associated with OTC Leveraged Products; (b) the Retail Client is at risk of losing all of their capital outlay and any profits not redeemed; (c) the Retail Client is at risk of losing money and accumulating losses rapidly; (d) margin trading and use of leverage amplifies losses when they occur; (e) margin-trading limits, stop-loss limits, or other systems and controls designed to mitigate or limit loss exposures may not be effective or may fail. question: When an Authorised Person is preparing the separate risk disclosure statement to be provided in good time during onboarding (before carrying on any business for a Retail Client) for OTC Leveraged Products, which content elements must be included to support the documented acknowledgement that the Retail Client understands and accepts the risks?
expected_answer: To support obtaining a documented acknowledgement that a Retail Client has received, reviewed, and understands and accepts the risks of trading OTC Leveraged Products, the Authorised Person must ensure the onboarding risk disclosure statement is both timely and substantively complete. [#SRC:3af19a86-294a-44cc-9abc-df79783033e8] Substantively, the risk disclosure statement must contain a prominent warning that the Retail Client can lose substantially more than the initial margin posted. [#TGT:0987d811-ce0e-4ab8-93b8-90149e88b955] It must further state that it may not address all risks; that the Retail Client may lose all capital outlay and any profits not redeemed; that losses can arise and accumulate quickly; that leverage and margin trading amplify losses; that stop-loss limits and other controls may be ineffective or fail; that slippage (differences between approved and executed prices) can occur; and that most Retail Clients lose money when transacting in OTC Leveraged Products. [#TGT:0987d811-ce0e-4ab8-93b8-90149e88b955] Where relevant, it must also explain stop-loss orders and clarify whether they are guaranteed, and if not, that they may not cap losses in highly volatile conditions. question: Where the parties have agreed that Rule 19.11.1(3) does not apply because a Low Value Payment Instrument does not allow for the stopping or prevention of its use, what ongoing capability must the Payment Service Provider still maintain for Payment Service Users regarding reporting loss, theft, misappropriation, or unauthorised use of the Payment Instrument?
expected_answer: Even if the parties agree to disapply the specific rule on notifying loss of a Payment Instrument for a Low Value Payment Instrument that cannot be stopped or prevented from being used, the Payment Service Provider must still maintain a continuous reporting channel for the Payment Service User. [#SRC:1db4fdad-1fa0-4aae-ad68-56d8705902d9] In practice, the Payment Service Provider’s baseline obligation is to ensure that appropriate means are available at all times for a Payment Service User to notify the Payment Service Provider when the Payment Instrument is lost, stolen, misappropriated, or used without authorisation. [#TGT:9b652a81-4dfa-4909-b738-a9285f01f41a] The disapplication described is limited to the identified rules (including Rule 19.11.1(3) and Rule 19.20.1(4)) and only in the stated circumstance that the Low Value Payment Instrument does not allow stopping or prevention of its use. [#SRC:1db4fdad-1fa0-4aae-ad68-56d8705902d9] Accordingly, regardless of whether the parties have agreed that Rule 19.11.1(3) does not apply in that scenario, the Payment Service Provider must still keep always-on, appropriate notification means so the Payment Service User can report the relevant events to the Payment Service Provider. [#TGT:9b652a81-4dfa-4909-b738-a9285f01f41a]

debug_context.source_text: The parties may agree that the following Rules do not apply where a Low Value Payment Instrument does not allow for the stopping or prevention of its use: (a) Rule 19.11.1 (3) (notification of loss of Payment Instrument); and (b) Rule 19.20.1(4) (Payer not liable for certain losses).
debug_context.target_text: The Payment Service Provider must ensure that appropriate means are available at all times to enable a Payment Service User to notify the Payment Service Provider of the loss, theft, misappropriation or unauthorised use of the Payment Instrument.

question: If a Low Value Payment Instrument can’t be stopped and the parties agree that the rule about notifying loss (Rule 19.11.1(3)) doesn’t apply, does the Payment Service Provider still need to keep a way for users to report loss or unauthorised use at any time? What exactly has to be available?
expected_answer: Yes. Even where the parties agree that certain rules do not apply for a Low Value Payment Instrument because it does not allow stopping or preventing its use—including the rule dealing with notification of loss of a Payment Instrument (Rule 19.11.1(3))—the Payment Service Provider still has an ongoing operational duty to support user reporting. [#SRC:1db4fdad-1fa0-4aae-ad68-56d8705902d9] Specifically, the Payment Service Provider must ensure that appropriate means are available at all times so that a Payment Service User can notify the Payment Service Provider of the loss, theft, misappropriation, or unauthorised use of the Payment Instrument. [#TGT:9b652a81-4dfa-4909-b738-a9285f01f41a] The agreement described in the Low Value Payment Instrument provision is limited to disapplying the listed rules (Rule 19.11.1(3) and Rule 19.20.1(4)) and only in the stated condition that the instrument cannot be stopped or prevented from being used. [#SRC:1db4fdad-1fa0-4aae-ad68-56d8705902d9] That limitation does not remove the separate requirement that reporting channels exist continuously and cover the four types of events (loss, theft, misappropriation, and unauthorised use). [#TGT:9b652a81-4dfa-4909-b738-a9285f01f41a]

question: Where an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT that is not covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement and is using the FCCA, how should the firm determine and apply E* in the credit risk weighted exposure calculation, and what haircut methodology options are available when calculating E* for such a collateralised transaction (other than an OTC Derivative transaction or a long settlement transaction)?
expected_answer: In this scenario, the Authorised Person must compute an adjusted exposure value (E*) and use it in place of the unadjusted exposure (E) when determining the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount for the relevant CR Exposure. [#SRC:99f36cb9-d6c3-4b1b-a90c-5d85b901b3de] This substitution requirement applies where the firm has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT, the SFT is not covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement, and the firm is using the FCCA. [#SRC:99f36cb9-d6c3-4b1b-a90c-5d85b901b3de] The firm must calculate E* in accordance with the specified App4 rules (A4.3.2 to A4.3.6) referenced for this purpose. [#SRC:99f36cb9-d6c3-4b1b-a90c-5d85b901b3de] When calculating E* for collateralised transactions other than OTC Derivative transactions and long settlement transactions, the Authorised Person must determine the appropriate haircuts to apply using one of two permitted approaches: standard supervisory haircuts or own estimate haircuts. [#TGT:19b5846d-b958-4e12-a8d2-ffe1b2dd7ed8] Accordingly, for the described SFT exposure, E* is calculated under the referenced App4 framework and then used as the exposure input for credit risk weighting, with haircuts selected via one of the two allowed haircut methodologies. [#SRC:99f36cb9-d6c3-4b1b-a90c-5d85b901b3de] [#TGT:19b5846d-b958-4e12-a8d2-ffe1b2dd7ed8]

debug_context.source_text: Measurement of E for pre settlement Counterparty Exposures arising from SFTs. An Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for any SFT that is not covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement and using the FCCA, must calculate E* in accordance with Rules A4.3.2 to A4.3.6 in App4, and substitute E* for E when calculating the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount for that CR Exposure under Section 4.8.
debug_context.target_text: Calculation of E* for collateralised transactions other than OTC Derivative transactions and long settlement transactions. An Authorised Person must calculate the appropriate haircuts to be applied using one of the following methods: (a) standard supervisory haircuts; or (b) own estimate haircuts.

question: If an Authorised Person takes eligible financial Collateral for an SFT, the SFT is not under a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement, and the firm is using the FCCA, what number should it use instead of E when working out the credit risk weighted exposure—and how can it choose the haircut method when calculating that number for a collateralised transaction that is not an OTC Derivative transaction or a long settlement transaction?
expected_answer: The firm should use E* (not E) as the exposure figure when it calculates the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount for the CR Exposure, provided it has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT, the SFT is not covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement, and it is using the FCCA. [#SRC:99f36cb9-d6c3-4b1b-a90c-5d85b901b3de] To get E*, the Authorised Person must follow the calculation approach set out in the referenced App4 rules (A4.3.2 to A4.3.6). [#TGT:19b5846d-b958-4e12-a8d2-ffe1b2dd7ed8] Those two options are: (a) standard supervisory haircuts, or (b) own estimate haircuts. [#TGT:19b5846d-b958-4e12-a8d2-ffe1b2dd7ed8] Putting this together, the firm calculates E* under the App4 framework, applies haircuts using one of the two permitted haircut methods for the relevant type of collateralised transaction, and then substitutes E* for E in the credit risk weighted exposure calculation. [#SRC:99f36cb9-d6c3-4b1b-a90c-5d85b901b3de] [#TGT:19b5846d-b958-4e12-a8d2-ffe1b2dd7ed8]

question: When calculating RWA for securitisation Exposures, how must an Authorised Person use the Exposure measurement methodology, and how does that methodology’s stated purpose (covering both Credit RWA for Credit Risk Exposures under Rule 4.8.3 and securitisation Exposures under Rule 4.8.4) connect to the step in which the Exposure value is determined under Section 4.9?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must determine the Exposure value for each of its SE Exposures using the Exposure measurement methodology specified in Section 4.9, and it must do so in a way that recognises the effects of any applicable CRM. [#TGT:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] This reliance on Section 4.9 aligns with the stated purpose of the measurement methodology, which prescribes how Exposures are calculated for determining Credit RWA for Credit Risk (CR) Exposures under Rule 4.8.3 and for securitisation (SE) Exposures under Rule 4.8.4. [#SRC:84ee9ffb-686e-47d9-b971-908e8cec77f1] After establishing the Exposure value under Section 4.9, the Authorised Person must allocate an applicable Credit Quality Grade for the SE Exposure under Section 4.11 and then compute the RWA amount for each SE Exposure using the formula RWA(SE) = SE x CRW, where SE is the Exposure value calculated under the Section 4.9 methodology and CRW is the risk weight determined from the Credit Quality Grade. [#TGT:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] SE Exposures that must be included as deductions from any component of Capital Resources are excluded from this per-exposure RWA calculation step. [#TGT:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646]

debug_context.source_text: The measurement methodology in this Section prescribes the manner of calculation of Exposures for the purpose of determining the Credit RWA for Credit Risk (CR) Exposures as provided in Rule 4.8.3 and for securitisation (SE) Exposures as provided in Rule 4.8.4.
debug_context.target_text: Calculation of RWA for securitisation Exposures (SE Exposures). To calculate its RWA for all its SE Exposures, an Authorised Person must: (a) calculate the value of the Exposure for each of its SE Exposures in accordance with Exposure measurement methodology specified in Section 4.9 and recognising the effects of any applicable CRM; (b) allocate an applicable Credit Quality Grade for that SE Exposure in accordance with the Rules in Section 4.11; (c) calculate the RWA amount for each SE Exposure, except for those SE Exposures which the Authorised Person is required to include as deductions from any component of Capital Resources, using the following formula: RWA(SE) = SE x CRW where: (i) "RWA(SE)" refers to the risk weighted Exposure amount for that securitisation Exposure; (ii) "SE" refers to the Exposure value or amount for that SE Exposure calculated in accordance with (a); and (iii) "CRW" refers to the applicable risk weight for that SE Exposure determined in accordance with (b); and (d) add the RWA amounts calculated in accordance with (c) for all its SE Exposures to the RWA amounts calculated in accordance with Rule 4.8.5 in respect of its Early Amortisation Exposures.

question: If an Authorised Person is working out RWA for securitisation Exposures, what are the main steps they must follow, and how does the Exposure measurement methodology’s stated role for both Credit Risk (Rule 4.8.3) and securitisation (Rule 4.8.4) explain why they start by measuring the Exposure under Section 4.9?
expected_answer: To calculate RWA for securitisation Exposures, an Authorised Person must start by calculating the Exposure value for each SE Exposure using the Exposure measurement methodology in Section 4.9 and taking into account any applicable CRM. [#TGT:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] This starting point is consistent with the stated function of the measurement methodology, which sets out how to calculate Exposures for determining Credit RWA for Credit Risk (CR) Exposures under Rule 4.8.3 and for securitisation (SE) Exposures under Rule 4.8.4. [#SRC:84ee9ffb-686e-47d9-b971-908e8cec77f1] After the Exposure value is measured, the Authorised Person must assign a Credit Quality Grade for the SE Exposure under Section 4.11 and then calculate the RWA amount for each SE Exposure using RWA(SE) = SE x CRW, where SE is the Exposure value from the Section 4.9 step and CRW is the risk weight that follows from the Credit Quality Grade. [#TGT:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] The Authorised Person does not apply that formula to any SE Exposures that it is required to include as deductions from any component of Capital Resources. [#TGT:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] Finally, it must add up the RWA amounts for all SE Exposures and combine them with the RWA amounts calculated under Rule 4.8.5 for Early Amortisation Exposures. [#TGT:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646]

question: Where a RIE settles Digital Securities without engaging a RCH and instead uses a DSF, what written confirmation must the RIE provide to the FSRA/Regulator about its arrangements, and what additional compliance condition is imposed on the DSF in that scenario?
expected_answer: A RIE that does not engage a RCH for the settlement of Digital Securities and instead uses a DSF must provide the FSRA, in writing, with details of the satisfactory arrangements it has made for that settlement approach. [#SRC:cf09ad93-5f69-4c7f-8239-0281b7659c5e] This aligns with the broader requirement that, when a Recognised Investment Exchange engages a party that is not a Recognised Clearing House or a Non-Abu Dhabi Global Market Clearing House, it must confirm to the Regulator in writing the satisfactory arrangements made under Rule 3.8.1. [#TGT:58de7c59-691a-427d-b34d-d7fd9baf874e] In the specific Digital Securities/DSF context, the written submission is not only a confirmation that arrangements are satisfactory, but must include the details of those arrangements. [#SRC:cf09ad93-5f69-4c7f-8239-0281b7659c5e] Additionally, the FSRA requires that using a DSF for settlement purposes is conditional on the DSF complying with the requirements of MIR Rule 4.3.3, with any references in that rule to a RCH read as references to a DSF. [#SRC:cf09ad93-5f69-4c7f-8239-0281b7659c5e] Accordingly, the RIE’s written confirmation to the Regulator/FSRA about satisfactory arrangements must be paired with ensuring the engaged non-RCH party (the DSF) meets the MIR Rule 4.3.3 standard as adapted for DSFs. [#SRC:cf09ad93-5f69-4c7f-8239-0281b7659c5e] [#TGT:58de7c59-691a-427d-b34d-d7fd9baf874e]

debug_context.source_text: DIGITAL SECURITIES SETTLEMENT Digital Settlement Facilities (DSFs) Pursuant to MIR Rule 3.8.3, however, and in the context of Digital Securities, a RIE or MTF must provide the FSRA, in writing, with the details of the satisfactory arrangements made when such RIE or MTF does not engage a RCH (for example, to use in this context, a DSF). To clarify, the FSRA will require that arrangements to use a DSF for settlement purposes will require the DSF to comply with the requirements of MIR Rule 4.3.3 (with the references to a RCH being read as references to a DSF).
debug_context.target_text: If a Recognised Investment Exchange engages a party that is not a Recognised Clearing House or a Non-Abu Dhabi Global Market Clearing House, the Recognised Investment Exchange must confirm to the Regulator, in writing, the satisfactory arrangements made under Rule 3.8.1.

question: If a Recognised Investment Exchange uses a Digital Settlement Facility (DSF) to settle Digital Securities instead of using a Recognised Clearing House, what does it need to send in writing to the Regulator/FSRA, and what rule does the DSF have to meet (with any needed wording change)?
expected_answer: In this situation, the Recognised Investment Exchange must make a written submission to the Regulator/FSRA about the settlement arrangements it has put in place with the non-RCH party. [#TGT:58de7c59-691a-427d-b34d-d7fd9baf874e] Beyond describing the arrangements, the FSRA requires that the DSF used for settlement must comply with MIR Rule 4.3.3, and that any references in that rule to a RCH are treated as references to a DSF. [#SRC:cf09ad93-5f69-4c7f-8239-0281b7659c5e] [#TGT:58de7c59-691a-427d-b34d-d7fd9baf874e]

question: When considering whether to support or give full effect to a Foreign Resolution Action by exercising Resolution Tools or Resolution Powers (including any need for ex-ante judicial approval under section 27), in what circumstances may the Regulator refuse to recognise the Foreign Resolution Action in whole or in part?
expected_answer: The Regulator may decline to recognise a Foreign Resolution Action (in full or only for certain parts) even where the contemplated next step would be to support or give full effect to it through the use of Resolution Tools or Resolution Powers (and even if ex-ante judicial approval under section 27 would otherwise be relevant to that exercise). [#TGT:5798f720-7021-4b63-9ebe-f1a30aebee29] Refusal is available if the Regulator is satisfied that at least one specified condition applies. [#SRC:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba] Those conditions include: recognition would harm financial stability in the ADGM; the Resolution Conditions have not been met for the relevant entity listed in section 2 in connection with the Regulator’s proposed Resolution Action under section 78(5); or Resolution Action in relation to an ADGM Branch under section 78(5) is not needed to meet one or more Resolution Objectives. [#SRC:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba] The Regulator may also refuse recognition if the foreign action would treat creditors located or payable in the ADGM differently (in treatment or legal rights) solely because of their ADGM location compared with creditors (including depositors) in the relevant non-ADGM jurisdiction. [#SRC:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba] Finally, refusal is permitted where recognition and supportive action would have material fiscal implications for the UAE or the ADGM. [#SRC:d95a8aaf-4663-4372-87b7-54040b62f0ba]

question: How should an entity determine whether it must hold an additional capital buffer when it is (i) an Authorised Person to whom the FSRA applies proportionality under COBS Rule 17.3 / MIR Rule 3.2.1 in relation to virtual assets, and (ii) also a Recognised Investment Exchange subject to a baseline capital formula expressed in months of operational expenses? In your answer, explain how the proportionality and risk assessment interacts with the months-of-expenses baseline and the possibility of a Regulator direction.
expected_answer: Where the entity is both an Authorised Person in scope of the FSRA’s proportionality approach for capital buffers and a Recognised Investment Exchange with a months-of-expenses capital baseline, it should treat the Recognised Investment Exchange requirement as establishing a minimum capital amount and then assess whether an additional buffer is required under the proportionality/risk framework. [#TGT:1f2f00c6-1680-4516-adc8-b360f33ebe96] Specifically, as a Recognised Investment Exchange it must hold capital equal to six months’ operational expenses, and—unless the Regulator directs otherwise—may also be required to hold an additional buffer of up to a further six months’ operational expenses. [#TGT:1f2f00c6-1680-4516-adc8-b360f33ebe96] Separately, when applying COBS Rule 17.3 / MIR Rule 3.2.1 to an Authorised Person, the FSRA applies proportionality to decide whether any additional capital buffer must be held, considering the size, scope, complexity, and nature of the Authorised Person’s activities and operations, and (if a buffer is needed) the appropriate amount of regulatory capital for that buffer. [#SRC:01e0aad6-805e-4a33-ac77-66a5d6eb6d5a] If the FSRA considers the Authorised Person to be high risk, it may attract higher regulatory capital requirements, which would inform whether the entity should expect a larger buffer beyond the baseline months-of-expenses amount (subject to any Regulator direction affecting the Recognised Investment Exchange buffer). [#SRC:01e0aad6-805e-4a33-ac77-66a5d6eb6d5a] [#TGT:1f2f00c6-1680-4516-adc8-b360f33ebe96]

question: When an Authorised Person acts as a clearing member intermediary between a client and a CCP, how should it determine the exposure measure it uses to calculate Credit RWA for its Trade Exposure to that client, and when would a different method be permitted for derivatives or long settlement transactions?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person that is acting as a clearing member intermediary between a client and a CCP must calculate Credit RWA for its Trade Exposure to the client using the specific credit risk framework referenced for that Trade Exposure, including the associated treatment of any client-posted Collateral where applicable. [#SRC:57fed3b7-e493-4c49-9c2d-c8c8194bbac8] Where the Trade Exposure arises from Derivative transactions (whether OTC or exchange-traded) or from long settlement transactions, the exposure-at-default input to that calculation must be determined using the Standardised Approach to Counterparty Credit Risk (SA-CCR) as set out for those transaction types, unless the Authorised Person has received permission from the Regulator to use an internal model instead. [#TGT:05fe705c-077c-46d7-8bf8-8ff6d49dfcff] In practical terms, this means the firm should (i) identify that it is acting in the clearing member intermediary capacity and therefore has a Trade Exposure to the client, (ii) calculate Credit RWA for that exposure under the referenced rule set and apply the relevant provisions for any Collateral posted by the client, and (iii) for any derivatives or long settlement components, compute EAD under SA-CCR unless an internal-model permission has been granted by the Regulator. [#SRC:57fed3b7-e493-4c49-9c2d-c8c8194bbac8] [#TGT:05fe705c-077c-46d7-8bf8-8ff6d49dfcff]

question: How must an Authorised Person determine the amount of its Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital when it has private sector credit exposures in multiple jurisdictions, including how the weighted average of the applicable jurisdictional buffer rates is computed and then applied to the Total Risk Exposure Amount?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must set its Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital as a product of (i) its Total Risk Exposure Amount and (ii) a weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates applicable to the jurisdictions where its private sector credit exposures are located. [#SRC:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c] The Total Risk Exposure Amount used in this calculation is the Total Risk Exposure Amount calculated in accordance with Rule 3.5.7, and the weighted average rate must be calculated in accordance with the specified rules for determining that weighted average. [#SRC:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c] To compute the weighted average of the Countercyclical Capital Buffer rates across jurisdictions, the Authorised Person must: (1) for each jurisdiction in which it has private sector credit exposures, take the Total Risk Exposure Amount that relates to the private sector credit exposures in that jurisdiction, divide it by the Total Risk Exposure Amount that relates to the Authorised Person’s private sector credit exposures across all jurisdictions, and multiply the result by the applicable Countercyclical Capital Buffer rate in that jurisdiction; and then (2) sum these jurisdiction-level contributions across all jurisdictions. [#TGT:e71f9d6c-0033-443d-9ce0-aa873bdd8124] The resulting weighted average rate is then multiplied by the Total Risk Exposure Amount to yield the required Countercyclical Capital Buffer of CET1 Capital. [#SRC:61013be0-a186-4ad3-9c9e-4fe2164b5b2c]

question: How should a Third Party Provider demonstrate that its professional indemnity insurance is sufficient to reimburse Customers for operational risk events while also complying with the Transaction Limits requirement tied to the average daily value of Third Party Transactions over the past ninety calendar days?
expected_answer: A Third Party Provider should treat “sufficient” professional indemnity insurance as a dual obligation: it must be adequate to reimburse Customers if operational risk events occur, and it must continuously satisfy the Transaction Limits coverage-to-activity threshold. [#SRC:c9a29acd-37bb-40cb-9516-3121dbf18b53] [#TGT:aaaa3ad8-9dea-490e-bd62-04177ed8aa0b] In practice, this means the Third Party Provider must maintain professional indemnity insurance coverage and monitor it against its transaction activity so that the remaining coverage is always more than thirty times the average daily value of all Third Party Transactions calculated over the past ninety calendar days. [#TGT:aaaa3ad8-9dea-490e-bd62-04177ed8aa0b] At the same time, the coverage level must be maintained with the purpose of reimbursing Customers if an operational risk event occurs, so the Third Party Provider should not allow coverage to fall below a level that would undermine that reimbursement objective. [#SRC:c9a29acd-37bb-40cb-9516-3121dbf18b53] Accordingly, compliance requires ongoing maintenance of coverage and ongoing calculation of the ninety-day average daily transaction value to confirm the “greater than thirty times” condition is met at all times. [#TGT:aaaa3ad8-9dea-490e-bd62-04177ed8aa0b]

question: What capabilities must a Recognised Investment Exchange have to determine whether a participant or Member has exceeded a position limit set for a Derivative or class of Derivatives, and what specific categories of positions must it include in that determination (including any Derivative-equivalent treatment for Options)?
expected_answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange must be able to assess whether a participant or Member has gone beyond any position limit that has been set for a Derivative or a class of Derivatives under the relevant rule framework, and it must have capabilities that support making that determination. [#SRC:eadea557-36b4-4076-8a57-1d53f951f4a8] In performing the determination for a position limit imposed in respect of a Derivative, the Recognised Investment Exchange must aggregate more than the participant’s or Member’s own direct holdings. [#TGT:24094c9c-2c15-4682-bda2-38f4934fbe17] Specifically, it must take into account positions held by other Persons that are directly or indirectly controlled by the participant or Member, so that controlled entities’ positions are included in the exceedance test. [#TGT:24094c9c-2c15-4682-bda2-38f4934fbe17] It must also include positions held by other Persons who, under an express or implied agreement or understanding, act as if the position were held by the participant or Member. [#TGT:24094c9c-2c15-4682-bda2-38f4934fbe17] In addition, it must include positions relating to an Option on the Derivative contract, and those option positions must be calculated on a Derivative-equivalent basis for purposes of determining whether the limit has been exceeded. [#TGT:24094c9c-2c15-4682-bda2-38f4934fbe17] These aggregation and calculation elements are part of what the exchange’s capabilities must support when determining exceedance of the applicable position limit. [#SRC:eadea557-36b4-4076-8a57-1d53f951f4a8]

question: Where the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person and the parties have a written agreement disapplying Rule 19.21.5 (liability for charges) and/or setting a different time period for unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions for the purposes of Rule 19.17.1, how should the Payment Service Provider’s liability to the Payment Service User for charges and interest arising from non-execution, defective, or late execution of a Payment Transaction be treated?
expected_answer: Even where the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person and the parties have agreed in writing that certain listed Rules do not apply (including Rule 19.21.5 on liability for charges) and/or have agreed a different time period for unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions for the purposes of Rule 19.17.1, the Payment Service Provider’s liability described in the TARGET provision remains a defined liability statement for charges and interest consequences of execution failures. [#TGT:7a0dd0a5-6eb8-41ba-8900-b4048ce180fa] The SOURCE text is relevant to scope because it permits, for non-Natural Person users, a written agreement to switch off enumerated Rules (including Rule 19.21.5) and to alter the time period tied to unauthorised or incorrectly executed transactions for Rule 19.17.1 purposes. question: For a CR Exposure in the central government and central bank asset class, how must an Authorised Person determine the applicable risk-weighting when Rule 4.12.5 is not met, given that the table-based risk weights are stated to apply subject to Rule 4.12.5?
expected_answer: If Rule 4.12.5 is not met for a CR Exposure, the CR Exposure must be handled under Rule 4.12.4 rather than being risk weighted using the central government and central bank asset class table. [#SRC:d005dde9-921a-4f5c-ac96-c708712bf938] This conclusion applies even where the exposure falls within the central government and central bank asset class, because the table-based approach is expressly conditional on Rule 4.12.5 being satisfied. [#TGT:f3576eb9-2d51-4fbe-bf30-26823907def6] In other words, the table (with risk weights by Credit Quality Grade, including 0% for Grade 1, 20% for Grade 2, 50% for Grade 3, 100% for Grades 4 and 5, 150% for Grade 6, and 100% for Unrated) is the method an Authorised Person must use only when Rule 4.12.5 applies. [#TGT:f3576eb9-2d51-4fbe-bf30-26823907def6] Where the Rule 4.12.5 condition is not met, the required treatment is to follow Rule 4.12.4 for that CR Exposure, instead of applying any of those table risk weights. [#SRC:d005dde9-921a-4f5c-ac96-c708712bf938] The practical compliance step is therefore to first assess whether Rule 4.12.5 is met; if it is not, the exposure is routed to Rule 4.12.4 rather than the table. [#SRC:d005dde9-921a-4f5c-ac96-c708712bf938] [#TGT:f3576eb9-2d51-4fbe-bf30-26823907def6]

question: When an Authorised Person calculates the Exposure value for SFTs as on-balance sheet items using IFRS and the applicable netting requirements, what must it be able to demonstrate to the Regulator is in place for netting to be recognised, including the legal and procedural elements and the failure events covered?
expected_answer: For on-balance sheet SFTs, the Exposure value is determined using IFRS together with the applicable netting requirements, so netting can only be relied on where the Authorised Person can substantiate to the Regulator that its netting framework meets the specified contractual, legal-review, and ongoing-review conditions. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] In practice, this means the Authorised Person must be able to show: (1) it has a netting contract or other agreement that creates a single legal obligation across all transactions included in the netting set, so that if the counterparty fails to perform due to default, bankruptcy, liquidation, or similar circumstances, the Authorised Person has only a right to receive or duty to pay the net sum of positive and negative mark-to-market values; (2) it has written, reasoned legal reviews supporting that courts and administrative authorities would treat the exposure as a net amount under the counterparty’s chartering jurisdiction (and branch jurisdiction where relevant), the law governing the individual transactions, and the law governing any contract needed to effect netting; and (3) it maintains procedures to keep the legal characteristics of the netting arrangements under review as relevant law may change. [#TGT:2d7c2f1d-0a70-43b7-b68c-a2e4ca99c15a]

debug_context.source_text: In relation to on-balance sheet items: a. for SFTs, the Exposure value should be calculated in accordance with IFRS and the Netting requirements referred to in Rule 4.9.14; b. for Derivatives, including written credit protection, the Exposure value should be calculated as the sum of the on-balance sheet value in accordance with IFRS and an add-on for potential future Exposure calculated in accordance with Rules A4.6.14 to A4.6.21 of App 4; and c. for other on-balance sheet items, the Exposure value should be calculated based on their balance sheet values in accordance with Rule 4.9.3.
debug_context.target_text: Netting Sets . In every case in which netting is applied, the Authorised Person must demonstrate to the Regulator that it has the following in place: (a) A netting contract with the counterparty or other agreement which creates a single legal obligation, covering all included transactions, such that the Authorised Person would have either a claim to receive or obligation to pay only the net sum of the positive and negative mark-to-market values of included individual transactions in the event a counterparty fails to perform due to any of the following: (i) default, (ii) bankruptcy, (iii) liquidation, or (iv) similar circumstances. (b) Written and reasoned legal reviews that, in the event of a legal challenge, the relevant courts and administrative authorities would find the exposure of the Authorised Person to be such a net amount under: (i) The law of the jurisdiction in which the counterparty is chartered and, if the foreign branch of a counterparty is involved, then also under the law of the jurisdiction in which the branch is located; (ii) The law that governs the individual transactions; and (iii) The law that governs any contract or agreement necessary to effect the netting. (c) Procedures to ensure that the legal characteristics of netting arrangements are kept under review in light of the possible changes in relevant law.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity makes a disclosure under Rule 11.9.1 that includes forecast financial information derived from a Production Target, how must it address (i) the material economic assumptions (including any claim of commercial sensitivity) and (ii) the need to disclose key underlying assumptions and outcomes from a relevant Technical Study used to support confidence in modifying factors for Ore Reserves?
expected_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity’s Rule 11.9.1 disclosure of forecast financial information derived from a Production Target must be supported by transparent assumptions, and it must also align with the expectation that key assumptions and outcomes from any relevant Technical Study underpinning Ore Reserves confidence are disclosed. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] [#TGT:30cf9cda-951e-48ba-9be2-61a889a87464] Specifically, the disclosure must include all material economic assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] If the Mining Reporting Entity considers those material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, it must state that view and explain the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions (rather than omitting them without explanation). [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] It must also include all other material assumptions utilised. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] In addition, because achieving the required level of confidence in modifying factors for an Ore Reserves estimate requires a relevant Technical Study (preliminary feasibility study or feasibility study), the key underlying assumptions and outcomes of that Technical Study are also to be disclosed. [#TGT:30cf9cda-951e-48ba-9be2-61a889a87464] Finally, the disclosure must identify the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, including the information required by Rule 11.8.3. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]

(c) all other material assumptions utilised. (2) the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).

The key underlying assumptions and outcomes of the Technical Study are also to be disclosed.

question: When an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, how must it determine the maximum distributable amount (including the profit base and the applicable quartile factor), and what specific actions must it refrain from taking until it has both calculated that amount and notified the Regulator?
expected_answer: If an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must calculate a maximum distributable amount and then use that calculation as a gating condition before taking certain capital- and remuneration-related actions. [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e] The maximum distributable amount is determined by multiplying (i) a defined profit sum by (ii) a factor that depends on where the Authorised Person’s CET1 Capital (that is not used to meet the Capital Requirement, including any Individual Capital Requirement) falls within the Combined Buffer Requirement quartiles. [#SRC:429f39da-ff13-4d90-856c-4f12c224cdc1] The profit sum is the total of interim or year-end profits that were not included in CET1 Capital and that accrued after the most recent distribution of profits and after any actions referenced in Rule 3.19.3(b). [#SRC:429f39da-ff13-4d90-856c-4f12c224cdc1] The applicable factor is 0 in the first quartile, 0.2 in the second, 0.4 in the third, and 0.6 in the fourth. [#SRC:429f39da-ff13-4d90-856c-4f12c224cdc1] Until it has calculated the maximum distributable amount and notified the Regulator, it must not: (a) make a distribution connected with CET1 Capital; (b) create an obligation to pay variable remuneration or discretionary pension benefits; (c) pay variable remuneration where the obligation was created when it failed to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement; or (d) make payments on AT1 and T2 Capital instruments. [#TGT:30965fe8-bf1e-44f4-9cd5-7e9b5f84a81e]

debug_context.source_text: Subject to sub-paragraph (4), an Authorised Person must determine the maximum distributable amount by multiplying the sum specified in (a) by the factor determined under (b): (a) the total of interim or year-end profits that were not included in CET1 Capital pursuant to Rule 3.10.2 and which have accrued after the most recent distribution of profits and after any of the actions referred to in Rule 3.19.3(b); (b) where the CET1 Capital of the Authorised Person (which is not used to meet the Capital Requirement, including any Individual Capital Requirement as may be imposed pursuant to Chapter 10) falls: (i) within the first quartile of the Combined Buffer Requirement, the factor shall be 0; (ii) within the second quartile of the Combined Buffer Requirement, the factor shall be 0.2; (iii) within the third quartile of the Combined Buffer Requirement, the factor shall be 0.4; (iv) within the fourth quartile of the Combined Buffer Requirement, the factor shall be 0.6.
debug_context.target_text: Restrictions on distributions. Where an Authorised Person fails to meet the Combined Buffer Requirement, it must: (a) calculate the maximum distributable amount in accordance with Rule 3.19.6; and (b) ensure that it does not undertake any of the following actions until such time as it has calculated the maximum distributable amount and notified the Regulator under Rule 3.19.7: (i) make a distribution in connection with CET1 Capital, or create an obligation to pay variable remuneration or discretionary pension benefits, or pay variable remuneration if the obligation to pay was created at a time when the institution failed to meet its Combined Buffer Requirement; or (ii) make payments on AT1 and T2 Capital instruments.

question: When an Authorised Person is assessing a guarantee as credit risk mitigation (CRM), how do the eligibility conditions for recognising the guarantee’s effects interact with the risk-weight treatment for CR Exposures to specified multilateral development bank (MDB) institutions, and which named institutions receive the stated risk weight?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person can only recognise the effects of CRM from a guarantee if the guarantor falls within the permitted set of provider types, including an MDB referred to in Rule 4.12.8 (as well as other listed categories such as central governments/central banks, PSEs, qualifying banks and Securities firms, or certain externally rated entities). [#SRC:281505d3-a15a-449a-9095-dc247d0e2e5d] Separately, for the MDB asset class treatment described, the Authorised Person is required to apply a 0% risk weight to any CR Exposure to each of the specifically named institutions: the Bank for International Settlements, the International Monetary Fund, the European Central Bank, and the European Commission.
