question: How do the admission-to-listing condition for a Listed Entity's Securities and the post-listing obligation for a person with Securities included in the Official List interact with respect to admission to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, including the timing expectation once Securities are on the Official List?
expected_answer: Admission to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange is both a prerequisite for admission to the Official List and an ongoing requirement once Securities are included in the Official List, with an explicit timing expectation after inclusion. [#SRC:67967cc2-0e3b-48cb-a597-8c681f5ce812] Before a Listed Entity's Securities can be admitted to the Official List, those Securities must be admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, meaning trading admission is a condition that must be satisfied for listing to occur. [#SRC:67967cc2-0e3b-48cb-a597-8c681f5ce812] Separately, once a person has any Securities included in the Official List, those Securities are required to be admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, and this must happen as soon as possible, establishing a timing standard tied to the fact of inclusion in the Official List. [#TGT:cf5937f6-4240-4b27-bbff-f05abc35d577] Read together, the framework links the Official List status to Recognised Investment Exchange trading admission at two points: (i) as an entry condition for a Listed Entity seeking admission to the Official List, and (ii) as a prompt post-inclusion obligation for any person whose Securities are included in the Official List. [#SRC:67967cc2-0e3b-48cb-a597-8c681f5ce812] [#TGT:cf5937f6-4240-4b27-bbff-f05abc35d577]

question: If Securities are going onto the Official List, what has to be true about trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, and once the Securities are already on the Official List, how quickly must they be admitted to trading?
expected_answer: Trading admission on a Recognised Investment Exchange is required both to get Securities onto the Official List and to ensure they are properly handled once they are already included, with a specific speed requirement after inclusion. [#SRC:67967cc2-0e3b-48cb-a597-8c681f5ce812] For admission to the Official List, a Listed Entity's Securities must be admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, so listing is not available unless trading admission on such an exchange is in place. [#SRC:67967cc2-0e3b-48cb-a597-8c681f5ce812] After that point, where a person has any Securities included in the Official List, those Securities must be admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange as soon as possible, which adds a timing expectation linked to the Securities being included in the Official List. question: Where an Applicant/Authorised Person will undertake a Regulated Activity involving conventional assets in addition to Virtual Assets and therefore must seek FSRA approval for both asset types, how should the firm assess whether fees for the two categories could be charged cumulatively, and what discretion does the Regulator have to reduce, waive, or refund fees (including supplementary or late payment fees) in that context?
expected_answer: If an Applicant/Authorised Person plans to conduct a Regulated Activity involving conventional assets as well as Virtual Assets, it must obtain FSRA approval to carry on the Regulated Activity in relation to both asset types. [#SRC:743f4b18-44d3-4fe2-ac7a-077cdd333689] In assessing whether fees for the conventional and Virtual Asset-related activities will be cumulative, the firm should treat non-cumulative outcomes as dependent on the FSRA’s exercise of discretion to reduce or waive a fee, rather than as an automatic entitlement. [#SRC:743f4b18-44d3-4fe2-ac7a-077cdd333689] The Regulator’s discretion is broad: it may, at any time, reduce, waive, or refund all or part of any fee, and this expressly includes supplementary or late payment fees, where it considers that doing so would be fair and reasonable in the circumstances of the particular case. question: When an Authorised Person recognises the effect of eligible financial Collateral, how must it choose between the Financial Collateral Simplified Approach (FCSA) and the Financial Collateral Comprehensive Approach (FCCA), and if it uses the FCCA, what instruments qualify as eligible financial Collateral (including any conditions for Units in a Collective Investment Fund)?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral by applying one of two specified approaches: the Financial Collateral Simplified Approach (FCSA) or the Financial Collateral Comprehensive Approach (FCCA). [#SRC:f161ce59-6314-4980-8eaf-752bb38a5a19] If the Authorised Person elects to use the FCCA, the set of eligible financial Collateral includes (i) any instrument that is listed in Rule 4.13.5, (ii) any equity Security (expressly including a convertible bond) provided it is traded on a regulated exchange, and (iii) any Unit in a Collective Investment Fund that invests in those regulated-exchange-traded equity Securities. [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85] For Units in a Collective Investment Fund to be eligible under the FCCA, two conditions must be met: the Unit price must be publicly quoted on a daily basis, and at least 90% of the Fund’s deposited property must be invested in instruments that are listed in the FCCA rule and in Rule 4.13.5. [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85] This FCCA eligibility scope operates within the broader requirement that the Authorised Person use either FCSA (which adopts the treatment under Rule 4.13.5 for collateral composition) or FCCA (which adopts the treatment under Rule 4.13.6) to recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral. [#SRC:f161ce59-6314-4980-8eaf-752bb38a5a19]

debug_context.target_text: For an Authorised Person using the FCCA, eligible financial Collateral comprises: (a) any instrument listed in Rule 4.13.5; (b) any equity Security (including a convertible bond) that is traded on a regulated exchange; and (c) any Unit in a Collective Investment Fund which invests in equity Securities referred to in (b), where: (i) a price for the Units is publicly quoted daily; and (ii) at least 90% of the deposited property of the Fund is invested in instruments listed in this Rule and Rule 4.13.5.

question: For an Authorised Person that is Providing Custody in relation to Virtual Assets, how do the minimum frequencies for (i) sending the COBS Rule 15.8.1(a) statements to a Retail Client and (ii) conducting reconciliations compare with the separate requirement to reconcile Client Accounts held with Third Party Agents to monthly statements from those Third Party Agents?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person that is Providing Custody in relation to Virtual Assets must apply an accelerated cadence for two COBS Chapter 15 activities, while also meeting a distinct monthly reconciliation obligation for Third Party Agent-held Client Accounts. [#SRC:5b7dc83f-010b-4f5e-8eb9-e928d151c11e] Specifically, the statements referenced in COBS Rule 15.8.1(a) must be provided to a Retail Client no less frequently than once per month. [#SRC:5b7dc83f-010b-4f5e-8eb9-e928d151c11e] In addition, all reconciliations that are required under COBS Rule 15.9.1 must be performed at least weekly, which is more frequent than a monthly cycle. [#SRC:5b7dc83f-010b-4f5e-8eb9-e928d151c11e] Separately, regardless of that weekly minimum for COBS Rule 15.9.1 reconciliations, the Authorised Person must also reconcile its records of Client Accounts held with Third Party Agents against the monthly statements it receives from those Third Party Agents at least every calendar month. [#TGT:99a621ce-b3ab-4dbc-a9c7-eac1065776e6] Taken together, this means the Retail Client statement cadence is monthly, the COBS Rule 15.9.1 reconciliation cadence is weekly, and the Third Party Agent statement-to-record reconciliation cadence is at least every calendar month. [#SRC:5b7dc83f-010b-4f5e-8eb9-e928d151c11e][#TGT:99a621ce-b3ab-4dbc-a9c7-eac1065776e6]

debug_context.source_text: For the purposes of an Authorised Person that is Providing Custody in relation to Virtual Assets, the following requirements in COBS, Chapter 15 shall be read as follows - (a) the statements required under COBS Rule 15.8.1(a) must be sent to a Retail Client at least monthly; and (b) all reconciliations required under COBS Rule 15.9.1 must be conducted at least every week.

question: When the Regulator is considering disclosing Confidential Information to a criminal law enforcement agency (in the U.A.E or otherwise) for the purpose of a criminal investigation or criminal proceedings under paragraph 199(1)(b)(v), do the prior written consent conditions that apply to other disclosure gateways (including where the information originates from another authority or is CRD Information) need to be satisfied?
expected_answer: For a disclosure by the Regulator to a criminal law enforcement agency (whether in the U.A.E or elsewhere) specifically for a criminal investigation or criminal proceedings under paragraph 199(1)(b)(v), the Regulator is not required to comply with the requirements in section 199(2). [#SRC:3ea3d5aa-2378-40cd-ab7a-f454859a385c] By contrast, for disclosures made under paragraphs (1)(b)(i), (ii), (iii), (iv), (vi) and 1(c), the Regulator cannot disclose Confidential Information unless the conditions in paragraphs (a) and (b) are met. [#TGT:3c8ef7e5-1e03-4523-abe0-9bd8451cee4c] Those conditions include obtaining prior written consent from the governmental or regulatory authority that originally provided the Confidential Information where the information (in whole or in part) originates from such an authority (whether in the Abu Dhabi Global Market or otherwise). [#TGT:3c8ef7e5-1e03-4523-abe0-9bd8451cee4c] In addition, where the Confidential Information is CRD Information, the EEA Competent Authority that provided it must give prior written consent, and if that consent is purpose-limited, the Regulator’s disclosure must be solely for that purpose. [#TGT:3c8ef7e5-1e03-4523-abe0-9bd8451cee4c] Accordingly, the criminal law enforcement disclosure route under paragraph 199(1)(b)(v) is treated differently from the other listed routes because it is expressly carved out from section 199(2)’s requirements. [#SRC:3ea3d5aa-2378-40cd-ab7a-f454859a385c]

question: When determining the risk weight for a CR Exposure, how should an Authorised Person treat an exposure that is categorised as a cash item but is specifically a cheque, draft, or other item drawn on another banking institution that is payable immediately upon presentation or is in the process of collection?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must classify and risk-weight the CR Exposure by applying the specific treatment for cheques, drafts, and similar items drawn on other banking institutions when the item is payable immediately upon presentation or is in the process of collection, rather than relying solely on the general ability to apply a 0% risk weight to cash items. [#TGT:fa446f03-a066-46e1-beb1-d67d0862d0f8] While the framework allows an Authorised Person to apply a 0% risk weight to a CR Exposure that is categorised as a cash item, that permission is expressly conditional and therefore does not automatically determine the outcome for every instrument that might be viewed as a cash item. [#SRC:881a93fe-965d-4247-98b7-13b0248c8b98] In practice, where the exposure is a cheque, draft, or other item drawn on another banking institution and meets the “payable immediately” or “in collection” condition, the Authorised Person must apply a 20% risk weight to that exposure. [#TGT:fa446f03-a066-46e1-beb1-d67d0862d0f8] The key compliance step is to confirm both (i) the categorisation as a cash item and (ii) whether the instrument is drawn on another banking institution and is payable immediately or in collection, because the latter condition triggers the mandatory 20% treatment. [#SRC:881a93fe-965d-4247-98b7-13b0248c8b98] [#TGT:fa446f03-a066-46e1-beb1-d67d0862d0f8]

debug_context.source_text: Subject to Rule 4.12.3, an Authorised Person may apply a 0% risk weight to any CR Exposure categorised as a cash item.
debug_context.target_text: An Authorised Person must apply a 20% risk weight to cheques, drafts and other items drawn on other banking institutions that are either payable immediately upon presentation or that are in the process of collection.

question: If an Authorised Person has a CR Exposure that looks like a cash item, but it is a cheque or draft drawn on another banking institution and it is either payable right away or still being collected, what risk weight should be used?
expected_answer: The risk weight should be 20% in that situation, because the rule for cheques, drafts, and other items drawn on other banking institutions applies when they are payable immediately upon presentation or are in the process of collection. [#TGT:fa446f03-a066-46e1-beb1-d67d0862d0f8] Even though an Authorised Person is permitted to apply a 0% risk weight to a CR Exposure that is categorised as a cash item, that permission is stated as conditional and therefore does not, by itself, settle the treatment for every instrument that might be treated as a cash item. [#SRC:881a93fe-965d-4247-98b7-13b0248c8b98] To apply the correct risk weight, the Authorised Person should check two things: first, that the exposure is a CR Exposure and is categorised as a cash item; and second, whether it is a cheque, draft, or similar item drawn on another banking institution that is payable immediately or is still being collected. [#SRC:881a93fe-965d-4247-98b7-13b0248c8b98] [#TGT:fa446f03-a066-46e1-beb1-d67d0862d0f8] If the second condition is met, the mandatory 20% risk weight applies to that item, rather than applying 0% solely because it is treated as a cash item. [#TGT:fa446f03-a066-46e1-beb1-d67d0862d0f8] [#SRC:881a93fe-965d-4247-98b7-13b0248c8b98]

question: When an Issuer is preparing an Offer of Digital Securities and wants the Regulator to treat an investment that is not otherwise a Security as a Security for the purposes of the Regulations and Rules, what role does the FSRA expect the Issuer’s legal advisers to play, and how does the Regulator effect that treatment (including the form of action and any conditions)?
expected_answer: In this scenario, the Issuer should use suitable legal advisers to support compliance across the Offer process, including helping the Issuer obtain the FSRA’s treatment of the Digital Security as a Security under the relevant framework, and to manage the Offer documentation process with the FSRA. [#SRC:a2de4d3e-7795-4d1c-b950-8cb4b9024c89] The Regulator effects the treatment of an investment that is not a Security as a Security by issuing a written notice deeming it to be a Security for the purposes of the Regulations and the Rules made under them, and it may attach whatever terms and conditions it considers appropriate to that deeming. [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c] Practically, the FSRA expects legal advisers to assist the Issuer in ensuring compliance with the applicable provisions of FSMR and MKT (including the Listing Rules within MKT), and to support the drafting of Offer documentation that will be reviewed by the FSRA. [#SRC:a2de4d3e-7795-4d1c-b950-8cb4b9024c89] The FSRA also generally expects to engage directly with the Issuer’s legal advisers throughout the process, particularly around drafting and FSRA review of the Offer documentation, which aligns with the need to address any terms and conditions the Regulator may impose in its written notice. [#SRC:a2de4d3e-7795-4d1c-b950-8cb4b9024c89] [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c]

question: Where an executed Third Party Transaction was not authorised in accordance with Rule 20.7 and it leads to an unauthorised Payment Transaction, what refunds must the Third Party Provider make (including how amounts are netted between the Primary Financial Institution and the Customer), and by when must the refund be provided once the Third Party Provider has confirmed the Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed?
expected_answer: In the scenario where an executed Third Party Transaction was not authorised in accordance with Rule 20.7 and it results in an unauthorised Payment Transaction, the Third Party Provider has a dual refund obligation that allocates amounts between the Primary Financial Institution and the Customer, and it must also meet a specific timing standard once it has confirmed the issue. [#TGT:5c21fe85-f19e-4984-bd0b-9f4b0d76bebe] Specifically, the Third Party Provider must (a) reimburse the Primary Financial Institution for the amount the Primary Financial Institution may already have repaid to the Customer, and (b) reimburse the Customer for the amount of the unauthorised Payment Transaction, reduced by any amount the Third Party Provider has already reimbursed to the Primary Financial Institution (so the Customer is not paid twice for the same loss). [#TGT:5c21fe85-f19e-4984-bd0b-9f4b0d76bebe] Once the Third Party Provider has confirmed that the Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed, it must provide the refund as soon as practicable and, at the latest, by the end of the day after the day of that confirmation. [#SRC:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259] This timing requirement applies to the refund obligation described, ensuring prompt remediation after confirmation. [#SRC:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259]

expected_answer: When an executed Third Party Transaction was not authorised in line with Rule 20.7 and it leads to an unauthorised Payment Transaction, the Third Party Provider must make refunds to both the Primary Financial Institution and the Customer, with an offset to prevent double recovery. [#TGT:5c21fe85-f19e-4984-bd0b-9f4b0d76bebe] The Third Party Provider must refund the Primary Financial Institution for any amount the Primary Financial Institution may already have refunded to the Customer. [#TGT:5c21fe85-f19e-4984-bd0b-9f4b0d76bebe] It must also refund the Customer for the amount of the unauthorised Payment Transaction, but it can subtract (i.e., pay “less”) any amount it has already refunded to the Primary Financial Institution, so the Customer is not effectively reimbursed twice for the same unauthorised amount. [#TGT:5c21fe85-f19e-4984-bd0b-9f4b0d76bebe] After the Third Party Provider has confirmed that the Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed, it must provide the refund promptly and no later than the end of the day following the day of that confirmation. [#SRC:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259] This creates a clear latest cut-off tied to the confirmation date, rather than the original execution date. [#SRC:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259]

question: When an Authorised Person (and its participants) proposes to use a delivery and/or storage facility for Accepted Spot Commodities from outside the ADGM, what jurisdictional limitation applies and what specific facility-level conditions must be satisfied for that facility to be acceptable for the purposes of Rule 22.4.1?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person, and its participants, may use delivery and/or storage facilities for Accepted Spot Commodities only if the facilities are located either within the ADGM or in another appropriate jurisdiction that can meet the requirements tied to Rule 22.4.2; therefore, a facility outside ADGM is permissible only if it qualifies as being in an “other appropriate jurisdiction” and meets those requirements. [#SRC:4230a066-37c4-4630-bb93-d9a0ed5bc81b] For the purposes of Rule 22.4.1, a facility used by an Authorised Person that operates from outside ADGM must operate under rules and regulations equivalent to those applying in the Abu Dhabi Global Market. [#TGT:dda13926-2cce-4e09-a50f-508bd4257bd5] In addition, the facility must at all times comply with all applicable laws in the relevant jurisdiction or elsewhere, including local port conditions, customs requirements, anticorruption laws, and taxation requirements. [#TGT:dda13926-2cce-4e09-a50f-508bd4257bd5] It must also adhere to appropriate international standards for storage and delivery mechanisms (including IOSCO’s Good and Sound Practices) and maintain OHSAS 18001 Health & Safety Management or equivalent certification standards. [#TGT:dda13926-2cce-4e09-a50f-508bd4257bd5] Finally, the facility must have appropriate audit and control arrangements for inventories, deliveries and physical infrastructure, and appropriate insurance arrangements covering operational, security, fraud, natural disasters and other applicable risks. [#TGT:dda13926-2cce-4e09-a50f-508bd4257bd5]

question: Where an Authorised Person operating an MTF or OTF wishes to also operate a RIE, what must happen to its FSP upon obtaining a Recognition Order, and how does the Recognition Order’s stipulation affect (i) whether the RIE may operate the MTF/OTF and (ii) which rulebook provisions apply to that MTF/OTF function?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person that is operating an MTF or OTF and wants to also operate a RIE must give up (relinquish) its FSP when it obtains the Recognition Order to operate the RIE. [#SRC:d27a9a5d-f443-4ca1-a549-8316b911bfe7] Once the entity is a Recognised Investment Exchange, it may only carry on the Regulated Activity of operating an MTF or OTF if its Recognition Order expressly contains a stipulation allowing that additional function. [#TGT:8e498a69-8f0c-44c3-970c-58d870656388] Where the FSRA licenses the entity to carry out both Regulated Activities (for example, operating an MTF and operating an RIE), the Recognition Order is expected to include a stipulation to that effect (noted as being pursuant to MIR Rule 3.4.1). [#SRC:d27a9a5d-f443-4ca1-a549-8316b911bfe7] If the Recognition Order includes the stipulation permitting operation of an MTF or OTF, then the MTF/OTF-specific rules in COBS apply to that function, and they apply only to that function rather than to the RIE’s other activities. [#TGT:8e498a69-8f0c-44c3-970c-58d870656388] In practical compliance terms, the Recognition Order is the key instrument that both triggers the FSP relinquishment for the transitioning Authorised Person and defines the permitted scope and applicable rule set for any MTF/OTF activity conducted by the Recognised Investment Exchange. [#SRC:d27a9a5d-f443-4ca1-a549-8316b911bfe7][#TGT:8e498a69-8f0c-44c3-970c-58d870656388]

If licensed by the FSRA to carry out both Regulated Activities (e.g., operating an MTF and operating an RIE), the Recognition Order will include a stipulation to that effect pursuant to MIR Rule 3.4.1.
debug_context.target_text: A Recognised Investment Exchange may carry on the Regulated Activity of operating an MTF or OTF provided that its Recognition Order includes a stipulation permitting it to do so. If it does include such a stipulation, the specific rules on MTFs and OTFs in COBS will apply to that function, but that function only.

question: If an Authorised Person already runs an MTF or OTF and then wants to become a RIE, what do they have to do with their FSP when they get the Recognition Order, and what does the Recognition Order need to say so the RIE can keep running the MTF/OTF—and which rules apply to that MTF/OTF work?
expected_answer: When an Authorised Person that operates an MTF or OTF decides to also operate a RIE, it must relinquish its FSP at the point it obtains the Recognition Order to operate the RIE. [#SRC:d27a9a5d-f443-4ca1-a549-8316b911bfe7][#TGT:8e498a69-8f0c-44c3-970c-58d870656388]

question: When an Authorised Person that has its registered head office in ADGM applies to the Regulator for approval to establish a branch outside ADGM, what fee basis applies to the application, and in what circumstance may the Regulator additionally impose a supplementary fee linked to the destination jurisdiction’s regulatory cooperation arrangements?
expected_answer: For an application by an Authorised Person that has its registered head office in ADGM to establish a branch outside ADGM, the applicant must pay an application fee calculated as 50% of the highest application fee in Chapter 3 for the Regulated Activities it proposes to carry on from that branch. [#TGT:363c3cff-9b23-461e-a521-d56d8c16221f] In addition to that application-fee basis, the Regulator may also charge a supplementary fee where the proposed branch would operate in a jurisdiction in which there is not an adequate memorandum of understanding between the Regulator and the relevant Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator for that jurisdiction. [#SRC:a2ed572d-bcf6-4660-b11b-d8db3a7aad92] Practically, this means the fee outcome has two components: (i) a mandatory application fee tied to the highest Chapter 3 fee applicable to the Regulated Activities intended to be undertaken from the branch, and (ii) a potential extra charge that depends on whether the destination jurisdiction has adequate regulatory cooperation arrangements in place with the Regulator. [#TGT:363c3cff-9b23-461e-a521-d56d8c16221f] [#SRC:a2ed572d-bcf6-4660-b11b-d8db3a7aad92] The supplementary fee is not automatic; it is triggered by the absence of an adequate memorandum of understanding with the relevant Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator in the jurisdiction where the branch would operate. [#SRC:a2ed572d-bcf6-4660-b11b-d8db3a7aad92]

debug_context.target_text: Where an Authorised Person that has its registered head office in ADGM applies to the Regulator for approval to establish a branch outside ADGM, it must pay to the Regulator an application fee equal to 50% of the highest application fee set out in Chapter 3 of these Rules for those Regulated Activities it seeks to undertake from the proposed branch.

[#SRC:a2ed572d-bcf6-4660-b11b-d8db3a7aad92] So, to assess what may be payable, you need both (1) the Chapter 3 “highest application fee” reference point for the specific Regulated Activities intended to be undertaken from the branch, and (2) the status of regulatory cooperation arrangements (the adequacy of the memorandum of understanding) with the destination jurisdiction’s Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator. question: When the Board of a Listed Entity (and each individual Director who is a member of that Board) is operating within a section that uses the term “Shareholder,” how should that term be applied where the relevant vote is by holders of Debentures on a variation of rights or terms, and what related rule-considerations are the Regulator expecting to be treated as applicable?
expected_answer: For the Board of a Listed Entity and each individual Director who is a member of that Board, the section’s references to “Shareholder” should be treated as extending to holders of all classes of Securities where that makes sense for the Listed Entity’s circumstances, rather than being read narrowly as equity holders only. [#TGT:2669439e-beee-42e0-90fd-9b8bbdac7183] In particular, where holders of Debentures are being asked to vote on a variation of rights or terms, the Regulator’s expectation is that the relevant decision-makers treat the “Shareholder” references as capturing the Debenture holders for that purpose. [#SRC:73f40402-9aa2-40a2-b7f9-ccba8d02720b] As a result, the Regulator expects the Person referred to in Rule 9.3.1—operating in this section that applies to the Board and its individual Directors—to give appropriate weight to the requirements in Rules 9.3.6 and 9.3.7 as though those requirements were written to apply to the relevant Debenture holders. [#SRC:73f40402-9aa2-40a2-b7f9-ccba8d02720b] This approach ensures that, in Debenture-holder voting scenarios, the same section-level “Shareholder” framework is applied consistently across the applicable actors (the Board and each Director) while aligning with the Regulator’s stated expectations for how the rules should be considered in context. [#TGT:2669439e-beee-42e0-90fd-9b8bbdac7183] [#SRC:73f40402-9aa2-40a2-b7f9-ccba8d02720b]

debug_context.source_text: The Regulator will expect a Person referred to in Rule 9.3.1 to consider references to a “Shareholder” in this section to refer equally to holders of all classes of Securities as may be applicable in the context of the Listed Entity. For example, in a situation where holders of Debentures are to be asked to vote on a variation of rights or terms, the Regulator will expect a Person referred to in Rule 9.3.1 to give due consideration to the requirements of Rules 9.3.6 and 9.3.7 as if it referred to the relevant Debenture holders.

question: Where a Passported Fund remains materially prejudicial in ADGM despite measures taken by a Home Regulator, how does the Regulator’s ability to request urgent discussions with that Home Regulator connect to the Regulator’s subsequent power to take protective measures if those urgent discussions do not resolve the issues within a reasonable period?
expected_answer: In the Passported Fund context, if a Home Regulator has already taken measures (if any) but the Fund Manager’s activities in ADGM (or those of its Agent or any other Licensed Person promoting the Passported Fund) continue to be materially prejudicial to Unitholders situated in ADGM or to ADGM’s financial stability or integrity, the Regulator may initiate the process by requesting urgent discussions with the Home Regulator responsible for supervision and enforcement of the Passported Fund. [#TGT:722d2090-eec8-4ae1-8d98-db9a10f13e55] If those urgent discussions (as referenced in Rule 9.5.2) do not resolve the issues to the Regulator’s satisfaction within a period that is reasonable in the circumstances, the Regulator may then escalate by taking all appropriate measures needed to protect the interests of Unitholders domiciled in ADGM or to protect the financial stability and integrity of the ADGM market. [#SRC:6a79069b-b2b7-4349-9fa6-ae21f98b3a02] This linkage means the “urgent discussions” step functions as a precursor mechanism in the scenario where prejudice persists despite Home Regulator action, and the trigger for further intervention is the failure of those discussions to achieve a satisfactory resolution within a reasonable timeframe. [#TGT:722d2090-eec8-4ae1-8d98-db9a10f13e55] [#SRC:6a79069b-b2b7-4349-9fa6-ae21f98b3a02]

question: When an Authorised Person is acting as a Virtual Asset Custodian and applying the custody requirements in COBS Rules 17.1 to 17.6 together with the additional Rules in COBS Rule 17.8, how must the terms “Client Investments” and “Investments” be interpreted in relation to Virtual Assets, and what is the stated regulatory purpose for that interpretive approach?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person providing custody of virtual assets as a Virtual Asset Custodian must apply the custody framework in COBS Rules 17.1 to 17.6 and also comply with the additional requirements in COBS Rule 17.8. [#SRC:15ac7d0d-8853-444c-8a24-8678075fa3c7] In doing so, the interpretive rule for Rule 17.8.1 requires that “Investment” or “Investments” (and therefore the related references to “Client Investments”) be treated as including “Virtual Asset” or “Virtual Assets”, as applicable. [#TGT:1a0d0b8c-b8bf-48a1-b6ab-683d17ae56a0] This means that, for the purposes of applying the custody obligations that operate by reference to “Client Investments,” Virtual Assets are brought within that same terminology rather than being treated as outside the scope of those references. [#TGT:1a0d0b8c-b8bf-48a1-b6ab-683d17ae56a0] The stated regulatory purpose for this approach is to ensure that Accepted Virtual Assets receive the same protections as other similar products and activities under FSMR and the FSRA Rulebook. [#SRC:15ac7d0d-8853-444c-8a24-8678075fa3c7]

COBS Rule 17.8.2 requires that the existing definitions of “Client Assets” and “Client Investments” be read to include “Virtual Assets”. This approach has been taken by the FSRA to ensure that Accepted Virtual Assets are afforded the same protections as other similar products and activities under FSMR and the FSRA Rulebook.

question: When applying the 20% cap formula for a Listed Entity’s proposed issue or agreement to issue Equity Securities, how must the entity count Convertible Securities and partly paid Securities when determining the number of Equity Securities for the “Relevant Issues” subtraction, and how does that counting interact with the requirement for approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities?
expected_answer: A Listed Entity must not issue, or agree to issue, more Equity Securities than the maximum number produced by the formula (20% × Base Amount) minus Relevant Issues unless it has approval from the holders of Ordinary Securities. [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] To apply that formula correctly, the entity must calculate the number of Equity Securities it is issuing or agreeing to issue (including those that contribute to “Relevant Issues”) using the specified counting rules, unless the Regulator determines otherwise. [#SRC:e56b6a34-d8ed-4fe6-8138-3c085996ee3f] In that calculation, each partly paid Security is counted as the maximum number of fully paid Ordinary Securities into which it can be paid up, and each Convertible Security is counted as the maximum number of fully paid Ordinary Securities into which it can be converted. [#SRC:e56b6a34-d8ed-4fe6-8138-3c085996ee3f] Those counted amounts then feed into the “Relevant Issues” figure, which is defined as Equity Securities issued or agreed to be issued in the prior 12 months, excluding those done with holder approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5 or under an exception in Rule 9.7.4. [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] Accordingly, the counting method determines the size of the subtraction for Relevant Issues and, in turn, whether the proposed issue exceeds the cap and therefore requires holder approval. [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]

debug_context.source_text: Requirements applicable to new issues under Rule 9.7.1 . In calculating the number of Equity Securities that a Listed Entity may issue or agree to issue under Rule 9.7.1 (including the number contributing to “Relevant Issues”), unless the Regulator determines otherwise, the following must be applied: (1) each fully paid Ordinary Security is counted as one; (2) each partly paid Security is counted as the maximum number of fully paid Ordinary Securities into which it can be paid up; (3) each Convertible Security is counted as the maximum number of fully paid Ordinary Securities into which it can be converted; and (4) in any other case, each Security is counted as the Regulator may decide, having regard to the need to ensure that holders of Ordinary Securities have an opportunity to vote on issues that may dilute their holdings or the characteristics of the Security.
debug_context.target_text: Restrictions on new Issues of Equity Securities . A Listed Entity must not issue, or agree to issue, more Equity Securities than the number calculated according to the following formula, without the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities: Maximum number of Equity Securities = (20% * Base Amount) – Relevant Issues), where: Base Amount = the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities on issue as of the date 12 months before the date of issue or agreement (the “12 months Base Amount”), plus the number of: (1) fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exceptions (8), (15) or (16); (2) fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exception (15), where the agreement was: (i) entered into before the commencement of the 12 month period; or (ii) approved, or taken under the Rules to have been approved, under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; and (3) any other fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement with approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; Guidance The Base Amount may include fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an agreement to issue Securities within Rule 9.7.4 exception (14) where the issue is subsequently approved under Rule 9.7.1. (4) partly paid Ordinary Securities that became fully paid in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement, but subtracting the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities cancelled in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement. Relevant Issues = the number of Equity Securities issued, or agreed to be issued, in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement to issue other than: (a) with the approval of the holders of its Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; or (b) under an exception in Rule 9.7.4.

question: If a Listed Entity is checking whether it needs holders of Ordinary Securities to approve a new issue because of the 20% limit, how should it count partly paid Securities and Convertible Securities when working out the number of Equity Securities for the calculation, including the “Relevant Issues” part?
expected_answer: To decide whether approval from holders of Ordinary Securities is needed, the Listed Entity must compare the proposed issue (or agreement to issue) against the maximum allowed under the formula: (20% × Base Amount) minus Relevant Issues; issuing above that maximum is not permitted without that approval. [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] When determining the number of Equity Securities for this purpose (including the amount that contributes to “Relevant Issues”), the entity must apply the counting approach set for new issues unless the Regulator determines otherwise. [#SRC:e56b6a34-d8ed-4fe6-8138-3c085996ee3f] Under that approach, a partly paid Security is treated as the maximum number of fully paid Ordinary Securities it could become if fully paid up, and a Convertible Security is treated as the maximum number of fully paid Ordinary Securities it could convert into. [#SRC:e56b6a34-d8ed-4fe6-8138-3c085996ee3f] Those counted totals are then used when identifying “Relevant Issues,” which covers Equity Securities issued or agreed to be issued in the prior 12 months, but excludes issues made with approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5 and issues made under an exception in Rule 9.7.4. [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] Using these counting rules ensures the cap test reflects potential dilution in fully paid Ordinary Securities terms. [#SRC:e56b6a34-d8ed-4fe6-8138-3c085996ee3f]

question: When calculating CET1 deductions for investments in CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities under Rule 3.10.7(g) and (h), how should an Authorised Person determine whether to use gross long positions or a net long position approach for Trading Book holdings, and what additional method applies where the Trading Book exposure is indirect via index Securities?
expected_answer: For Rule 3.10.7(g) and (h), an Authorised Person must apply the Trading Book-specific netting methodology described for those holdings, rather than defaulting to a gross-long-only approach for all positions. [#TGT:f6640865-b279-44c1-941f-091a1619258c] The SOURCE establishes that, for Rule 3.10.7(f), (g) and (h), the deductible amount is calculated on the basis of gross long positions (with a stated cross-reference to Rule 3.10.15), which creates the baseline calculation concept that must be reconciled with the TARGET’s Trading Book treatment for (g) and (h). [#SRC:40c66431-d7b0-41ae-bc47-0ae63f4d9454] In practice under (g) and (h), for holdings in the Trading Book, the holdings must be calculated using the net long position in the same underlying Exposure, but only where the short position’s maturity matches the long position’s maturity or the short has a residual maturity of at least one year. [#TGT:f6640865-b279-44c1-941f-091a1619258c] Additionally, where the Trading Book holding is indirect and takes the form of holdings of index Securities, the amount to be deducted must be determined by calculating the underlying Exposure to the capital instruments of the Relevant Entities included in the indices. [#TGT:f6640865-b279-44c1-941f-091a1619258c]

debug_context.source_text: CET1 Deductions - investments in CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities. For the purposes of Rule 3.10.7(f), (g) and (h), the amount of holdings of CET1 Capital instruments and other capital instruments of Relevant Entities to be deducted, must be calculated, subject to Rule 3.10.15, on the basis of the gross long positions.
debug_context.target_text: CET1 Deductions - investments in CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities. For the purposes of Rule 3.10.7(g) and (h), an Authorised Person must make the deductions in accordance with the following: (a) the holdings in the Trading Book of the capital instruments of Relevant Entities must be calculated on the basis of the net long position in the same underlying Exposure provided the maturity of the short position matches the maturity of the long position or has a residual maturity of at least one year; and (b) the amount to be deducted for indirect holdings in the Trading Book of the capital instruments of Relevant Entities that take the form of holdings of index Securities must be determined by calculating the underlying Exposure to the capital instruments of the Relevant Entities in the indices.

question: Where a Fund Manager enters into a Delegation Agreement or Outsourcing Agreement under the Fund Rules, which text governs the applicable requirements: the chapter that states it does not apply to Fund Managers, or Appendix A1 (APP 1); and what core agreement and record-keeping provisions must the Fund Manager (and, if appointed, the Trustee) ensure are included and maintained, noting any stated carve-out for a Qualified Investor Fund?
expected_answer: For a Fund Manager, the chapter that expressly excludes Fund Managers is not the governing text; instead, the Fund Manager is directed to the provisions in section 15.3 and Appendix A1.3 of the Fund Rules, so the operative requirements for delegation/outsourcing sit in APP 1 rather than that chapter. [#SRC:77d6d088-e887-4010-b1f2-c066a0409cca] APP 1 applies to a Fund Manager and, if appointed, the Trustee for every Delegation Agreement and Outsourcing Agreement made under the Rules, but it is stated not to apply to a Qualified Investor Fund. [#TGT:20b3551f-5646-4001-97ce-63eeaabbec5b] Within that scope, the Fund Manager/Trustee must ensure the relevant agreement describes the functions/activities and service standards, and prevents the Service Provider from further delegation/outsourcing without prior approval from the Fund Manager/Trustee (as applicable). [#TGT:20b3551f-5646-4001-97ce-63eeaabbec5b] The agreement must also require the Service Provider to keep transaction records that support preparation of compliant accounts, retain those records for at least six years, keep them open to inspection by the Regulator, the Fund’s Auditor and any oversight function provider, and be able to reproduce them in English hard copy within no more than three days if the Regulator requests. [#TGT:20b3551f-5646-4001-97ce-63eeaabbec5b] Separately, the Fund Manager/Trustee must keep records of all agreements and instructions to the Service Provider for at least six years. [#TGT:20b3551f-5646-4001-97ce-63eeaabbec5b]

debug_context.source_text: This chapter does not apply to Fund Managers, who are subject to the provisions of section 15.3 and Appendix A1.3 of the Fund Rules.
debug_context.target_text: DELEGATION AND OUTSOURCING A1.1 Application A1.1.1.(1) This Appendix (‎APP 1) applies to a Fund Manager and, if appointed, the Trustee in relation to every: (a) Delegation Agreement; and (b) Outsourcing Agreement. made or entered into pursuant to these Rules. A1.1.1.(2) This Appendix does not apply to a Qualified Investor Fund. A1.2 Mandatory provisions A1.2.1.(1) A Fund Manager or Trustee must ensure that any agreement specified in Rule ‎A1.1.1(1): (a) sets out the functions or activities and service standards that will be applied to the carrying out of such functions or activities; (b) provides that the Service Provider cannot in turn delegate any activities delegated to it, or outsource any functions outsourced to it, without prior approval of the Fund Manager or Trustee as applicable; (c) requires the Service Provider to: (i) maintain records to show and explain transactions in relation to each activity or function performed in relation to the Fund; (ii) maintain such records in a manner to enable the Fund Manager or Trustee to prepare accounts in compliance with these Rules and any other applicable legislation; (iii) retain the records for at least six years from the date to which they relate; (iv) keep the records, at all reasonable times, open to inspection by the Regulator, the Fund's Auditor and any Person providing the oversight function for the Fund; and (v) ensure that the records are, if requested by the Regulator, capable of reproduction within a reasonable period not exceeding 3 days, in hard copy and in English. A1.2.1.(2) A Fund Manager or Trustee must ensure that a Delegation Agreement contains an undertaking by the Service Provider to: (a) comply with any Regulator Rules applicable to the activity; and (b) disclose to the Regulator and to the Fund Manager or Trustee, as the case may be, any material information that it would disclose to its Financial Services Regulator, if relevant, in relation to the conduct of the activity. A1.2.1.(3) A Fund Manager or Trustee must maintain records of all agreements, and any instructions given to a Service Provider under the terms of an agreement, for at least six years. A1.2.Guidance A1.2.Guidance.1 Other Rules may also impact on the contents of a Delegation Agreement or Outsourcing Agreement. For instance, consideration should be given to GEN Rules 3.3.31 and 3.3.32 and accompanying Guidance. A1.2.Guidance.2 Without limiting the application of any Rules, the Regulator expects that any agreement relating to a material delegation would include as a minimum: a. unambiguous descriptions and definitions of the activities or functions to be provided by the Service Provider and the duties of both parties; b. an agreed standard between the parties or resources and services supported as necessary by performance measures in accordance with the applicable Rules; c. the requirement for regular detailed reporting to a specified frequency from the Service Provider in respect of its duties and activities; d. provisions relating to the reporting of relevant events such as technological changes or error reporting and, in particular, any event which undermines the ability of the Service Provider to fulfil its duties; and e. the requirement for an annual review (at a minimum) of the performance of the Service Provider. A1.3 Provisions relating to Eligible Custodians A1.3.1.(1) A Fund Manager or Trustee must ensure that a Delegation Agreement in relation to Providing Custody will: (a) require that the title of any account of the Eligible Custodian to hold Fund Property sufficiently distinguishes that account from any account containing Investments belonging to the Eligible Custodian, and is in the form requested by the Fund Manager or Trustee; (b) require that the Fund's Investments will only be credited and withdrawn in accordance with the instructions of the Fund Manager or Trustee; (c) require, subject to ‎(2), that the Eligible Custodian will hold the Fund's Investments separately from assets belonging to the Eligible Custodian; (d) set out the arrangements for recording and registering the Funds, claiming and receiving dividends and other entitlements and interest and the giving and receiving of instructions; (e) require the Eligible Custodian to deliver a statement to the Fund Manager or Trustee (including the frequency of such statement), which details the Fund's Investments deposited to the account; (f) require, subject to ‎(2), that all the Investments standing to the credit of the account are held by the Eligible Custodian as the agent of the Fund Manager or the Trustee and the Eligible Custodian is not entitled to combine the account with any other account or to exercise any charge, mortgage, lien, right of set-off or counterclaim against Investments in that account in respect of any sum owed to the Eligible Custodian on any other account of the Fund Manager, Trustee or any other Person; and (g) detail the extent of liability of the Eligible Custodian in the event of default. A1.3.1.(2) Neither the Fund Manager nor the Trustee is required to meet the requirements in ‎(1)‎(c) and ‎(f), where either the Eligible Custodian or any other Person acting as the prime broker of the Fund does so in compliance with the requirements in Rule ‎12.3.9. A1.4 Provisions relating to Acting as the Administrator of a Collective Investment Fund A1.4.1 A Fund Manager or Trustee must ensure that a Delegation Agreement in relation to Acting as the Administrator of a Collective Investment Fund requires that the Service Provider must not hold or control monies or assets belonging to third parties in connection with such administration except in the following circumstances: (a) holding cheques to the order of a Fund's bank account, provided such cheques are securely held for a maximum of three business days prior to being deposited into the relevant Fund's bank account or returned to the drawer of the cheque; or (b) where the Service Provider has control over bank accounts kept for the purposes of the Fund, the accounts must be conducted strictly in accordance with the Fund Manager's instructions and any agreed mandate with the bank.

question: If a Fund Manager is looking at a chapter that says it does not apply to Fund Managers, but the Fund Manager is also entering into a Delegation Agreement or Outsourcing Agreement, which part should they follow instead, and what are the main things the agreement must cover (including how long records must be kept and how fast they must be reproduced if the Regulator asks), and does this change for a Qualified Investor Fund?
expected_answer: A Fund Manager should not treat the excluded chapter as the source of its requirements, because that chapter says it does not apply to Fund Managers and points Fund Managers to section 15.3 and Appendix A1.3 of the Fund Rules. [#SRC:77d6d088-e887-4010-b1f2-c066a0409cca] For delegation and outsourcing, APP 1 is the relevant text because it applies to a Fund Manager and, if appointed, the Trustee for every Delegation Agreement and Outsourcing Agreement made under the Rules, while also stating that APP 1 does not apply to a Qualified Investor Fund. [#TGT:20b3551f-5646-4001-97ce-63eeaabbec5b] Under APP 1, the Fund Manager/Trustee must ensure the agreement spells out what functions or activities are being performed and what service standards apply, and it must stop the Service Provider from passing the work on again (delegating or outsourcing) unless the Fund Manager/Trustee gives prior approval. question: When an Authorised Person is using the FCCA and wants to recognise the effects of CRM by taking eligible financial Collateral, what must the Authorised Person do in relation to Rule 4.13.8, and which types of Collateral qualify as eligible financial Collateral (including any conditions that apply to Units in a Collective Investment Fund)?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person using the FCCA may treat certain assets as eligible financial Collateral for purposes of recognising the effects of CRM, but only if the Authorised Person also ensures the applicable conditions in Rule 4.13.8 are met for the relevant Collateral type. [#SRC:c36bf3cf-160f-43ab-bb40-9d7f5ceec7b8] In this FCCA context, eligible financial Collateral includes (a) any instrument listed in Rule 4.13.5, (b) any equity Security (including a convertible bond) that is traded on a regulated exchange, and (c) any Unit in a Collective Investment Fund that invests in the equity Securities described in (b), provided the Unit price is publicly quoted daily and at least 90% of the Fund’s deposited property is invested in instruments listed in this Rule and Rule 4.13.5. [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85] Accordingly, even where the Collateral falls within one of these eligible categories (including the Fund Unit category with its daily quotation and 90% investment tests), the Authorised Person must still check and comply with the Rule 4.13.8 requirements as the condition for recognising CRM effects for Collateral types covered by Rules 4.13.5 to 4.13.7. [#SRC:c36bf3cf-160f-43ab-bb40-9d7f5ceec7b8] [#TGT:2d7f3106-4761-4113-abe3-580e52ee1c85]

question: Where the Regulator permits a deferral of the Rule 3.6.1 requirements for large volume or certain types of trades (as specified in Rule 3.6.8), how should a Recognised Investment Exchange reconcile that deferral with its obligation to publish post-trade price, volume and time information as close to real time as technically possible, including for portfolio trades and trades executed outside normal trading hours?
expected_answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange should treat the real-time publication duty as the baseline for post-trade transparency, but where the Regulator has permitted a deferral for large volume or certain types of trades, it must operate that deferral transparently and in a way that still fits within the Exchange’s overall publication arrangements. [#TGT:1a356c1e-9ff4-4ac4-a46d-1f2fd06ac0a6] Specifically, when a deferral applies, the Exchange must ensure that the fact a deferral exists and the terms governing it are disclosed to Members and users of its facilities, and also to investors. [#SRC:7f823646-b062-4581-a37a-a39040c4edad] Outside the scope of any permitted deferral, the Exchange must have arrangements to make the price, volume and time of executed transactions in Financial Instruments available to the public and the Regulator as close to real time as is technically possible, assuming reasonable efficiency and expenditure on systems. [#TGT:1a356c1e-9ff4-4ac4-a46d-1f2fd06ac0a6] For portfolio trades, the Exchange’s arrangements must provide information for each constituent transaction as close to real time as possible, while taking into account the need to allocate prices to particular Financial Instruments. [#TGT:1a356c1e-9ff4-4ac4-a46d-1f2fd06ac0a6] For transactions occurring on the Exchange outside normal trading hours, the Exchange must make the post-trade information public before the opening of the next trading day, even though the timing differs from normal real-time publication. [#TGT:1a356c1e-9ff4-4ac4-a46d-1f2fd06ac0a6]

question: When applying the Large Exposures framework, how must an Authorised Person determine whether a position is a “Large Exposure” (including the aggregation scope across books and counterparty groupings), and what ongoing monitoring and breach-notification actions are required once that determination is made?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must treat an Exposure as a “Large Exposure” when the total Exposure to a Counterparty (or to a group of Connected Counterparties or Closely Related Counterparties) reaches at least 10% of the firm’s Tier 1, calculated on an aggregated basis across both the Trading Book and the Non Trading Book. [#TGT:3708b0bd-05d2-4200-a5ff-5292100ca4a8] To make that determination, the firm must first identify its Exposures and the relevant Counterparties, including whether counterparties are Closely Related to each other or Connected to the Authorised Person, then measure and value those Exposures and express them as a proportion of Tier 1, and aggregate Exposures to the same Counterparty or relevant counterparty group. [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675] Once the firm has identified exposures that meet (or approach) the 10% Tier 1 threshold under the cross-book aggregation rule, it must monitor and control its Exposures daily to keep them within the Large Exposures limits. [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675] If the limits in the Section are breached, the Authorised Person must notify the Regulator immediately and then provide written confirmation. [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675]

debug_context.source_text: Applicability and limits. For the purposes of this Section an Authorised Person must: (a) identify its Exposures; (b) identify its Counterparties, including whether any are Closely Related to each other or Connected to the Authorised Person; (c) measure the size of its Exposures; (d) establish the value of its Exposures; (e) determine the size of its Exposures as a proportion of its Tier 1; (f) identify whether it has Exposures which are subject to the requirements of Section 4.13 (CRM); (g) identify which, if any, of its Exposures are exempt in accordance with Section A4.11 from the limits set out in Rules 4.15.4 to 4.15.7; (h) aggregate its Exposures to the same Counterparty or group of Closely Related Counterparties or group of Connected Counterparties; (i) monitor and control its Exposures on a daily basis within the Large Exposures limits; and (j) notify the Regulator immediately of any breach of the limits set out in this Section and confirm it in writing.
debug_context.target_text: Large Exposures limits. A Large Exposure of an Authorised Person means a total Exposure which is equal to or greater than 10% of the firm's Tier 1, to any Counterparty, group of Connected Counterparties, or group of Closely Related Counterparties, aggregated across the Authorised Person's Trading Book and Non Trading Book.

question: When an Authorised Person is considering recognising the effects of CRM of a Credit Derivative provided by an MDB, how does the eligibility condition for the CRM provider interact with the requirement to apply a 0% risk weight to certain CR Exposures, and which named institutions are covered by the 0% risk weight rule?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person can only recognise the effects of CRM of a Credit Derivative where the protection provider falls within the permitted set of entities, which includes an MDB (as referenced in the relevant MDB rules) among other listed provider types. [#SRC:089417ca-c77d-4879-bc10-8d8138b1853b] Separately, for CR Exposure classification and risk-weighting within the MDB asset class, the Authorised Person is required to apply a 0% risk weight when the CR Exposure is to one of four specifically named institutions. [#TGT:eee311ad-dd67-489b-99c2-e2d73f7efc16] Putting these together, if the Credit Derivative’s CRM provider is an MDB (meeting the CRM-provider eligibility condition), the Authorised Person may recognise the CRM effects; and when the relevant CR Exposure is to the Bank for International Settlements, the International Monetary Fund, the European Central Bank, or the European Commission, the Authorised Person must apply a 0% risk weight to that CR Exposure under the MDB asset class rule. [#SRC:089417ca-c77d-4879-bc10-8d8138b1853b] [#TGT:eee311ad-dd67-489b-99c2-e2d73f7efc16] The CRM-provider eligibility list does not itself set the risk weight for these named CR Exposures, and the 0% risk weight rule does not itself expand the set of eligible CRM providers beyond what is permitted for recognising Credit Derivative CRM. [#SRC:089417ca-c77d-4879-bc10-8d8138b1853b] [#TGT:eee311ad-dd67-489b-99c2-e2d73f7efc16]

question: For an Authorised Person that both operates as a Virtual Asset Custodian holding Accepted Virtual Assets for Clients and also maintains Client Accounts with Third Party Agents, what reconciliation activities are required, and what are the minimum frequencies for each activity (including any statement-related reconciliation)?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person in this combined scenario must run multiple reconciliation processes on different scopes and timelines, and must also provide periodic client reporting for Accepted Virtual Assets. [#SRC:0fb3a173-21f7-447a-9b86-6c07aede7c32] Specifically, for Accepted Virtual Assets held under custody for Clients, it must reconcile each Client’s Accepted Virtual Asset holdings at least weekly, and it must send statements of a Retail Client’s Accepted Virtual Assets holdings at least monthly. [#SRC:0fb3a173-21f7-447a-9b86-6c07aede7c32] In addition, where it has Client Accounts held with Third Party Agents, it must at least every calendar month reconcile its own records of those Client Accounts against the monthly statements it receives from the Third Party Agents. [#TGT:99a621ce-b3ab-4dbc-a9c7-eac1065776e6] Separately from the monthly Third Party Agent reconciliation, it must at least every six months (i) count all Safe Custody Assets physically held by the Authorised Person or its Nominee Company and reconcile that count to its records, and (ii) reconcile individual Client ledger balances to its records of Safe Custody Assets balances held in Client Accounts. [#TGT:99a621ce-b3ab-4dbc-a9c7-eac1065776e6]

question: If an Authorised Person is a Virtual Asset Custodian and also uses Third Party Agents for Client Accounts, how often does it need to do reconciliations and send statements, and what exactly is being checked each time?
expected_answer: The Authorised Person has to meet separate minimum frequencies depending on whether it is dealing with Accepted Virtual Assets under custody or Safe Custody Assets/Client Accounts (including those with Third Party Agents). [#SRC:0fb3a173-21f7-447a-9b86-6c07aede7c32] For Accepted Virtual Assets it holds under custody for Clients, it must perform reconciliations of a Client’s Accepted Virtual Asset holdings at least every week, and it must send statements of a Retail Client’s Accepted Virtual Assets holdings at least monthly. [#SRC:0fb3a173-21f7-447a-9b86-6c07aede7c32] For Client Accounts held with Third Party Agents, it must at least every calendar month compare (reconcile) its own records of those Client Accounts to the monthly statements it receives from the Third Party Agents. [#TGT:99a621ce-b3ab-4dbc-a9c7-eac1065776e6] It also has two six‑monthly checks: it must count all Safe Custody Assets physically held by the Authorised Person or its Nominee Company and reconcile the count to its records, and it must reconcile each Client’s ledger balance to the Authorised Person’s records of Safe Custody Assets balances held in Client Accounts. [#TGT:99a621ce-b3ab-4dbc-a9c7-eac1065776e6]

debug_context.source_text: AUTHORISED PERSONS PROVIDING CUSTODY OF VIRTUAL ASSETS Safe Custody of Clients’ Virtual Assets Authorised Persons operating as Virtual Asset Custodians are required, with respect to the Accepted Virtual Assets they hold under custody for Clients, to: a) Send out statements of a Client’s Accepted Virtual Assets holdings to Retail Clients at least monthly (as required under COBS Rule 15.8.1(a)); and b) Carry out all reconciliations of a Client’s Accepted Virtual Asset holdings at least every week (as required under COBS Rule 15.9.1).
debug_context.target_text: An Authorised Person must: (a) at least every calendar month, reconcile its records of Client Accounts held with Third Party Agents with monthly statements received from those Third Party Agents; (b) at least every six months, count all Safe Custody Assets physically held by the Authorised Person, or its Nominee Company, and reconcile the result of that count to the records of the Authorised Person; and (c) at least every six months, reconcile individual Client ledger balances with the Authorised Person's records of Safe Custody Assets balances held in Client Accounts.

question: When a Payment Order for an individual Payment Transaction is transmitted using a Payment Instrument issued under a Framework Contract, which post-initiation information must the Payment Service Provider still provide immediately after initiation, and what category of information may it omit because another Payment Service Provider provides it under Section 19.2?
expected_answer: For an individual Payment Transaction sent via a Payment Instrument issued under a Framework Contract, the Payment Service Provider must still provide (or make available) the post-initiation, transaction-specific information immediately after the initiation of the Payment Order to the Payer and, where applicable, to the Payee. [#SRC:a48a07c2-0731-4505-939e-07110e2af622] This includes confirmation that initiation with the Payer’s Payment Service Provider was successful, a reference that lets the Payer and Payee identify the Payment Transaction (including identifying the Payer and Payee and, where appropriate, information transferred with the Payment Order), the transaction amount in the currency used in the Payment Order, any charges payable (and where applicable a breakdown in the Payment Order currency), any exchange-rate details and the post-conversion amount where an exchange rate is used, the date the Payment Service Provider received the Payment Order, and the Credit Value Date. [#SRC:a48a07c2-0731-4505-939e-07110e2af622] However, in this Framework Contract/Payment Instrument scenario, the Payment Service Provider for that single Payment Transaction does not need to provide the “general information” that would otherwise be required under Rule 19.5.1, to the extent that such general information has been provided or will be provided under Section 19.2 by another Payment Service Provider in respect of the Framework Contract. [#TGT:c337e2ea-0d58-45b9-970f-810639f88bf2]

debug_context.source_text: Subject to Rule 19.5.3, a Payment Service Provider must provide or make available to the Payer and, where applicable, to the Payee, immediately after the initiation of a Payment Order: (a) confirmation of the successful initiation of the Payment Order with the Payer’s Payment Service Provider; (b) a reference enabling the Payer and the Payee to identify the Payment Transaction, including the Payer and Payee, and, where appropriate, any information transferred with the Payment Order; (c) the amount of the Payment Transaction, in the currency used in the Payment Order; (d) the amount of any charges payable in relation to the Payment Transaction and, where applicable, a breakdown of the amounts of such charges expressed in the currency of the Payment Order; (e) where an exchange rate is used in the Payment Transaction the actual rate used or a reference to it, and the amount of the Payment Transaction after that currency conversion; (f) the date on which the Payment Service Provider received the Payment Order; and (g) the Credit Value Date.
debug_context.target_text: Where a Payment Order for an individual Payment Transaction is transmitted by way of a Payment Instrument issued under a Framework Contract, the Payment Service Provider in respect of that single Payment Transaction need not provide or make available under Rule 19.5.1 the general information which has been provided or will be provided under Section 19.2 by another Payment Service Provider in respect of a Framework Contract.

question: If a one-off Payment Transaction is sent using a Payment Instrument under a Framework Contract, what details must the Payment Service Provider give right after the Payment Order is started, and what “general information” can it skip because another Payment Service Provider gives it under Section 19.2?
expected_answer: Even when the Payment Order for an individual Payment Transaction is sent through a Payment Instrument issued under a Framework Contract, the Payment Service Provider must still give (or make available) the immediate, after-initiation information to the Payer and, if relevant, the Payee. [#SRC:a48a07c2-0731-4505-939e-07110e2af622] Practically, that means it must provide: confirmation that the Payment Order was successfully initiated with the Payer’s Payment Service Provider; a reference that allows the Payer and Payee to identify the Payment Transaction (including identifying the Payer and Payee and, where appropriate, any information transferred with the Payment Order); the amount in the currency used in the Payment Order; the amount of any charges payable (and, where applicable, a breakdown in the Payment Order currency); exchange-rate information and the converted amount where an exchange rate is used; the date the Payment Service Provider received the Payment Order; and the Credit Value Date. [#SRC:a48a07c2-0731-4505-939e-07110e2af622] In the same scenario, the Payment Service Provider for that single Payment Transaction can omit the “general information” that would otherwise be required under Rule 19.5.1, but only where that general information has been provided or will be provided under Section 19.2 by another Payment Service Provider in relation to the Framework Contract. [#TGT:c337e2ea-0d58-45b9-970f-810639f88bf2]

question: In what admission-related scenarios would the Regulator generally require a Reporting Entity to complete MKT Form 10-1 quarterly, and how do those scenarios align with the specific triggers that make quarterly completion mandatory?
expected_answer: A Reporting Entity must complete MKT Form 10-1 on a quarterly basis when the Regulator requires it, including where that requirement is imposed as a condition of admission to the Official List. [#TGT:67e6fb61-6313-4d10-b3bb-b9b99d81cb75] The Regulator will generally require this quarterly reporting in admission-related circumstances where the Listed Entity being admitted to the Official List is admitted under the assets eligibility test, has less than three years of audited financial statements, or is otherwise considered to need quarterly cash reporting (including where the admission involves a cash-box). [#SRC:ef54c7e6-d860-4e8b-aed8-ddcd2cbacab8] Read together, these passages indicate that the “condition of admission” trigger for quarterly MKT Form 10-1 completion can be met in practice by the Regulator’s general approach to admissions that present heightened cash-reporting needs—such as assets-test admissions, shorter audited financial history, or cash-box admissions. [#SRC:ef54c7e6-d860-4e8b-aed8-ddcd2cbacab8] [#TGT:67e6fb61-6313-4d10-b3bb-b9b99d81cb75] Separately, quarterly completion is also mandatory if the Regulator classifies the Reporting Entity as a Mining Exploration Reporting Entity or a Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity, or if the Regulator requires it pursuant to section 84 of the FSMR. [#TGT:67e6fb61-6313-4d10-b3bb-b9b99d81cb75]

debug_context.source_text: The Regulator will generally require a Reporting Entity to comply with Rule 10.1.3B(1)(i) in circumstances where the Listed Entity with Securities being admitted to the Official List is admitted under the assets eligibility test (see Rule 2.3.16), has less than three years of audited financial statements as prescribed in Rule 2.3.2(1), or is considered by the Regulator, for other reasons, to require quarterly cash reports, such as the admission of a cash-box.
debug_context.target_text: A Reporting Entity must complete MKT Form 10-1 on a quarterly basis if the Regulator: (a) requires it as a condition of admission to the Official List pursuant to section 52(1)(b) of the FSMR; (b) classifies the Reporting Entity as a Mining Exploration Reporting Entity or a Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity; or (c) requires it pursuant to section 84 of the FSMR.

question: Where a Recognised Investment Exchange seeks to operate an MTF using Virtual Assets, what combined operational conditions apply regarding (i) the need for a stipulation in its Recognition Order, (ii) the applicable framework for the MTF activity versus the remainder of its operations, and (iii) any additional market it must operate in connection with operating an MTF?
expected_answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange may operate an MTF using Virtual Assets only if its Recognition Order contains a stipulation allowing it to operate an MTF. [#SRC:54b67759-66a7-4cbd-a335-1a40ee4894bb] If that stipulation is granted, the Recognised Investment Exchange must apply the Virtual Asset Framework specifically to its operation of the MTF using Virtual Assets, while ensuring that all other parts of its business continue to be run in compliance with the MIR Rules. [#SRC:54b67759-66a7-4cbd-a335-1a40ee4894bb] In addition, when a Recognised Investment Exchange is operating an MTF (including where the MTF is operated using Virtual Assets under the stipulated Recognition Order), it must also operate a market that complies with the Recognition Requirements. [#TGT:85479490-968f-42f7-baaa-2580214b953d] Taken together, this means the permission to run the MTF is conditional on the Recognition Order stipulation, the MTF’s Virtual Asset activity is governed by the Virtual Asset Framework, the remainder of operations stays under the MIR Rules, and the Recognised Investment Exchange must concurrently operate a Recognition Requirements-compliant market while operating the MTF. [#SRC:54b67759-66a7-4cbd-a335-1a40ee4894bb] [#TGT:85479490-968f-42f7-baaa-2580214b953d]

debug_context.source_text: MULTILATERAL TRADING FACILITIES AND VIRTUAL ASSETS Recognised Investment Exchanges Operating an MTF using Virtual Assets Pursuant to MIR Rule 3.4.1, a Recognised Investment Exchange may operate an MTF, provided that its Recognition Order includes a stipulation permitting it to do so. MIR Rule 3.4.2 requires that where such a stipulation is granted to a Recognised Investment Exchange, the Recognised Investment Exchange must meet the requirements of the Virtual Asset Framework in relation to operation of an MTF (using Virtual Assets) while the remainder of its operations must be operated in compliance with the MIR Rules.
debug_context.target_text: A Recognised Investment Exchange operating an MTF or an OTF, must also operate a market that complies with the Recognition Requirements.

question: For an Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm, what systems-and-controls capability is required to support compliance with the “at all times” capital standard, and what immediate notification duty is triggered if those controls indicate the firm cannot currently meet, or is unlikely to meet in future, the relevant capital rule?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm must be able to maintain and evidence continuous compliance with its capital standard by combining (i) an “at all times” capital threshold and (ii) systems and controls that let it verify and demonstrate its position. Specifically, a Domestic Firm must hold Capital Resources that are at least equal to its Capital Requirement at all times. [#TGT:fc38613a-248b-40ef-9af7-6cd69a5b516e] To support that continuous requirement, the Authorised Person must have appropriate systems and controls designed to ensure it can be certain it has adequate Capital Resources to meet the capital adequacy requirements at all times and to enable it to demonstrate its capital position at any particular time if the Regulator requires. [#SRC:0d56af9f-7fc4-44a3-9bb7-147697b47f79] If, through operating those systems and controls, the Authorised Person concludes that it does not currently satisfy, or is not likely to be able to satisfy in future, the requirements of Rule 3.2.3, it must immediately inform the Regulator in accordance with Rule 3.2.5. [#SRC:0d56af9f-7fc4-44a3-9bb7-147697b47f79] In practice, this means the firm’s monitoring and reporting framework should be capable of identifying any shortfall (or expected shortfall) against the Capital Resources ≥ Capital Requirement standard and triggering immediate regulatory notification when that conclusion is reached. [#TGT:fc38613a-248b-40ef-9af7-6cd69a5b516e] [#SRC:0d56af9f-7fc4-44a3-9bb7-147697b47f79]

debug_context.source_text: For the purposes of Part 2, an Authorised Person is required to have appropriate systems and controls in place to enable it to be certain that it has adequate Capital Resources to meet the requirements in Part 4 on capital adequacy at all times and to allow it to demonstrate that at any particular time if required to do so by the Regulator. Where through the operation of those systems and controls an Authorised Person forms the view that it does not currently or is not likely to be able to satisfy the requirements of Rule 3.2.3 in future, that Authorised Person is required to immediately inform the Regulator in accordance with Rule 3.2.5.
debug_context.target_text: Domestic Firms – adequate capital resources. An Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm must have, at all times, Capital Resources which equal or exceed the amount of its Capital Requirement.

expected_answer: A Domestic Firm must continuously meet a minimum capital position and have internal arrangements that let it check and prove that position. The baseline requirement is that an Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm must, at all times, have Capital Resources that are at least equal to its Capital Requirement. [#SRC:0d56af9f-7fc4-44a3-9bb7-147697b47f79] Put together, the firm should use its controls to detect any actual or expected failure to keep Capital Resources at or above the Capital Requirement and then notify the Regulator immediately once that conclusion is reached.
