question: When the Regulator receives the notice referred to in Rule 3.1.2 for a Passported Fund intended to be Promoted in relevant Host Jurisdiction(s), what are the Regulator’s required steps and timing for notifying Host Regulator(s) and completing registration, and in what circumstances is the Regulator prohibited from transmitting the notice of intent under Rule 3.1.4(a)?
expected_answer: The Regulator’s process starts with a time-bound obligation to notify Host Regulator(s), but that transmission is barred in specified circumstances; only after Host Regulator confirmation does the Regulator complete publication and notification steps. [#SRC:49f2d65b-c143-456c-8e45-d05767ba59c7] [#TGT:2f9bc2f5-72a6-45ee-8ec3-fac8a19ab60c] Within five Business Days after receiving the notice described in Rule 3.1.2 (and subject to Rule 3.1.5), the Regulator must send a notice of its intent to use the passporting procedures to the Host Regulator(s) in each relevant Host Jurisdiction where the Passported Fund is intended to be Promoted. [#SRC:49f2d65b-c143-456c-8e45-d05767ba59c7] However, the Regulator must not transmit that notice under Rule 3.1.4(a) if it considers the Fund Manager or the Private Fund does not comply, or may in the future not comply, with applicable legislation (including these Rules), or if refraining is considered necessary and appropriate to advance one or more of the Regulator’s objectives. [#TGT:2f9bc2f5-72a6-45ee-8ec3-fac8a19ab60c] If the notice is transmitted and the relevant Host Regulator(s) confirm their respective Register of Passported Funds has been updated to include the Passported Fund’s details, the Regulator must then promptly (i) publish the Passported Fund’s details on the Register of Passported Funds and (ii) notify the Fund Manager that registration is complete. [#SRC:49f2d65b-c143-456c-8e45-d05767ba59c7]

debug_context.source_text: The Regulator shall: (a) Within five Business Days of receipt of the notice set out in Rule 3.1.2, and subject to Rule 3.1.5, provide notice of the intent to use the passporting procedures under these Rules to the Host Regulator(s) in the relevant Host Jurisdiction(s) where the Passported Fund is intended to be Promoted; and (b) promptly following confirmation from the relevant Host Regulator(s) that its respective Register of Passported Funds has been updated to include the details of the Passported Fund: (i) publish the details of the Passported Fund on the Register of Passported Funds; and (ii) notify the Fund Manager that registration on the Register of Passported Funds is complete.
debug_context.target_text: The Regulator shall not transmit a notice under Rule 3.1.4‎(a): (a) if it considers that the Fund Manager or the Private Fund does not comply with, or it has reasonable grounds for determining that the Fund Manager or the Private Fund may in the future not comply with, applicable legislation including these Rules; or (b) if it considers that it is necessary and appropriate to refrain from doing so in order to further one or more of its objectives.

question: If a Passported Fund is meant to be Promoted in a Host Jurisdiction, what does the Regulator normally do within five Business Days after getting the Rule 3.1.2 notice, what does it do after the Host Regulator(s) confirm their register is updated, and when is the Regulator not allowed to send the notice of intent under Rule 3.1.4(a)?
expected_answer: Normally, the Regulator must quickly notify the Host Regulator(s) and then, once the Host Regulator(s) confirm their register update, finish the public registration steps; but the Regulator is not allowed to send the initial notice of intent in certain cases. [#SRC:49f2d65b-c143-456c-8e45-d05767ba59c7] [#TGT:2f9bc2f5-72a6-45ee-8ec3-fac8a19ab60c] First, within five Business Days after receiving the notice mentioned in Rule 3.1.2 (and subject to Rule 3.1.5), the Regulator must send a notice to the Host Regulator(s) in the relevant Host Jurisdiction(s) saying it intends to use the passporting procedures for the Passported Fund that is intended to be Promoted there. [#SRC:49f2d65b-c143-456c-8e45-d05767ba59c7] But the Regulator must not send that notice under Rule 3.1.4(a) if it thinks the Fund Manager or the Private Fund does not comply, or might later not comply, with applicable legislation (including these Rules), or if it believes holding back is necessary and appropriate to support one or more of its objectives. [#TGT:2f9bc2f5-72a6-45ee-8ec3-fac8a19ab60c] After the relevant Host Regulator(s) confirm their respective Register of Passported Funds has been updated to include the Passported Fund’s details, the Regulator must then promptly publish the fund’s details on the Register of Passported Funds and tell the Fund Manager that registration is complete. [#SRC:49f2d65b-c143-456c-8e45-d05767ba59c7]

question: Where the Regulator triggers a Reporting Entity’s quarterly obligation to complete MKT Form 10-1 (including by requiring it as a condition of admission to the Official List, by classifying it as a Mining Exploration Reporting Entity or a Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity, or by requiring it under section 84 of the FSMR), what specific information must the Regulator communicate to the Reporting Entity about the applicability and duration of the relevant Rule 10.1.3B(1) obligation, and how does that communication relate to the quarterly cadence?
expected_answer: When the Regulator’s action results in a Reporting Entity being required to complete MKT Form 10-1 on a quarterly basis—whether because it is imposed as a condition of admission to the Official List under section 52(1)(b) of the FSMR, because the Regulator classifies the Reporting Entity as a Mining Exploration Reporting Entity or a Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity, or because the Regulator requires it under section 84 of the FSMR—the Regulator must also provide a clear notice addressing the Rule 10.1.3B(1) compliance framework. [#TGT:67e6fb61-6313-4d10-b3bb-b9b99d81cb75] Specifically, in applying Rule 10.1.3B(1), the Regulator will inform the Reporting Entity (i) that the Rule applies to it, (ii) the length of time the Reporting Entity is required to comply with the Rule, and (iii) where applicable, any other requirement imposed on the Reporting Entity in relation to its obligations under the Rule. [#SRC:6ad7b78f-3be1-497f-944b-9d2ddcef1e86] This communication is the mechanism that ties the quarterly MKT Form 10-1 obligation to an identified period of compliance (and any additional related requirements), so the Reporting Entity understands both that the quarterly requirement has been triggered and how long the Rule-based obligations are expected to continue. [#TGT:67e6fb61-6313-4d10-b3bb-b9b99d81cb75] [#SRC:6ad7b78f-3be1-497f-944b-9d2ddcef1e86]

question: When an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business is preparing its Resolution Pack, what specific Third Party Agent acknowledgement record must be included if the firm passes, or permits to be passed, Safe Custody Assets to a Third Party Agent, and what minimum content must that acknowledgement cover?
expected_answer: If an Authorised Person passes, or permits to be passed, Safe Custody Assets to a Third Party Agent, it must obtain a written acknowledgement from that Third Party Agent, and the relevant acknowledgement record must be included in the Resolution Pack as part of the required records for Client Investments involving a Third Party Agent. [#TGT:57e8f079-f256-41f4-b1d3-fcbba0690a98] [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] The acknowledgement must, at a minimum, address operational and safeguarding points, including: the account title must clearly distinguish the account from any account holding Investments belonging to the Authorised Person and be in the form the Authorised Person requests; Client Investment credits/withdrawals must follow the Authorised Person’s instructions; and Client Investments must be held separately from the Third Party Agent’s own assets. [#TGT:57e8f079-f256-41f4-b1d3-fcbba0690a98] It must also set out arrangements for recording/registering Client Investments and handling dividends/entitlements/interest and instructions, require delivery of statements to the Authorised Person (including frequency) detailing Client Investments deposited, and confirm that Investments in the account are held by the Authorised Person as agent with restrictions on combining accounts or asserting charges, liens, set-off, or counterclaims against those Investments for sums owed on other accounts. [#TGT:57e8f079-f256-41f4-b1d3-fcbba0690a98] Finally, the acknowledgement must state the extent of the Third Party Agent’s liability in the event of default, and that written acknowledgement record is part of the Resolution Pack’s Third Party Agent acknowledgement materials for Client Investments. [#TGT:57e8f079-f256-41f4-b1d3-fcbba0690a98] [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]

question: When an Authorised Person conducts periodic stress tests for securitisation activities and off balance sheet Exposures, what specific scope elements must be covered to ensure the tests address both the firm-wide impact in stressed market conditions and the risk that pipeline transactions may not complete, including where securitisation is intended as a means of CRM or for liquidity purposes?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person’s periodic stress testing must be structured to cover both (i) the required activity/exposure perimeter and (ii) the stressed-scenario impacts and transaction-completion risks that arise across the firm. [#TGT:d430637c-0076-42dd-b3ff-ff739c34e3aa] In scope, the stress tests must relate to the Authorised Person’s securitisation activities and its off balance sheet Exposures, and must also test the future ability to transact securitisation when it is used as a means of CRM or for liquidity purposes. [#TGT:d430637c-0076-42dd-b3ff-ff739c34e3aa] Within that perimeter, the tests must consider the firm wide impact of securitisation activities and Exposures under stressed market conditions and assess the implications for other sources of risk, so the analysis is not limited to the securitisation book in isolation. [#SRC:f5a97111-7275-4609-b7ad-615fcf8e3d97] The stress tests must include both existing securitisation Exposures and transactions in the pipeline, explicitly reflecting the risk that pipeline transactions may fail to complete in a stressed market scenario. [#SRC:f5a97111-7275-4609-b7ad-615fcf8e3d97] Together, these elements ensure the stress testing addresses ongoing and prospective securitisation capacity (including CRM/liquidity use) while capturing firm-wide stressed impacts and pipeline execution risk. [#TGT:d430637c-0076-42dd-b3ff-ff739c34e3aa] [#SRC:f5a97111-7275-4609-b7ad-615fcf8e3d97]

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity makes a disclosure under Rule 11.9.1 that includes forecast financial information derived from a Production Target, how should it handle material economic assumptions it considers commercially sensitive, and what level of summary is still expected when commercially sensitive information is withheld?
expected_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity disclosing under Rule 11.9.1 must still include the required content about its assumptions and cannot use “commercial sensitivity” as a basis to omit substantive disclosure altogether. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] Specifically, it must disclose all material economic assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information; if it considers those material economic assumptions commercially sensitive, it must say so and explain the methodology used to determine them; and it must also disclose all other material assumptions utilised. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] In addition, because the forecast financial information is derived from a Production Target, the disclosure must include that Production Target and include all information required for it (by incorporating the information contained in Rule 11.8.3). [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] Where commercially sensitive information is not disclosed, the Listing Authority’s approach is that the disclosure must still provide a fair and balanced summary of the full significant terms and include any other relevant information that is Inside Information (in the context of the withheld material). [#TGT:5717861f-e414-48f4-8041-511cc068bfdf] The Reporting Entity also cannot avoid disclosure merely by labelling commercially sensitive information as a trade secret to try to rely on Rule 7.2.2(1)(e). [#TGT:5717861f-e414-48f4-8041-511cc068bfdf]

debug_context.source_text: A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include: (1) in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information: (a) all material economic assumptions employed; (b) if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and Guidance A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure. (c) all other material assumptions utilised. (2) the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
debug_context.target_text: DISCLOSURES – SYSTEMS, CONTROLS & CONTENT Commercially sensitive information The Listing Authority does recognise, however, that there are circumstances where a Reporting Entity will not wish to Disclose a copy of such an agreement, for example, where it contains commercially sensitive information that ought not be Disclosed. In such cases, the Disclosure made about the agreement is still required to contain a fair and balanced summary of the full significant terms of the agreement, and any other relevant information relating to the agreement that is Inside Information. A Reporting Entity is, however, not entitled to avoid the Disclosure of commercially sensitive information by characterising it as a trade secret in order to benefit from the provisions of Rule 7.2.2(1)(e).

question: When assessing whether information qualifies as “Inside Information” for instruments that are not Commodity Derivatives, how should a firm apply the “significant effect on price” limb across Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, Accepted Spot Commodities, and Related Instruments, given that the definition is stated in section 95(2)?
expected_answer: To determine whether information is “Inside Information” for items that are not Commodity Derivatives, the firm must apply the section 95(2) definition and test all three limbs, including the price-sensitivity limb, across the relevant product set. [#SRC:ba7db39b-8edf-4a95-94c3-14bd0ddb9c18] The information must be of a Precise nature and not generally available, and it must relate (directly or indirectly) to one or more Reporting Entities or Issuers of the Financial Instruments or to one or more of the Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, or Accepted Spot Commodities. [#SRC:ba7db39b-8edf-4a95-94c3-14bd0ddb9c18] For the “significant effect on price” limb, the assessment is satisfied where, if the information were generally available, it would be likely to have a significant effect on the price of the Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, or Accepted Spot Commodities, and it also explicitly extends to having a significant effect on the price of Related Instruments. [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977] This means the firm should evaluate price impact not only on the primary Financial Instruments/Accepted Virtual Assets/Accepted Spot Commodities referenced by the information, but also on any Related Instruments within scope, while keeping the analysis confined to instruments “which are not Commodity Derivatives.” [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977]

question: If you have precise information that isn’t public and it’s about a Reporting Entity or Issuer, how do you decide whether it counts as “Inside Information” for products that are not Commodity Derivatives, especially when it might move the price of a Related Instrument?
expected_answer: You treat it as “Inside Information” only if it meets the full definition for products that are not Commodity Derivatives, including the part about likely price impact. [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977] First, the information must be of a Precise nature and not generally available. [#SRC:ba7db39b-8edf-4a95-94c3-14bd0ddb9c18] Second, it must relate directly or indirectly either to one or more Reporting Entities or Issuers of the Financial Instruments, or to one or more of the Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, or Accepted Spot Commodities. [#SRC:ba7db39b-8edf-4a95-94c3-14bd0ddb9c18] Third, you must consider whether making it public would be likely to have a significant effect on price. [#SRC:ba7db39b-8edf-4a95-94c3-14bd0ddb9c18] In doing that price test, you do not stop at the main product mentioned: the definition also covers a likely significant effect on the price of Related Instruments (as well as Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, and Accepted Spot Commodities) within the non-Commodity Derivatives scope. [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977] If any of these elements is missing, the information does not meet the definition. [#SRC:ba7db39b-8edf-4a95-94c3-14bd0ddb9c18]

question: For an Authorised Person with a Financial Services Permission (“A”), in what circumstances may the Regulator exercise its power (including where the concern relates to Threshold Condition Rules), and how do the illustrative risk-based examples (e.g., impacts on Customers or the start of enforcement action or insolvency proceedings) fit within those circumstances?
expected_answer: The Regulator may exercise its power under subsection (3) in relation to an Authorised Person with a Financial Services Permission (“A”) when it appears that one of the specified triggers is met, including failure (or likely failure) to satisfy the Threshold Condition Rules, a contravention of these Regulations or Rules made under them, a sustained inactivity period, or where exercising the power is desirable to further the Regulator’s objectives. [#TGT:6bdcc8f0-94b9-4927-a3a2-ec203ebaaa47] In applying the Threshold Condition Rules trigger, the kinds of situations that can indicate failure or likely failure include inadequate or inappropriate resources, not being fit and proper, being incapable of being supervised effectively, or having inadequate compliance arrangements to meet applicable legal and regulatory requirements. [#SRC:3b016133-6155-4e6f-9aa0-90f439b15003] Separately, the “desirable to further objectives” trigger can encompass circumstances where there is a risk of an adverse effect on its Customers or where enforcement action or insolvency proceedings have commenced, as examples of when exercising the power may be necessary or desirable in pursuit of objectives. [#SRC:3b016133-6155-4e6f-9aa0-90f439b15003] In addition, the Regulator may act where A has failed for at least 12 months to carry on a Regulated Activity to which the Financial Services Permission relates, which is an independent basis beyond the illustrative risk examples. [#TGT:6bdcc8f0-94b9-4927-a3a2-ec203ebaaa47]

question: When a Person is required to obtain the prior written approval of the Regulator under Rule 8.8.4(1) and is proposing to acquire or increase the level of control in a Domestic Firm, what notice must be submitted, what actions may the Regulator take on the proposal, and how is the 90‑day decision period affected if the submission is incomplete or unclear (including any ability to shorten the processing period)?
expected_answer: A Person who falls within the prior-approval trigger in Rule 8.8.4(1) and is proposing to acquire or increase the level of control in a Domestic Firm must submit written notice to the Regulator in the form the Regulator prescribes/sets. [#TGT:9b45a767-f8c2-493b-b0ae-d9f349767787] [#SRC:4068f5d7-33d4-473c-b314-4ee227d051bd] On receiving that notice/application, the Regulator may decide to approve the proposed acquisition/increase, object to it, or approve it subject to conditions relating to the proposal. [#SRC:4068f5d7-33d4-473c-b314-4ee227d051bd] If the written application is incomplete or unclear, the Regulator may request further clarification or information in writing, and it may do so at any point while processing the application. [#SRC:4068f5d7-33d4-473c-b314-4ee227d051bd] The 90-day period within which the Regulator will make its decision does not start running until the requested clarification or additional information has been provided to the Regulator’s satisfaction. [#SRC:4068f5d7-33d4-473c-b314-4ee227d051bd] The Regulator may also agree, in its absolute discretion, to a shorter processing period if the applicant requests it and all required information is already available to the Regulator. [#SRC:4068f5d7-33d4-473c-b314-4ee227d051bd]

question: Where a final notice orders restitution in the form of payment and identifies the person entitled to receive the amount, what is the enforcement consequence if all or part of the required payment is still unpaid at the end of the period stated in that final notice, and who may enforce it?
expected_answer: If a final notice orders restitution by payment and identifies the recipient(s), then any required payment that remains unpaid (in whole or in part) after the relevant period stated in the final notice can be pursued as an enforceable debt by the person entitled to receive it. [#SRC:98fb6898-5355-4c14-b332-e120dcbff722] This conclusion depends on the final notice having set out the payment obligation in a way that makes clear what must be paid and to whom: when restitution is ordered as a payment, the final notice must specify the amount to be paid or distributed and must identify the person or persons to whom it is to be paid (or among whom it is to be distributed), along with the arrangements for making that payment or distribution. [#TGT:e6a2d41b-716b-42a8-ae2d-d7f1a822a015] Once those elements are stated in the final notice, the “person entitled to the payment” is the person (or one of the persons) identified as the recipient under the restitution order, and that person may enforce the unpaid obligation as a debt if the payment has not been made by the end of the stated period. [#SRC:98fb6898-5355-4c14-b332-e120dcbff722] The trigger for debt enforceability is the non-payment at the end of the period stated in the final notice, not merely the existence of the restitution order. [#SRC:98fb6898-5355-4c14-b332-e120dcbff722]

question: When a law enforcement agency seeks a person’s interview answers taken under section 206(1)(a) for use in criminal proceedings against that same person, how do the Regulator’s notification practice and the Investigator’s disclosure prohibition operate together, including the consent pathway and the law/court-order exception?
expected_answer: In this scenario, disclosure to a law enforcement agency for criminal proceedings against the person is generally blocked unless a specific condition is met, and the person is typically given a chance to respond before disclosure occurs. The Investigator is prohibited from disclosing the person’s statement (i.e., answers to questions asked under a section 206(1)(a) requirement) to any law enforcement agency for that purpose unless the person consents or the Regulator must disclose due to law or a court order. [#TGT:c7705df9-fea6-4645-8706-3fe2fddac9ff] When the Regulator receives such a request from a law enforcement agency, the Regulator will generally notify the person concerned so the person has an opportunity either to consent to the disclosure or to challenge the request. [#SRC:1e42ed63-f4af-4b44-9cb5-90fa843a8951] This notification practice aligns with the consent-based disclosure route described for the Investigator, because the person’s consent is one of the two stated gateways for disclosure. [#TGT:c7705df9-fea6-4645-8706-3fe2fddac9ff] However, the notification is not expected where disclosure is compelled: the Regulator may be required by law or court order to disclose the statement, and in that case the Regulator may disclose without following the general notification approach. [#SRC:1e42ed63-f4af-4b44-9cb5-90fa843a8951] The same law/court-order compulsion is also an express exception to the Investigator’s non-disclosure rule. [#TGT:c7705df9-fea6-4645-8706-3fe2fddac9ff]

question: When the Regulator decides to refuse to make a Recognition Order, what procedure must it follow, and what are the key steps and exceptions within that procedure (including who must receive notice and how representations are handled)?
expected_answer: If the Regulator decides to refuse to make a Recognition Order, it must follow the procedure set out in Rule 6.9.6. [#SRC:5925da54-dd5e-4377-b2bb-22795223cb43] That procedure describes how the Regulator will act when refusing to make a Recognition Order (and also when making directions), and it includes specific exceptions where the full procedure may not apply or may be shortened. [#TGT:8f0e941a-957c-499b-952d-fa26d94c0efd] In applying the procedure to a refusal, the Regulator will: (i) give written notice to the Recognised Body (or Applicant) explaining why it intends to take the proposed action, inviting representations, and stating the deadline for those representations (which the Regulator may later extend); (ii) receive representations from the Recognised Body or Applicant; (iii) generally require written representations first and only usually hear oral representations on request; (iv) if it decides not to hear requested oral representations, write promptly explaining why and allow further time to respond; (v) have regard to representations made; and (vi) once it has reached its decision, notify the Recognised Body or Applicant in writing. [#TGT:8f0e941a-957c-499b-952d-fa26d94c0efd] The procedure is stated not to apply in the case of a revocation of a Recognition Order where the Recognised Body concerned has given its consent, and it may be cut short where (in a case where the Regulator proposes to make a direction) the Regulator considers it reasonably necessary not to follow, or to cut short, the procedure. [#TGT:8f0e941a-957c-499b-952d-fa26d94c0efd]

question: For a Person seeking to have the Units of a Foreign Fund admitted to an Official List, what jurisdictional/regulatory status must the Foreign Fund have, and once admitted, what type of ongoing reporting obligations would apply by reference to the treatment of Domestic Funds?
expected_answer: A Person can have the Units of a Foreign Fund admitted to an Official List only where the Foreign Fund either is a regulated Fund from a Recognised Jurisdiction or has been approved by the Regulator as a Fund subject to equivalent regulation (specifically, equivalent to that applying to a Public Fund). [#TGT:62faaa96-65f3-443e-b76c-0c846bc2b135] Where a Foreign Fund meets that Recognised Jurisdiction or Regulator-equivalence gateway and is admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, it would then be subject to financial and periodic reporting requirements that are similar to the financial reporting requirements applicable to Domestic Funds. [#SRC:4dfab9ab-e004-4159-9273-0bf8e49e9b87] In practical compliance terms, the admission decision hinges on the Foreign Fund’s regulatory pedigree (Recognised Jurisdiction regulation or Regulator approval for equivalent regulation), and the post-admission compliance expectation is that the Foreign Fund’s financial and periodic reporting will track the Domestic Fund reporting standard in substance. [#TGT:62faaa96-65f3-443e-b76c-0c846bc2b135] [#SRC:4dfab9ab-e004-4159-9273-0bf8e49e9b87]

question: When an Authorised Person wants to provide credit to a Related Person on terms more favourable than those offered to Persons who are not Related Persons, what must its Credit Risk policy include to rely on the employee-credit-policy carve-out while still meeting the conflicts/approval-process controls for Related Person transactions?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person may only treat more-favourable credit to a Related Person as permissible if it is delivered under an Employee credit policy that is widely available to Employees and is approved by the Authorised Person's Governing Body or the Governing Body's delegate. [#TGT:30c111c6-d50e-462c-a490-ec0ee91dec91] To rely on that approach within its Credit Risk policy framework, the policy must also include adequate conflicts-of-interest procedures for the provision and management of credit, including measures to prevent any Person who directly or indirectly benefits from the credit from being involved in granting or managing it. [#SRC:00064b4f-3f4c-467b-8568-29e635e11496] The employee policy must clearly specify the terms, conditions and limits for providing credit to those Employees, including limits at both individual and aggregate levels, and it must include mechanisms to ensure ongoing compliance. [#TGT:30c111c6-d50e-462c-a490-ec0ee91dec91] Those mechanisms must include immediate reporting to the Governing Body or its delegate if there is any deviation from, or breach of, the applicable terms, conditions, or procedures so timely and appropriate action can be taken. [#TGT:30c111c6-d50e-462c-a490-ec0ee91dec91] Separately, where the policy allows Exposures to Related Persons (on no-more-favourable terms), it must require prior written approval by the Governing Body or its delegate for Exposures (and any write-off) exceeding specified amounts or otherwise posing special risks, and it must exclude beneficiaries from the approval process. [#SRC:00064b4f-3f4c-467b-8568-29e635e11496]

In relation to conflicts of interest and Related Person transactions, the policy must: (a) set out adequate procedures for handling conflicts of interest relating to the provision and management of credit, including measures to prevent any Person directly or indirectly benefiting from the credit being part of the process of granting or managing the credit; (b) subject to Rule 4.4.5, prohibit Exposures to Related Persons on terms that are more favourable than those available to Persons who are not Related Persons; and (c) if Exposures to Related Persons are allowed on terms which are no more favourable than those available to Persons who are not Related Persons, set out procedures that: (i) require such Exposures, and any write off of such Exposures, exceeding specific amounts or otherwise posing special risks to the Authorised Person, to be made subject to the prior written approval of the firm's Governing Body or the Governing Body's delegate; and (ii) exclude Persons directly or indirectly benefiting from the grant or write off of such Exposures being part of the approval process.

The prohibition in Rule 4.4.4(b) does not apply to Providing Credit to a Related Person under a credit policy on terms (such as for credit assessment, tenor, interest rates, amortisation schedules and requirements for Collateral) that are more favourable than those on which it provides credit to Persons who are not Related Persons, provided the credit policy: (a) is an Employee credit policy that is widely available to Employees of the Authorised Person; (b) is approved by the Authorised Person's Governing Body or the Governing Body's delegate; (c) clearly sets out the terms, conditions and limits (both at individual and aggregate levels) on which credit is to be provided to such Employees; and (d) requires adequate mechanisms to ensure on going compliance with the terms and conditions of that credit policy, including immediate reporting to the Governing Body or the Governing Body's delegate where there is a deviation from or a breach of the terms and conditions or procedures applicable to the provision of such credit for timely and appropriate action.

question: For a collateralised transaction (other than an OTC Derivative transaction or a long settlement transaction) that is covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement or qualifying cross product Netting agreement, how must an Authorised Person determine E* when using standard supervisory haircuts or own estimate haircuts under the FCCA, and what are the permitted methods and key inputs for calculating the add on component of that E* calculation?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must determine E* (the exposure value after risk mitigation) for the specified collateralised transactions by applying the required formula that combines the fair value of the Exposure, the fair value of eligible financial Collateral received, and an add on amount for volatility effects. [#SRC:dcbb270d-c9cc-4b97-840b-71ad5f53c4fa] This requirement applies when the transaction is covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement or qualifying cross product Netting agreement and is not an OTC Derivative transaction or a long settlement transaction, and the Authorised Person is using standard supervisory haircuts or own estimate haircuts under the FCCA. [#SRC:dcbb270d-c9cc-4b97-840b-71ad5f53c4fa] To complete the E* calculation, the add on must be calculated using one of two permitted approaches. [#TGT:6705e521-28ce-43be-8404-ffdc3b3ba923] Under the formula-based approach, the add on is determined using inputs that include ES (the absolute value of the net position in a given Security) with its corresponding HS haircut, and EFX (the absolute value of the net position in a currency different from the settlement currency) with its corresponding HFX haircut for currency mismatch between the Collateral and Exposure. [#TGT:6705e521-28ce-43be-8404-ffdc3b3ba923] Alternatively, the add on may be calculated using VaR models, but only if the Authorised Person has received approval from the Regulator as referenced in Rule A4.3.5. [#TGT:6705e521-28ce-43be-8404-ffdc3b3ba923]

debug_context.source_text: Calculation of E* for collateralised transactions other than OTC Derivative transactions and long settlement transactions. An Authorised Person using standard supervisory haircuts or own estimate haircuts under the FCCA must calculate E* for any collateralised transaction covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement or qualifying cross product Netting agreement other than OTC Derivative transactions or long settlement transactions, using the following formula: where: E* = Exposure value after risk mitigation; E = fair value of the Exposure calculated in accordance with Section 4.9 of these Rules; C = fair value of eligible financial Collateral received; and add on = the add on amount to reflect the market price volatility and foreign exchange volatility, calculated in accordance with Rule A4.3.8 below.
debug_context.target_text: An Authorised Person must calculate the add on using one of the following approaches: (a) the approach according to the following formula: where: ES = absolute value of the net position in a given Security; HS = haircut appropriate to ES EFX = absolute value of the net position in a currency different from the settlement currency; and HFX = haircut appropriate for currency mismatch between the Collateral and Exposure; or (b) the approach using VaR models, provided the Authorised Person has received approval from the Regulator as referred to in Rule A4.3.5.

question: Where an Authorised Person is Providing Custody in relation to Accepted Spot Commodities and therefore must comply with COBS, Chapters 14, 15 and 16, how must the Chapter 14–16 terms “Client Assets” and “Investment(s)” (including the related “Client Investments” concept) be interpreted for that compliance purpose?
expected_answer: For an Authorised Person that is Providing Custody in relation to Accepted Spot Commodities, the compliance obligation is to follow the requirements in COBS, Chapters 14, 15 and 16, but to do so using the modified reading of key terms specified for those chapters. [#TGT:23d45c5e-fd58-4146-bd4e-5dfef1a17395] In that context, when Chapters 14, 15 and 16 refer to “Client Assets,” those references must be treated as also covering “Accepted Spot Commodities,” so custody-related controls and requirements that apply to “Client Assets” are applied to Accepted Spot Commodities as well. [#SRC:89eab6b1-87b1-4aee-956d-d75d4f8c556a] Likewise, when those chapters use “Investment” or “Investments,” those terms must be read to include “Accepted Spot Commodity” or “Accepted Spot Commodities,” and this extended meaning carries through to the associated concept of “Client Investments.” [#SRC:89eab6b1-87b1-4aee-956d-d75d4f8c556a] Practically, this means the Authorised Person should not treat Accepted Spot Commodities as outside the scope of Chapter 14–16 requirements merely because the chapters use the labels “Client Assets” or “Investments”; instead, the chapters’ requirements are applied with those terms understood to encompass Accepted Spot Commodities. [#TGT:23d45c5e-fd58-4146-bd4e-5dfef1a17395] [#SRC:89eab6b1-87b1-4aee-956d-d75d4f8c556a]

debug_context.source_text: For the purposes of Rule 22.8.1, the following references in Chapters 14, 15 and 16 should be read as follows – (a) references to “Client Assets” shall be read as encompassing “Accepted Spot Commodities”; and (b) references to “Investment” or “Investments”, (and, a result, the corresponding references to “Client Investments”) shall be read as encompassing “Accepted Spot Commodity” or “Accepted Spot Commodities”, as applicable.
debug_context.target_text: An Authorised Person that is Providing Custody in relation to Accepted Spot Commodities must comply with the requirements set out in COBS, Chapters 14, 15 and 16.

question: When an Authorised Person evaluates its Exposure to interest rate risk arising from its Non Trading Book activities, how must the Rule 7.2.1 stress scenario be applied, and how does that interact with the requirement to measure risk Exposures by material currency where the balance sheet includes multiple currencies?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person’s evaluation of Exposure to interest rate risk from its Non Trading Book activities must incorporate a specific stress component: the evaluation must assess the impact of a sudden, unexpected, parallel interest-rate shift of 200 basis points applied in both an upward and a downward direction. [#SRC:0dd318fb-6509-4aaf-96be-2ee00073b4c6] This stress requirement sits within (and therefore must be included as part of) the broader obligation to carry out an evaluation of Exposure to interest rate risk arising from Non Trading Book activities. [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3] Where the Authorised Person has balance sheet positions in more than one currency, the evaluation must also measure risk Exposures separately for each material currency, meaning the required 200 basis point parallel-rate shock analysis must be capable of being reflected at the level of each material currency exposure rather than only as a single aggregated figure. [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3] In practice, the evaluation should therefore (i) address Non Trading Book interest rate risk Exposure, (ii) apply the 200 basis point parallel change in both directions as the specified sudden and unexpected scenario, and (iii) present the resulting risk Exposures by each material currency when multiple currencies are present on the balance sheet. [#SRC:0dd318fb-6509-4aaf-96be-2ee00073b4c6] [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3]

debug_context.source_text: The evaluation under Rule 7.2.1 must cover the effect of a sudden and unexpected parallel change in interest rates of 200 basis points in both directions.
debug_context.target_text: An Authorised Person must carry out an evaluation of its Exposure to the interest rate risk arising from its Non Trading Book activities. An Authorised Person with balance sheet positions in different currencies must measure its risk Exposures in each of the material currencies.

question: If an Authorised Person is checking interest rate risk from its Non Trading Book, what exact interest-rate shock has to be included, and what do they do differently if they have balance sheet positions in more than one currency?
expected_answer: The Authorised Person must evaluate its Exposure to interest rate risk that comes from its Non Trading Book activities, and that evaluation must include a defined stress test. [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3] Specifically, the evaluation must cover what happens under a sudden and unexpected parallel move in interest rates of 200 basis points, tested in both directions (i.e., a 200 basis point increase and a 200 basis point decrease). [#SRC:0dd318fb-6509-4aaf-96be-2ee00073b4c6] If the Authorised Person has balance sheet positions in different currencies, it cannot treat the exposure as a single undifferentiated number; it must measure its risk Exposures in each of the material currencies. [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3] Putting these requirements together, the evaluation should be structured so that the required 200 basis point parallel-rate shock (up and down) is reflected in the measured risk Exposures for each material currency when multiple currencies are involved. [#SRC:0dd318fb-6509-4aaf-96be-2ee00073b4c6] [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3] This ensures the evaluation both applies the mandated shock scenario and respects the currency-by-currency measurement requirement where relevant. [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3]

question: Where the Board of a Listed Entity is convening a meeting for holders of Debentures to vote on a variation of rights or terms, how should the proxy-voting obligation for meetings of “Shareholders” be applied, and what additional rule-context must the Person referred to in Rule 9.3.1 take into account when treating those Debenture holders as the relevant voting constituency?
expected_answer: In that scenario, the proxy-voting obligation should be applied to the Debenture holders as if they were the “Shareholders” for the purpose of the meeting, so that each eligible Debenture holder is provided both the right and the practical means to vote by proxy at the meeting where voting rights are exercisable. [#TGT:6364a6a2-b7e3-4559-8102-002850811697] This follows because the Regulator expects references to “Shareholder” in the relevant section to be read as extending to holders of all classes of Securities where that makes sense for the Listed Entity, including Debentures when they are the class being asked to vote on a variation of rights or terms. [#SRC:73f40402-9aa2-40a2-b7f9-ccba8d02720b] In addition, when Debenture holders are the voting group, the Person referred to in Rule 9.3.1 is expected to actively consider the requirements of Rules 9.3.6 and 9.3.7 on the same basis—i.e., as though those provisions referred to the relevant Debenture holders rather than only to equity Shareholders. [#SRC:73f40402-9aa2-40a2-b7f9-ccba8d02720b] Practically, this means the meeting arrangements should not limit proxy access to equity holders only; instead, proxy rights and mechanisms must be made available to the class of Security holders who are entitled to vote at that meeting, with the Rule 9.3.6 and 9.3.7 considerations applied to that class. [#TGT:6364a6a2-b7e3-4559-8102-002850811697] [#SRC:73f40402-9aa2-40a2-b7f9-ccba8d02720b]

debug_context.source_text: The Regulator will expect a Person referred to in Rule 9.3.1 to consider references to a “Shareholder” in this section to refer equally to holders of all classes of Securities as may be applicable in the context of the Listed Entity. For example, in a situation where holders of Debentures are to be asked to vote on a variation of rights or terms, the Regulator will expect a Person referred to in Rule 9.3.1 to give due consideration to the requirements of Rules 9.3.6 and 9.3.7 as if it referred to the relevant Debenture holders.

question: If a Listed Entity holds a meeting where Debenture holders (not ordinary Shareholders) can vote on changing their rights or terms, do they also need to be able to vote by proxy, and who is expected to treat the “Shareholder” wording as covering those Debenture holders (including considering Rules 9.3.6 and 9.3.7)?
expected_answer: Yes. When Debenture holders are the group that can vote at the meeting (for example, on a change to their rights or terms), they should be treated as the relevant “Shareholders” for applying the proxy requirement, meaning each eligible Debenture holder must be given both the right and the means to vote by proxy at that meeting. [#TGT:6364a6a2-b7e3-4559-8102-002850811697] This is because the Regulator expects that, in the relevant section, references to “Shareholder” are read to include holders of all classes of Securities where appropriate for the Listed Entity, and it gives the Debenture-holder voting example to illustrate that approach. [#SRC:73f40402-9aa2-40a2-b7f9-ccba8d02720b] The Regulator’s expectation is directed at the Person referred to in Rule 9.3.1, who must give proper attention to the requirements of Rules 9.3.6 and 9.3.7 as though those rules referred to the relevant Debenture holders in that context. [#SRC:73f40402-9aa2-40a2-b7f9-ccba8d02720b] So, even though the proxy rule is written for meetings where “Shareholders” can vote, it should be implemented for the actual voting class at the meeting, and the Rule 9.3.6/9.3.7 considerations should be applied on the same “as if” basis for that class. [#TGT:6364a6a2-b7e3-4559-8102-002850811697] [#SRC:73f40402-9aa2-40a2-b7f9-ccba8d02720b]

question: For a Remote Body’s annual report to the Regulator, how should the reporting period be set and sequenced across successive reports, and how does the suggested one-year period for the report submitted under Rule 7.4.1 fit with the start/end-date mechanics and the two‑month submission timing?
expected_answer: A Remote Body’s annual report should be structured so that each report covers a defined period that runs continuously from the end of the prior reporting period, and the report should then be delivered to the Regulator within the specified post-period deadline; within that framework, a one‑year coverage period is presented as the most convenient choice for the report submitted under Rule 7.4.1. [#SRC:1bdaf884-5e47-444f-a4b8-9cedd8d6e757] [#TGT:dfcc4e9a-d1ad-454a-9f55-22de40772814] For the period boundaries, the period covered by a report begins the day after the period covered by the last report, or—if there is no prior report—begins after the making of the Recognition Order recognising the Remote Body as such. [#TGT:dfcc4e9a-d1ad-454a-9f55-22de40772814] The period ends on the date specified in the report, or if no date is specified, it ends on the date of the report itself. [#TGT:dfcc4e9a-d1ad-454a-9f55-22de40772814] If the Remote Body changes the period covered by its report, it should still ensure there is no gap or overlap by making the first day of the new period the day immediately following the last day of the previous period. [#TGT:dfcc4e9a-d1ad-454a-9f55-22de40772814] Regardless of whether the period chosen is the convenient one‑year period referenced for Rule 7.4.1 reporting, copies should be sent to the Regulator within two months after the end of the period to which the report relates. [#SRC:1bdaf884-5e47-444f-a4b8-9cedd8d6e757] [#TGT:dfcc4e9a-d1ad-454a-9f55-22de40772814]

debug_context.source_text: The period covered by the report to be submitted under Rule 7.4.1 would most conveniently be one year.

In relation to the report: (a) the period covered by such a report starts on the day after the period covered by its last report or, if there is no such report, after the making of the Recognition Order recognising the Remote Body as such, and ends on the date specified in the report or, if no date is specified, on the date of the report. (b) if a Remote Body changes the period covered by its report, it should ensure that the first day of the period covered by a report is the day immediately following the last day of the period covered by the previous report. (c) copies of the report should be sent to the Regulator within two months after the end of the period to which it relates.

question: If a Remote Body wants its annual report to cover about a year (as suggested for the report under Rule 7.4.1), when does that year start and end, what happens if it changes the period later, and how soon after the period ends must it send the report to the Regulator?
expected_answer: The Remote Body can align its annual report to cover a one‑year period, which is described as the most convenient length for the report submitted under Rule 7.4.1, but it still must follow the rules on how each reporting period starts/ends and when the report is sent. [#SRC:1bdaf884-5e47-444f-a4b8-9cedd8d6e757] [#TGT:dfcc4e9a-d1ad-454a-9f55-22de40772814] The start of the period is tied to what came before: it begins the day after the period covered by the last report, or if there has not been a prior report, it begins after the making of the Recognition Order recognising the Remote Body as such. [#TGT:dfcc4e9a-d1ad-454a-9f55-22de40772814] The end of the period is either the date the Remote Body states in the report, or if it does not state an end date, the period ends on the date of the report. [#TGT:dfcc4e9a-d1ad-454a-9f55-22de40772814] If the Remote Body later changes the period it covers, it should keep the timeline continuous by making the first day of the new period the day immediately after the last day of the previous period. [#TGT:dfcc4e9a-d1ad-454a-9f55-22de40772814] After the period ends (whether it is a year or another length), copies of the report should be sent to the Regulator within two months. [#SRC:1bdaf884-5e47-444f-a4b8-9cedd8d6e757] [#TGT:dfcc4e9a-d1ad-454a-9f55-22de40772814]

debug_context.source_text: The period covered by the report to be submitted under Rule 7.4.1 would most conveniently be one year.
debug_context.target_text: A Remote Body shall provide the Regulator with an annual report which contains the information set out in Rule ‎7.4.2. In relation to the report: (a) the period covered by such a report starts on the day after the period covered by its last report or, if there is no such report, after the making of the Recognition Order recognising the Remote Body as such, and ends on the date specified in the report or, if no date is specified, on the date of the report. (b) if a Remote Body changes the period covered by its report, it should ensure that the first day of the period covered by a report is the day immediately following the last day of the period covered by the previous report. (c) copies of the report should be sent to the Regulator within two months after the end of the period to which it relates.

question: For Derivatives (including written credit protection), how should a firm reconcile the SOURCE requirement to compute an Exposure value using an IFRS on-balance sheet amount plus an add-on for potential future Exposure with the TARGET SA-CCR requirement to calculate EAD per netting set using alpha, replacement cost (RC), and potential future exposure (PFE)?
expected_answer: For Derivatives (including written credit protection), the Exposure value framework in the SOURCE is built from two components: (i) an on-balance sheet amount determined under IFRS and (ii) an add-on for potential future Exposure calculated under specified App 4 rules. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] When the firm is applying the SA-CCR method described in the TARGET, it must calculate EAD separately for each netting set and determine it using the formula EAD = alpha * (RC + PFE), with alpha fixed at 1.4. [#TGT:696b66b8-fa0b-4bd0-80cd-98ac02852918] To reconcile the two, the firm should treat the TARGET’s PFE term as the structured “add-on for potential future Exposure” concept referenced in the SOURCE, because both are explicitly defined as potential future exposure amounts calculated under App 4 rule references. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] [#TGT:696b66b8-fa0b-4bd0-80cd-98ac02852918] In addition, the TARGET requires RC (replacement cost) to be calculated under its specified rule set and combined with PFE before applying alpha, and this netting-set-by-netting-set EAD calculation provides the SA-CCR-specific way to operationalize the Exposure measurement for derivatives alongside the SOURCE’s IFRS-plus-add-on structure. [#TGT:696b66b8-fa0b-4bd0-80cd-98ac02852918] [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007]

debug_context.source_text: In relation to on-balance sheet items: a. for SFTs, the Exposure value should be calculated in accordance with IFRS and the Netting requirements referred to in Rule 4.9.14; b. for Derivatives, including written credit protection, the Exposure value should be calculated as the sum of the on-balance sheet value in accordance with IFRS and an add-on for potential future Exposure calculated in accordance with Rules A4.6.14 to A4.6.21 of App 4; and c. for other on-balance sheet items, the Exposure value should be calculated based on their balance sheet values in accordance with Rule 4.9.3.
debug_context.target_text: Derivatives and long settlement transactions – Standardised Approach to Counterparty Credit Risk (SA-CCR). EAD is to be calculated separately for each netting set. It is determined as follows: EAD = alpha* (RC + PFE) where: alpha = 1.4 RC = the replacement cost calculated according to Rules A4.6.19 to A4.6.24 PFE = the amount for potential future exposure calculated according to Rule A4.6.26

question: If you are working out exposure for Derivatives (including written credit protection), what are the pieces you need from the SOURCE (IFRS amount plus add-on) and how does the TARGET say to combine RC and PFE (with alpha) for each netting set?
expected_answer: For Derivatives (including written credit protection), the SOURCE says the Exposure value is made up of two parts: the on-balance sheet value measured under IFRS, plus an add-on for potential future Exposure that is calculated using the referenced App 4 rules. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] The TARGET then gives a specific SA-CCR calculation that must be done separately for each netting set, which is important because it sets the unit of calculation (netting set) rather than a single portfolio-wide number. [#TGT:696b66b8-fa0b-4bd0-80cd-98ac02852918] Under SA-CCR, EAD is computed as EAD = alpha * (RC + PFE), where alpha is 1.4, RC is replacement cost calculated under the specified rules, and PFE is the potential future exposure amount calculated under the specified rule. [#TGT:696b66b8-fa0b-4bd0-80cd-98ac02852918] Linking the two passages, the “add-on for potential future Exposure” concept in the SOURCE aligns with the TARGET’s PFE component, because both are explicitly framed as potential future exposure amounts determined by referenced App 4 rule calculations. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] [#TGT:696b66b8-fa0b-4bd0-80cd-98ac02852918] Practically, you would identify the IFRS on-balance sheet amount per the SOURCE and then use the TARGET’s netting-set SA-CCR structure (RC and PFE with alpha) to express the exposure measurement in the SA-CCR form. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] [#TGT:696b66b8-fa0b-4bd0-80cd-98ac02852918]

question: If the Regulator approves an Application for a Key Individual with conditions and/or for a limited period because it considers that desirable to further its objectives, what mechanism allows the Recognised Body concerned to seek changes to those conditions, and what specific actions may the Regulator take on such a request?
expected_answer: When an application for approval of a Key Individual has been granted subject to conditions, the Recognised Body concerned has a route to request changes to those conditions by applying to the Regulator to vary the approval, but this is framed as applying where the approval was granted subject to one or both of the conditions under Rule 2.3.6. [#SRC:88fdc472-9333-426a-82ae-9602a9ab3418] This sits alongside the Regulator’s broader discretion to approve an Application subject to any conditions it considers appropriate and, if it considers it desirable to further one or more of its objectives, to approve for a limited period only. [#TGT:40fe745f-7cd6-4472-a500-6dcd7eb20714] On a Recognised Body’s application to vary the approval, the Regulator’s available outcomes are specifically to adjust the existing conditions by varying a condition, to lift an existing condition by removing a condition, or to add further constraints by imposing a new condition. [#SRC:88fdc472-9333-426a-82ae-9602a9ab3418] The TARGET passage explains the context in which conditions (and a limited approval period) may be attached in the first place—namely, where the Regulator considers this desirable to advance its objectives—while the SOURCE passage provides the procedural lever and the closed list of condition-related actions the Regulator may take once a variation request is made. [#TGT:40fe745f-7cd6-4472-a500-6dcd7eb20714] [#SRC:88fdc472-9333-426a-82ae-9602a9ab3418]

debug_context.source_text: Where an application for approval of a Key Individual is granted subject to one or both of the conditions under Rule 2.3.6, the Recognised Body concerned may apply to the Regulator to vary the approval. The Regulator may then: (a) vary a condition; (b) remove a condition; or (c) impose a new condition.
debug_context.target_text: The Regulator may approve the Application: (a) subject to any conditions that it considers appropriate; and (b) for a limited period only; if it appears to the Regulator that it is desirable to do so in order to further one or more of its objectives.

question: When reviewing an Applicant’s submission that includes (among other items) details of arrangements for cooperating with the Regulator and other appropriate authorities (including draft memoranda of understanding or letters), how may the Regulator extend its information-gathering beyond the application contents, and from whom and where may it seek additional engagement?
expected_answer: The Regulator is not limited to assessing only the materials listed as items that an application “should include”; it may go further by requesting additional information from the Applicant, including information of the type referenced as being specified in Rule 2.15.4. [#SRC:428b2c75-c493-42dd-8496-629f64a61282] In practice, this means that even if the Applicant has provided the application content covering cooperation arrangements—such as details of how it will cooperate with the Regulator and other appropriate authorities, including draft memoranda of understanding or letters—the Regulator may still require further information beyond those submitted documents. [#TGT:e3ca5363-b207-4179-91e2-c6e34ac4384e] In addition to seeking further information directly from the Applicant, the Regulator may also need to hold discussions with the appropriate authorities in the Applicant’s home jurisdiction, which adds an external engagement channel that complements the Applicant’s own described cooperation framework. [#SRC:428b2c75-c493-42dd-8496-629f64a61282] Accordingly, an Applicant should be prepared both to supplement its application package and to support cross-jurisdictional regulatory discussions that the Regulator considers necessary. [#SRC:428b2c75-c493-42dd-8496-629f64a61282]

question: If an Applicant has already put in its application the last three annual reports and accounts and the current year’s quarterly management accounts, can the Regulator still ask for more information, and can it also talk to authorities in the Applicant’s home jurisdiction?
expected_answer: Yes. Even where the application includes financial materials such as copies of the last three annual reports and accounts and, for the current financial year, quarterly management accounts, the Regulator may still require further information from the Applicant. [#TGT:e3ca5363-b207-4179-91e2-c6e34ac4384e] The Regulator’s ability to seek more is not confined to the listed application contents; it may request additional information, including information described as being specified in Rule 2.15.4. [#SRC:428b2c75-c493-42dd-8496-629f64a61282] Separately from requesting more documents or explanations from the Applicant, the Regulator may also need to have discussions with the appropriate authorities in the Applicant’s home jurisdiction. [#SRC:428b2c75-c493-42dd-8496-629f64a61282] Taken together, this means that providing the specified financial submissions is necessary for a complete application package, but it does not prevent follow-up requests or cross-border regulatory engagement if the Regulator considers those steps needed. [#TGT:e3ca5363-b207-4179-91e2-c6e34ac4384e]

question: When an Authorised Person calculates the maximum distributable amount using the multiplication method in the SOURCE, how should it treat interim or year-end profits that were not included in CET1 Capital, given the TARGET’s description of what CET1 Capital consists of, and how does the CET1 Capital quartile position affect the factor applied?
expected_answer: In determining the maximum distributable amount, an Authorised Person must start from the specified pool of profits and then apply a factor that depends on where its CET1 Capital sits within the Combined Buffer Requirement. [#SRC:429f39da-ff13-4d90-856c-4f12c224cdc1] The profit pool used in the multiplication is limited to interim or year-end profits that were not included in CET1 Capital and that accrued after the most recent distribution of profits and after any actions referenced in the SOURCE. [#SRC:429f39da-ff13-4d90-856c-4f12c224cdc1] This “not included in CET1 Capital” condition should be understood against the CET1 Capital composition: CET1 Capital is made up of specified capital elements such as capital instruments meeting Rule 3.10.3 conditions, related share premium, retained earnings, accumulated other comprehensive income (as defined in IFRS), and other IFRS-disclosed reserves (with stated exclusions). [#TGT:6ae8d23c-06f5-4f8c-b1b1-824cb6db43eb] After identifying the eligible profit pool, the Authorised Person must multiply it by the factor tied to its CET1 Capital (excluding CET1 used to meet the Capital Requirement, including any Individual Capital Requirement) falling into the first, second, third, or fourth quartile of the Combined Buffer Requirement: 0, 0.2, 0.4, or 0.6 respectively. [#SRC:429f39da-ff13-4d90-856c-4f12c224cdc1]

debug_context.source_text: Subject to sub-paragraph (4), an Authorised Person must determine the maximum distributable amount by multiplying the sum specified in (a) by the factor determined under (b): (a) the total of interim or year-end profits that were not included in CET1 Capital pursuant to Rule 3.10.2 and which have accrued after the most recent distribution of profits and after any of the actions referred to in Rule 3.19.3(b); (b) where the CET1 Capital of the Authorised Person (which is not used to meet the Capital Requirement, including any Individual Capital Requirement as may be imposed pursuant to Chapter 10) falls: (i) within the first quartile of the Combined Buffer Requirement, the factor shall be 0; (ii) within the second quartile of the Combined Buffer Requirement, the factor shall be 0.2; (iii) within the third quartile of the Combined Buffer Requirement, the factor shall be 0.4; (iv) within the fourth quartile of the Combined Buffer Requirement, the factor shall be 0.6.
debug_context.target_text: CET1 Capital consists of the sum of the following capital elements: (a) capital instruments, provided the conditions laid down in Rule 3.10.3 are fully met; (b) Share premium accounts related to the instruments referred to in (a); (c) retained earnings; (d) accumulated other comprehensive income, as defined in the International Financial Reporting Standards; and (e) other reserves which are required to be disclosed under International Financial Reporting Standards, excluding any amounts already included in accumulated other comprehensive income or retained earnings.

question: If an Authorised Person has profits since the last profit distribution, how do they decide which profits go into the maximum distributable amount calculation, using the CET1 Capital definition in the TARGET and the quartile-based factor rules in the SOURCE?
expected_answer: To decide what profits feed into the maximum distributable amount calculation, the Authorised Person must first identify the relevant profits and then apply the correct quartile-based factor. [#SRC:429f39da-ff13-4d90-856c-4f12c224cdc1] The profits that can be used are only interim or year-end profits that were not included in CET1 Capital, and they must have accrued after the most recent distribution of profits and after any actions referenced in the SOURCE. [#SRC:429f39da-ff13-4d90-856c-4f12c224cdc1] Whether profits were “included in CET1 Capital” should be assessed in light of what CET1 Capital consists of: it is the sum of specified elements including qualifying capital instruments (subject to Rule 3.10.3 conditions), related share premium accounts, retained earnings, accumulated other comprehensive income (as defined in IFRS), and other IFRS-disclosed reserves (excluding amounts already counted in accumulated other comprehensive income or retained earnings). [#TGT:6ae8d23c-06f5-4f8c-b1b1-824cb6db43eb] Once the eligible profit amount is set, the Authorised Person multiplies it by a factor determined by where its CET1 Capital (excluding CET1 used to meet the Capital Requirement, including any Individual Capital Requirement) falls within the Combined Buffer Requirement quartiles: 0 in the first quartile, 0.2 in the second, 0.4 in the third, and 0.6 in the fourth. [#SRC:429f39da-ff13-4d90-856c-4f12c224cdc1]

question: When an Authorised Person is considering recognising the effects of CRM of a Credit Derivative where the protection provider is an MDB, how does the eligibility condition for recognising CRM interact with the requirement to risk weight a CR Exposure in the MDB asset class, including the applicable risk weights by Credit Quality Grade and for unrated exposures?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person may recognise the effects of CRM of a Credit Derivative provided by an MDB only where the MDB is one of the MDBs referred to in Rules 4.12.7 to 4.12.9, so the protection provider must fall within that MDB category for CRM recognition to be available. [#SRC:089417ca-c77d-4879-bc10-8d8138b1853b] Separately, where the exposure is a CR Exposure in the MDB asset class, the Authorised Person must apply the MDB asset class risk-weighting table (noting it is stated to be subject to Rules 4.12.8 and 4.12.9). [#TGT:9ef96fbf-ed8f-40fb-bf4c-e2e1957a371c] In practice, this means you address two linked determinations: (i) whether the protection provider qualifies as an MDB for purposes of recognising CRM effects, and (ii) how the relevant CR Exposure in the MDB asset class is risk weighted under the table. [#SRC:089417ca-c77d-4879-bc10-8d8138b1853b] [#TGT:9ef96fbf-ed8f-40fb-bf4c-e2e1957a371c] Under the table, Credit Quality Grade 1 receives a 0% risk weight; Grades 2 and 3 receive 50%; Grades 4 and 5 receive 100%; Grade 6 receives 150%; and unrated exposures receive 50%. question: When determining the Credit RWA of an Authorised Person, how must the securitisation Exposures (SE Exposures) component be calculated, including the treatment of SE Exposures that are instead required to be deducted from Capital Resources and the interaction with Early Amortisation Exposures?
expected_answer: In calculating Credit RWA, an Authorised Person must include a distinct SE Exposures component within the overall sum that makes up its Credit RWA. [#SRC:5e5b0814-b3c0-441d-b92e-c7fe290a8020] For that SE Exposures component, the Authorised Person must determine an Exposure value for each SE Exposure using the Exposure measurement methodology in Section 4.9 and taking into account any applicable CRM, then assign a Credit Quality Grade under Section 4.11 to identify the applicable risk weight. [#TGT:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] It must then compute the RWA amount for each SE Exposure using the formula RWA(SE) = SE × CRW, where SE is the Exposure value and CRW is the risk weight derived from the Credit Quality Grade. [#TGT:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] However, this per-exposure RWA calculation does not apply to SE Exposures that the Authorised Person is required to include as deductions from any component of Capital Resources. [#TGT:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] Finally, it must aggregate the RWA amounts for all SE Exposures (as calculated) and add them to the RWA amounts calculated under Rule 4.8.5 for Early Amortisation Exposures, and this combined result forms the SE Exposures element included in Credit RWA. [#TGT:fb2fbe0f-8a2e-409a-9ab8-53aff2c4c646] [#SRC:5e5b0814-b3c0-441d-b92e-c7fe290a8020]

question: When calculating the Exposure value for on-balance sheet Derivatives (including written credit protection), how should the firm incorporate the potential future Exposure add-on, and how does that interact with the SA-CCR requirement to calculate RC and PFE differently for margined versus unmargined netting sets, including the cap on EAD for margined netting sets?
expected_answer: For on-balance sheet Derivatives (including written credit protection), the Exposure value is determined by combining two elements: the on-balance sheet value measured under IFRS and an additional amount for potential future Exposure that is calculated under the specified App 4 rules. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] When the derivative exposures are being assessed under SA-CCR, the firm must ensure that the replacement cost (RC) and potential future exposure (PFE) components are computed using different methods depending on whether the relevant netting set is margined or unmargined, so the PFE concept used for the add-on must be aligned to the appropriate margined/unmargined treatment. [#TGT:949c0178-dbd8-44f8-b832-e4c2a327c941] In addition, where the firm determines an exposure at default (EAD) for a margined netting set, it must apply the cap that limits that margined EAD to no more than the EAD that would result if the same netting set were calculated on an unmargined basis. [#TGT:949c0178-dbd8-44f8-b832-e4c2a327c941] Practically, this means the IFRS on-balance sheet value remains part of the Exposure value, while the potential future Exposure add-on is calculated per the referenced rules and then reflected consistently with the SA-CCR margined/unmargined netting set framework and the EAD cap. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] [#TGT:949c0178-dbd8-44f8-b832-e4c2a327c941]

debug_context.source_text: In relation to on-balance sheet items: a. for SFTs, the Exposure value should be calculated in accordance with IFRS and the Netting requirements referred to in Rule 4.9.14; b. for Derivatives, including written credit protection, the Exposure value should be calculated as the sum of the on-balance sheet value in accordance with IFRS and an add-on for potential future Exposure calculated in accordance with Rules A4.6.14 to A4.6.21 of App 4; and c. for other on-balance sheet items, the Exposure value should be calculated based on their balance sheet values in accordance with Rule 4.9.3.

The replacement cost (RC) and the potential future exposure (PFE) components must be calculated differently for margined and unmargined netting sets. The EAD for a margined netting set is to be capped at the EAD of the same netting set calculated on an unmargined basis.

question: Where a RIE or MTF settles Digital Securities without engaging a RCH (for example, by using a DSF), what must be provided to the FSRA and what compliance standard applies to the DSF, and how does this interact with the statement that a Recognised Clearing House is not treated as breaching its Recognition Requirement solely because it cannot arrange settlement of a specific transaction?
expected_answer: If a RIE or MTF does not engage a RCH for Digital Securities settlement (for example, instead using a DSF), it must give the FSRA written details of the satisfactory arrangements it has made for settlement in that scenario. [#SRC:cf09ad93-5f69-4c7f-8239-0281b7659c5e] In addition, the settlement arrangements must be structured so that the DSF meets the requirements of MIR Rule 4.3.3, applying that rule as if references to a RCH were references to the DSF. [#SRC:cf09ad93-5f69-4c7f-8239-0281b7659c5e] This DSF-focused obligation is distinct from, and not replaced by, the position that a Recognised Clearing House is not regarded as failing to comply with the Recognition Requirement merely because it cannot arrange settlement for a particular transaction. [#TGT:a15123d3-b822-401d-9551-e8759dd9e84e] Practically, the RIE or MTF cannot treat an inability to settle a specific transaction as eliminating the need to document and submit its non-RCH settlement arrangements to the FSRA, nor can it avoid ensuring the DSF is held to the MIR Rule 4.3.3 standard (with the RCH references adapted). [#SRC:cf09ad93-5f69-4c7f-8239-0281b7659c5e] The RCH statement instead clarifies how a RCH is assessed against its Recognition Requirement in a narrow circumstance, without changing the separate written-notification and DSF-compliance expectations when a RCH is not engaged. [#TGT:a15123d3-b822-401d-9551-e8759dd9e84e]

debug_context.source_text: DIGITAL SECURITIES SETTLEMENT Digital Settlement Facilities (DSFs) Pursuant to MIR Rule 3.8.3, however, and in the context of Digital Securities, a RIE or MTF must provide the FSRA, in writing, with the details of the satisfactory arrangements made when such RIE or MTF does not engage a RCH (for example, to use in this context, a DSF). To clarify, the FSRA will require that arrangements to use a DSF for settlement purposes will require the DSF to comply with the requirements of MIR Rule 4.3.3 (with the references to a RCH being read as references to a DSF).
debug_context.target_text: A Recognised Clearing House will not be regarded as failing to comply with the Recognition Requirement merely because it is unable to arrange for a specific transaction to be settled.

expected_answer: When a RIE or MTF settles Digital Securities without engaging a RCH (for example, by using a DSF), it must send the FSRA a written submission describing the details of the satisfactory settlement arrangements it has put in place for that non-RCH approach. question: Where the Behaviour consists of disseminating information by any means that gives, or is likely to give, a false or misleading impression as to a Financial Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity, what knowledge standard must be satisfied by the person who disseminates the information, and how is that standard framed (subjective vs objective) under the referenced test?
expected_answer: In this scenario, the knowledge element is satisfied if the person who disseminates the information either actually knew the information was false or misleading or, applying an objective standard, could reasonably be expected to have known it was false or misleading. [#TGT:69005f53-8e03-4e6f-b2eb-82b1fff946ef] This knowledge requirement is framed as a two-limb test: a subjective limb based on what the disseminator in fact knew, and an objective limb based on what the disseminator could reasonably be expected to know. [#SRC:c2310748-8c6b-4e04-95ef-fdccf6275cfc] The conduct context that triggers the need to apply this test is dissemination “by any means” of information that gives, or is likely to give, a false or misleading impression about the specified categories (a Financial Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset, or an Accepted Spot Commodity). [#TGT:69005f53-8e03-4e6f-b2eb-82b1fff946ef] When assessing whether the knowledge element is met for that dissemination, the applicable standard is therefore not limited to proof of actual awareness; it also captures cases where the person should have known, judged against what could reasonably be expected. [#SRC:c2310748-8c6b-4e04-95ef-fdccf6275cfc]

Section 92(6) requires that the person who disseminates the information either knows or could reasonably be expected to know that the information is false or misleading. That is, it sets out either a subjective or objective test relating to knowledge that must be met.

question: If someone shares information (in any way) that gives or is likely to give a false or misleading impression about a Financial Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset, or an Accepted Spot Commodity, what does it mean that they “knew or could reasonably be expected to have known” the information was false or misleading?
expected_answer: It means the knowledge condition can be met in two different ways for the person who disseminates the information: either they actually knew the information was false or misleading, or they did not know but could reasonably be expected to have known it was false or misleading. [#TGT:69005f53-8e03-4e6f-b2eb-82b1fff946ef] The first route is a subjective test focused on the person’s real awareness, while the second route is an objective test focused on what a person in that position could reasonably be expected to know. [#SRC:c2310748-8c6b-4e04-95ef-fdccf6275cfc] This two-part knowledge standard is applied specifically in the situation where the Behaviour is dissemination of information “by any means” that gives, or is likely to give, a false or misleading impression about the listed types of assets or instruments. [#TGT:69005f53-8e03-4e6f-b2eb-82b1fff946ef] So, for that kind of dissemination, it is not necessary to show only actual knowledge; it is also enough if the person is judged, on a reasonable-expectation basis, as someone who should have known the information was false or misleading. question: Where an Authorised Person acts as both a Money Remitter and a Payment Account Provider, how must it determine the monthly payment volume base for its overall Variable Capital Requirement, and how is that base then applied to the Payment Account Provider Variable Capital Requirement rate bands?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person that performs both Money Remitter and Payment Account Provider activities must first form a single monthly payment volume figure by aggregating (i.e., adding together) the monthly payment volumes attributable to those related activities, and it must use that combined figure as the basis for its overall Variable Capital Requirement calculation. [#SRC:b68ce9bd-b816-410b-92f6-32569f63a223] Once that combined monthly payment volume is determined, the Payment Account Provider Variable Capital Requirement is calculated by applying the tiered percentage rates to the combined volume in sequence: 2.5% applies to the first $10 million, 1% applies to the next $90 million, 0.5% applies to the next $150 million, and 0.25% applies to any remaining monthly payment volume above those tiers. [#TGT:7593338e-8695-47bb-ad6a-b441de562eb4] In practical terms, this means the firm does not calculate separate tiered amounts for each activity and then add the results; instead, it adds the monthly payment volumes for the two activities first and then runs the combined total through the tier structure to arrive at the Variable Capital Requirement amount. [#SRC:b68ce9bd-b816-410b-92f6-32569f63a223] [#TGT:7593338e-8695-47bb-ad6a-b441de562eb4]
