A Payment Account Provider must calculate its Variable Capital Requirement as the sum of the following: (a) 2.5% of the first $10 million of monthly payment volume; (b) 1% of the next $90 million of monthly payment volume; (c) 0.5% of the next $150 million of monthly payment volume; and (d) 0.25% of any remaining monthly payment volume.

question: If an Authorised Person is both a Money Remitter and a Payment Account Provider, do they add the two monthly payment volumes together first, and then use the Payment Account Provider percentage bands to work out the Variable Capital Requirement?
expected_answer: Yes. When an Authorised Person is acting as both a Money Remitter and a Payment Account Provider, it must combine the monthly payment volumes for those related activities by adding them together, and that combined monthly payment volume is used to calculate the overall Variable Capital Requirement. [#SRC:b68ce9bd-b816-410b-92f6-32569f63a223] After you have that single combined monthly payment volume, the Payment Account Provider calculation applies a stepped set of percentages to the total: 2.5% is applied to the first $10 million of monthly payment volume, 1% to the next $90 million, 0.5% to the next $150 million, and 0.25% to anything above those amounts. [#TGT:7593338e-8695-47bb-ad6a-b441de562eb4] This linkage matters because the combined-volume step determines which parts of the total fall into each band (for example, whether the total exceeds $10 million or $100 million), and the banded percentages then determine the resulting Variable Capital Requirement amount. question: For a Petroleum Reporting Entity preparing a Summary of Reserves and Resources, how does the exemption for entities that file SEC compliant Forms 10-K and 20-F Reports annually with the SEC affect the obligation to include the MKT Form 12-1 table (including the “no earlier than one month prior” dating condition) that is otherwise required, and what is the resulting compliance position?
expected_answer: A Petroleum Reporting Entity that is required to file SEC compliant Forms 10-K and 20-F Reports annually with the SEC is exempt from complying with Rule 12.14.1. [#SRC:b249219a-57ec-4b15-be46-58475357c6c1] Separately, the rule governing the Summary of Reserves and Resources states that, subject to Rule 12.14.3, a Petroleum Reporting Entity must include a table in the form of MKT Form 12-1, and that table must be prepared as of a date no earlier than one month before the Summary of Reserves and Resources is disclosed. [#TGT:cd137cde-9ef8-4ed1-a401-6bf47f8ccb04] Read together, the SEC annual filer status removes the need to comply with Rule 12.14.1, but it does not, on these texts alone, remove the separate obligation to include the MKT Form 12-1 table with the specified timing condition when disclosing the Summary of Reserves and Resources. [#SRC:b249219a-57ec-4b15-be46-58475357c6c1] [#TGT:cd137cde-9ef8-4ed1-a401-6bf47f8ccb04] Accordingly, unless another provision (expressly referenced as Rule 12.14.3) changes the requirement, the entity should still include the MKT Form 12-1 table dated within the one-month window for the Summary of Reserves and Resources disclosure. [#TGT:cd137cde-9ef8-4ed1-a401-6bf47f8ccb04]

question: Where a Mining Reporting Entity has already made a compliant disclosure of Non-Equivalent Estimates, under what conditions may a later disclosure omit the detailed items normally required for material Non-Equivalent Estimates (such as source/date, reliability, and the Competent Person statement), and what specific statement must still be included in the later disclosure?
expected_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity may omit the detailed information otherwise required for a disclosure of material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation only if the later disclosure is structured as a true follow-on to an earlier disclosure that already met those detailed requirements. [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b] To do so, the later disclosure must (i) point back to the earlier compliant disclosure, and (ii) include the Mining Reporting Entity’s confirmation that the earlier information still applies and that there is no new material information or data affecting either how the Non-Equivalent Estimates should be relied on/interpreted or the Mining Reporting Entity’s ability to verify them as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves under a Mining Reporting Standard. [#SRC:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4] Even when relying on that omission pathway, the later disclosure must still carry an at least equally prominent and proximate statement about the Non-Equivalent Estimates that addresses the same core matters as the required prominent/proximate warning for Non-Equivalent Estimates (i.e., that they are not reported under a Mining Reporting Standard, have not been sufficiently worked by a Competent Person for classification, and may never become reportable as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves). [#SRC:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4] [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b]

debug_context.source_text: If a Mining Reporting Entity has disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates that comply with the requirements of Rule 11.7.3, then any subsequent disclosure made in respect of the Non-Equivalent Estimates does not need to include the information in that Rule if the subsequent disclosure: (1) references the earlier disclosure that was in compliance with that Rule; (2) contains a confirmation from the Mining Reporting Entity that: (a) the information provided in the earlier disclosure in compliance with that Rule continues to apply; and (b) there is no new material information or data relating to the Non-Equivalent Estimates that impacts on the: (i) reliability or interpretation of the Non-Equivalent Estimates; or (ii) Mining Reporting Entity’s ability to verify the Non-Equivalent Estimates as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard; and (3) includes an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement about the disclosed Non-Equivalent Estimates addressing the matters contained in Rule 11.7.3(1).

(2) the source(s) and date(s) of the Non-Equivalent Estimates; (3) if the Non-Equivalent Estimates use categories of Mineralisation, a statement identifying whether the categories used: (a) are different to those defined in a Mining Reporting Standard, and an explanation of the differences; or (b) are the same as those defined in a Mining Reporting Standard; (4) the relevance of the Non-Equivalent Estimates to the Mining Reporting Entity; (5) the reliability of the Non-Equivalent Estimates; Guidance: For example, the Mining Reporting Entity may want to have regard to the relevant criteria listed in Table 1 of the JORC Code. (6) a summary of the evaluation and/or exploration work on which the Non-Equivalent Estimates are based; (7) a summary of the key assumptions, mining and processing parameters and methods used to prepare the Non-Equivalent Estimates; (8) details of any more recent estimates or data relevant to interpreting the Non-Equivalent Estimates, and the source(s) and date(s) of the estimates or data; (9) the evaluation and/or exploration work that needs to be undertaken to verify the Non-Equivalent Estimates as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves in accordance with a Mining Reporting Standard; (10) the proposed timing of the evaluation and/or exploration work disclosed in (9); (11) the proposed source of funding for the evaluation and/or exploration work disclosed pursuant to (9); (12) the mineral resources classification and reporting standard used in determining the Non-Equivalent Estimates; and (13) a statement by a named Competent Person(s) that the information in the disclosure provided pursuant to (3) to (9) is an accurate representation of the available data and studies relating to the Non-Equivalent Estimates.

expected_answer: The Mining Reporting Entity can avoid repeating the full set of detailed disclosure items for material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation only when the new announcement is clearly tied to an earlier announcement that already included those items. [#SRC:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4] The later disclosure still needs a prominent and nearby warning statement about the Non-Equivalent Estimates, and it must be at least as prominent and proximate as the earlier required warning. [#SRC:21c96fff-8e3a-453f-9d85-4a922d8e7bf4] That warning must cover the key points that the estimates are Non-Equivalent Estimates not disclosed under a Mining Reporting Standard, that a Competent Person has not done enough work to classify them as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, and that it is uncertain they will ever be reportable as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves after further work. question: For the non-prejudicing obligation that applies when an Employee discloses information regarding money laundering, which recipients qualify as an "other relevant body" beyond the Regulator, and how should a Relevant Person apply that classification when assessing whether its treatment of the Employee is prohibited?
expected_answer: A Relevant Person must treat the term “other relevant body” as covering specific types of authorities identified by the Regulator, and then ensure its conduct toward the Employee does not amount to prejudice when the disclosure is made to any of those recipients. [#TGT:c583c762-1740-4364-8f60-66ff7bd606e1] In applying this, the Relevant Person should recognize that the Regulator considers a “relevant body” to include the FIU, any other financial intelligence unit, the police, and an Abu Dhabi or Federal ministry or authority. [#SRC:bb51c6c0-5515-4091-9e92-a671edcc2bb4] Accordingly, if an Employee discloses information regarding money laundering to the Regulator, or instead to the FIU, another financial intelligence unit, the police, or an Abu Dhabi or Federal ministry or authority involved in preventing money laundering, the Relevant Person must ensure it does not prejudice that Employee because of the disclosure. [#TGT:c583c762-1740-4364-8f60-66ff7bd606e1] [#SRC:bb51c6c0-5515-4091-9e92-a671edcc2bb4] The practical compliance step is to map the disclosure recipient to this “relevant body” list and treat disclosures to any listed recipient the same as disclosures to the Regulator for purposes of the non-prejudicing requirement. [#TGT:c583c762-1740-4364-8f60-66ff7bd606e1] [#SRC:bb51c6c0-5515-4091-9e92-a671edcc2bb4]

debug_context.target_text: A Relevant Person must ensure that it does not prejudice an Employee who discloses any information regarding money laundering to the Regulator or to any other relevant body involved in the prevention of money laundering.

question: If an Employee reports money laundering information, who counts as an “other relevant body” they can report to (besides the Regulator), and what does the Relevant Person have to do about how it treats that Employee?
expected_answer: The Relevant Person has to make sure it does not prejudice an Employee for sharing information about money laundering, whether the Employee reports to the Regulator or to another qualifying body involved in preventing money laundering. [#TGT:c583c762-1740-4364-8f60-66ff7bd606e1] To know which outside recipients qualify, the Regulator’s view is that a “relevant body” includes the FIU, any other financial intelligence unit, the police, and an Abu Dhabi or Federal ministry or authority. [#SRC:bb51c6c0-5515-4091-9e92-a671edcc2bb4] Putting these together, if the Employee makes the disclosure to any of those bodies (for example, the FIU or the police) rather than directly to the Regulator, the Relevant Person still must ensure the Employee is not prejudiced because of the disclosure. [#TGT:c583c762-1740-4364-8f60-66ff7bd606e1] [#SRC:bb51c6c0-5515-4091-9e92-a671edcc2bb4] In practice, the Relevant Person should treat disclosures to the listed bodies as within the same protected category as disclosures to the Regulator when deciding how it will act toward the Employee. question: During a Restriction Period, how should a Listed Entity comply with the prohibition on seeking or agreeing to release a holding lock, while also meeting the requirement to obtain and submit an undertaking (within two Business Days after issuing Restricted Securities) from an eligible third party to impose and maintain that holding lock?
expected_answer: A Listed Entity must both (i) ensure a holding lock is put in place through a qualifying third-party undertaking promptly after issuance of Restricted Securities and (ii) avoid any conduct during the Restriction Period that would undermine that lock, including requesting or agreeing to its release. [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76] [#SRC:344f9898-63f7-4bec-afdc-2c9984f6502d] The timing obligation applies within two Business Days after the issue of Restricted Securities and requires the Listed Entity to obtain and submit to the Regulator an undertaking from a bank, trustee, custodian, Recognised Body, CSD, or another entity the Regulator considers suitable. [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76] That undertaking must cover placing a holding lock on the Restricted Securities held by that entity and not releasing the lock without the Regulator’s prior written consent. [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76] Separately, during a Restriction Period, a Listed Entity (as well as any Security Holder or Controller subject to a Restriction Agreement) must not ask for or agree to the release of a holding lock imposed in accordance with Rule 9.6.9. [#SRC:344f9898-63f7-4bec-afdc-2c9984f6502d] In practice, the Listed Entity should align its post-issuance undertaking process with the Restriction Period prohibition by ensuring any lock-release discussions are avoided unless the Regulator’s prior written consent is obtained under the undertaking framework. [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76] [#SRC:344f9898-63f7-4bec-afdc-2c9984f6502d]

debug_context.source_text: Entry into Restriction Agreements and Application of Restriction. During a Restriction Period, a Listed Entity, Security Holder or Controller subject to a Restriction Agreement must not: (1) amend an executed Restriction Agreement; or (2) ask for or agree to the release of a holding lock that has been imposed in accordance with Rule 9.6.9.
debug_context.target_text: Timing and Enforcement. A Listed Entity must obtain, and submit to the Regulator, within two Business Days after the issue of Restricted Securities, an undertaking from a bank, trustee, custodian, Recognised Body, CSD or other entity deemed suitable by the Regulator, to place a holding lock on the Restricted Securities held by it, and not to release the holding lock without the Regulator’s prior written consent.

question: If Restricted Securities have just been issued, what does a Listed Entity need to do within two Business Days to get a holding lock set up, and what must it avoid doing during the Restriction Period if it is subject to a Restriction Agreement?
expected_answer: The Listed Entity needs to take prompt steps to secure a third-party commitment to impose a holding lock and then ensure no one covered by the Restriction Agreement tries to get that lock lifted during the Restriction Period. [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76] [#SRC:344f9898-63f7-4bec-afdc-2c9984f6502d] Within two Business Days after the issue of Restricted Securities, the Listed Entity must obtain an undertaking and submit it to the Regulator. [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76] The undertaking must come from a bank, trustee, custodian, Recognised Body, CSD, or another entity the Regulator deems suitable, and it must require that entity to place a holding lock on the Restricted Securities it holds. [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76] It must also state that the holding lock will not be released unless the Regulator gives prior written consent. [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76] At the same time, during a Restriction Period, a Listed Entity, Security Holder, or Controller that is subject to a Restriction Agreement must not ask for or agree to the release of a holding lock that was imposed in accordance with Rule 9.6.9. [#SRC:344f9898-63f7-4bec-afdc-2c9984f6502d] The practical result is that the Listed Entity should treat the lock as maintained unless the Regulator’s written consent is obtained and should avoid any request or agreement to release it during the Restriction Period. question: When applying the 25% Tier 1 Large Exposures cap to positions in the Non Trading Book (and, where relevant, the Trading Book), what specific identification, measurement/aggregation, monitoring, and breach-notification steps must an Authorised Person perform so that the limit is assessed after eligible CRM is reflected?
expected_answer: To apply the 25% of Tier 1 Large Exposures cap to exposures in the Non Trading Book (and, where applicable, the Trading Book), an Authorised Person must operationalize a process that both quantifies exposures relative to Tier 1 and ensures the limit is assessed after eligible CRM is reflected. [#TGT:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f] This requires the Authorised Person to identify its Exposures and the relevant Counterparties (including whether any are Closely Related to each other or Connected to the Authorised Person), measure and establish the value of those Exposures, and determine each Exposure’s size as a proportion of Tier 1. [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675] Because the limit is applied after taking into account eligible CRM, the Authorised Person must also identify whether it has Exposures that are subject to the requirements of Section 4.13 (CRM) so the effect of eligible CRM can be reflected in the limit assessment. [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675] The Authorised Person must aggregate Exposures to the same Counterparty or to groups of Closely Related or Connected Counterparties, then monitor and control Exposures daily within the Large Exposures limits. [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675] If the 25% Tier 1 limit is breached, it must notify the Regulator immediately and confirm the breach in writing. [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675]

For the purposes of this Section an Authorised Person must: (a) identify its Exposures; (b) identify its Counterparties, including whether any are Closely Related to each other or Connected to the Authorised Person; (c) measure the size of its Exposures; (d) establish the value of its Exposures; (e) determine the size of its Exposures as a proportion of its Tier 1; (f) identify whether it has Exposures which are subject to the requirements of Section 4.13 (CRM); (g) identify which, if any, of its Exposures are exempt in accordance with Section A4.11 from the limits set out in Rules 4.15.4 to 4.15.7; (h) aggregate its Exposures to the same Counterparty or group of Closely Related Counterparties or group of Connected Counterparties; (i) monitor and control its Exposures on a daily basis within the Large Exposures limits; and (j) notify the Regulator immediately of any breach of the limits set out in this Section and confirm it in writing.

question: For unauthorised Third Party Transactions, when is a Third Party Provider required to provide a refund, and how does the position change if the Third Party Provider has reasonable grounds to suspect fraudulent behaviour by the Customer?
expected_answer: For an unauthorised (or incorrectly executed) Third Party Transaction, the Third Party Provider is required to provide a refund under Rule 20.12.1 promptly: it must do so as soon as practicable and, at the latest, by the end of the day after the day it confirms the transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed. [#TGT:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259] This timing obligation is framed around the point of confirmation, so the operational trigger for the deadline is the Third Party Provider’s confirmation that the Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed. [#TGT:74fba309-e803-4091-943a-510cb845f259] However, the specific requirement to provide a refund within the timeframe prescribed in Rule 20.12.2 is disapplied where the Third Party Provider has reasonable grounds to suspect fraudulent behaviour by the Customer. [#SRC:ddd7b7c2-8a0a-43d4-ab4e-f9dec2d2b012] In practice, this means that even though refunds are generally expected quickly once unauthorised status is confirmed, the Third Party Provider is not bound by the Rule 20.12.2 timeframe in the fraud-suspicion scenario described. [#SRC:ddd7b7c2-8a0a-43d4-ab4e-f9dec2d2b012] The analysis therefore turns on (i) confirmation of unauthorised/incorrect execution for the standard deadline, and (ii) whether there are reasonable grounds to suspect Customer fraud for the Rule 20.12.2 timing carve-out. question: If a Third Party Provider confirms a Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed, how quickly must it refund, and what happens to the refund timing rule if it reasonably suspects the Customer is acting fraudulently?
expected_answer: Once the Third Party Provider has confirmed that a Third Party Transaction was unauthorised or incorrectly executed, it must provide a refund under Rule 20.12.1 as soon as practicable and no later than the end of the next day (the day after the confirmation day). question: Where an Exposure is only partially guaranteed by an Authorised Person's Parent Financial Institution and the guaranteed portion would attract a lower risk weight under Section 4.12, how should the Authorised Person determine what portion (if any) can be excluded from the Large Exposure limits, and what additional parental-guarantee conditions and ongoing confirmations/notifications apply if the Authorised Person relies on the parental-guarantee treatment to exclude the Exposure?
expected_answer: The Authorised Person should treat the exemption as limited to the guaranteed slice of the Exposure: if the Exposure is only partly covered by a guarantee from the Authorised Person's Parent Financial Institution and that covered slice would receive a lower risk weight under Section 4.12, only the portion subject to the guarantee is exempt from the Large Exposure limit in Rule 4.15.5. [#SRC:81186429-473c-4428-ac22-2536fc6258c3] If the Authorised Person instead seeks to exclude an Exposure from the Large Exposure limits under the parental-guarantee treatment, it may do so only within Rules 4.15.5 to 4.15.7 and only where the Parent either commits (via a legally binding agreement) to increase Tier 1 promptly and on demand to fully reverse loss effects or to ensure compliance with the Capital Requirement, or where the Parent (or regulated Group member) guarantees the Exposure to a Counterparty (or group of Closely Related Counterparties) that are not Connected to the Authorised Person and the specified conditions are met. [#TGT:032faf55-93b1-4f6a-ab8f-56eea4f82cff] Ongoing items include obtaining Home State Regulator confirmation, providing annual confirmation on enforceability, and notifying the Regulator at the 200%, 400% and 600% Tier 1 thresholds, with an overall Large Exposure limit of 800%. [#TGT:032faf55-93b1-4f6a-ab8f-56eea4f82cff]

When considering the treatment of this Rule an Authorised Person may also consider the exemptions permitted under Rule 4.15.18 relating to parental guarantees.

An Authorised Person may exclude an Exposure from the Large Exposure limits set out in Rules 4.15.5 to 4.15.7 if the Authorised Person's Parent; (a) is set to increase, on the basis of a legally binding agreement, the Authorised Person's Tier 1, promptly and on demand, by: (i) an amount that is sufficient to reverse completely the effect of any loss the Authorised Person may sustain in connection with that Exposure; or (ii) the amount required to ensure that the Authorised Person complies with its Capital Requirement set out in Chapter 3; or (b) guarantees the Exposure to a Counterparty or to a group of Closely Related Counterparties which are not Connected to the Authorised Person only if the following conditions are met: (i) the guarantee is to be provided by the Authorised Person's Parent, or regulated member of its Group; (ii) the criteria for guarantees must be in line with the CRM requirements as set out in Section 4.13; (iii) the entity providing the guarantee must be a bank regulated to standards acceptable to the Regulator; (iv) the total amount of guarantees provided to the Authorised Person must be less than 10% of the Tier 1 of the entity providing the guarantee; (v) the Parent must have an external credit assessment from a recognised credit rating agency that corresponds to a Credit Quality Grade 1 or 2; (vi) the Authorised Person must provide confirmation from the Home State Regulator of the entity providing the guarantee that it is satisfied that the entity providing the guarantee has sufficient resources to provide such guarantees and has no objection to the provision of such guarantees; (vii) the Authorised Person should provide an annual confirmation that there are no changes to the enforceability of such guarantees; and (viii) the Authorised Person must notify the Regulator when such guarantees represent 200%, 400% and 600% of Tier 1. The overall Large Exposure limit of 800% will apply.

question: When designing an arrangement to make information public, what specific features must be present to treat the information as “made public” and “machine-readable,” and what operational controls and commercial access conditions must the arrangement also include?
expected_answer: An arrangement should be structured so the information qualifies as “made public” and meets “machine-readable” expectations, while also embedding reliability controls and fair public access terms. To be treated as made public, the information must be accessible through automated electronic means in a machine-readable manner, use technology that supports consolidation and commercially viable use, and be provided with instructions explaining how users can access it. [#SRC:bd13815d-1605-4be7-a0e5-e56cac1c6b24] In addition, where “machine-readable” criteria are relevant, the data should be in a computer-readable physical form and placed on a computer storage device in a location and format that are known in advance to the party seeking access. [#SRC:bd13815d-1605-4be7-a0e5-e56cac1c6b24] Operationally, the arrangement must take all reasonable steps to ensure the published information is reliable, continuously monitored for errors, and corrected promptly when errors are found. [#TGT:2a6804eb-793b-44fd-9895-a7d9d195c64e] It must also facilitate consolidation with similar data from other sources (aligning with the consolidation-focused technology expectation) and make the information available on a non-discriminatory commercial basis at a reasonable cost. [#TGT:2a6804eb-793b-44fd-9895-a7d9d195c64e] Finally, publishing only on a non-machine-readable website would not satisfy the relevant publication requirement. [#SRC:bd13815d-1605-4be7-a0e5-e56cac1c6b24]

debug_context.source_text: In respect of arrangements pertaining to public disclosure in Rule 3.7.1: (a) For the purposes of Rule 3.7.1(b), information is made public, if it: (i) is accessible by automated electronic means in a machine-readable way; (ii) utilises technology that facilitates consolidation of the data and permits commercially viable usage; and (iii) is accompanied by instructions outlining how users can access the information. (b) For the purposes of Rule3.7.3(a)(i), an arrangement fulfils the 'machine-readable' criteria where the data: (i) is in a physical form that is designed to be read by a computer; (ii) is in a location on a computer storage device where that location is known in advance by the party wishing to access the data; and (iii) is in a format that is known in advance by the party wishing to access the data. (c) Publication on a non-machine-readable website would not meet the requirements of Rule 3.7.1(a).

question: For an Authorised Person that is a Payment Account Provider and has a Financial Services Permission to carry on the Regulated Activity of Providing Money Services, how must it determine its Capital Requirement, and how is the Variable Capital Requirement component calculated using monthly payment volume tiers?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person with a Financial Services Permission to carry on the Regulated Activity of Providing Money Services that undertakes the activity of a Payment Account Provider must set its Capital Requirement by taking the highest applicable amount under the capital-calculation hierarchy for its activities, which includes comparing the applicable Base Capital Requirement to the Payment Account Provider’s Variable Capital Requirement. [#SRC:b9a60932-1035-44e7-a556-855195ef9304] For the Payment Account Provider activity specifically, the Variable Capital Requirement is determined by applying a tiered percentage schedule to monthly payment volume and summing the results across tiers. [#TGT:7593338e-8695-47bb-ad6a-b441de562eb4] In practice, this means the Payment Account Provider’s Variable Capital Requirement is the total of: 2.5% applied to the first $10 million of monthly payment volume, plus 1% applied to the next $90 million, plus 0.5% applied to the next $150 million, plus 0.25% applied to any remaining monthly payment volume above those tiers. [#TGT:7593338e-8695-47bb-ad6a-b441de562eb4] The resulting Variable Capital Requirement is then used as the Payment Account Provider component in the overall “highest of” comparison that determines the Capital Requirement for that activity (alongside the applicable Base Capital Requirement). [#SRC:b9a60932-1035-44e7-a556-855195ef9304]

question: When calculating CET1 Capital deductions for holdings of CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities, how should an Authorised Person determine whether the holding is treated as a “significant investment” (thereby falling under the deduction category for significant investments rather than the category for non-significant investments), and what types of deductions are required to be taken from CET1 Capital in that calculation?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must first classify its holdings of CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities by determining whether the holding constitutes a “significant investment,” because the CET1 deduction category differs depending on that classification. [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd] A holding is treated as a significant investment if any of the specified conditions are met: the Authorised Person owns more than 10% of the CET1 Capital instruments issued by the Relevant Entity; or the Authorised Person has Close Links with the entity and owns its CET1 Capital instruments; or the Authorised Person owns the entity’s CET1 Capital instruments and the entity is not included in consolidation under Chapter 8 but is included in the same accounting consolidation as the Authorised Person for IFRS financial reporting. [#SRC:c9f19d0b-d036-4cfe-88ba-7e2528a70c11] Once classified, the Authorised Person must deduct from the calculation of its CET1 Capital the applicable amount of direct and indirect holdings in Relevant Entities where it does not have a significant investment, and separately the applicable amount of direct and indirect holdings in Relevant Entities where it does have a significant investment. [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd] In addition, the CET1 deduction calculation includes other specified items such as current-year losses, IFRS-defined goodwill and other intangible assets, and deferred tax assets that rely on future profitability. [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd]

For the purposes of Rules 3.10.7(g) and (h), an investment by an Authorised Person in a Relevant Entity must be considered as a significant investment if it meets any of the following conditions: (a) the Authorised Person owns more than 10% of the CET1 Capital instruments issued by that entity; (b) the Authorised Person has Close Links with that entity and owns CET1 Capital instruments issued by that entity; or (c) the Authorised Person owns CET1 Capital instruments issued by that entity and the entity is not included in consolidation pursuant to Chapter 8 of these Rules but is included in the same accounting consolidation as the Authorised Person for the purposes of financial reporting under the International Financial Reporting Standards.
debug_context.target_text: CET1 Deductions. Subject to the following Rules in this Section, an Authorised Person must deduct the following from the calculation of its CET1 Capital: (a) losses for the current financial year; (b) goodwill and other intangible assets as defined in the International Financial Reporting Standards; (c) deferred tax assets that rely on future profitability; (d) defined benefit pension fund assets of the Authorised Person; (e) the applicable amount, by reference to Rule 3.10.12, of direct and indirect holdings by an Authorised Person of its own CET1 Capital instruments including instruments under which an Authorised Person is under an actual or contingent obligation to effect a purchase by virtue of an existing contractual obligation; (f) holdings of the CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities where those entities have a reciprocal cross holding with the Authorised Person which have the effect of artificially inflating the Capital Resources of the Authorised Person; (g) the applicable amount, by reference to Rule 3.10.13, of direct and indirect holdings by the Authorised Person of CET1 Capital instruments of Relevant Entities where the Authorised Person does not have a significant investment in those entities; (i) the amount of items required to be deducted from the calculation of AT1 Capital in accordance with the relevant Rules under Section 3.11, that exceeds the AT1 Capital of the Authorised Person; (j) the Exposure amount of the following items which qualify for a risk weight of 1000%, where the Authorised Person deducts that Exposure amount from CET1 Capital as an alternative to applying a risk weight of 1000%: (i) Qualifying Holdings; question: If an Authorised Person owns CET1 Capital instruments issued by a Relevant Entity, what facts make that ownership a “significant investment,” and how does that decision change which CET1 deduction bucket the holding goes into?
expected_answer: To place a holding into the correct CET1 deduction bucket, an Authorised Person must decide whether its holding in a Relevant Entity is a “significant investment,” because the CET1 rules distinguish between deductions for holdings where the Authorised Person has a significant investment and holdings where it does not. [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd] The holding is a significant investment if any one of these conditions applies: the Authorised Person owns more than 10% of the CET1 Capital instruments issued by the Relevant Entity; or the Authorised Person has Close Links with the entity and owns its CET1 Capital instruments; or the Authorised Person owns the entity’s CET1 Capital instruments and, while the entity is not consolidated under Chapter 8, it is included in the same IFRS accounting consolidation as the Authorised Person for financial reporting. [#SRC:c9f19d0b-d036-4cfe-88ba-7e2528a70c11] If the holding meets one of those tests, the Authorised Person must treat it as a holding where it has a significant investment and deduct the applicable amount under the significant-investment category. [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd] If none of the tests are met, the holding falls into the non-significant-investment category and the applicable amount must be deducted under that separate category. question: When the Regulator acts on its own initiative against an Authorised Person with a Financial Services Permission, what specific circumstances can trigger use of the power, and what range of outcomes (including partial changes versus full cancellation) may the Regulator impose on the Financial Services Permission?
expected_answer: The Regulator may act on its own initiative in relation to an Authorised Person with a Financial Services Permission when it appears that one or more specified triggering circumstances apply, and it may respond either by varying the permission (including limited changes to Regulated Activities) or by cancelling it entirely. [#SRC:cd2e3201-9c8d-41db-ae9e-c56f0e181dcb] Triggering circumstances include where the Authorised Person is failing or likely to fail to satisfy the Threshold Condition Rules, has contravened these Regulations or Rules made under them, has not carried on a relevant Regulated Activity for at least 12 months, or where exercising the power is desirable to further one or more of the Regulator’s objectives. [#TGT:702ea9bb-da70-4ea7-91e8-a693eb99447b] If the Regulator proceeds, it may cancel the Financial Services Permission to carry on one or more Regulated Activities, and in that context it may instead (or additionally) vary the Financial Services Permission by adding or removing a Regulated Activity, or by changing the description of a Regulated Activity provided the change does not widen that description. [#SRC:cd2e3201-9c8d-41db-ae9e-c56f0e181dcb] The Regulator may also vary the Financial Services Permission by including, in the permission as varied, any provision that could be included if a new Financial Services Permission were being sought, and it retains the option to cancel the permission entirely. [#SRC:cd2e3201-9c8d-41db-ae9e-c56f0e181dcb]

question: When an Authorised Person (and its participants) selects a delivery and/or storage facility for Accepted Spot Commodities from an appropriate jurisdiction outside the ADGM, what specific facility-level conditions must be satisfied to meet the Rule 22.4.2 standard referenced by the location restriction?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person and its participants may use a delivery and/or storage facility for Accepted Spot Commodities outside the ADGM only if the jurisdiction is “appropriate” because the facility can meet the requirements of Rule 22.4.2, rather than merely being located outside the ADGM. [#TGT:4230a066-37c4-4630-bb93-d9a0ed5bc81b] For a facility operating from outside ADGM, Rule 22.4.2 requires that it operate under rules and regulations equivalent to those applying in the Abu Dhabi Global Market. [#SRC:dda13926-2cce-4e09-a50f-508bd4257bd5] In addition, the facility must continuously comply with all applicable laws in the relevant jurisdiction or elsewhere, including port conditions, customs requirements, anticorruption laws, and taxation requirements. [#SRC:dda13926-2cce-4e09-a50f-508bd4257bd5] The facility must also adhere to appropriate international standards for storage and delivery mechanisms (including IOSCO Good and Sound Practices) and maintain OHSAS 18001 Health & Safety Management (or equivalent) certification standards. [#SRC:dda13926-2cce-4e09-a50f-508bd4257bd5] Finally, it must have appropriate audit and control arrangements for inventories, deliveries, and physical infrastructure, and appropriate insurance covering operational, security, fraud, natural disasters, and other applicable risks. [#SRC:dda13926-2cce-4e09-a50f-508bd4257bd5]

debug_context.source_text: For the purposes of Rule 22.4.1, any delivery and/or storage facility used by an Authorised Person must be a facility in relation to which – (a) where the delivery and/or storage facility operates from outside ADGM, it operates under rules and regulations equivalent to those applying in the Abu Dhabi Global Market; (b) the delivery and/or storage facility will, at all times, comply with all applicable laws in the relevant jurisdiction or elsewhere, including in particular and without limitation: (i) local port conditions; (ii) local, national and global customs requirements; (iii) local, national and global anticorruption laws; (iv) local, national and global taxation requirements; and (v) any other applicable rules and regulations; (c) the delivery and/or storage facility adheres to: (i) appropriate international standards for storage and delivery mechanisms, including with regard to IOSCO’s Good and Sound Practices; and (ii) OHSAS 18001 Health & Safety Management or equivalent certification standards; (d) it has appropriate audit and control arrangements in place, in relation to inventories, deliveries and physical infrastructure; and (e) it has appropriate insurance arrangements in place to cover operational, security, fraud, natural disasters and other applicable risks.
debug_context.target_text: An Authorised Person, and its participants, must only use delivery and/or storage facilities for Accepted Spot Commodities from: (a) within the ADGM, or (b) other appropriate jurisdictions that can meet the requirements of Rule 22.4.2.

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity makes a disclosure that includes a statement about Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources, Ore Reserves or Production Targets, how do the preparation requirements interact with the scope of materials covered and the expectation to use a specific table format for consistency?
expected_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure that contains statements about Exploration Targets, Exploration Results, Mineral Resources, Ore Reserves or Production Targets must be prepared in accordance with both a Mining Reporting Standard and the chapter setting the disclosure requirements. [#TGT:5d4c0697-2ff8-49a4-9682-8e63acb63b9d] In applying that preparation obligation, the scope of covered disclosures is broad: the relevant rule applies to all disclosures made or required under the Rules that include such statements, including (among other examples) a Prospectus, Exempt Offer document, bidder’s and target’s statements, annual reports, financial statements, technical papers, presentations, and website content and disclosures. [#SRC:96612327-1f00-4faf-abc6-2c914cc73738] To support consistency across those various disclosure channels, Issuers and Mining Reporting Entities are expected to be mindful of the table format for disclosing Ore Reserves and Mineral Resources set out in MKT Form-11-1. [#SRC:96612327-1f00-4faf-abc6-2c914cc73738] Practically, this means the entity should (i) ensure the disclosure is prepared under the specified standard and chapter framework, and (ii) align the presentation of Ore Reserves and Mineral Resources with the referenced table format when those topics are included, so that disclosures remain consistent across documents and media. [#TGT:5d4c0697-2ff8-49a4-9682-8e63acb63b9d] [#SRC:96612327-1f00-4faf-abc6-2c914cc73738]

question: For an Issuer making an Exempt Offer of a Digital Security, how do the requirements that the Digital Security be deemed a Security under Section 58(2)(b) of FSMR and the Regulator’s power to deem an investment to be a Security interact, and does the Issuer need FSRA approval for the Exempt Offer document itself?

[#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c] Read together, this means the “deemed Security” status relevant to an Exempt Offer can be achieved through the deeming mechanism contemplated in the framework, while still operating within the Exempt Offer context described for Digital Securities. [#SRC:6a0e8ba4-de85-4c15-9077-73f73de9d727] [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c] Separately, the Issuer of the Exempt Offer document is not required to obtain FSRA approval for the Exempt Offer document itself. [#SRC:6a0e8ba4-de85-4c15-9077-73f73de9d727] Nothing in the deeming power text states that such a deeming decision requires FSRA approval of the Exempt Offer document; instead, it focuses on the Regulator’s ability to deem and to set any associated terms and conditions by written notice. [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c]

question: Where a Payment Service Provider proposes to change the exchange rate used in Payment Transactions under a Framework Contract, what implementation standard applies to that exchange-rate change and what is the minimum advance notice period for providing the change to the Payment Service User before it takes effect?
expected_answer: A proposed change to the exchange rate used in Payment Transactions must be applied in a way that is neutral and does not collectively disadvantage Payment Service Users, and it must also be communicated to the Payment Service User at least two months before the change takes effect. [#TGT:e696d18d-c269-44cd-907e-9701efbb42dc] [#SRC:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5] This conclusion applies when the Payment Service Provider is making a change that falls within proposed changes to the existing terms of the Framework Contract or to the information that must be provided under Rule 19.2.1, because those categories trigger the advance-provision requirement. [#SRC:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5] In practice, the Payment Service Provider should (i) ensure the method for implementing and calculating the revised exchange rate is neutral and non-discriminatory in its collective effect on Payment Service Users, and (ii) provide the proposed change to the Payment Service User no later than two months before the effective date stated for the change. [#TGT:e696d18d-c269-44cd-907e-9701efbb42dc] [#SRC:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5] The notice obligation is expressly stated as being subject to Rule 19.2.7, so the Payment Service Provider must apply that stated qualification when determining whether and how the two-month timing applies in the specific case. [#SRC:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5]

question: Where a contravention is committed by one person, how does liability attach to another person who is Knowingly Concerned, and how do the consequences differ when the contravention is of FSMR or Rules versus a contravention of these Regulations?
expected_answer: If a contravention is committed by one person and another person is Knowingly Concerned in that contravention, both texts treat the involvement as a basis for liability for both individuals, but they describe the legal framing slightly differently depending on the instrument. [#SRC:a2dd84dd-1b01-465d-808a-b2f653dd4e93] [#TGT:5e4bc632-0693-4b1c-a3b9-ef28fb2a8441] For contraventions of FSMR or Rules, the SOURCE explains that when one person is Knowingly Concerned in another person’s contravention, section 220 of FSMR provides that both persons may be held liable for committing a contravention. [#SRC:a2dd84dd-1b01-465d-808a-b2f653dd4e93] For contraventions of these Regulations, the TARGET states that the person who is Knowingly Concerned, as well as the person who committed the underlying contravention, commits the contravention and is liable to be proceeded against and dealt with accordingly. [#TGT:5e4bc632-0693-4b1c-a3b9-ef28fb2a8441] In practical compliance terms, the shared trigger is the “Knowingly Concerned” involvement in another’s contravention, while the linkage across the two passages is that the SOURCE ties liability to section 220 of FSMR for FSMR/Rules contraventions, whereas the TARGET expressly describes exposure to being proceeded against for contraventions of these Regulations. [#SRC:a2dd84dd-1b01-465d-808a-b2f653dd4e93] [#TGT:5e4bc632-0693-4b1c-a3b9-ef28fb2a8441]

question: When applying the formula-based restriction on new Issues of Equity Securities, how must a Listed Entity treat Securities whose approval under Rule 9.7.5 has lapsed when determining whether the issue would exceed the “Maximum number of Equity Securities” without holder approval, and which component(s) of the calculation are affected?
expected_answer: A Listed Entity must treat Securities whose approval under Rule 9.7.5 has lapsed as no longer qualifying as issued “with approval under Rule 9.7.5” for the purposes of the Rule 9.7.1 calculation, and instead count them within “Relevant Issues” under Rule 9.7.1. [#SRC:76970fb8-577b-4a21-8996-4c8bde4ef2d2] This matters because the restriction on new Issues of Equity Securities limits issuance (absent approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities) to a “Maximum number of Equity Securities” computed as (20% * Base Amount) – Relevant Issues. [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] Under the definition of Relevant Issues, Equity Securities issued or agreed to be issued in the prior 12 months are excluded only if they were issued with holder approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5, or under an exception in Rule 9.7.4. [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] Because a lapsed Rule 9.7.5 approval removes the ability to treat those Securities as approved under Rule 9.7.5 for Rule 9.7.1 purposes, they cannot be excluded on that basis and must be included in Relevant Issues. [#SRC:76970fb8-577b-4a21-8996-4c8bde4ef2d2] Including them increases Relevant Issues and therefore reduces the Maximum number available without holder approval under the formula. [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]

debug_context.target_text: Restrictions on new Issues of Equity Securities . A Listed Entity must not issue, or agree to issue, more Equity Securities than the number calculated according to the following formula, without the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities: Maximum number of Equity Securities = (20% * Base Amount) – Relevant Issues), where: Base Amount = the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities on issue as of the date 12 months before the date of issue or agreement (the “12 months Base Amount”), plus the number of: (1) fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exceptions (8), (15) or (16); (2) fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exception (15), where the agreement was: (i) entered into before the commencement of the 12 month period; or (ii) approved, or taken under the Rules to have been approved, under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; and (3) any other fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement with approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; Guidance The Base Amount may include fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an agreement to issue Securities within Rule 9.7.4 exception (14) where the issue is subsequently approved under Rule 9.7.1. (4) partly paid Ordinary Securities that became fully paid in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement, but subtracting the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities cancelled in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement. Relevant Issues = the number of Equity Securities issued, or agreed to be issued, in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement to issue other than: (a) with the approval of the holders of its Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; or (b) under an exception in Rule 9.7.4.

expected_answer: If an approval under Rule 9.7.5 has lapsed, the Securities covered by that lapsed approval must no longer be treated as Securities issued with approval under Rule 9.7.5 for the Rule 9.7.1 counting exercise. [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] Because the lapsed approval means the Securities cannot be treated as approved under Rule 9.7.5 for this purpose, they are not excluded on that basis and therefore increase Relevant Issues, reducing the maximum headroom under the formula. [#SRC:76970fb8-577b-4a21-8996-4c8bde4ef2d2] [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]

question: When calculating CET1 Capital, how must an Authorised Person treat (i) Credit Enhancing Interest Only Strips (net of the deductions from CET1 Capital required at Rule 4.14.13) and (ii) any increase in issued capital or reserves resulting from a securitisation (including gain-on-sale amounts tied to expected future margin income), and how do these treatments interact in the CET1 deduction calculation?
expected_answer: In calculating CET1 Capital, an Authorised Person must apply two distinct deduction treatments that can both affect the same overall CET1 computation: (1) a mandatory full deduction for Credit Enhancing Interest Only Strips (after netting for specified prior deductions), and (2) a requirement to deduct securitisation-driven increases in issued capital or reserves (including certain gain-on-sale components). Specifically, Credit Enhancing Interest Only Strips—measured net of the deductions from CET1 Capital required at Rule 4.14.13—must be deducted at a 100% rate from CET1 Capital. [#SRC:c0b36aad-933a-4667-a073-ebb69b3f1aab] Separately, the Authorised Person must include as deductions from CET1 Capital any increase in issued capital or reserves that arises from a securitisation, with an explicit example being expected future margin income that creates a gain on sale and is recognised as issued capital or reserves. [#TGT:6300f7af-226b-41ca-ac50-e4802726964c] Practically, this means the firm should (a) identify any securitisation-related uplift recorded in issued capital or reserves and deduct it from CET1, and (b) identify any Credit Enhancing Interest Only Strips and deduct them fully, using the net-of-Rule-4.14.13 amount as the base for the 100% deduction. [#SRC:c0b36aad-933a-4667-a073-ebb69b3f1aab] [#TGT:6300f7af-226b-41ca-ac50-e4802726964c]

An Authorised Person must include as deductions from CET1 Capital any increase in issued capital or reserves resulting from a securitisation, such as that associated with expected future margin income resulting in a gain on sale that is recognised as issued capital or reserves.

[#TGT:6300f7af-226b-41ca-ac50-e4802726964c] Second, Credit Enhancing Interest Only Strips are deducted from CET1 Capital at 100%, but the amount to which the 100% rate applies is the strips “net of the deductions from CET1 Capital required at Rule 4.14.13.” [#SRC:c0b36aad-933a-4667-a073-ebb69b3f1aab] Put together, the firm should (a) identify and deduct the securitisation-driven increase in issued capital or reserves (including the gain-on-sale amount tied to expected future margin income), and (b) separately compute the net amount of Credit Enhancing Interest Only Strips after applying the referenced Rule 4.14.13 deductions, then deduct that net strip amount in full from CET1 Capital. question: If an Authorised Person has a CR Exposure to a central government or central bank of a GCC member country (including an individual Emirate of the UAE treated as a GCC member country), and the exposure is not denominated and funded in that domestic currency, how must the exposure be treated and can a 0% risk weight still be applied?
expected_answer: A CR Exposure to a central government or central bank of a GCC member country may receive a 0% risk weight only when it is both denominated and funded in that GCC member country’s domestic currency (and, for this purpose, each individual Emirate of the UAE is treated as though it were a GCC member country). [#TGT:0b38a29a-6f32-46d4-b772-9682878dc7c1] If those conditions are not satisfied, the exposure does not meet the stated requirements for that treatment and must instead be handled under the alternative treatment specified for cases where the requirements of Rule 4.12.5 are not met. [#SRC:d005dde9-921a-4f5c-ac96-c708712bf938] In practical terms, the Authorised Person should first determine whether the counterparty is a central government or central bank of a GCC member country (including an individual Emirate of the UAE as treated for this purpose) and then verify that the exposure is denominated and funded in the relevant domestic currency. [#TGT:0b38a29a-6f32-46d4-b772-9682878dc7c1] Where either the denomination or funding condition is missing, the exposure must be treated in accordance with Rule 4.12.4 rather than receiving the 0% risk weight described for qualifying exposures. [#SRC:d005dde9-921a-4f5c-ac96-c708712bf938]

debug_context.source_text: Where the requirements of Rule 4.12.5 are not met the CR Exposure should be treated in accordance with Rule 4.12.4.
debug_context.target_text: Central government and central bank asset class. An Authorised Person may apply a 0% risk weight to any CR Exposure to central governments or central banks of a GCC member country which are denominated and funded in the domestic currency of the GCC member country. For the purposes of this Rule, individual Emirates of the UAE will be considered as though they were GCC member countries.

question: When can an Authorised Person use a 0% risk weight for a CR Exposure to a GCC central government/central bank, and what happens if the Rule 4.12.5 requirements for that treatment are not met (including for an individual Emirate of the UAE)?

[#TGT:0b38a29a-6f32-46d4-b772-9682878dc7c1] If the requirements of Rule 4.12.5 are not met, the CR Exposure must be treated under Rule 4.12.4 instead of using the treatment tied to meeting Rule 4.12.5. [#SRC:d005dde9-921a-4f5c-ac96-c708712bf938] To apply this correctly, the Authorised Person should (i) confirm the counterparty falls within the central government/central bank category and the relevant GCC member country (including an individual Emirate of the UAE as treated for this purpose), and (ii) check that both the denomination and funding are in that domestic currency. [#TGT:0b38a29a-6f32-46d4-b772-9682878dc7c1] If either of those currency conditions is not satisfied, the exposure is handled using the Rule 4.12.4 approach because the Rule 4.12.5 requirements have not been met. question: For an Authorised Person that is a Virtual Asset Custodian, how does the requirement to treat “Client Assets” and “Client Investments” as including “Virtual Assets” affect the minimum technology governance systems and controls that must be implemented for Virtual Asset Wallets, keys, transaction origin/destination, security, and risk management?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person that is a Virtual Asset Custodian must treat “Virtual Assets” as falling within the scope of “Client Assets” and “Client Investments,” so the custody protections applied to those categories extend to Accepted Virtual Assets, and the firm must operationalise that treatment through the minimum technology governance and control framework required for Virtual Asset activities. [#SRC:15ac7d0d-8853-444c-8a24-8678075fa3c7] In practice, this means the firm’s custody arrangements for Virtual Assets should be supported by documented procedures and controls that cover the full lifecycle and oversight of Virtual Asset Wallets (including setup, access privileges, user management, limits, and audit/oversight). [#TGT:106f67c2-a790-4552-b747-f71402211db6] It also requires procedures for private and public keys (generation, exchange, storage, backup, destruction, access management, sharing, and re-use as applicable), because those mechanisms are integral to controlling and safeguarding Virtual Assets held in custody. [#TGT:106f67c2-a790-4552-b747-f71402211db6] Additionally, the firm must have systems and controls to determine the origin of incoming Virtual Assets and the destination of outgoing Virtual Assets to mitigate misuse risk, aligning with the objective of affording Accepted Virtual Assets protections comparable to other products and activities under the FSMR and the FSRA Rulebook. [#TGT:106f67c2-a790-4552-b747-f71402211db6] [#SRC:15ac7d0d-8853-444c-8a24-8678075fa3c7] Finally, the firm must maintain a security plan (covering sensitive data, networks/systems, cloud services, physical facilities, and documents) and a risk management plan addressing operational, technology (including hacking), market risk for each Accepted Virtual Asset, and Financial Crime risk. [#TGT:106f67c2-a790-4552-b747-f71402211db6]

debug_context.source_text: AUTHORISED PERSONS PROVIDING CUSTODY OF VIRTUAL ASSETS In addition to having to meet the requirements set out in COBS Rules 17.1 to 17.6, Virtual Asset Custodians are required to meet the additional Rules set out in COBS Rule 17.8. COBS Rule 17.8.2 requires that the existing definitions of “Client Assets” and “Client Investments” be read to include “Virtual Assets”. This approach has been taken by the FSRA to ensure that Accepted Virtual Assets are afforded the same protections as other similar products and activities under FSMR and the FSRA Rulebook.
debug_context.target_text: Technology Governance and Controls An Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets must, as a minimum, have in place systems and controls with respect to the following: (a) Virtual Asset Wallets. Procedures describing the creation, management and controls of Virtual Asset wallets, including: (i) wallet setup/configuration/deployment/deletion/backup and recovery; (ii) wallet access privilege management; (iii) wallet user management; (iv) wallet rules and limit determination, review and update; and (v) wallet audit and oversight. (b) Private and public keys. Procedures describing the creation, management and controls of private and public keys, including, as applicable: (i) private key generation; (ii) private key exchange; (iii) private key storage; (iv) private key backup; (v) private key destruction; (vi) private key access management; (vii) public key sharing; and (viii) public key re-use. (c) Origin and destination of Virtual Asset funds. Systems and controls to mitigate the risk of misuse of Virtual Assets, setting out how – (i) the origin of Virtual Assets is determined, in case of an incoming transaction; and (ii) the destination of Virtual Assets is determined, in case of an outgoing transaction. (d) Security. question: If an Authorised Person is holding Virtual Assets for clients, what does it mean that “Client Assets” and “Client Investments” must be read to include “Virtual Assets,” and what minimum systems and controls must the firm have for wallets, keys, tracking where funds come from/go to, security, and risk management?
expected_answer: Reading “Client Assets” and “Client Investments” to include “Virtual Assets” means Virtual Assets (including Accepted Virtual Assets) are intended to receive the same type of protections as other similar products and activities under the FSMR and the FSRA Rulebook, rather than being treated as outside the client-asset/client-investment framework. [#SRC:15ac7d0d-8853-444c-8a24-8678075fa3c7] For an Authorised Person conducting a Regulated Activity in relation to Virtual Assets, the minimum way to implement that protective approach is to have systems and controls that specifically govern how Virtual Assets are created, accessed, safeguarded, and monitored in the firm’s technology environment. [#TGT:106f67c2-a790-4552-b747-f71402211db6] Concretely, the firm must maintain procedures for Virtual Asset Wallets that cover wallet creation and lifecycle actions (such as configuration, deployment, deletion, backup and recovery), access privilege management, user management, wallet rules/limits and their review, and audit/oversight. [#TGT:106f67c2-a790-4552-b747-f71402211db6] It must also maintain procedures for private and public keys (including generation, storage, backup, destruction, access management, and sharing/re-use as applicable). [#TGT:106f67c2-a790-4552-b747-f71402211db6] To reduce misuse risk, it must have controls to determine the origin of Virtual Assets for incoming transactions and the destination for outgoing transactions, which supports the goal of applying comparable protections to Accepted Virtual Assets. [#TGT:106f67c2-a790-4552-b747-f71402211db6] [#SRC:15ac7d0d-8853-444c-8a24-8678075fa3c7] Finally, it must have a security plan (covering data privacy, networks/systems, cloud services, physical facilities, and documents) and a risk management plan addressing operational, technology/hacking, market risk for each Accepted Virtual Asset, and Financial Crime risk. [#TGT:106f67c2-a790-4552-b747-f71402211db6]

question: When an Authorised Person uses the FCSA to recognise eligible financial Collateral for a CR Exposure, how must it split the Exposure into collateralised and uncollateralised portions, and what CRW must it apply to the collateralised portion when the CRW applicable to the Collateral would otherwise be below 20%, including the specific exceptions that permit 0% or 10%?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person using the FCSA must treat eligible financial Collateral by separating the CR Exposure into two parts and then applying the appropriate CRW to each part, with a floor on the collateralised portion unless an exception applies. [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb] The collateralised portion must be set equal to the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral, and the uncollateralised portion must be the CR Exposure amount reduced by that latest fair value. [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb] For Credit RWA calculation purposes, the collateralised portion generally takes the CRW applicable to the Collateral as if the Authorised Person had a direct Exposure to it, while the uncollateralised portion takes the CRW applicable to the obligor. [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb] However, if the CRW that would be used for the collateralised portion (i.e., the CRW applicable to the Collateral) is below 20%, the Authorised Person must apply 20% to the collateralised portion unless one of the specified cases applies. [#TGT:2d046015-ac18-47c6-9602-153602c0f438] The exceptions include qualifying SFTs (0% if the Counterparty is a core market participant; 10% if not), certain daily-marked OTC Derivatives with no currency mismatch (0% if collateralised by cash; 10% if collateralised by specified 0%-risk-weight government/central bank/PSE exposures), and certain no-currency-mismatch transactions where the Collateral is specified cash on Deposit or specified 0%-risk-weight government/central bank/PSE exposures and the latest fair value used for the collateralised portion has been discounted by 20%. [#TGT:2d046015-ac18-47c6-9602-153602c0f438]

debug_context.source_text: Recognition of eligible financial Collateral under FCSA. Subject to A4.3.28, an Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for a CR Exposure and is using the FCSA may recognise the effects of CRM of the eligible financial Collateral as follows: (a) break down the Exposure into - (i) a collateralised portion with E equal to the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral; and (ii) an uncollateralised portion with E equal to the E of the CR Exposure less the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral; and (b) for the purposes of calculating the Credit RWA amount pursuant to Rule 4.8.3, use: (i) for the collateralised portion, the CRW that is applicable to the eligible financial Collateral as though the Authorised Person had a direct Exposure to that Collateral; and (ii) for the uncollateralised portion, the CRW that is applicable to the obligor.

If the CRW determined in accordance with A4.3.27(b)(i) is less than 20%, an Authorised Person must apply a CRW of 20% to the collateralised portion of the CR Exposure, except in the following cases: (a) a qualifying SFT where the Counterparty in the transaction is a core market participant, in which case the Authorised Person may apply a risk weight of 0%; (b) a qualifying SFT where the Counterparty in the transaction is not a core market participant, in which case the Authorised Person may apply a risk weight of 10%; (c) an OTC Derivative transaction subject to daily mark to market that is collateralised by cash, and where there is no currency mismatch, in which case the Authorised Person may apply a risk weight of 0%; (d) an OTC Derivative transaction subject to daily mark to market that is collateralised by Exposures to central governments, central banks or PSE or a combination thereof qualifying for a 0% risk weight in accordance with the Rules in Chapter 4, and where there is no currency mismatch, in which case the Authorised Person may apply a risk weight of 10%; and (e) a transaction where there is no currency mismatch and the Collateral comprises - (i) cash on Deposit as set out in Rule 4.13.5(a); or (ii) Exposures in the central government and central bank asset class or in the PSE asset class or a combination thereof qualifying for a 0% risk weight under the Rules in Section 4.12, and the latest fair value of such Collateral has been discounted by 20% for the purposes of determining the value of the collateralised portion of the CR Exposure in accordance with Rule A4.3.27(a)(i), in which case the Authorised Person may apply a CRW of 0%.

question: If an Authorised Person is using the FCSA and the Collateral’s risk weight would come out below 20%, what do they do with the Exposure split (collateralised vs uncollateralised) and when can they use 0% or 10% instead of 20% for the collateralised part?
expected_answer: Under the FCSA approach, the Authorised Person must first split the CR Exposure into a collateralised portion and an uncollateralised portion, and then apply risk weights to each portion based on what each portion represents. [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb] The collateralised portion is measured as the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral, and the uncollateralised portion is the CR Exposure amount minus that latest fair value. [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb] For Credit RWA purposes, the collateralised portion uses the CRW that applies to the Collateral as if it were a direct Exposure to that Collateral, while the uncollateralised portion uses the CRW that applies to the obligor. [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb] If the CRW for the collateralised portion (based on the Collateral) would be less than 20%, the default outcome is that the Authorised Person must apply a 20% CRW to the collateralised portion. [#TGT:2d046015-ac18-47c6-9602-153602c0f438] The Authorised Person may instead apply 0% or 10% only in the listed cases, including qualifying SFTs depending on whether the Counterparty is a core market participant, and certain daily mark-to-market OTC Derivative transactions with no currency mismatch depending on whether the Collateral is cash or specified 0%-risk-weight government/central bank/PSE exposures. [#TGT:2d046015-ac18-47c6-9602-153602c0f438] A further 0% option exists for certain no-currency-mismatch transactions where the Collateral is specified cash on Deposit or specified 0%-risk-weight government/central bank/PSE exposures and the latest fair value used in the collateralised portion has been discounted by 20%. [#TGT:2d046015-ac18-47c6-9602-153602c0f438]

question: When preparing the quarterly report disclosure that must include (at least once every 12 months) the Summary of Reserves and Resources, what specific table format and “as of” date constraint must the Mining Reporting Entity apply to that Summary, and how does that constraint relate to the timing of the quarterly report’s disclosure of when the previous and upcoming Summary will be made?
expected_answer: A Mining Exploration Reporting Entity’s quarterly report must, at least once every 12 months, include the Summary of Reserves and Resources required by Rule 11.11.1 unless that Summary is instead included in the entity’s annual report, and the quarterly report must also state when the prior and the next such Summary was and will be disclosed. [#SRC:737c3487-346b-4104-8b50-78dd337bed22] When that Summary of Reserves and Resources is prepared for disclosure (including when it is the item being tracked as “previous” and “upcoming” in the quarterly report), a Mining Reporting Entity must include a table in the form of MKT Form 11-1. [#TGT:dca099e1-1fc2-460e-8853-332c309ad9bd] In addition, the table must be presented “as of” a date that is no earlier than one month before the Summary of Reserves and Resources is disclosed. [#TGT:dca099e1-1fc2-460e-8853-332c309ad9bd] Practically, this means the entity should align the quarterly report’s disclosure of the timing of the previous and upcoming Summary with a Summary that contains the required MKT Form 11-1 table and uses an “as of” date that falls within the permitted one-month lookback from the actual disclosure date. [#SRC:737c3487-346b-4104-8b50-78dd337bed22] [#TGT:dca099e1-1fc2-460e-8853-332c309ad9bd]

A Mining Exploration Reporting Entity must disclose a report for each quarter of its financial year containing the following information in respect of the Mining Exploration Reporting Entity and all controlled entities, on a consolidated basis, if applicable: (1) details of the activities relating to mining: (a) Exploration, or a statement that there have been no activities relating to Exploration; and (b) production and development, or a statement that there have been no activities relating to mining production and development; (2) a summary of any expenditure incurred relating to mining: (a) Exploration activities; and (b) production and development; (3) the Mining Tenements held at the end of the quarter, their location and the percentage interest held, including the beneficial interests in farm-in or farm-out agreements; (4) the Mining Tenements, including beneficial interests in farm-in or farm-out agreements acquired or disposed of during the quarter, and their location; (5) at least once every 12 months, the Summary of Reserves and Resources required by Rule 11.11.1 unless it is included in the Mining Exploration Reporting Entity’s annual report; and (6) when the previous, and upcoming, disclosure required by (5) was, and will be, disclosed.

What table has to be inside that Summary, and how recent does the table’s “as of” date have to be compared with the Summary’s disclosure date?

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity publishes forecast financial information derived from a Production Target and, in the same disclosure package, also discloses an estimate of Ore Reserves, what specific categories of assumptions and supporting information must be included for (i) the forecast financial information and (ii) the Ore Reserves estimate, including how commercially sensitive material economic assumptions are to be handled?
expected_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity must ensure the disclosure covers two distinct but complementary information sets: the assumption framework supporting the forecast financial information derived from a Production Target, and the key technical context required when an Ore Reserves estimate is disclosed. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] [#TGT:cb1ec09f-a7d3-4c38-ba2e-4e72ed8c3129] For the forecast financial information, the disclosure must include all material economic assumptions used, plus all other material assumptions applied. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] If the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions commercially sensitive, it must state that they are commercially sensitive and explain the methodology used to determine those material economic assumptions (rather than omitting the topic entirely). [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] The disclosure must also identify the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived, and include the information required to be contained in that Production Target disclosure. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] Separately, when disclosing an estimate of Ore Reserves, the disclosure must also include key information on mining (recovery/dilution) factors or assumptions, metallurgical factors or assumptions, cut-off parameters, study status, and the relative accuracy/confidence. [#TGT:cb1ec09f-a7d3-4c38-ba2e-4e72ed8c3129]

debug_context.source_text: A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include: (1) in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information: (a) all material economic assumptions employed; (b) if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and Guidance A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure. (c) all other material assumptions utilised. (2) the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity shares forecast financial information based on a Production Target and also includes an Ore Reserves estimate, what details do they need to add about assumptions for the forecast and what extra technical details must be included for the Ore Reserves part (including what to do if the economic assumptions are commercially sensitive)?
