question: Where a Prospectus includes a statement made by a public official or contained in an official public document, how does accurate and fair reproduction of that statement affect the compensation exposure of a person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus, if an investor alleges loss from an untrue or misleading statement or a material omission?
expected_answer: A person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus can face compensation exposure to an acquirer of the relevant Securities if that acquirer suffered loss or damage because the Prospectus contained an untrue or misleading statement or omitted a material matter that was required to be included. [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac] However, when the challenged content is a statement made by a public official or contained in an official public document and the Prospectus includes it by reproducing it accurately and fairly, the reproducing person does not incur liability under section 70(1) of the FSMR for loss resulting from that statement. [#SRC:4c5cd124-5d5b-497d-821c-877b1c83741f] In practice, this means you must first identify whether the alleged loss is said to arise from (i) an untrue or misleading statement in the Prospectus or (ii) an omission of a required material matter, and whether the claimant is a person who acquired Securities to which the Prospectus relates. [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac] If the allegation instead targets a public-official/official-document statement that was carried into the Prospectus, the key condition for avoiding section 70(1) liability for resulting loss is that the Prospectus reproduces that statement accurately and fairly. [#SRC:4c5cd124-5d5b-497d-821c-877b1c83741f]

debug_context.source_text: A Person does not incur any liability under section 70(1) of the FSMR for any loss resulting from a statement made by a public official or contained in an official public document which is included in the Prospectus if the statement is accurately and fairly reproduced.
debug_context.target_text: Any person prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus is liable to pay compensation to another person who has acquired Securities to which the Prospectus relates and who has suffered loss or damage arising from any untrue or misleading statement in the Prospectus or the omission from it of any material matter required to have been included in the Prospectus by or under these Regulations.

question: If someone buys Securities covered by a Prospectus and then says they lost money because the Prospectus had a wrong statement or left out something important, when can a person who is listed in the Regulator’s Rules as liable for the Prospectus avoid liability if the disputed text came from a public official or an official public document?
expected_answer: A person who is prescribed in the Rules made by the Regulator as being liable for a Prospectus is generally exposed to paying compensation to someone who acquired the Securities covered by that Prospectus and suffered loss or damage because the Prospectus included an untrue or misleading statement or because it omitted a material matter that was required to be included. [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac] If the disputed content is specifically a statement made by a public official or contained in an official public document, there is a distinct protection: the person does not incur liability under section 70(1) of the FSMR for loss resulting from that statement, provided the Prospectus reproduces the statement accurately and fairly. [#SRC:4c5cd124-5d5b-497d-821c-877b1c83741f] To apply this, confirm (1) the claimant is an acquirer of the relevant Securities and claims loss tied to the Prospectus, and (2) the alleged problem is tied to a public-official/official-document statement that appears in the Prospectus. [#TGT:06cd3b51-1068-4851-9420-1345002addac] If those conditions are met, the decisive compliance step for the protection is ensuring the statement was carried over into the Prospectus in an accurate and fair way. [#SRC:4c5cd124-5d5b-497d-821c-877b1c83741f]

question: For an Authorised Person evaluating Exposure to interest rate risk from Non Trading Book activities, how should the firm determine the minimum frequency of those evaluations, and what additional measurement step applies where it has balance sheet positions in different currencies?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must perform evaluations of its Exposure to the interest rate risk arising from its Non Trading Book activities, and it must do so often enough to remain reasonably satisfied that it continuously understands both how much it is exposed to the relevant risks and the nature of that Exposure. [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3] [#SRC:79d37689-e1b6-4801-8b67-ba7d7bafd0ae] In setting the minimum frequency, the firm cannot rely solely on its own judgment of what is “necessary”; it must also ensure that the evaluations are conducted at least as often as the floor specified by Rule 7.2.6 (i.e., no less frequently than that Rule requires). [#SRC:79d37689-e1b6-4801-8b67-ba7d7bafd0ae] Where the Authorised Person has balance sheet positions in different currencies, the evaluation must include measuring its risk Exposures separately in each material currency, rather than only on an aggregated basis. [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3] Taken together, this means the firm should (i) scope the evaluation to interest rate risk from Non Trading Book activities, (ii) set a frequency that is both sufficient for continuous understanding and not below the Rule 7.2.6 minimum, and (iii) apply currency-by-currency measurement for all material currencies when multi-currency balance sheet positions exist. [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3] [#SRC:79d37689-e1b6-4801-8b67-ba7d7bafd0ae]

An Authorised Person must carry out the evaluations required by Rule 7.2.1 as frequently as necessary for it to be reasonably satisfied that it has at all times a sufficient understanding of the degree to which it is exposed to the risks referred to in that Rule and the nature of that Exposure. In any case it must carry out those evaluations no less frequently than required by Rule 7.2.6.

An Authorised Person with balance sheet positions in different currencies must measure its risk Exposures in each of the material currencies.

question: For an Insurer preparing its balance sheet as at the Solvency Reference Date, how should it classify (i) the premium liability for policies in force and (ii) the value of reinsurance and other recoveries expected to be received for claims referred to in Rules 5.4.7 and 5.4.8, and what measurement basis applies to the recoveries?
expected_answer: As at the Solvency Reference Date, an Insurer must recognize two different items with opposite balance-sheet classifications: the premium liability must be treated as a liability, while expected reinsurance and other recoveries for certain claims must be treated as an asset. [#TGT:3c34e221-794b-4399-b4bd-b38a5f2a10c6] The premium liability is defined as the value of future claim payments and the related direct and indirect settlement costs that arise from future events insured under policies that are in force at that Solvency Reference Date, so it is recorded on the liability side when those policies remain in force at that date. [#TGT:3c34e221-794b-4399-b4bd-b38a5f2a10c6] Separately, for claims referred to in Rules 5.4.7 and 5.4.8, the Insurer must treat as an asset the value of reinsurance and other recoveries it expects to receive in respect of those claims. question: When a Person referred to in Rule 3.7.2 is a member of the Governing Body of a Listed Fund and acquires (or changes) an interest that qualifies as a “notifiable interest” because it arises through direct or indirect ownership (including beneficial ownership) of Units or through involvement in a financial or commercial arrangement relating to the Listed Fund, what notice must be given, to whom, and within what timeframe?
expected_answer: A Person referred to in Rule 3.7.2 must notify the other members of the Governing Body when a notifiable interest arises or changes, and the notice must be provided within five Business Days of that event. [#SRC:6786cba0-c996-4e15-b9a7-84ae5417cab9] For this purpose, a “notifiable interest” exists for a member of the Governing Body of a Listed Fund where the Person’s interest arises through either (i) direct or indirect ownership of Units, including beneficial ownership, or (ii) involvement in any financial or commercial arrangement with or relating to the Listed Fund. [#TGT:f46130c3-20bf-4c61-b32d-f638950b9c65] Accordingly, once the Person’s interest fits within either of those categories and it comes into existence or is modified, the compliance action is to deliver a notice to the other Governing Body members, and to do so within the five Business Day window measured from when the interest arose or changed. [#SRC:6786cba0-c996-4e15-b9a7-84ae5417cab9] The trigger for the timing is the arising or changing of the interest, while the scope of what counts as notifiable is determined by the ownership/beneficial ownership of Units or the relevant financial or commercial involvement with the Listed Fund. question: When an RIE operates an MTF or OTF using Accepted Spot Commodities, what conditions must be satisfied regarding (i) the Recognition Order stipulation, (ii) compliance with the Spot Commodities Framework versus the MIR Rules for other activities, and (iii) the need to operate a market that complies with the Recognition Requirements?
expected_answer: An RIE can operate an MTF or OTF using Accepted Spot Commodities only where its Recognition Order contains a stipulation allowing it to do so, and it must structure its compliance so that the spot-commodity venue activity is governed by the Spot Commodities Framework while its other operations remain governed by the MIR Rules; in addition, it must also operate a market that meets the Recognition Requirements. [#SRC:3b0fe405-26d0-4f37-83e9-73ab112be809] Once that stipulation is granted, the RIE must comply with the Spot Commodities Framework for the operation of the MTF or OTF insofar as it uses Spot Commodities, while the remainder of the RIE’s operations must continue to be run in compliance with the MIR Rules. [#SRC:3b0fe405-26d0-4f37-83e9-73ab112be809] Separately and in parallel with those venue-specific and remainder-of-business compliance allocations, a Recognised Investment Exchange operating an MTF or an OTF must also operate a market that complies with the Recognition Requirements, meaning the RIE cannot treat the MTF/OTF operation as standalone without maintaining a Recognition Requirements-compliant market alongside it. [#TGT:85479490-968f-42f7-baaa-2580214b953d]

question: When an Authorised Person calculates its Leverage Ratio, how must it determine the Exposure Measure component, including the required aggregation of exposure categories, and how does that Exposure Measure fit into the overall Leverage Ratio methodology?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must compute its Leverage Ratio using a defined ratio methodology in which the Exposure Measure is the denominator and the Capital Measure is the numerator. [#SRC:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b] Specifically, the Leverage Ratio is calculated as Capital Measure divided by Exposure Measure, where the Capital Measure is the Authorised Person’s Tier 1 Capital (as calculated under Rule 3.9.1) and the Exposure Measure is the value of the Authorised Person’s Exposures (as calculated under Rules 3.21.5 and 3.21.6). [#SRC:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b] For purposes of determining that Exposure Measure under Rule 3.21.2(b), the Exposure Measure must be calculated by summing two categories of items: (a) on-balance sheet items and (b) off-balance sheet items. [#TGT:7cb04504-3a85-4cd6-9010-652aec3cc07c] Accordingly, the Exposure Measure used in the Leverage Ratio denominator must reflect an aggregate of both on-balance sheet and off-balance sheet items, consistent with the Exposure Measure calculation requirement, and then be applied within the overall Leverage Ratio formula described above. [#SRC:220da97b-3f62-4f06-9964-190f0410661b] [#TGT:7cb04504-3a85-4cd6-9010-652aec3cc07c]

question: For purposes of applying the 20% placement capacity formula that limits how many Equity Securities a Listed Entity may issue without holder approval, how must the Listed Entity treat the sale or reissue of forfeited Equity Securities when calculating the “Relevant Issues” component for the prior 12-month period?
expected_answer: In applying the restriction that a Listed Entity must not issue (or agree to issue) more Equity Securities than the formula-based maximum without approval of holders of Ordinary Securities, the Listed Entity must count the sale or reissue of forfeited Equity Securities as an “issue” when determining whether there has been an issue of Equity Securities for calculating “Relevant Issues.” [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] This treatment directly affects the “Relevant Issues” subtraction in the maximum number formula (Maximum number of Equity Securities = (20% * Base Amount) – Relevant Issues), because “Relevant Issues” is defined as the number of Equity Securities issued, or agreed to be issued, in the 12 months before the date of the issue or agreement (subject to specified exclusions). [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] Accordingly, when compiling the 12‑month count for “Relevant Issues,” the Listed Entity should include any sale or reissue of forfeited Equity Securities as part of the issued (or agreed to be issued) Equity Securities in that period, unless it falls within an exclusion stated in the “Relevant Issues” definition. [#SRC:863c68f4-2e55-4333-9bce-fc4093841356] [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] This ensures the capacity calculation reflects forfeited securities transactions as issues for the purpose of the Relevant Issues tally used in the formula. [#SRC:863c68f4-2e55-4333-9bce-fc4093841356] [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]

A Listed Entity must not issue, or agree to issue, more Equity Securities than the number calculated according to the following formula, without the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities: Maximum number of Equity Securities = (20% * Base Amount) – Relevant Issues), where: Base Amount = the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities on issue as of the date 12 months before the date of issue or agreement (the “12 months Base Amount”), plus the number of: (1) fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exceptions (8), (15) or (16); (2) fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exception (15), where the agreement was: (i) entered into before the commencement of the 12 month period; or (ii) approved, or taken under the Rules to have been approved, under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; and (3) any other fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement with approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; Guidance The Base Amount may include fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an agreement to issue Securities within Rule 9.7.4 exception (14) where the issue is subsequently approved under Rule 9.7.1. question: When an Authorised Person designs the strategy’s system for controlling Liquidity Risk so it can implement the requirements in Rule 9.2.6, what specific capabilities and governance features must that system include, particularly regarding review of compliance with limits and operating procedures and the presence of approval processes and mechanisms?
expected_answer: The strategy’s Liquidity Risk control system must be built so the Authorised Person can implement the requirements referenced in Rule 9.2.6, and it must also meet the detailed functional and governance expectations for the system referred to in Rule 9.2.1(5). [#SRC:5c690bca-7ecd-4950-8e21-6c4cb9357647] [#TGT:844184dc-c876-465f-8cc6-61d7c4911988] In practice, this means the system is not merely descriptive within the strategy; it must be capable of supporting implementation and oversight through defined review and control features. [#SRC:5c690bca-7ecd-4950-8e21-6c4cb9357647] [#TGT:844184dc-c876-465f-8cc6-61d7c4911988] Specifically, the system must enable the Authorised Person’s Governing Body and senior management to review whether the Authorised Person is complying with limits that are set in accordance with Rule 9.2.7 and with the relevant operating procedures. [#TGT:844184dc-c876-465f-8cc6-61d7c4911988] In addition, the system must include appropriate approval processes, limits, and other mechanisms that are designed to provide reasonable assurance that the Authorised Person’s Liquidity Risk management processes are adhered to. [#TGT:844184dc-c876-465f-8cc6-61d7c4911988] Taken together, the strategy requirement to include such a system and the system’s required review and assurance features define both the inclusion and the minimum operational content of the Liquidity Risk control framework. [#SRC:5c690bca-7ecd-4950-8e21-6c4cb9357647] [#TGT:844184dc-c876-465f-8cc6-61d7c4911988]

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation, how can it avoid having to comply with Rule 11.2.1(1), and what specific disclosure content must it still ensure is included (including the required prominent statement and the Competent Person-related elements)?
expected_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity that discloses material Non-Equivalent Estimates of Mineralisation may treat Rule 11.2.1(1) as not applicable only if it instead complies with the specified alternative rules (Rule 11.7.2, Rule 11.7.3, Rule 11.7.4, and Rule 11.7.6). [#SRC:ec29aad6-3d7b-4466-a6ab-0022accf5f26] Even when relying on that carve-out, the entity must still ensure the disclosure contains the required Non-Equivalent Estimates content, including a prominent nearby statement that the estimates are Non-Equivalent Estimates not made under a Mining Reporting Standard, that a Competent Person has not done enough work to classify them as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves under a Mining Reporting Standard, and that it is uncertain whether further evaluation/exploration will ever allow such disclosure under a Mining Reporting Standard. [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b] The disclosure must also include the sources and dates of the estimates; explain whether any Mineralisation categories used differ from (or match) those in a Mining Reporting Standard; address relevance and reliability; summarise the work and key assumptions/parameters/methods used; provide any newer relevant estimates/data with sources and dates; and describe what work is needed to verify the estimates as Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, including proposed timing and funding source. [#TGT:df1ba511-2466-416a-9520-40451002811b] Finally, it must state the classification/reporting standard used and include a statement by a named Competent Person(s) attesting that the information provided for items (3) to (9) accurately reflects available data and studies. question: For an issue of Securities under an Employee Incentive Scheme that relies on the exception to Rule 9.7.1 based on holder approval within the last three years, how should a Listed Entity treat those scheme issues when applying the 12‑month “Maximum number of Equity Securities” restriction formula—specifically, what meeting-notice disclosures are required for the scheme approval, and how do issues made with that approval affect the “Relevant Issues” subtraction?
expected_answer: A Listed Entity can rely on the Employee Incentive Scheme pathway that treats the scheme issue as an exception to Rule 9.7.1 only if the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities approved the issue of Equity Securities under the scheme within three years before the issue date, and the notice of meeting included specified scheme information. [#SRC:a2108df9-4a76-4d9c-8a4a-7e058e5e8113] For that approval, the notice must cover (i) a summary of the scheme terms, (ii) the number of Securities issued under the scheme since admission to the Official List (or since the last approval under the rule), and (iii) the maximum number of Equity Securities proposed to be issued under the scheme after the approval. [#SRC:a2108df9-4a76-4d9c-8a4a-7e058e5e8113] When the Listed Entity then applies the 12‑month restriction formula that limits new issues to (20% * Base Amount) minus Relevant Issues unless Ordinary Security holders approve, Equity Securities issued (or agreed to be issued) in the prior 12 months with holder approval under Rule 9.7.1 are excluded from “Relevant Issues.” [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] Accordingly, scheme issues made pursuant to that Rule 9.7.1 approval are not counted in the “Relevant Issues” figure that is subtracted in the formula, even though they are Equity Securities issued in the 12‑month lookback. [#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933]

debug_context.source_text: An issue of Securities under an Employee Incentive Scheme if within three years before the issue date: (a) in the case of a scheme established before the Listed Entity’s Securities were admitted to the Official List – a summary of the terms of the scheme and the maximum number of Equity Securities proposed to be issued under the scheme were set out in in its Approved Prospectus or documents lodged with the Regulator under Rule 2.4.3; or (b) the holders of the Listed Entity’s Ordinary Securities have approved the issue of Equity Securities under the scheme as an exception to Rule 9.7.1. The notice of meeting must have included: (i) a summary of the terms of the scheme; (ii) the number of Securities issued under the scheme since the Listed Entity’s Securities were admitted to the Official List, or the date of the last approval under this Rule; and (iii) the maximum number of Equity Securities proposed to be issued under the scheme following the approval.
debug_context.target_text: Restrictions on new Issues of Equity Securities . A Listed Entity must not issue, or agree to issue, more Equity Securities than the number calculated according to the following formula, without the approval of the holders of Ordinary Securities: Maximum number of Equity Securities = (20% * Base Amount) – Relevant Issues), where: Base Amount = the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities on issue as of the date 12 months before the date of issue or agreement (the “12 months Base Amount”), plus the number of: (1) fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exceptions (8), (15) or (16); (2) fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an exception in Rule 9.7.4 other than exception (15), where the agreement was: (i) entered into before the commencement of the 12 month period; or (ii) approved, or taken under the Rules to have been approved, under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; and (3) any other fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement with approval under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; Guidance The Base Amount may include fully paid Ordinary Securities issued in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement under an agreement to issue Securities within Rule 9.7.4 exception (14) where the issue is subsequently approved under Rule 9.7.1. (4) partly paid Ordinary Securities that became fully paid in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement, but subtracting the number of fully paid Ordinary Securities cancelled in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement. Relevant Issues = the number of Equity Securities issued, or agreed to be issued, in the 12 months before the date of issue or agreement to issue other than: (a) with the approval of the holders of its Ordinary Securities under Rule 9.7.1 or Rule 9.7.5; or (b) under an exception in Rule 9.7.4.

question: If a Listed Entity wants to issue Securities under an Employee Incentive Scheme and use the fact that Ordinary Security holders approved it (within the last three years) as an exception, what exactly must have been in the meeting notice, and when the entity later checks the 12‑month 20% issue limit formula, do those approved scheme issues count in “Relevant Issues” or not?

[#TGT:a5d5f764-a746-4801-8e14-9584a84d3933] So, if the scheme issues were made under that Rule 9.7.1 approval, they are not included in “Relevant Issues” for the subtraction step. question: When an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT that is covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement and is using the FCCA, how must it determine the haircut approach for calculating E* and how is that E* then used in the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount calculation for CR Exposures to a single Counterparty under Section 4.8?
expected_answer: In this scenario, the Authorised Person must both (i) select a permitted haircut methodology for the E* computation and (ii) apply the resulting E* as the exposure measure used for Credit Risk weighting for the relevant Counterparty. Specifically, for calculating E* in collateralised transactions (other than OTC Derivative transactions and long settlement transactions), the Authorised Person must determine the appropriate haircuts using either standard supervisory haircuts or own estimate haircuts. [#TGT:19b5846d-b958-4e12-a8d2-ffe1b2dd7ed8] Where the Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT that is covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement and is using the FCCA, it must calculate E* for all its CR Exposures to any single Counterparty covered by that qualifying bilateral Netting agreement, following the App4 rule set referenced for the chosen haircut approach (supervisory or own estimate). [#SRC:56e2cb44-f613-4f2a-bd4c-8726a79a5776] After E* is calculated for those exposures, the Authorised Person must substitute E* in place of E when calculating the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount for its CR Exposures to that Counterparty under Section 4.8. [#SRC:56e2cb44-f613-4f2a-bd4c-8726a79a5776]

question: For an Authorised Person in Category 1, 2, 3A or 5, when do the thresholds for Foreign Currency business and overall net open position remove the obligation to calculate a Foreign Exchange Risk Capital Requirement, and if the thresholds are not met, what calculation approaches are permitted for Trading Book and Non Trading Book foreign exchange positions?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person in Category 1, 2, 3A or 5 is not required to calculate a Foreign Exchange Risk Capital Requirement only if it meets both quantitative conditions relating to its Foreign Currency business and its overall net open position. [#TGT:79d3cd2f-93a5-4f25-af68-c67e7fd4cb97] Specifically, the exemption applies where (i) its Foreign Currency business—measured as the greater of the sum of gross long positions and the sum of gross short positions across all Foreign Currencies—does not exceed 100% of its Capital Resources (as defined in Chapter 3), and (ii) its overall net open position (as defined in Rule A6.4.4) does not exceed 2% of its Capital Resources (as defined in Chapter 3). [#TGT:79d3cd2f-93a5-4f25-af68-c67e7fd4cb97] If either condition is not satisfied, then (subject to Rule 5.6.2) the Authorised Person must calculate its Foreign Exchange Risk Capital Requirement for both Trading Book and Non Trading Book foreign exchange positions using one of two permitted approaches: applying an internal Market Risk model that has been approved by the Regulator for this purpose, or applying the Rules in Section A6.4. [#SRC:956c9f62-c5f8-4b6f-ae68-4426034873a1]

debug_context.source_text: An Authorised Person in Category 1, 2, 3A or 5 must, subject to Rule 5.6.2, calculate its Foreign Exchange Risk Capital Requirement in respect of Trading Book and Non Trading Book foreign exchange positions by: (a) applying its internal Market Risk model which has been approved by the Regulator for this purpose; or (b) applying the Rules in Section A6.4.

question: When the Regulator is seeking to transfer a Fund's property or liability to another Fund, what is the specific regulatory mechanism described for changing the applicable text, and how does that mechanism relate to the Regulator’s broader ability to modify provisions in the relevant Chapter to further its objectives?
expected_answer: For a transfer of a Fund’s property or liability to another Fund, the described mechanism is that the Regulator prescribes a modification specifically to Part 7 of the FSMR, and that modification is framed as being necessary to achieve the transfer purpose. [#SRC:7e35037e-5597-44db-a661-2b4b5c406c0c] This transfer-focused prescription sits within the Regulator’s broader power to make changes by issuing Rules that modify provisions in the Chapter when the modification is necessary to further one or more of the Regulator’s objectives. [#TGT:dd850ae5-8271-4248-96a6-5e1990ae4418] Read together, the texts indicate that (i) the transfer scenario is tied to a concrete subject matter—moving property or liabilities between Funds—and a defined location for the change (Part 7), and (ii) the general enabling route for modifications is the Regulator acting “by Rules” where necessity is linked to advancing its objectives. [#SRC:7e35037e-5597-44db-a661-2b4b5c406c0c] [#TGT:dd850ae5-8271-4248-96a6-5e1990ae4418] Accordingly, in the transfer context, the Regulator’s modification should be understood as a targeted Part 7 modification prescribed for that transfer purpose, implemented through the Regulator’s Rules-based modification power where the necessity threshold is met. [#SRC:7e35037e-5597-44db-a661-2b4b5c406c0c] [#TGT:dd850ae5-8271-4248-96a6-5e1990ae4418]

question: When an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business plans to deposit Client Money into a Client Account established with a Third-Party Agent, what specific written acknowledgment must it obtain from the Third-Party Agent, and how should that acknowledgment be treated within the Authorised Person’s Resolution Pack record set?
expected_answer: The Authorised Person must obtain a written acknowledgment from the Third-Party Agent before it deposits Client Money into a Client Account established with that Third-Party Agent. question: What ongoing review arrangements must a Recognised Investment Exchange maintain to ensure a Price Reporting Agency continues to satisfy the specific procedural, transparency, governance, independence, conflict-management, and complaints-handling characteristics required for the purposes of Rules 3.11.1 and 3.11.3?
expected_answer: A Recognised Investment Exchange must maintain arrangements that provide for regular, ongoing review of whether a Price Reporting Agency continues to meet the applicable requirements, rather than treating the assessment as a one-time check. [#SRC:7728ff1d-b279-4806-b3fd-13f3e8a34e79] In conducting that regular review, the Recognised Investment Exchange should assess continued compliance against the characteristics a Price Reporting Agency must have for the purposes of Rules 3.11.1 and 3.11.3, including both process design and organisational controls. [#TGT:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a] The review arrangements should be capable of checking, at a minimum, that the Price Reporting Agency: (i) maintains fair, non-discriminatory, and publicly available procedures for establishing prices of a Financial Instrument; (ii) continues to provide adequate transparency over methodology, calculation, and inputs so users can understand derivation and limitations; (iii) where appropriate, prioritises concluded transactions and minimises selective reporting; (iv) remains of good standing and repute as independent and objective; (v) retains a sound corporate governance framework; (vi) has arrangements to avoid staff conflicts of interest that are, or are likely to be, materially adverse to the price establishment process; and (vii) maintains adequate complaint resolution mechanisms for its assessment process and methodology. [#TGT:8a81e6cb-f1f1-4988-af97-f966f288017a] The key compliance outcome is that the Recognised Investment Exchange’s regular review arrangements are aligned to verifying continued satisfaction of these requirements over time. [#SRC:7728ff1d-b279-4806-b3fd-13f3e8a34e79]

question: For an unmargined derivatives netting set, how should a firm determine the replacement cost (RC) using the RC formula, and how does that interact with the requirement to include an on-balance sheet value and a potential future exposure add-on when calculating the exposure value for derivatives (including written credit protection)?
expected_answer: A firm should calculate RC for an unmargined derivatives netting set by applying the specified max formula to the netting set’s derivative value and the haircut value of net collateral, and separately ensure that the exposure value for derivatives includes both an IFRS-based on-balance sheet component and a potential future exposure add-on. [#TGT:7925206c-3c2f-45a8-940b-3cbf102d8e84] For RC, the firm must identify V as the value of the derivative transactions in the relevant netting set, with that netting set constituted in accordance with Rule A4.6.18, and identify C as the haircut value of the net collateral held, calculated under Section A4.3; RC is then max{V − C, 0}. [#TGT:7925206c-3c2f-45a8-940b-3cbf102d8e84] In parallel, when determining the exposure value for derivatives (including written credit protection) as an on-balance sheet item, the firm must compute it as the sum of (i) the on-balance sheet value in accordance with IFRS and (ii) an add-on for potential future exposure calculated under Rules A4.6.14 to A4.6.21 of App 4. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] Practically, this means the RC computation relies on the netting-set construct and collateral haircut mechanics, while the exposure value requirement ensures the derivatives exposure measure also incorporates IFRS recognition plus a prescribed potential future exposure add-on. [#SRC:b0cdb789-c9b6-4f36-a6b3-bf1e213d2007] [#TGT:7925206c-3c2f-45a8-940b-3cbf102d8e84]

debug_context.source_text: In relation to on-balance sheet items: a. for SFTs, the Exposure value should be calculated in accordance with IFRS and the Netting requirements referred to in Rule 4.9.14; b. for Derivatives, including written credit protection, the Exposure value should be calculated as the sum of the on-balance sheet value in accordance with IFRS and an add-on for potential future Exposure calculated in accordance with Rules A4.6.14 to A4.6.21 of App 4; and c. for other on-balance sheet items, the Exposure value should be calculated based on their balance sheet values in accordance with Rule 4.9.3.

RC for unmargined transactions is calculated in accordance with the following formula: RC = max{V – C; 0} where: V = the value of the derivative transactions in the netting set (constituted in accordance with Rule A4.6.18); and C = the haircut value of the net collateral held, calculated in accordance with Section A4.3.

question: When preparing the weekly position report referred to under Rule 3.3.12, how must the Recognised Investment Exchange both (i) categorise persons and (ii) distinguish between risk-reducing positions and other positions, and what classification basis and example categories should it use when applying the person-categorisation requirement?
expected_answer: In the weekly position report referred to under Rule 3.3.12, the Recognised Investment Exchange must do two things in parallel: it must categorise persons (by applying the relevant categorisation approach) and it must also separate positions into risk-reducing versus other positions, to the extent possible. [#SRC:2722b40a-c3fd-4d87-a5aa-65796ac6bdf2] For the person-categorisation element, the Recognised Investment Exchange should, to the extent possible, classify all persons holding positions in Derivatives by the nature of their main business, taking into account any applicable authorisation or registration. [#TGT:e0fb58e1-186e-41c2-ac8a-9b521a2fcdaa] Practically, that means the report should reflect business-nature categories such as: financial intermediary (including those Dealing in Investments as Agent, Dealing in Investments as Principal, or Arranging Credit, and equivalents outside ADGM), investment fund (including those Managing Assets or Managing a Collective Investment Fund, and similar overseas concepts), another Financial Institution (including insurance management), or a commercial undertaking. [#TGT:e0fb58e1-186e-41c2-ac8a-9b521a2fcdaa] Alongside that categorisation, the Recognised Investment Exchange must differentiate, to the extent possible, between positions that in an objectively measurable way reduce risks directly relating to commercial activities and other positions. [#SRC:2722b40a-c3fd-4d87-a5aa-65796ac6bdf2] The combined output is a weekly report that links each person’s business-based category with whether their positions are risk-reducing or not, to the extent possible. [#SRC:2722b40a-c3fd-4d87-a5aa-65796ac6bdf2]

question: Where an Authorised Person holds money received from a Professional Client under a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement, how should that money be treated for Client Money classification purposes, and do the Client Money Rules and Safe Custody Rules apply to it?
expected_answer: Money received under a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement from a Professional Client is treated as not being Client Money. [#SRC:875ef4dc-f3c8-464c-b6f3-6216b864e3bc] When that money is held by an Authorised Person pursuant to a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement, the Client Money Rules do not apply to it. [#TGT:d541bbc2-9a05-45ff-8063-6dd671feecb7] This conclusion depends on both (i) the client classification condition that the payer is a Professional Client and (ii) the holding condition that the asset or money is held by an Authorised Person under the same type of agreement. [#SRC:875ef4dc-f3c8-464c-b6f3-6216b864e3bc] [#TGT:d541bbc2-9a05-45ff-8063-6dd671feecb7] In addition, where an Authorised Person holds a Safe Custody Asset pursuant to a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement, the Safe Custody Rules do not apply in respect of that Safe Custody Asset. [#TGT:d541bbc2-9a05-45ff-8063-6dd671feecb7] Accordingly, in the specific scenario of money received from a Professional Client under a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement and held by an Authorised Person under that agreement, the money is outside the definition of Client Money and is also outside the scope of the Client Money Rules. [#SRC:875ef4dc-f3c8-464c-b6f3-6216b864e3bc] [#TGT:d541bbc2-9a05-45ff-8063-6dd671feecb7]

debug_context.source_text: In accordance with Rule 15.11.A.2 Money received under the Title Transfer Collateral Agreement from a Professional Client is not Client Money.
debug_context.target_text: The Client Money Rules and Safe Custody Rules do not apply in respect of a Safe Custody Asset or Client Money which is held by an Authorised Person pursuant to a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement.

[#SRC:875ef4dc-f3c8-464c-b6f3-6216b864e3bc] Separately, when Client Money (or a Safe Custody Asset) is held by an Authorised Person under a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement, the Client Money Rules and Safe Custody Rules do not apply in respect of that holding. [#TGT:d541bbc2-9a05-45ff-8063-6dd671feecb7] Putting these together, the classification point (Professional Client money under a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement is not Client Money) and the scope point (rules do not apply where held by an Authorised Person under that agreement) both need to be satisfied to fully describe the regulatory treatment. question: For an Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm, how should the Governing Body’s assessment of capital adequacy affect the firm’s obligation to maintain Capital Resources “at all times,” including any expectation to hold additional capital and liquid assets beyond the specified minimum types and amounts?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm must continuously meet the baseline capital requirement and also use its Governing Body’s assessment to determine whether additional resources are needed beyond that baseline. Specifically, the Domestic Firm is required to have and maintain, at all times, Capital Resources of the types and amounts specified in, and calculated in accordance with, these Rules. [#TGT:afbb9f59-2c26-47f6-ac38-4c36ecd40d56] In parallel, for the purposes of Rule 3.2.4, the Authorised Person’s Governing Body should evaluate whether the Capital Resources required by the Regulator under these Rules are adequate when viewed against the Authorised Person’s specific business model and risk profile. [#SRC:097ade5d-12c3-4d41-876b-1634652a822d] Where that assessment indicates the required Capital Resources do not adequately reflect the nature and risks of the Authorised Person’s business, the Authorised Person should maintain additional resources. [#SRC:097ade5d-12c3-4d41-876b-1634652a822d] This aligns with the Domestic Firm obligation to ensure it maintains capital and liquid assets in addition to the baseline requirement that are adequate in relation to the nature, size and complexity of its business, so there is no significant risk that liabilities cannot be met as they fall due. [#TGT:afbb9f59-2c26-47f6-ac38-4c36ecd40d56]

question: Before an Authorised Person establishes a business relationship with a Retail Client and also intends to offer OTC Leveraged Products (or provide advice or make arrangements relating to them), what combined pre-engagement assessment must the Authorised Person perform, and what conclusions must it be able to reach about the Retail Client?
expected_answer: The Authorised Person must complete a pre-engagement evaluation that both (i) considers the Retail Client’s understanding of risk and potential loss magnitude before establishing the business relationship and (ii) satisfies the specific OTC Leveraged Products gating test before offering, advising on, or arranging those products. [#SRC:e79e3adf-b4c6-4c32-81c3-6440c56574a6] [#TGT:be7639eb-37d0-4a64-80e4-a7694dd68cc0] Practically, this means the Authorised Person should, prior to establishing the relationship, consider whether the Retail Client demonstrates an understanding of the risks and the potential magnitude of losses they may be exposed to. [#SRC:e79e3adf-b4c6-4c32-81c3-6440c56574a6] In addition, the Authorised Person is prohibited from offering OTC Leveraged Products, or providing advice or making arrangements on behalf of the Retail Client relating to OTC Leveraged Products, unless it has first assessed the Retail Client’s skill, experience, knowledge, financial resources, and risk tolerance. [#TGT:be7639eb-37d0-4a64-80e4-a7694dd68cc0] The assessment must be completed to a level that allows the Authorised Person to reasonably conclude that the Retail Client has adequate experience and skill to understand the potential risk of loss involved in investing in OTC Leveraged Products and has liquid financial resources sufficient to absorb potential losses from trading in those products. [#TGT:be7639eb-37d0-4a64-80e4-a7694dd68cc0]

question: For an Authorised Person with a Financial Services Permission to carry on the Regulated Activity of Providing Money Services that undertakes the activity of a Money Remitter, how must it determine the Capital Requirement for that activity, and how is the Money Remitter Variable Capital Requirement component calculated using monthly payment volume tiers?
expected_answer: For the Money Remitter activity, the Authorised Person must set the Capital Requirement by taking the highest applicable amount among the specified capital measures for that activity, including the Money Remitter’s Variable Capital Requirement and the relevant Expenditure Based Capital Minimum, and also comparing against the applicable Base Capital Requirement. [#SRC:b9a60932-1035-44e7-a556-855195ef9304] In particular, for a Money Remitter the Capital Requirement must be the highest of: (i) the applicable Base Capital Requirement; and (ii) the Money Remitter-specific combination of (A) the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum and (B) the Variable Capital Requirement calculated in accordance with the Money Remitter rule. [#SRC:b9a60932-1035-44e7-a556-855195ef9304] The Variable Capital Requirement for a Money Remitter is calculated as a tiered percentage applied to monthly payment volume and then summed across tiers. [#TGT:b1b3ae34-d42b-4c08-83fb-9ddac72f228c] Concretely, it equals 1.25% of the first $10 million of monthly payment volume, plus 0.5% of the next $90 million, plus 0.25% of the next $150 million, plus 0.125% of any remaining monthly payment volume. [#TGT:b1b3ae34-d42b-4c08-83fb-9ddac72f228c] The resulting Variable Capital Requirement figure is then used as the Variable Capital Requirement input when determining the highest amount for the Money Remitter activity’s Capital Requirement. [#SRC:b9a60932-1035-44e7-a556-855195ef9304]

question: If an Authorised Person provides Money Services and acts as a Money Remitter, what numbers does it have to compare to set its Capital Requirement for that activity, and how do you work out the Money Remitter Variable Capital Requirement from monthly payment volume?
expected_answer: When the Authorised Person is carrying on the Regulated Activity of Providing Money Services and the relevant activity is being a Money Remitter, it must determine the Capital Requirement for that activity by selecting the highest amount from the required capital measures, rather than choosing a lower figure. [#SRC:b9a60932-1035-44e7-a556-855195ef9304] For a Money Remitter, those measures include the applicable Base Capital Requirement and, for the Money Remitter category, both the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum and the Variable Capital Requirement calculated under the Money Remitter method. [#SRC:b9a60932-1035-44e7-a556-855195ef9304] To compute the Money Remitter Variable Capital Requirement, you apply a set of percentage rates to bands of monthly payment volume and add the results together. [#TGT:b1b3ae34-d42b-4c08-83fb-9ddac72f228c] The bands are: 1.25% on the first $10 million, 0.5% on the next $90 million, 0.25% on the next $150 million, and 0.125% on any remaining monthly payment volume above those amounts. [#TGT:b1b3ae34-d42b-4c08-83fb-9ddac72f228c] After calculating that tiered sum, the Authorised Person uses it as the Variable Capital Requirement input when identifying the highest figure that becomes the Capital Requirement for the Money Remitter activity. [#SRC:b9a60932-1035-44e7-a556-855195ef9304]

question: For an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business, how should the requirement to perform accurate reconciliations of Client Accounts at least every calendar month be reflected in the contents of the Resolution Pack, and what specific reconciliation-related record must be included?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person conducting Investment Business must both (i) run accurate reconciliations of Client Accounts on a schedule that is as frequent as needed but no less than monthly, and (ii) ensure the Resolution Pack contains evidence of those reconciliations in the form of the most recent reconciliation records for Client Money and Client Investments. [#TGT:2b1f7591-fc25-4d91-a3bd-88140fd07c1b] [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] The monthly reconciliation obligation is framed as a systems-and-controls requirement aimed at ensuring reconciliations are accurate and performed at least every calendar month, so the firm should operate controls that reliably produce reconciliation outputs on that cadence (or more often where necessary). [#TGT:2b1f7591-fc25-4d91-a3bd-88140fd07c1b] To align the Resolution Pack with that operational requirement, the Pack must include the most recent reconciliations of Client Money and Client Investments, which provides a concrete, current record demonstrating that reconciliation activity is being performed and documented. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] In practice, this means the firm should be able to point from its monthly (or more frequent) reconciliation process for Client Accounts to the latest completed reconciliation records for Client Money and Client Investments that are filed in the Resolution Pack. [#TGT:2b1f7591-fc25-4d91-a3bd-88140fd07c1b] [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]

debug_context.source_text: The following records must be included in the Resolution Pack of an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business: (a) Rules ‎2.7.1 and ‎3.7.1(d) (records of Client classification and Client agreements); (b) Rules 14.6.2 and ‎15.4.3 (master lists of all Client Accounts in relation to Client Money and Client investments); (c) Rule ‎15.4.4 and Rule ‎15.4.5 (adequate records and Client's written permission re use of Client Investments); (d) Rules 14.7.1 and 14.7.4 (assessment of appropriateness of Third-Party Agent and acknowledgement by Third-Party agent in respect of Client Money); and (e) Rule ‎15.5.1 and 15.6.1 (assessment of appropriateness of Third Party Agent and acknowledgement by Third-Party Agent in respect of Client Investments); and (f) Rule 14.11.1 and ‎15.9.1 (most recent reconciliations of Client Money and Client Investments).
debug_context.target_text: An Authorised Person conducting Investment Business must maintain adequate systems and controls to ensure that accurate reconciliations of Client Accounts are carried out as regularly as necessary but at least every calendar month.

question: If an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business has to reconcile Client Accounts at least every calendar month, what does it need to keep in its Resolution Pack to show this, and what kind of control expectation goes with the monthly reconciliation rule?
expected_answer: The firm needs to do two connected things: it must have systems and controls that make sure reconciliations of Client Accounts are accurate and done as often as needed, but at least once each calendar month, and it must keep the latest reconciliation records in its Resolution Pack. [#TGT:2b1f7591-fc25-4d91-a3bd-88140fd07c1b] [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] The control expectation is not just to perform reconciliations occasionally; it is to maintain adequate systems and controls designed to ensure the reconciliations are carried out accurately and on a regular schedule that meets the minimum monthly frequency. [#TGT:2b1f7591-fc25-4d91-a3bd-88140fd07c1b] To evidence that reconciliation activity in the Resolution Pack, the Pack must include the most recent reconciliations of Client Money and Client Investments, meaning the latest completed reconciliation records for those areas should be present and up to date. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] Put together, the monthly reconciliation requirement drives the cadence and accuracy of the process, while the Resolution Pack requirement specifies that the newest reconciliation outputs for Client Money and Client Investments must be retained in that Pack as part of the firm’s records. [#TGT:2b1f7591-fc25-4d91-a3bd-88140fd07c1b] [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]

question: For an Issuer conducting an Exempt Offer under Rule 4.3.1(13), how should the Issuer reconcile the requirement that the Product Summary Note carry a prominent front-page disclaimer with the general prohibition on including disclaimers in relation to information disclosed in, or in respect of, the Product Summary Note?
expected_answer: In an Exempt Offer under Rule 4.3.1(13), the Issuer is required to include a specific prominent disclaimer on the front of the Product Summary Note, in bold, using the disclaimer referenced in Rule 4.3.4. [#TGT:624cf5d5-aef8-4bd2-9587-d41858b3ede2] At the same time, Issuers are generally required to refrain from including disclaimers relating to information disclosed in the Product Summary Note or disclaimers made in respect of the Product Summary Note. [#SRC:6d1b4cca-e1ac-42ee-bfe9-70c2c65bcf04] Read together, the Issuer should treat the front-page disclaimer mandated for the Exempt Offer Product Summary Note as the only disclaimer content that is affirmatively required, and avoid adding any other disclaimer language that would operate as a disclaimer “in relation to” the information in the Product Summary Note or “in respect of” the Product Summary Note. [#TGT:624cf5d5-aef8-4bd2-9587-d41858b3ede2] [#SRC:6d1b4cca-e1ac-42ee-bfe9-70c2c65bcf04] This approach aligns with the Product Summary Note content controls that it must be fair and balanced, not false or misleading, and must not omit information in a way that makes any part false or misleading, which would be undermined by additional disclaimer-style qualifications. [#TGT:624cf5d5-aef8-4bd2-9587-d41858b3ede2]

debug_context.source_text: Subject to Rule 4.3.5, Issuers shall refrain from including disclaimers in relation to information disclosed in the Product Summary Note or in respect of the Product Summary Note.

If the Issuer makes the Offer document available online, the Product Summary Note must be made available online together with the Offer document; (f) not contain any information that is not contained in the Offer document; (g) not contain any Inside Information that differs in any material particular from that set out in the Offer document; and (h) not omit any information from any part of the Product Summary Note which would result in that part of the Product Summary Note being construed as false or misleading. (2) The Product Summary Note shall contain the prominent disclaimer set out in Rule 4.3.4 in bold, on its front. (3) The Issuer must give notice the Regulator of its intention to provide a Product Summary Note at least ten Business Days prior to the Exempt Offer, in such form as the Regulator may prescribe. (4) When the Issuer makes any change to the Offer document, the Product Summary Note must be updated if the change has a material effect on the key information of the Securities offered. (5) Issuers must ensure there is clear naming of the Securities offered. The name of the Securities must be descriptive of the nature of the Securities offered. It must not give investors a misleading view of the true nature and risks of the Securities offered.

question: When preparing a Product Summary Note for an Exempt Offer under Rule 4.3.1(13), what disclaimer-related content is the Issuer required to include, and what disclaimer-related content must the Issuer avoid including in or about the Product Summary Note?
expected_answer: For an Exempt Offer under Rule 4.3.1(13), the Issuer must include a particular disclaimer: the Product Summary Note must carry the prominent disclaimer referenced in Rule 4.3.4, placed on the front of the Product Summary Note and shown in bold. question: For a Listed Entity/Reporting Entity preparing its annual financial report, how should it address the separate obligation to comply with Rule 9.2.10 on annual reporting of Corporate Governance Principles compliance, and what specific disclosures must appear in that annual financial report to satisfy the annual reporting on compliance requirements?
expected_answer: A Listed Entity/Reporting Entity should treat its annual financial report as the vehicle that must contain the required annual compliance disclosures, while also recognizing that it has an additional, explicit obligation to comply with Rule 9.2.10 regarding annual reporting of its compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles. [#SRC:88ccc385-cfe8-4e4e-afd3-80026e74b4dd] In the annual financial report of a Listed Entity to which the annual reporting section applies, the report must first state whether the best practice standards in APP 4 (the Corporate Governance Principles) have been adopted. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] If adoption is not full (including partial adoption), the report must explain the reasons for not fully adopting the standards and describe any actions taken to achieve compliance to the extent standards were not adopted or were only partially adopted. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] The annual financial report must also include a statement by Directors on whether, in their opinion, the Corporate Governance framework is effective in promoting compliance with the Corporate Governance Principles, supported by information, assumptions, and any necessary qualifications. [#TGT:5c3c0f6f-29a7-4b86-b0fe-109213900f3e] These annual financial report disclosures should be prepared in a way that enables the entity to meet the separate Rule 9.2.10 annual reporting compliance obligation. [#SRC:88ccc385-cfe8-4e4e-afd3-80026e74b4dd]

question: When a Mining Reporting Entity makes a disclosure that includes Exploration Results or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves, how must it both (i) obtain and reflect the Competent Person(s)’ prior written consent regarding the form and context of the presentation, and (ii) include the required Competent Person statements (named person, employment/Related Party status and employer, and professional organisation membership) within that same disclosure?
expected_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity should treat the Competent Person(s)’ prior written consent as a prerequisite to making the disclosure in the first place, and then ensure the disclosure text contains the specific Competent Person statements required for disclosures that include Exploration Results or estimates of Mineral Resources or Ore Reserves. [#SRC:c30b96f6-edff-4774-b206-68a20fe00ba8] [#TGT:1133d38f-067b-4a0a-b325-b5c7b2512203] Practically, this means the entity must secure written approval from the relevant Competent Person(s) covering the form and context in which the Exploration Results or the Mineral Resources/Ore Reserves estimates (and their supporting information) are presented, before issuing the disclosure. [#SRC:c30b96f6-edff-4774-b206-68a20fe00ba8] In the disclosure itself, it must also state that the disclosure is based on and fairly represents information and supporting documentation prepared by a named Competent Person(s). [#TGT:1133d38f-067b-4a0a-b325-b5c7b2512203] Additionally, for each Competent Person, it must specify whether the person is an employee of the Mining Reporting Entity or a Related Party, and if neither, identify the Competent Person’s employer. question: When preparing the annual report explanation referenced in the SOURCE, how should a Reporting Entity frame that explanation so it aligns with the Regulator’s rulemaking scope in TARGET—specifically regarding Corporate Governance principles and standards (including board of Directors and individual members, Controllers, employees or other persons), fair treatment of Shareholders, and conflicts of interests—and what long-term management outcome should the explanation demonstrate?
expected_answer: A Reporting Entity should use the annual report explanation to show, in a practical and outcomes-focused way, how its real-world Corporate Governance practices meet the outcomes that section 73 of the FSMR and the Principles are intended to achieve, rather than merely describing formal structures. [#SRC:f3baa5a3-304f-41e2-b57d-97db937d12c1] In doing so, the explanation should be framed to reflect the areas the Regulator may prescribe by Rules for Corporate Governance: principles and standards applicable to the Reporting Entity (including requirements that may apply to its board of Directors and individual members, Controllers, employees, or any other person as appropriate), requirements relating to fair treatment of Shareholders, and provisions addressing conflicts of interests. [#TGT:d0183f42-1701-4885-9dcb-cb96c2d62d6d] The explanation should therefore connect the Reporting Entity’s actual practices to these rule-prescribed governance dimensions and make clear how those practices support an adequate Corporate Governance framework. [#SRC:f3baa5a3-304f-41e2-b57d-97db937d12c1][#TGT:d0183f42-1701-4885-9dcb-cb96c2d62d6d] The management outcome the explanation should demonstrate is that the framework promotes prudent and sound management in the long-term interest of the Reporting Entity and its Shareholders. [#SRC:f3baa5a3-304f-41e2-b57d-97db937d12c1]

question: When may deferred publication of transaction information be authorised for a large transaction, and how must the firm determine whether the transaction meets the relevant minimum qualifying size by using the ADT-based thresholds and permitted delays table?
expected_answer: Deferred publication may be authorised only where the trade is between a Member (or, where applicable, an Authorised Person) acting on own account and that firm’s Client, and the transaction size is at or above the relevant minimum qualifying size for the instrument and transaction. [#SRC:d4233e73-f88e-4a70-8ab9-b5f982f14d48] To determine whether the size condition is met, the firm must first classify the Financial Instrument (admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange) by its average daily turnover (ADT) calculated under the Rule 3.6.10 methodology, and then apply the table’s ADT band and the chosen permitted publication delay to identify the corresponding minimum qualifying size threshold. [#SRC:d4233e73-f88e-4a70-8ab9-b5f982f14d48] The table links each permitted delay (e.g., 60 minutes, 180 minutes, until end of trading day, or later trading-day-based delays) to ADT ranges and specifies the minimum qualifying size as either a fixed amount, a percentage of ADT, or a max/min expression depending on the ADT band. [#TGT:096764ad-3a3c-4347-9345-61ad740d7e27] Any authorisation for deferred publication cannot extend beyond the maximum deferral period specified for the relevant class of Financial Instrument and transaction. [#SRC:d4233e73-f88e-4a70-8ab9-b5f982f14d48]

question: Where an Authorised Person is Providing Custody in relation to Virtual Assets, how should the term “Investments” (and the related concept of “Client Investments”) be interpreted for the purposes of Rule 17.8.1, and what additional COBS chapter compliance obligations apply in that custody scenario (including any guidance relevant to holding or controlling Client Money)?

question: When a Petroleum Reporting Entity makes a subsequent disclosure that refers back to earlier disclosed estimates of Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves (rather than presenting new estimates), what Competent Person-related statements must still appear in the subsequent disclosure, and what conditions must be met to rely on the earlier disclosure for the consent and statement requirements?
expected_answer: A subsequent disclosure that refers to previously disclosed estimates must still include the Competent Person identification statements required for any disclosure containing Prospective Resources, Contingent Resources or Petroleum Reserves, and it may rely on the earlier disclosure for the “first-time” consent-and-statement package only if the specific cross-reference and confirmation conditions are met. [#TGT:6f4cc15d-24f2-4ffc-a2ad-dff5dce98f79] Separately, the prior written consent as to the form and context of how the estimates and supporting information are presented applies only the first time the Petroleum Reporting Entity discloses original or updated estimates, provided that any later disclosure referencing those estimates points back to the earlier disclosure that contained the relevant statement and consent. [#SRC:9c4480c6-f416-4989-b1c9-ad5cf7c5d72e] The subsequent disclosure must also confirm that the entity is not aware of new information or data that materially affects the earlier disclosure and that the material assumptions and technical parameters underpinning the earlier estimates continue to apply without material change. question: Where an Authorised Person has taken eligible financial Collateral for an SFT, how should it treat the exposure measure in its credit risk calculation when (i) the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined under Rule 4.9.15 and (ii) the SFT is covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement and the Authorised Person is using the FCCA (including where supervisory haircuts or own estimate haircuts are used)?
expected_answer: In this combined scenario, the Authorised Person may recognise the effect of eligible financial Collateral for the SFT when measuring the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure determined under Rule 4.9.15, but it must also apply the FCCA netting-based exposure measure for credit risk capital purposes and use that measure in place of E in the credit risk calculation. [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778] Specifically, because the SFT is covered by a qualifying bilateral Netting agreement and the Authorised Person is using the FCCA, it must calculate E* for all its CR Exposures to any single Counterparty that are covered by that qualifying bilateral Netting agreement, following Rules A4.3.2 to A4.3.6 in App4 (including the case where supervisory haircuts or own estimate haircuts are used). [#TGT:56e2cb44-f613-4f2a-bd4c-8726a79a5776] After calculating E*, the Authorised Person must substitute E* for E when calculating the Credit Risk weighted Exposure amount for its CR Exposures to that Counterparty under Section 4.8. [#TGT:56e2cb44-f613-4f2a-bd4c-8726a79a5776] In parallel, for the same SFT where eligible financial Collateral has been taken and the pre settlement Counterparty Exposure is determined under Rule 4.9.15, the effect of that Collateral may be recognised in accordance with Rules 4.9.17 to 4.9.20. [#SRC:b2a0076b-8f51-4fc4-ac5b-6df2d25c4778]

question: How should an Authorised Person determine whether it falls within Category 1 or Category 3B when its Financial Services Permission includes both (i) Providing Custody for a Fund or Acting as the Trustee of an Investment Trust and (ii) Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu, and what exclusion conditions must be checked for each category?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person should classify itself by identifying which category’s determinative permission it holds and then confirming it satisfies that category’s stated exclusions. For Category 1, the key trigger is that its Financial Services Permission authorises Accepting Deposits or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAu, and it must also not meet the criteria of Category 5. [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66] For Category 3B, the key trigger is that its Financial Services Permission authorises Providing Custody (where it does so for a Fund) or Acting as the Trustee of an Investment Trust, and it must also not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A or 5. [#SRC:c1ffeb55-d01d-48f4-b82b-88eb654acbbe] Where the firm holds permissions that could point to both categories (e.g., custody/trustee permissions and deposit/PSIAu permissions), the Category 3B test explicitly requires checking and excluding Category 1 status, while the Category 1 test requires checking and excluding Category 5 status. [#SRC:c1ffeb55-d01d-48f4-b82b-88eb654acbbe] [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66] In applying these tests, note that each passage’s guidance indicates that other authorised Regulated Activities may exist, but the specified permissions are what determine category membership. [#SRC:c1ffeb55-d01d-48f4-b82b-88eb654acbbe] [#TGT:e705fde9-d397-4a9f-b5a0-471529529c66]

question: Where Securities are Exempt Securities under Rule 4.4.1 and are being admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, how do the SOURCE carve-out from the section 61(1) prohibition (including the stated condition tied to Rule 4.4.2) and the TARGET requirement for an Approved Prospectus interact for the act of having Securities admitted to trading?
expected_answer: For Securities that are Exempt Securities under Rule 4.4.1 and are being admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange, the SOURCE establishes that the section 61(1) prohibition is disapplied for that admission, but only on the condition that the requirement in Rule 4.4.2 is met. [#SRC:f70272ac-30bf-4e62-92d7-8b863f75cdf9] Separately, the TARGET sets a general rule that a person must not have Securities admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange unless an Approved Prospectus exists for the relevant Securities (noting that this is expressed as being subject to subsection (3)). [#TGT:82ade9b4-bba4-449c-815c-32d6ef292b54] Read together for the specific scenario described, the admission-to-trading activity sits within a SOURCE exception to the section 61(1) prohibition, but that exception is expressly conditional on compliance with Rule 4.4.2. [#SRC:f70272ac-30bf-4e62-92d7-8b863f75cdf9] At the same time, the TARGET’s baseline prohibition on having Securities admitted to trading without an Approved Prospectus still frames the admission activity unless the “subject to subsection (3)” qualifier applies in the circumstances. [#TGT:82ade9b4-bba4-449c-815c-32d6ef292b54] Accordingly, compliance analysis must account for both: the SOURCE’s conditional disapplication for Exempt Securities admissions and the TARGET’s Approved Prospectus condition for admissions to trading. [#SRC:f70272ac-30bf-4e62-92d7-8b863f75cdf9] [#TGT:82ade9b4-bba4-449c-815c-32d6ef292b54]

question: For a decision that may adversely affect a person’s rights, liabilities, or interests, when is it eligible to be referred to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review, and how do the exclusions and examples in FSMR (including operational decisions and certain decisions outside the Part 21 procedure such as exercise of our Own-Initiative Powers) interact with the rule that covers decisions made under these Regulations or Rules made by the Regulator?
expected_answer: A person may refer to the Appeals Panel for a full merits review a decision that meets the adverse-effect threshold, but the availability of referral must be read together with the FSMR carve-out for operational decisions and the FSMR indication that some additional categories of decisions are also referable even though they are not within the Part 21 procedure. [#TGT:bf2d397a-fa96-4c70-89f4-170288bb4c23] [#SRC:6389ecfc-9991-4085-8bb8-c41086f2dfea] The threshold condition is that the decision may affect the person’s rights or liabilities or otherwise adversely affect the person’s interests, and the referral is made by that affected person. [#TGT:bf2d397a-fa96-4c70-89f4-170288bb4c23] Within that scope, FSMR states that all of our decisions meeting that threshold may be referred, except for operational decisions, which are excluded from referral. [#SRC:6389ecfc-9991-4085-8bb8-c41086f2dfea] In addition, FSMR explains that certain other decisions—specifically identified as not being subject to the Part 21 procedure—may still be referred for a full merits review, with the exercise of our Own-Initiative Powers given as an example. [#SRC:6389ecfc-9991-4085-8bb8-c41086f2dfea] Accordingly, for decisions made under these Regulations or Rules made by the Regulator that meet the adverse-effect threshold, referral is available unless the decision is operational, and FSMR also contemplates referral for specified non‑Part 21 decisions such as Own‑Initiative Powers. [#TGT:bf2d397a-fa96-4c70-89f4-170288bb4c23] [#SRC:6389ecfc-9991-4085-8bb8-c41086f2dfea]

question: For a Recognised Clearing House that is providing Central Counterparty Services, how do the Rules identified as applicable to it frame the specific operational capability it must maintain for segregation and portability, including the permitted account structures and the objective of portability when a Member or other participant defaults?
expected_answer: A Recognised Clearing House providing Central Counterparty Services is expressly subject to a set of identified Rules, including Rule 4.12 on segregation and portability, and it must implement operational arrangements that meet the segregation/portability outcomes described for that topic. [#SRC:6112097d-0f5d-40e8-9a64-1aa7b6b520a6] Concretely, it must have systems and procedures that allow segregation and portability of positions of the Clients of its Members and other participants on its facilities, together with any collateral provided to it in relation to those positions. [#TGT:9ca78053-40eb-4073-b9b8-df05a7009571] Those systems and procedures must support maintaining Client positions and related collateral either in individual Client accounts or in Omnibus Client Accounts, meaning the Recognised Clearing House must be able to operate either account model for the covered positions and collateral. [#TGT:9ca78053-40eb-4073-b9b8-df05a7009571] In addition, its portability arrangements must be structured so that, if a Member or other participant defaults, the defaulting Member’s or other participant’s Clients’ positions and collateral can be transferred to one or more other Members or participants. [#TGT:9ca78053-40eb-4073-b9b8-df05a7009571] This segregation-and-portability capability sits within the broader set of Rules applicable to such a Recognised Clearing House, which also includes stress testing of capital, credit risk, and collateral and margin requirements. [#SRC:6112097d-0f5d-40e8-9a64-1aa7b6b520a6]

question: Where a Mining Reporting Entity has already made a disclosure under Rule 11.8.2 that included the required material assumptions and proportion breakdown for a Production Target, under what conditions may a later disclosure about the same Production Target omit that detailed Rule 11.8.2 information, and what additional proximate statements are still required if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources or is based in part on an Exploration Target?
expected_answer: A subsequent disclosure about a Production Target can omit the detailed information that would otherwise be required (such as the material economic and other assumptions and the proportion breakdown across reserves/resources/Exploration Target) only if it is framed as a follow-on to an earlier Rule 11.8.2 disclosure that itself contained those elements. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] To rely on that streamlined approach, the later disclosure must (i) point back to the earlier disclosure that complied with the detailed requirements, and (ii) expressly confirm that the material assumptions used for the Production Target continue to apply and have not materially changed. question: For an Authorised Person dealing with a Retail Client in OTC Leveraged Products, how do the rules combine to (i) restrict offering/advising/arranging until an assessment is completed and (ii) require when that assessment must be reassessed, including the trigger for reassessment before the annual cycle?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person may not offer OTC Leveraged Products to a Retail Client, nor provide advice or make arrangements for that Retail Client relating to OTC Leveraged Products, unless the Authorised Person has first completed an assessment of the Retail Client. [#TGT:be7639eb-37d0-4a64-80e4-a7694dd68cc0] That initial assessment must cover the Retail Client’s skill, experience, knowledge, financial resources and risk tolerance, and it must be sufficient for the Authorised Person to reasonably conclude both that the Retail Client can understand the potential risk of loss and that the Retail Client has liquid financial resources adequate to absorb potential losses from trading in OTC Leveraged Products. [#TGT:be7639eb-37d0-4a64-80e4-a7694dd68cc0] Once the assessment required by Rule 23.5.1 has been completed, it is not a one-off exercise: it must be reassessed by an Authorised Person at least annually. [#SRC:98b97356-14ec-44f8-9af4-96ffa1211a76] In addition, if there is any material change in the Retail Client’s financial situation or risk tolerance before the annual reassessment date, the Authorised Person must reassess at that earlier point rather than waiting for the annual cycle. [#SRC:98b97356-14ec-44f8-9af4-96ffa1211a76]

question: When a person is compelled to attend an interview under section 206, what notice must be given before the interview, and what grounds are expressly not a reasonable excuse for refusing to answer questions or provide information/documents under the related requirements?
expected_answer: A person who is required to attend an interview must first be given written notice requiring their attendance to answer questions at that interview. [#SRC:4d708250-cc2d-408e-9e2f-d77689864eda] Once a requirement to answer questions (and, where applicable, to permit inspection/copying or to give/produce information or a Document) is made under sections 201, 203, or 206(1)(a), (b), (c) and (e), the person cannot treat certain concerns as a “reasonable excuse” for refusing or failing to comply. [#TGT:4a2d4419-4e18-431a-9f52-59dae76a79ab] In particular, the person is not entitled to refuse or fail to answer questions on the basis that the answers may incriminate them, make them liable for a penalty, or might reveal a communication made in confidence, with the confidentiality point being expressly subject to section 209(6). [#SRC:4d708250-cc2d-408e-9e2f-d77689864eda] The same types of grounds—tending to incriminate the person or revealing a communication made in confidence (again subject to section 209(6))—are also stated not to be a reasonable excuse for refusing or failing to permit inspection/copying of information or a Document, or to give/produce (or procure the giving/production of) information or a Document, when those obligations arise under the specified sections. [#TGT:4a2d4419-4e18-431a-9f52-59dae76a79ab]
