question: When assessing whether Behaviour that involves effecting transactions or orders to trade (other than for legitimate reasons and in conformity with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market) has secured the price of a Financial Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity at an abnormal or artificial level, what specific indicators is the Regulator likely to consider to determine whether the conduct creates, or is likely to create, an artificial price?
expected_answer: Where Behaviour involves effecting transactions or orders to trade other than for legitimate reasons and in conformity with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market, it can be problematic if it secures the price of a Financial Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity at an abnormal or artificial level. [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f] In determining whether the conduct creates, or is likely to create, an artificial price, the Regulator is likely to evaluate concrete indicators tied to the person’s relationship to the instrument and observable price dynamics. [#SRC:96c3bd3c-9315-4058-adc7-295da9439bb1] Key indicators the Regulator is likely to take into account include: [#SRC:96c3bd3c-9315-4058-adc7-295da9439bb1] - The extent to which the person had a direct or indirect interest in the price or value of the relevant Financial Instrument, Accepted Virtual Asset or Accepted Spot Commodity. [#SRC:96c3bd3c-9315-4058-adc7-295da9439bb1] - Whether price, rate, or option-volatility movements (and the volatility of those factors) for the relevant product are outside their normal intra-day, daily, weekly, or monthly range. [#SRC:96c3bd3c-9315-4058-adc7-295da9439bb1] - Whether the person has successively and consistently increased or decreased their bid, Offer, or the price paid for the relevant product. [#SRC:96c3bd3c-9315-4058-adc7-295da9439bb1] These indicators help connect the transaction/order Behaviour to whether it is securing an abnormal or artificial price level rather than reflecting legitimate trading consistent with Accepted Market Practices. [#TGT:e14e3ec9-c8a6-4747-a88e-b60c3395238f]

debug_context.source_text: Factors relating to creating an artificial price. In considering whether or not conduct creates, or is likely to create, an artificial price under section 92(4)(b), the Regulator is likely to take into account factors such as: (a) the extent to which the person had a direct or indirect interest in the price or value of the Financial Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity; (b) the extent to which price, rate or option volatility movements, and the volatility of these factors for the Financial Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity in question, are outside their normal intra-day, daily, weekly or monthly range; or (c) whether a person has successively and consistently increased or decreased his bid, Offer or the price he has paid for a Financial Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity.
debug_context.target_text: The third is where the Behaviour consists of effecting transactions or orders to trade (otherwise than for legitimate reasons and in conformity with Accepted Market Practices on the relevant market) which— (a) give, or are likely to give, a false or misleading impression as to the supply of, or demand for, or as to the price of, one or more Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities; or (b) secure the price of one or more such instruments at an abnormal or artificial level.

question: Under what conditions may a Fund Manager of a Domestic Fund also perform fund administration for the Fund, and what risk-management considerations must the Fund Manager ensure are addressed in that scenario, taking into account the role of Fund Administrators and Eligible Custodians (and, where appointed, prime brokers)?
expected_answer: A Fund Manager of a Domestic Fund may be able to carry out fund administration for the Fund only where the Fund’s risk management and portfolio functions are adequately separated. [#SRC:5cba2a1e-1340-4401-a5c7-23c937abe4fc] In that same operating model, the Fund Manager must still ensure that the risks inherent in the operation of the Fund are adequately addressed, and must do so with due regard to the nature of the strategies and investment process it employs and to the role of Fund Administrators and Eligible Custodians and, where appointed, prime brokers. [#TGT:b6eb6967-279e-4da2-9b77-1f703f2597f7] Practically, this means the Fund Manager should (i) confirm and maintain the separation between risk management and portfolio functions as the condition that enables it to perform administration, and (ii) structure its risk-management approach so it reflects both how the Fund is managed (strategies and investment process) and how key service providers contribute to the Fund’s operation. [#SRC:5cba2a1e-1340-4401-a5c7-23c937abe4fc] [#TGT:b6eb6967-279e-4da2-9b77-1f703f2597f7] The requirement to address operational risks applies even if the Fund Manager itself is acting as the Fund Administrator, so the Fund Manager must explicitly consider that role alongside Eligible Custodians and any appointed prime brokers when ensuring risks are adequately addressed. [#TGT:b6eb6967-279e-4da2-9b77-1f703f2597f7]

expected_answer: A Fund Manager of a Domestic Fund can only be in a position to perform fund administration for the Fund when the Fund’s risk management and portfolio functions are adequately separated. [#TGT:b6eb6967-279e-4da2-9b77-1f703f2597f7] When doing this, the Fund Manager must take into account (1) the nature of the strategies and investment process it uses and (2) the role played by Fund Administrators and Eligible Custodians and, if they are appointed, prime brokers. [#TGT:b6eb6967-279e-4da2-9b77-1f703f2597f7] Put together, the setup requirement (separating risk management from portfolio functions) is what allows the Fund Manager to take on administration, but it does not remove the duty to actively address operational risks in a way that matches how the Fund is run and how these service-provider roles fit into the Fund’s operation. [#SRC:5cba2a1e-1340-4401-a5c7-23c937abe4fc] [#TGT:b6eb6967-279e-4da2-9b77-1f703f2597f7] This means the Fund Manager should treat the administration role—whether performed internally or by others—as part of the overall risk picture it must manage. [#TGT:b6eb6967-279e-4da2-9b77-1f703f2597f7]

question: When seeking authorisation under the RegLab, how should an applicant align its own proposed test parameters and control boundaries with the Regulator’s blank-sheet measures (including client/exposure limits and geographical restrictions) that may be imposed when Rules are waived or modified for a FinTech Participant?
expected_answer: An applicant should treat its authorisation submission as needing to both (i) define how it will run the test and (ii) accommodate the Regulator’s ability to constrain the test’s scope and client impact when Rules are waived or modified for the FinTech Participant under the RegLab. [#SRC:7fae4f73-f02a-415f-88c1-6b1aa4936e19] In practice, the applicant must be able to clearly define the FinTech Proposal’s test parameters and control boundaries (along with key milestones and intended outcomes), and those definitions should be framed so they can operate within client and exposure limits and any boundaries/geographical restrictions the Regulator sets to control client impact and protect clients’ interests. [#TGT:40054dfa-768b-4ece-ac91-c15c83f4f16d] [#SRC:7fae4f73-f02a-415f-88c1-6b1aa4936e19] The applicant should also propose an acceptable reporting schedule for updates on development and testing, which supports oversight of compliance with any imposed limits or restrictions during the test. [#TGT:40054dfa-768b-4ece-ac91-c15c83f4f16d] Finally, because the Regulator may prescribe conditions and/or limitations as part of authorisation, the applicant should present its test design and controls in a way that can be adjusted to meet those prescribed constraints while continuing to satisfy applicable ADGM Regulations and Rules. [#TGT:40054dfa-768b-4ece-ac91-c15c83f4f16d] [#SRC:7fae4f73-f02a-415f-88c1-6b1aa4936e19]

question: When a Relevant Person is deciding whether to give a customer a low-risk rating under 7.1.1(1) based on geographical or jurisdictional risk factors, which types of publications qualify as “credible sources” for identifying countries with effective AML systems or FATF-consistent requirements, and which organisations may issue those publications?
expected_answer: In a low-risk rating decision under 7.1.1(1), a Relevant Person may rely on “credible sources” when evaluating geographical and jurisdictional risk factors, such as whether countries are identified as having effective systems to counter money laundering, low levels of corruption or other criminal activity, or have been assessed as having AML requirements consistent with and effectively implementing the FATF Recommendations. [#TGT:644bee29-fba0-448c-a5c0-c58e957e6e90] For the purpose of determining what counts as a “credible source” in this context, credible sources include (without limitation) mutual evaluations, detailed assessment reports, and follow-up reports. [#SRC:0ab1cb10-020d-43a9-94ea-fd6de14133ff] Those reports may be issued by FATF, the IMF, the World Bank, the OECD, and other International Organisations. [#SRC:0ab1cb10-020d-43a9-94ea-fd6de14133ff] Accordingly, when the Relevant Person is using the geographic/jurisdictional indicators in paragraph (c) to support a low-risk rating, it should ensure the country conclusions it relies on are drawn from one or more of these report types and issuers, rather than from unspecified or informal materials. [#TGT:644bee29-fba0-448c-a5c0-c58e957e6e90] This approach aligns the “credible sources” concept with the specific kinds of assessments and follow-ups produced by the listed international bodies. [#SRC:0ab1cb10-020d-43a9-94ea-fd6de14133ff]

debug_context.target_text: When undertaking a risk-based assessment of a customer and considering whether or not to assign a low-risk rating under ‎7.1.1(1), a Relevant Person must take into account all relevant risk factors that would reasonably apply to the customer, including but not limited to: (a) customer risk factors, including whether the customer is: (i) a public body or a publicly owned enterprise; (ii) resident, established, registered or conducts business in a geographical area or jurisdiction of lower risk (as set out in paragraph (c)); (iii) an Authorised Person or Recognised Body; (iv) a Regulated Financial Institution that is subject to regulation and supervision, including AML/TFS regulation and supervision, in a jurisdiction with AML/TFS regulations that are equivalent to the standards set out in the FATF Recommendations; (v) a Subsidiary of a Regulated Financial Institution referred to in (iv), if the law that applies to the Parent ensures that the Subsidiary also observes the same AML/TFS standards as its Parent; (vi) a company whose Securities are listed by the Regulator, another Financial Services Regulator or a Regulated Exchange, which is subject to disclosure obligations broadly equivalent to those set out in the Market Rules; (vii) a law firm, notary firm or other legal business that carries on its business in the ADGM; (viii) an accounting firm, insolvency firm, auditor or other audit firm that carries on its business in the ADGM; (b) product, service, transaction or delivery channel risk factors, including whether the product or service is: (i) a Contract of Insurance which is non-life insurance; (ii) a Contract of Insurance which is a life insurance product with no investment return or redemption or surrender value; (iii) an insurance policy for a pension scheme that does not provide for an early surrender option, and cannot be used as collateral; (iv) a pension, superannuation or similar scheme that satisfies the following conditions: (A) the scheme provides retirement benefits to employees; (B) contributions to the scheme are made by way of deductions from wages; and (C) the scheme rules do not permit the assignment of a member’s interest under the scheme; (v) a product where the risks of money laundering are adequately managed by other factors such as transaction limits or transparency of ownership; and (c) geographical and jurisdictional risk factors, including whether a country or countries: (i) are identified by credible sources as having effective systems to counter money laundering; (ii) are identified by credible sources as having a low level of corruption or other criminal activity, such as terrorism, money laundering, or the production and supply of illicit drugs; (iii) have been assessed by credible sources, as having: (A) requirements to counter money laundering that are consistent with the FATF Recommendations; and (B) effectively implement FATF Recommendations.

question: For an Authorised Person in any Category, how do the Rules allocate which provisions apply depending on whether it operates as a Branch or as a Domestic Firm, and what continuous capital-resources standard must be met when the Authorised Person operates as a Domestic Firm?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person in any Category must determine which specific Rules apply by reference to whether it is operating as a Branch or as a Domestic Firm, and that classification then drives the applicable obligations. [#SRC:125f72ef-4896-42ec-90ce-f01b83fa15b6] If the Authorised Person is operating as a Branch, the allocation in this Section indicates that Rule 3.2.2 is the relevant provision for that operating model. [#SRC:125f72ef-4896-42ec-90ce-f01b83fa15b6] If instead the Authorised Person is operating as a Domestic Firm, the allocation in this Section indicates that Rules 3.2.3 to 3.2.5 apply to that operating model. [#SRC:125f72ef-4896-42ec-90ce-f01b83fa15b6] In addition to that allocation, where the Authorised Person is a Domestic Firm it must maintain adequate capital resources on a continuous basis: at all times, its Capital Resources must be equal to or greater than the amount of its Capital Requirement. [#TGT:fc38613a-248b-40ef-9af7-6cd69a5b516e] This “at all times” condition is a standing requirement for Domestic Firms and therefore applies continuously for so long as the Authorised Person is operating as a Domestic Firm under the Section’s allocation. [#TGT:fc38613a-248b-40ef-9af7-6cd69a5b516e] [#SRC:125f72ef-4896-42ec-90ce-f01b83fa15b6]

debug_context.source_text: In this Section the Rules apply to an Authorised Person in any Category as follows: (a) Rule 3.2.2 applies to an Authorised Person operating as a Branch; and (b) Rules 3.2.3 to 3.2.5 apply to an Authorised Person operating as a Domestic Firm.
debug_context.target_text: Domestic Firms – adequate capital resources. An Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm must have, at all times, Capital Resources which equal or exceed the amount of its Capital Requirement.

[#SRC:125f72ef-4896-42ec-90ce-f01b83fa15b6] When the Authorised Person operates as a Domestic Firm, the Section specifies that Rules 3.2.3 to 3.2.5 apply to it in that capacity. [#SRC:125f72ef-4896-42ec-90ce-f01b83fa15b6] For the Domestic Firm operating model, there is also an ongoing capital standard: the Authorised Person must have Capital Resources that are at least equal to its Capital Requirement, and it must meet that test at all times. [#TGT:fc38613a-248b-40ef-9af7-6cd69a5b516e] This means the continuous “at all times” capital-resources threshold is tied to the Domestic Firm status identified in the Section’s allocation of Rules. question: When a Reporting Entity is preparing a chapter 10 financial disclosure document that is scheduled for later release, under what circumstances may it refrain from early disclosure, and when must it instead make an immediate disclosure under Rule 7.2.1—taking into account both the Listing Authority’s expectations and the fact that Rule 7.2.1 operates closely with periodic/financial disclosure obligations and broader general disclosure regimes (e.g., FSMR and Prospectus Offer documents)?
expected_answer: A Reporting Entity may generally avoid disclosing information early in a document that is intended to be released on a scheduled date, but only where the Listing Authority’s stated conditions for that approach are satisfied; otherwise, Rule 7.2.1 can require immediate disclosure even while the document is still being prepared. [#SRC:e8a0c0b9-00fb-491e-988e-ef77853ed914] This interaction is particularly relevant because Rule 7.2.1 is described as operating closely with periodic/financial disclosure obligations in chapter 10 and also alongside broader general disclosure obligations (including regimes such as FSMR and disclosure documents like Prospectus Offer documents and bidders/targets statements). [#TGT:05f69230-1c8e-4359-98fe-2f92e40b5e8f] In practice, the Listing Authority does not generally expect early disclosure of information that will appear in the scheduled document if all limbs in Rule 7.2.2 are met, or if the Listing Authority does not view disclosure as necessary under Rule 7.5.1(b) to avoid a false market. [#SRC:e8a0c0b9-00fb-491e-988e-ef77853ed914] However, during preparation of a chapter 10 financial disclosure, Inside Information may emerge that should be disclosed immediately under Rule 7.2.1, notwithstanding the planned later release of the chapter 10 document. [#SRC:e8a0c0b9-00fb-491e-988e-ef77853ed914] Because Rule 7.2.1 is framed as closely integrated with chapter 10 and general disclosure regimes, the Reporting Entity should treat the continuous disclosure trigger as capable of overriding the normal timing of periodic or other disclosure documents when Inside Information comes to light. [#TGT:05f69230-1c8e-4359-98fe-2f92e40b5e8f]

There will be cases, however, where in the course of preparing, for example, a financial disclosure required under chapter 10 of the Rules, Inside Information may come to light that ought to immediately Disclosed under Rule 7.2.1.

question: For a Captive Insurer that is not a Cell Company and carries on Long-Term Insurance Business that must be attributed to a Long-Term Insurance Fund under Rule 8.2, how do the Captive Insurer’s options (establishing funds or notifying the Regulator that it is deemed a single fund) interact with the Regulator’s residual discretion to direct the establishment of one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds for that business or any part of it?
expected_answer: A Captive Insurer that is not a Cell Company and carries on Long-Term Insurance Business that must be attributed to a Long-Term Insurance Fund under Rule 8.2 has a baseline compliance choice: it must either set up one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds or provide a written notice to the Regulator stating that the Captive Insurer is deemed to be a single Long-Term Insurance Fund. [#TGT:510a1a41-dd30-47bf-b331-893b2b70a469] However, that choice does not eliminate the Regulator’s ability to require fund establishment, because the Regulator retains residual discretion to direct that a Captive Insurer conducting Long-Term Insurance Business establish one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds for its Long-Term Insurance Business or for any part of that business. [#SRC:f6bf482b-33ba-4cf1-9375-26e6bfeb7ca7] In practice, this means the Captive Insurer can comply initially by notifying the Regulator that it is deemed a single fund, but the Regulator may still direct the Captive Insurer to establish one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds (including potentially for only part of the Long-Term Insurance Business). [#TGT:510a1a41-dd30-47bf-b331-893b2b70a469] [#SRC:f6bf482b-33ba-4cf1-9375-26e6bfeb7ca7] Accordingly, the Captive Insurer should treat the written-notice route as a permitted default position, while recognizing that the Regulator can override that position by directing the creation of one or more funds for the relevant business scope. [#TGT:510a1a41-dd30-47bf-b331-893b2b70a469] [#SRC:f6bf482b-33ba-4cf1-9375-26e6bfeb7ca7]

question: Under what conditions may an Authorised Person classify a Person as a Market Counterparty, and what specific pre-classification notification and response-period checks must be completed before classifying a Professional Client as a Market Counterparty for a particular Regulated Activity or Transaction (or for all Regulated Activities and Transactions)?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person may classify a Person as a Market Counterparty only where the Person meets the threshold status and the additional rule conditions, and the Authorised Person has completed the required pre-classification notice-and-response steps for the relevant scope of activities or transactions. [#SRC:fea099c3-b4b0-4ab5-8ad8-760375f23413] Specifically, the Person must qualify as a “deemed” Professional Client in accordance with Rule 2.4.2, and the requirements in Rule 2.5(b) must have been met. [#SRC:fea099c3-b4b0-4ab5-8ad8-760375f23413] In addition, before classifying a Professional Client as a Market Counterparty, the Authorised Person must ensure the Person has been provided with a prior written notification stating the intended classification as a Market Counterparty, and that notice must relate either to a particular Regulated Activity or Transaction or to all Regulated Activities and Transactions. [#TGT:8ae4e16d-21d1-4180-a88b-83808f0b29b3] The Authorised Person must also confirm that the Person has not asked to be classified otherwise within the period specified in that notice, meaning the classification should not proceed if such a request is made during the stated period. [#TGT:8ae4e16d-21d1-4180-a88b-83808f0b29b3]

question: When an Authorised Person takes out and maintains professional indemnity insurance cover that is appropriate to its nature, size, complexity and risk profile, what specific features should the insurance contract include regarding the Insurer and the scope of claims and legal costs, and how do the annual submission and notification duties to the Regulator apply to that cover?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must maintain professional indemnity insurance that fits the nature, size, complexity and risk profile of its business, and that same cover should be structured as a contract placed with a reputable and well capitalised Insurer and drafted to address the Authorised Person’s potential liabilities and related legal costs. [#TGT:c51237c3-d7ca-4ab3-b09b-f6382e6e7a0b] [#SRC:3c5ec7af-6f4a-41d7-988c-13494992bc71] In practical terms, the contract should include cover for claims where the Authorised Person may be liable due to the conduct of itself and its Employees, and it should also provide appropriate cover for legal costs that arise from a claim. [#SRC:3c5ec7af-6f4a-41d7-988c-13494992bc71] In addition to maintaining the cover, the Authorised Person must, at least once each year, give the Regulator a copy of the insurance cover for the next 12 months and be able to show that the cover is adequate against the same nature/size/complexity/risk-profile benchmark. [#TGT:c51237c3-d7ca-4ab3-b09b-f6382e6e7a0b] The Authorised Person must also notify the Regulator of any material changes to that cover, including changes to the level of cover and events such as renewal or termination. [#TGT:c51237c3-d7ca-4ab3-b09b-f6382e6e7a0b]

question: For investments made using Musharaka or Mudaraba contracts where commodities are the underlying assets, how must an Authorised Person calculate its Commodities Risk Capital Requirement, and how does that calculation method interact with the requirement for Category 1, 2 or 5 firms to calculate the requirement for Trading Book and Non Trading Book commodity positions using either an approved internal Market Risk model or the Section A6.5 rules?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person that makes investments using Musharaka or Mudaraba contracts with commodities as the underlying assets must determine its Commodities Risk Capital Requirement by following PRU Rule 5.7.1. [#SRC:bbd0d60b-0179-4756-8de1-848cacc7db4e] Where that same Authorised Person is in Category 1, 2 or 5, it must also ensure that its Commodities Risk Capital Requirement is calculated for both Trading Book and Non Trading Book commodity positions using one of the two permitted approaches: either an internal Market Risk model that has been approved by the Regulator for this specific purpose, or the rules in Section A6.5. [#TGT:e93a335b-caf1-4776-842f-11bd1e28aefe] In practice, this means the firm must (i) identify that the relevant exposures arise from Musharaka or Mudaraba investments with commodity underlyings, triggering the PRU Rule 5.7.1 basis, and (ii) for Category 1, 2 or 5, apply that calculation across both Trading Book and Non Trading Book commodity positions through either the approved internal model route or the Section A6.5 route. [#SRC:bbd0d60b-0179-4756-8de1-848cacc7db4e] [#TGT:e93a335b-caf1-4776-842f-11bd1e28aefe]

question: How does the FSRA determine whether a digital/virtual token offering is regulated as a Security, and how does that case-by-case assessment relate to the Regulator’s ability to deem a non-Security investment to be a Security by written notice (including any conditions attached)?
expected_answer: A digital/virtual token offering can be treated as regulated when the FSRA concludes, after a token-specific review, that the token has the economic and legal attributes of a Security; in that situation the FSRA treats the token as a “Digital Security” and therefore as a Security under the relevant FSMR provision. [#SRC:ad5b9e34-f66a-4e3f-8373-a85bdc331124] This assessment is explicitly conducted case by case, reflecting the FSRA’s approach to conventional Securities and acknowledging that the classification may not be obvious without FSRA review, with investor protection cited as a reason for this approach. [#SRC:ad5b9e34-f66a-4e3f-8373-a85bdc331124] In parallel, the Regulator has an express power to issue a written notice that deems an investment that is not a Security to be a Security for the purposes of the Regulations and the Rules made under them. [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c] That written notice power may be exercised on terms and conditions the Regulator considers appropriate, which provides a mechanism to formalize or tailor the regulatory treatment when applying the Regulations and Rules. [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c] Read together, the FSRA’s case-by-case token characterization supplies the substantive basis for treating a token as a Security, while the Regulator’s written-notice deeming power supplies an explicit instrument (with conditions) for applying the Regulations and Rules to an investment treated as a Security. [#SRC:ad5b9e34-f66a-4e3f-8373-a85bdc331124] [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c]

debug_context.source_text: REGULATORY TREATMENT OF DIGITAL SECURITIES As set out in the ICO Guidance, the FSRA’s assessment of whether an offering of a digital/virtual token is regulated under FSMR is conducted on a case-by-case basis (in keeping with FSRA’s treatment of ‘conventional’ Securities). If a digital/virtual token being offered is assessed to exhibit the (economic and legal) features and characteristics of a Security, the FSRA will deem the digital/virtual token (being a “Digital Security”) as a Security pursuant to Section 58(2)(b) of FSMR. This approach has been taken by the FSRA to ensure the protection of investors, noting that while a Digital Security may have the characteristics of a Security, this position is not always clear and accordingly requires review by the FSRA.
debug_context.target_text: Without limiting the generality of its powers, the Regulator may, by written notice— (a) exclude the application of any requirements; or (b) deem any investment which is not a Security to be a Security for the purposes of these Regulations and the Rules made under these Regulations; subject to such terms and conditions as it may consider appropriate.

question: If a digital/virtual token doesn’t clearly look like a Security, what does the FSRA do to decide whether it will be regulated, and what extra step can the Regulator take by written notice to treat an investment as a Security (and with what kind of limits)?
expected_answer: When it is unclear whether a digital/virtual token should be treated like a Security, the FSRA does not apply a one-size-fits-all label; instead, it reviews the specific offering on a case-by-case basis, consistent with how it handles conventional Securities. [#SRC:ad5b9e34-f66a-4e3f-8373-a85bdc331124] If, after that review, the token is found to have the economic and legal features and characteristics of a Security, the FSRA will treat the token as a “Digital Security” and therefore as a Security under the cited FSMR provision. [#SRC:ad5b9e34-f66a-4e3f-8373-a85bdc331124] The FSRA explains that this approach supports investor protection and is needed because the Security-like nature of a Digital Security is not always obvious without FSRA review. [#SRC:ad5b9e34-f66a-4e3f-8373-a85bdc331124] Separately, the Regulator can take an additional formal step: it may issue a written notice that deems an investment that is not a Security to be a Security for the purposes of the Regulations and the Rules made under them. [#TGT:95497208-1e94-4b51-8ff3-d9e77f64177c] That notice can be made subject to terms and conditions the Regulator considers appropriate, which means the deeming can come with tailored limits or requirements. question: When compiling the document in the Resolution Pack that identifies individuals critical or important to operational functions, which specific roles related to Client Money, Relevant Money and Safe Custody Assets must be treated as examples of such individuals, and how must their responsibilities be described in that Resolution Pack document?
expected_answer: In the Resolution Pack, the Authorised Person must include a document that identifies all senior manager, directors and other individuals (whether within the Authorised Person or elsewhere) who are critical or important to operational functions connected to the chapter’s obligations, and it must also state the nature of each person’s responsibility. [#TGT:9a2f70fe-ca63-4b72-a573-f428b37a1a24] For the purpose of that identification requirement, examples of individuals who are critical or important include (i) those needed to perform both internal and external reconciliations for Client Money, Relevant Money and Safe Custody Assets, and (ii) those responsible for client documentation that involves Client Money, Relevant Money and Safe Custody Assets. [#SRC:ad131b2c-da04-4e5f-bbc4-045f5ec9fcf1] Accordingly, the Resolution Pack’s “critical individuals” document should not only list the relevant people, but should describe their responsibilities in a way that makes clear whether they carry out the internal/external reconciliation functions and/or oversee the relevant client documentation functions, including where those individuals sit outside the Authorised Person. [#TGT:9a2f70fe-ca63-4b72-a573-f428b37a1a24] [#SRC:ad131b2c-da04-4e5f-bbc4-045f5ec9fcf1]

question: How should a firm that is an Authorised Person align its risk management systems and controls with GEN 3.3.4, and what additional FCA review activity may occur beyond the FCA’s own assessment when evaluating how the firm’s risks affect regulatory objectives?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person should design and operate risk management systems and controls so they collectively enable the firm to identify, assess, mitigate, control, and monitor its risks, and the firm must also ensure those systems provide the practical means to do so in line with GEN 3.3.4. [#TGT:6f83c3c2-989d-47c2-952e-b1d8c7fb6c21] [#SRC:f5c0b126-6b54-4fe9-9522-52952b6adad1] In practice, this means the firm’s framework should not only exist on paper but should function as an end-to-end capability for risk identification through ongoing monitoring and control, with controls and mitigation programmes that address the risks the firm faces. [#SRC:f5c0b126-6b54-4fe9-9522-52952b6adad1] Beyond the FCA undertaking its own assessment of the firm, the FCA may also review the firm’s internal risk self-assessment as part of its supervisory evaluation. [#SRC:f5c0b126-6b54-4fe9-9522-52952b6adad1] When doing so, the FCA may determine (based on that internal self-assessment and other information) how each risk impacts the FCA’s objectives, the likelihood of the risk occurring, and the nature of the controls and mitigation programmes the firm has in place. [#SRC:f5c0b126-6b54-4fe9-9522-52952b6adad1] Accordingly, the firm should ensure its internal self-assessment is consistent with, and evidences, the operation of the required systems and controls. [#TGT:6f83c3c2-989d-47c2-952e-b1d8c7fb6c21] [#SRC:f5c0b126-6b54-4fe9-9522-52952b6adad1]

expected_answer: An Authorised Person needs to set up and keep risk management systems and controls that let it identify, assess, mitigate, control, and monitor its risks. question: For an applicant intending to carry on a Regulated Activity where the client is a Retail Client under GEN 5.2.3, what specific systems, controls, and related policies/procedures must an Authorised Person demonstrate when applying for a Financial Services Permission to carry on that Regulated Activity with or for a Retail Client?
expected_answer: An applicant in scope of GEN 5.2.3 (i.e., intending to carry on a Regulated Activity where the client is a Retail Client) must, when it is an Authorised Person applying for a Financial Services Permission to carry on that Regulated Activity with or for a Retail Client, be able to show that it meets the specified “adequate systems and controls” requirements. [#SRC:1ad61409-a8d2-40b0-82f6-0ab30250c45a] [#TGT:b01b34df-ae4f-47a0-950f-31329255a884] In practical terms, the application should evidence all of the following elements: - Adequate systems and controls for carrying on Regulated Activities with or for a Retail Client. [#TGT:b01b34df-ae4f-47a0-950f-31329255a884] - Adequate systems and controls, including policies and procedures, designed to ensure compliance with the COBS requirements that are relevant to Retail Clients. [#TGT:b01b34df-ae4f-47a0-950f-31329255a884] - Adequate systems and controls to ensure Employees remain competent and capable to perform assigned functions, with particular focus on functions involving dealing with Retail Clients. [#TGT:b01b34df-ae4f-47a0-950f-31329255a884] - Adequate Complaints handling policies and procedures. [#TGT:b01b34df-ae4f-47a0-950f-31329255a884] These items collectively describe the requirements that GEN 5.2.3 points to for an applicant in the Retail Client context, and they are framed as conditions for the Financial Services Permission application by an Authorised Person. [#SRC:1ad61409-a8d2-40b0-82f6-0ab30250c45a] [#TGT:b01b34df-ae4f-47a0-950f-31329255a884]

question: For an Authorised Person that has established a branch outside ADGM from which it conducts Regulated Activities, how is the annual supervision fee determined and paid, and in what circumstance may the Regulator also charge a supplementary fee linked to the branch’s jurisdictional regulatory cooperation arrangements?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person that has established a branch outside ADGM and conducts Regulated Activities from that branch is required to pay the Regulator an annual supervision fee calculated as 50% of the highest annual supervision fee applicable to the Regulated Activities it undertakes from the branch. [#TGT:47c0063b-14dc-43a0-8e44-7b5238750a0c] For the first period, the initial supervision fee is not necessarily a full-year amount; it must be prorated and then paid following the approach specified in Rule 1.2.2(a). [#TGT:47c0063b-14dc-43a0-8e44-7b5238750a0c] In addition to these supervision-fee obligations for the outside-ADGM branch, the Regulator may impose a supplementary fee where the proposed branch would operate in a jurisdiction that lacks an adequate memorandum of understanding between the Regulator and the relevant Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator for that jurisdiction. [#SRC:a2ed572d-bcf6-4660-b11b-d8db3a7aad92] This supplementary fee is described as being in addition to the fees specified in Rule 7.1.1 and 7.1.2, and it is triggered by the absence of adequate cross-regulator cooperation arrangements for the branch’s jurisdiction. [#SRC:a2ed572d-bcf6-4660-b11b-d8db3a7aad92]

debug_context.source_text: The Regulator may charge a supplementary fee in addition to the fees specified in Rule 7.1.1 and 7.1.2 where the proposed branch would operate in a jurisdiction where there is no adequate memorandum of understanding in place between the Regulator and the relevant Non-ADGM Financial Services Regulator in that jurisdiction.
debug_context.target_text: An Authorised Person that has established a branch outside ADGM from which it conducts Regulated Activities must pay to the Regulator an annual supervision fee equal to 50% of the highest annual supervision fee for those Regulated Activities it undertakes from the branch. The initial supervision fee due shall be prorated and paid in accordance with Rule 1.2.2(a).

question: How should a Recognised Body structure its arrangements so that its monitoring and enforcement of compliance with its rules is complemented by procedures for handling complaints about Persons using its facilities and appeals against the Recognised Body’s decisions, including where the Recognised Body is a Recognised Investment Exchange monitoring transactions to detect disorderly trading conditions or Market Abuse?
expected_answer: A Recognised Body should implement a single, coherent set of arrangements that both (i) monitors and enforces compliance with its rules and (ii) provides formal procedures to address complaints and appeals arising from use of its facilities and its decision-making. [#TGT:2ab875a8-156c-4fce-8482-013f133be759] The monitoring and enforcement component must be effective, and where the Recognised Body is a Recognised Investment Exchange it must include effective transaction monitoring designed to identify disorderly trading conditions or Market Abuse. [#TGT:2ab875a8-156c-4fce-8482-013f133be759] In parallel, the arrangements must include procedures to investigate complaints made to the Recognised Body about the conduct of Persons when they are using the Recognised Body’s facilities. [#SRC:e5494e74-1e44-4fa9-8687-49f899851a47] The arrangements must also include procedures that ensure appeals against decisions of the Recognised Body are resolved in a manner that is fair, independent, and impartial. [#SRC:e5494e74-1e44-4fa9-8687-49f899851a47] Taken together, this means the Recognised Body’s compliance oversight (including transaction monitoring for a Recognised Investment Exchange) should be complemented by complaint-investigation and appeal-resolution processes so that issues detected through monitoring or raised by users can be examined and, where relevant, challenged through an impartial appeal mechanism. [#TGT:2ab875a8-156c-4fce-8482-013f133be759] [#SRC:e5494e74-1e44-4fa9-8687-49f899851a47]

[#TGT:2ab875a8-156c-4fce-8482-013f133be759] Specifically, it must have effective arrangements to monitor and enforce compliance with its rules; and if it is a Recognised Investment Exchange, those arrangements must include effective monitoring of transactions to identify disorderly trading conditions or Market Abuse. question: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses forecast financial information under Rule 11.9.1 that is derived from a Production Target, what specific Production Target-related content must be carried into the Rule 11.9.1 disclosure, and what additional Production Target disclosure elements are required under Rule 11.8.2 (including any required statements where forecast commodity prices or Inferred Mineral Resources are involved)?
expected_answer: A Rule 11.9.1 disclosure of forecast financial information must incorporate the underlying Production Target and, specifically, must include that Production Target together with all the information that Rule 11.8.3 requires for the Production Target. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] In addition, the Production Target disclosure framework in Rule 11.8.2 requires detailed content about how the Production Target was determined, which becomes relevant because the forecast financial information is expressly derived from that Production Target. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] In practice, the Production Target disclosure must cover the assumptions used to determine the Production Target, including all material economic assumptions, or (if treated as commercially sensitive) a sensitivity statement plus an explanation of the methodology used to determine those economic assumptions, and all other material assumptions. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] If forecast commodity prices were used to determine the Production Target, the disclosure must also state that the forecast commodity pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] Where the Production Target is wholly or partly based on Inferred Mineral Resources (or partly on an Exploration Target), the disclosure must include the specified prominent, proximate cautionary statements and, for a wholly Inferred basis, additional explanation and a Technical Study prepared by or under the supervision of a named independent Competent Person(s). [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]

debug_context.source_text: A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include: (1) in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information: (a) all material economic assumptions employed; (b) if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and Guidance A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure. (c) all other material assumptions utilised. (2) the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).
debug_context.target_text: A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.8.2 must include: (1) in relation to the assumptions used to determine the Production Target: (a) all material economic assumptions employed; or (b) if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and Guidance A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure. (c) all other material assumptions utilised. (2) if forecast commodity prices have been used in the determination of the Production Target, a statement that such forecast commodity pricing was arrived at on reasonable grounds. (3) the proportions of the Production Target based on: (a) Probable Ore Reserves and Proved Ore Reserves; (b) Indicated Mineral Resources and Measured Mineral Resources; (c) Inferred Mineral Resources; and (d) an Exploration Target. (4) a statement that the respective proportions of Inferred Mineral Resources and the Exploration Target (if applicable) are not the determining factors in the viability of the Production Target and do not feature as a significant proportion in the early mine plan; (5) if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources: (a) an explanation as to why the Mining Reporting Entity believes it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources; (b) the level of confidence in relation to which the Inferred Mineral Resources are estimated and the basis for that level of confidence; (c) a Technical Study of a sufficient level of confidence to support the Production Target, prepared by, or under the supervision of, a named independent Competent Person(s); and (d) an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that: “The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. Though further evaluation and/or exploration work is required to establish sufficient confidence that the production target will be met, there is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised. The mining reporting entity’s production target is based on its current expectation of future results or events, and should not be solely relied upon by investors when making investment decisions.” Guidance Any statement about a Production Target will be deemed to be misleading unless the person making the statement has reasonable grounds for making the statement. The Regulator considers that it is only under exceptional circumstances that a Mining Reporting Entity might form a view that it has reasonable grounds for a Production Target to be wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources. (6) if the Production Target is in part based on Inferred Mineral Resources, an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that: “The level of geological confidence associated with inferred mineral resources is low. There is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.” (7) if the Production Target is in part based on an Exploration Target: (a) a statement of the factors that lead the Mining Reporting Entity to believe that it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target based, in part, on an Exploration Target; and (b) an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that: “The potential quantity and grade of an Exploration Target is only conceptual in nature. There has been insufficient exploration to determine a Mineral Resource and there is no certainty that further exploration work will result in the determination of Mineral Resources or that the Production Target itself will be realised.”

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity is preparing a Rule 11.9.1 disclosure with forecast financial information and says some economic assumptions are commercially sensitive, what must it include about those assumptions, and how does that connect to the similar assumption disclosure required when it discloses the Production Target under Rule 11.8.2?
expected_answer: For forecast financial information disclosed under Rule 11.9.1, the Mining Reporting Entity must disclose all material economic assumptions used to determine that forecast information; if it considers those material economic assumptions commercially sensitive, it must say so and explain the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions, and it must also disclose all other material assumptions used. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] This requirement links directly to the Production Target disclosure because the Rule 11.9.1 disclosure must also include the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all information required by Rule 11.8.3). [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] Under Rule 11.8.2, when disclosing the Production Target itself, the Mining Reporting Entity must provide the same core assumption transparency: it must disclose all material economic assumptions used to determine the Production Target, or (if commercially sensitive) provide a statement that they are commercially sensitive and explain the methodology used to determine them, and it must disclose all other material assumptions used. [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a] As a result, when forecast financial information is built from a Production Target, the entity should ensure the commercially sensitive assumption treatment is consistent across both disclosures: the forecast-financial-information disclosure must contain the methodology explanation for sensitive economic assumptions, and the Production Target disclosure must do the same for the assumptions used to set the Production Target. [#SRC:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] [#TGT:8f759494-7a3a-4888-a07b-abac6b73113a]

There is no certainty that further evaluation and/or exploration work will result in the determination of indicated mineral resources or that the production target itself will be realised.” (7) if the Production Target is in part based on an Exploration Target: (a) a statement of the factors that lead the Mining Reporting Entity to believe that it has a reasonable basis for disclosing a Production Target based, in part, on an Exploration Target; and (b) an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement to the effect that: “The potential quantity and grade of an Exploration Target is only conceptual in nature. There has been insufficient exploration to determine a Mineral Resource and there is no certainty that further exploration work will result in the determination of Mineral Resources or that the Production Target itself will be realised.”

question: Where an Authorised Person is operating an MTF using Virtual Assets and wishes to also operate a Recognised Investment Exchange, how should the firm structure its authorisation/recognition so it can continue operating the MTF, and what is the compliance consequence for the MTF function once the Recognition Order includes the relevant stipulation?
expected_answer: To continue operating an MTF while also operating as a Recognised Investment Exchange, the firm must ensure that the Recognition Order expressly permits the additional MTF function, and it must manage the transition in status/permissions accordingly. An Authorised Person that is operating an MTF and seeks to also operate a Recognised Investment Exchange is required to relinquish its FSP upon obtaining the Recognition Order to operate as a Recognised Investment Exchange. [#SRC:16e6290e-4660-4e38-9618-89de6a251764] If the FSRA licenses the firm to carry out both activities (operating an MTF and operating a Recognised Investment Exchange), the Recognition Order should contain a stipulation reflecting that dual permission (referenced as being pursuant to MIR Rule 3.4.1). [#SRC:16e6290e-4660-4e38-9618-89de6a251764] In parallel, a Recognised Investment Exchange may only carry on the Regulated Activity of operating an MTF (or OTF) where its Recognition Order includes a stipulation permitting it to do so. [#TGT:8e498a69-8f0c-44c3-970c-58d870656388] Once that stipulation is present, the specific COBS rules on MTFs and OTFs apply to the MTF/OTF function, and they apply only to that function rather than to the Recognised Investment Exchange’s other activities. question: Where a Third Party Provider is permitted to make unilateral changes to the Governing Contract, what combined notice content and minimum advance delivery timing must it meet when proposing changes to the existing terms or to the information specified in Rule 20.2.2, including how Customer acceptance is treated and any termination right before the changes take effect?
expected_answer: When a Third Party Provider is allowed to make unilateral changes to the Governing Contract and proposes changes, it must both (i) deliver the proposed changes within the required lead time and (ii) include specific customer-facing statements about deemed acceptance and termination rights. [#SRC:e589a1c4-5c02-41c8-adbd-e32cae4d5468] [#TGT:29dd8b53-d149-4830-a218-06218e05b53f] For timing, proposed changes to either the existing terms of the Governing Contract or the information specified in Rule 20.2.2 must be provided to the Customer no later than two months before the date the changes are intended to take effect. [#TGT:29dd8b53-d149-4830-a218-06218e05b53f] For notice content, the Third Party Provider must inform the Customer that, unless the Customer notifies the Third Party Provider to the contrary before the proposed entry-into-force date, the Customer will be treated as having accepted the changes that were communicated under Rule 20.2.5. [#SRC:e589a1c4-5c02-41c8-adbd-e32cae4d5468] It must also inform the Customer that the Customer may terminate the Governing Contract without charge at any time before the proposed entry-into-force date. [#SRC:e589a1c4-5c02-41c8-adbd-e32cae4d5468]

If the Third Party Provider is allowed to make unilateral changes to the Governing Contract and proposes to make such changes, the Third Party Provider must inform the Customer that: (a) unless the Customer notifies the Third Party Provider to the contrary before the proposed date of entry into force of the changes, the Customer will be deemed to have accepted the changes comunicated to it under Rule 20.2.5; and (b) the Customer has the right to terminate the Governing Contract without charge at any time before the proposed date of entry into force of the changes.

question: When the Regulator is considering issuing a “negative” direction to a Recognised Body that has not taken action under its Default Rules but appears to be proposing to take or may take action, what consultation step and satisfaction threshold must be met before the direction can be given, and what are the permissible bases for that satisfaction?
expected_answer: If the Regulator is contemplating a “negative” direction (i.e., a direction not to take action) in a situation where a Recognised Body has not acted under its Default Rules but seems to be proposing to act or may act, the Regulator must first consult the Recognised Body concerned before giving the direction. [#TGT:380d251f-0ce7-47ae-9d49-d8e2e45a9c8e] [#SRC:d6293761-3213-4c1c-baf1-930292a4a8c3] Following that consultation, the Regulator is prohibited from giving the direction unless it is satisfied—based on the consultation—that at least one specified justification applies. [#SRC:d6293761-3213-4c1c-baf1-930292a4a8c3] Those permissible bases are: (a) taking action would be premature or otherwise undesirable in the interests of investors or other market participants; (b) the direction is necessary in light of the public interest in the financial stability of the Abu Dhabi Global Market; or (c) the direction is necessary to facilitate a proposed or possible use of a power under chapter 16 of COBS, or in connection with a particular exercise of a power under that Part. [#SRC:d6293761-3213-4c1c-baf1-930292a4a8c3] In practice, the “negative” direction scenario supplies the factual trigger (no Default Rules action yet, but potential action is contemplated), while the consultation and satisfaction tests govern whether the Regulator may proceed to issue the direction at all. [#TGT:380d251f-0ce7-47ae-9d49-d8e2e45a9c8e] [#SRC:d6293761-3213-4c1c-baf1-930292a4a8c3]

question: If a Recognised Body hasn’t used its Default Rules yet but looks like it is about to (or might) take action, what does the Regulator have to do before telling it not to act, and what reasons can justify that instruction?
expected_answer: Where a Recognised Body has not taken action under its Default Rules but it appears to the Regulator that the Recognised Body is proposing to take action or may take action, the Regulator may consider issuing a “negative” direction telling it not to take action. [#TGT:380d251f-0ce7-47ae-9d49-d8e2e45a9c8e] Before giving such a direction, the Regulator must consult the Recognised Body in question. question: When an Issuer is considering either (i) making an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM or (ii) seeking admission of Securities to trading on a RIE/Recognised Investment Exchange, what is the combined prohibition and what is the stated compliance pathway/exception that permits the activity?
expected_answer: An Issuer is prohibited from making an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM, and is likewise prohibited from having Securities admitted to trading on a RIE, unless the activity is carried out in the manner the applicable framework allows. [#SRC:5f3625e1-2e7d-4bc8-b5e4-a0649ca42237] The general rule is framed as a “shall not” restriction on any person making an Offer of Securities in the Abu Dhabi Global Market or arranging for Securities to be admitted to trading on a Recognised Investment Exchange. [#TGT:67094ff0-5048-4e6e-87e4-bb61836c324a] For an Issuer specifically, the SOURCE clarifies that the prohibition applies to Offers of Securities to the Public made in or from ADGM and to admissions to trading on a RIE, and it identifies the permitted route as doing so only in accordance with FSMR and MKT. [#SRC:5f3625e1-2e7d-4bc8-b5e4-a0649ca42237] The TARGET provides the complementary exception structure: the prohibition is lifted only where the action is “provided by or under these Regulations,” meaning the Regulations themselves must contain the enabling basis for the Offer or admission. [#TGT:67094ff0-5048-4e6e-87e4-bb61836c324a] Read together, the compliance pathway is that an Issuer may proceed only where the Regulations permit it and where the Issuer follows the FSMR and MKT requirements identified for such Offers/admissions. [#SRC:5f3625e1-2e7d-4bc8-b5e4-a0649ca42237] [#TGT:67094ff0-5048-4e6e-87e4-bb61836c324a]

question: If someone wants to make an Offer of Securities in the Abu Dhabi Global Market, and an Issuer wants to make an Offer of Securities to the Public in or from ADGM (or get Securities admitted to trading on a RIE), what do the rules say they can and cannot do, and what is the allowed way to do it?

[#TGT:67094ff0-5048-4e6e-87e4-bb61836c324a] For Issuers, the restriction is described in the specific context of “Offers of Securities to the Public” made in or from ADGM, and it also covers the scenario where the Issuer has Securities admitted to trading on a RIE. [#SRC:5f3625e1-2e7d-4bc8-b5e4-a0649ca42237] The permitted route is not a free choice: the Issuer may only proceed if it does so in accordance with the governing framework identified for these activities. [#SRC:5f3625e1-2e7d-4bc8-b5e4-a0649ca42237] In parallel, the general exception language requires that the Offer or admission must be “provided by or under these Regulations,” so the legal basis must come from the Regulations rather than from the person’s preference. [#TGT:67094ff0-5048-4e6e-87e4-bb61836c324a] Putting both together, an Issuer (and any person) must treat Offers in ADGM and admissions to trading as prohibited by default and only proceed where the Regulations permit it and, for Issuers, where the activity is carried out in line with FSMR and MKT. question: How should an Authorised Person be categorised where its Financial Services Permission includes Managing Assets and it also undertakes Dealing in Investments as Agent, but only in a way that is wholly incidental to Managing Assets; and how does that interact with the Category 2 test for Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal) and the requirement that dealing activities are not limited in scope?
expected_answer: The Authorised Person should be treated as falling within Category 3C (rather than Category 3A) if it carries out Dealing in Investments as Agent only in a manner that is wholly incidental to Managing Assets, and it otherwise meets the Category 3C conditions. [#TGT:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f] Category 3C applies where the Financial Services Permission authorises one or more specified Regulated Activities, including Managing Assets, and the firm does not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A, 3B or 5. [#SRC:9e40803b-0d63-4d4f-a8ff-0a644cc795d0] The “wholly incidental” linkage is important because, although Category 3A is generally determined by authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Agent (and the absence of certain other authorisations), the text expressly directs that incidental Dealing in Investments as Agent alongside Managing Assets results in Category 3C treatment. [#TGT:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f] Separately, Category 2 is triggered by authorisation for Providing Credit or Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal), combined with dealing activities that are not limited in scope, and the firm not meeting Categories 1 or 5. [#TGT:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f] Therefore, to remain in Category 3C, the firm must not meet the Category 2 criteria while satisfying the Category 3C conditions tied to Managing Assets and the exclusion of Categories 1, 2, 3A, 3B and 5. [#SRC:9e40803b-0d63-4d4f-a8ff-0a644cc795d0]

debug_context.source_text: Category 3C An Authorised Person is in Category 3C if: (a) its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or more of the Regulated Activities of: (i) Managing Assets; (ii) Managing a Collective Investment Fund; (iii) Providing Custody (where it does so other than for a Fund); (iv) Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAr; (v) Providing Trust Services (where it is acting as trustee in respect of at least one express trust); or (vi) Providing Money Services; and (b) it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A, 3B or 5. Guidance A Category 3C Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Managing Assets, Managing a Collective Investment Fund, Providing Custody other than for a Fund or Managing a Profit Sharing Investment Account which is a PSIAr, Providing Trust Services (where it is acting as a trustee in respect of at least one express trust) or Providing Money Services, and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rules 1.3.1, 1.3.2, 1.3.3 and 1.3.4 that are determinative of its belonging to Category 3C.
debug_context.target_text: An Authorised Person is in Category 2 if: (a) its Financial Services Permission authorises it to carry on one or both of the Regulated Activities of Providing Credit or Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal); (b) its dealing activities are not limited in scope as provided in Rule 1.3.3(1)(a)(i); and (c) it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1 or 5. Category 3A Guidance A Category 3A Authorised Person may be authorised to conduct other Regulated Activities, but it is the authorisation for Dealing in Investments as Agent and the absence of authorisation for the activities specified in Rules 1.3.1 and 1.3.2 that are determinative of its belonging to Category 3A. Provided that an Authorised Person carries out the Regulated Activity of Dealing in Investments as Agent in a manner that is wholly incidental to the activity of Managing an Investment Fund or Managing Assets, the Authorised Person shall be regarded as falling within Category 3C.

question: If an Authorised Person is allowed to do Managing a Collective Investment Fund and also does Dealing in Investments as Agent only as a small, wholly incidental part of that work, which category should it be in, and what would make it Category 2 instead?
expected_answer: It should be regarded as Category 3C if it carries out Dealing in Investments as Agent only in a manner that is wholly incidental to Managing an Investment Fund (or Managing Assets), and it otherwise fits the Category 3C definition. [#TGT:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f] Category 3C covers an Authorised Person whose Financial Services Permission authorises one or more listed Regulated Activities, including Managing a Collective Investment Fund, provided it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1, 2, 3A, 3B or 5. [#SRC:9e40803b-0d63-4d4f-a8ff-0a644cc795d0] This means the incidental dealing-as-agent activity does not push the firm into Category 3A, because the text explicitly directs that such incidental Dealing in Investments as Agent is treated as Category 3C when it is tied to Managing an Investment Fund or Managing Assets. [#TGT:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f] It would instead be Category 2 if its Financial Services Permission authorises Providing Credit or Dealing in Investments as Principal (not as Matched Principal), its dealing activities are not limited in scope, and it does not meet the criteria of Categories 1 or 5. [#TGT:6737c8c3-06cb-4da7-bbcd-9e8650ecf66f] So, the classification turns on (i) whether the firm meets the Category 3C activity-and-exclusion test and (ii) whether it meets the separate Category 2 principal-dealing/credit test. [#SRC:9e40803b-0d63-4d4f-a8ff-0a644cc795d0]

question: For an Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C or 4, how does the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum—being a component of the Capital Requirement calculation under Section 3.6—feed into the trigger for notifying the Regulator when Capital Resources decline, and what are the required timing and follow-up steps once the trigger is met?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person in Category 3B, 3C or 4 must treat the Capital Requirement as the benchmark for the notification trigger, and that Capital Requirement includes the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum as one component of its calculation under Section 3.6. [#SRC:596309d5-cc1a-4a45-9e6d-2042ff11da76] The notification obligation is triggered when the firm’s Capital Resources fall below 120% of that Capital Requirement (as calculated, including the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum component). [#TGT:bbfd9205-e2d8-4fa4-be46-44da5d8e990d] Once the threshold is breached, the firm must notify the Regulator immediately and then provide a written confirmation of that notification. [#TGT:bbfd9205-e2d8-4fa4-be46-44da5d8e990d] Because the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum is relevant to determining whether the Regulator has to be notified under Rule 3.20.2, the firm should ensure that this component is properly reflected in the Capital Requirement figure used to assess whether Capital Resources have dropped below the 120% level. [#SRC:596309d5-cc1a-4a45-9e6d-2042ff11da76] In practical terms, the firm’s compliance assessment should link (i) the Section 3.6 Capital Requirement computation (including the Expenditure Based Capital Minimum) to (ii) the immediate notification and written confirmation steps required upon falling below 120% of that computed requirement. question: Where a Listed Entity issues Securities under a dividend or distribution plan (including an issue under an agreement to Underwrite the shortfall), what disclosure pathway must be used, and what timing and pre-disclosure conditions apply to the issue?
expected_answer: The Listed Entity’s issue of Securities in this scenario must be supported by the specific pre-disclosure and timing conditions for the dividend/distribution plan (including any Underwriting shortfall arrangement), and the relevant disclosure must be made using the Rule 7.7.1 disclosure mechanism for the matters specified in APP 2. [#TGT:6cfc6a56-abb6-4c69-abdb-4c43dd17c326] In particular, where the issue is under an agreement to Underwrite the shortfall on a dividend or distribution plan, the details of the Underwriting agreement must have been Disclosed before the dividend or distribution payment date, using the disclosure route referenced for that pre-disclosure (Rule 3.8.1 or 7.6.1). [#SRC:2d5c5459-6ae1-4b60-9b4f-4f9784697558] The Listed Entity must also complete the issue within 15 Business Days after the date for payment of the dividend or distribution. [#SRC:2d5c5459-6ae1-4b60-9b4f-4f9784697558] Separately, to the extent the Listed Entity is also a Reporting Entity, it must Disclose (in accordance with Rule 7.7.1) the matters specified in APP 2 as part of its disclosure obligations. [#TGT:6cfc6a56-abb6-4c69-abdb-4c43dd17c326] Together, this means the entity must both satisfy the plan/Underwriting-specific preconditions and timing, and use the Rule 7.7.1 pathway for APP 2 matters where applicable. [#SRC:2d5c5459-6ae1-4b60-9b4f-4f9784697558][#TGT:6cfc6a56-abb6-4c69-abdb-4c43dd17c326]

question: For a Recognised Clearing House that is providing Central Counterparty Services, which specific Rule governs stress testing of capital, and what must the Recognised Clearing House do with the results of those stress tests in relation to its total financial resources?
expected_answer: For a Recognised Clearing House that is providing Central Counterparty Services, the stress testing of capital requirement is located in Rule 4.6. [#SRC:6112097d-0f5d-40e8-9a64-1aa7b6b520a6] In applying that stress testing framework, the Recognised Clearing House is required to use the stress test results as an input to assess whether its total financial resources are sufficient, and it must then change those resources where the evaluation indicates that adjustments are appropriate. [#TGT:3e191799-f7b9-49c8-84c3-cfefdc35ed2e] This means the stress testing activity is not merely performed for monitoring purposes; it must feed into an adequacy evaluation of total financial resources and, where warranted, lead to responsive action to recalibrate those resources. [#TGT:3e191799-f7b9-49c8-84c3-cfefdc35ed2e] The scope of this obligation is tied to the Recognised Clearing House’s provision of Central Counterparty Services, for which the applicable requirements are identified as including Rule 4.6 alongside other specified areas (credit risk, collateral and margin, and segregation and portability). [#SRC:6112097d-0f5d-40e8-9a64-1aa7b6b520a6]

question: For the purposes of an investigation, how may the Investigator exercise the power to require a person to attend an interview and answer questions, and what additional requirements can be included in the same written notice (including any conditions on time, place, or premises access)?
expected_answer: The Investigator’s power to compel interview attendance is exercised for the purposes of an investigation by requiring a person (the interviewee) to attend an interview and answer questions. [#SRC:a8953086-147f-4fb9-9370-ff7349385aaf] In operational terms, the Investigator may implement that power by issuing a written notice to the Person Under Investigation or to any other person, including someone not connected to the Person Under Investigation, requiring them to attend an interview at a specified time and place and answer questions. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] The same written notice can also impose additional, distinct requirements that support the investigation, including: producing specified documents (or documents of a specified description) at a specified time and place; providing information; providing assistance; and permitting entry to the person’s business premises during normal business hours so the Investigator can inspect and copy documents located there. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] Accordingly, when the Investigator uses the interview power for investigative purposes, the notice can combine the interview obligation with document, information, assistance, and premises-access obligations, each framed with the timing/place parameters or business-hours condition stated for that requirement. [#SRC:a8953086-147f-4fb9-9370-ff7349385aaf] [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]

question: For a Listed Entity that has issued or intends to issue Restricted Securities, how should it determine whether it must apply the restriction in APP 7, and how does the carve-out for categories 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8 and 9 of APP 7 operate when the entity qualifies under Rule 2.3.15 or meets the Regulator’s profitability/revenue or tangible-asset criteria?
expected_answer: A Listed Entity that has issued or intends to issue Restricted Securities is required to apply the restriction in APP 7 (or any other restrictions the Regulator chooses to impose) as the baseline obligation. [#SRC:8bfb4441-1b4c-4e2a-a529-07992ed8635f] However, when assessing what parts of APP 7 must be applied, the entity must also consider the specific non-application rule for certain APP 7 categories, which can remove the need to apply categories 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8 and 9 unless the Regulator decides otherwise. [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac] In practice, the entity should: (i) confirm it is within scope because it has issued or intends to issue Restricted Securities; (ii) start from the requirement to apply APP 7 restrictions (or other restrictions set by the Regulator); and then (iii) test whether it meets any of the qualifying conditions that switch off the listed APP 7 categories. [#SRC:8bfb4441-1b4c-4e2a-a529-07992ed8635f] The categories 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8 and 9 of APP 7 do not apply if the Listed Entity qualifies for admission to the Official List under Rule 2.3.15, or has a profitability/revenue track record acceptable to the Regulator, or (in the Regulator’s opinion) has tangible assets with readily ascertainable value forming a substantial proportion of total asset value—unless the Regulator decides otherwise. [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac]

question: If a Listed Entity plans to issue Restricted Securities, does it always have to apply APP 7 restrictions, or can some APP 7 categories be switched off when it qualifies under Rule 2.3.15 or meets the Regulator’s profitability/revenue or tangible-asset test?
expected_answer: The starting point is that a Listed Entity that has issued or intends to issue Restricted Securities must apply the restriction in APP 7, unless the Regulator uses its discretion to require different restrictions. [#SRC:8bfb4441-1b4c-4e2a-a529-07992ed8635f] But that baseline obligation is narrowed by a specific carve-out: unless the Regulator decides otherwise, the restrictions in categories 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8 and 9 of APP 7 do not apply for certain Listed Entities. [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac] To decide what to apply, the entity should check whether it meets any of the carve-out conditions while still recognizing that APP 7 is the default restriction framework for Restricted Securities. [#SRC:8bfb4441-1b4c-4e2a-a529-07992ed8635f] The carve-out applies if the Listed Entity (1) qualifies for admission to the Official List under Rule 2.3.15, or (2) has a track record of profitability or revenue that the Regulator accepts, or (3) in the Regulator’s opinion has tangible assets with a readily ascertainable value that make up a substantial proportion of the total value of its assets—unless the Regulator decides otherwise. [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac] This means the entity may still need to apply other APP 7 restrictions (or other restrictions the Regulator sets), but the listed categories can be disapplied when the conditions are met. question: Where an Authorised Person’s ability to maintain the minimum Leverage Ratio is threatened, what immediate notification duty is triggered, and how does the Tier 1 Capital requirement inform whether the Authorised Person is likely not to hold the amount and quality of capital needed to comply with Rule 3.21.3?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must provide an immediate written notification to the Regulator when it does not hold, or expects it will not hold, the amount and quality of capital needed to comply with Rule 3.21.3. [#SRC:cb563a7f-d8cf-4245-afdb-e5c995f3df81] In assessing whether that notification trigger is met, the Authorised Person must take into account its obligation to hold sufficient Tier 1 Capital so that it can maintain, at all times, at least a 3% Leverage Ratio (or a different level if the Regulator sets one). [#TGT:e9e2bf18-6110-4e9f-8060-c59b85e5cd8e] If the Authorised Person’s Tier 1 Capital position is such that it cannot maintain the required minimum Leverage Ratio on a continuous basis, that circumstance is relevant to whether it is likely not to hold the necessary capital amount and quality for Rule 3.21.3, and therefore whether the immediate notification obligation is engaged. [#TGT:e9e2bf18-6110-4e9f-8060-c59b85e5cd8e] [#SRC:cb563a7f-d8cf-4245-afdb-e5c995f3df81] The notification must be made immediately and in writing, and it is triggered by either an actual shortfall or a likely future shortfall in the required capital position. [#SRC:cb563a7f-d8cf-4245-afdb-e5c995f3df81]

[#SRC:cb563a7f-d8cf-4245-afdb-e5c995f3df81] This matters in practice because the Authorised Person is required to hold enough Tier 1 Capital to maintain a minimum Leverage Ratio of 3% at all times, unless the Regulator sets a different minimum. [#TGT:e9e2bf18-6110-4e9f-8060-c59b85e5cd8e] So, if the Authorised Person’s Tier 1 Capital position indicates it cannot keep that minimum Leverage Ratio continuously, that is a concrete sign it may be likely not to hold the capital needed for Rule 3.21.3, which is exactly the situation that triggers the immediate written notification duty. question: When the Investigator uses a written notice to require a person to “provide such information as the Investigator may require,” how broadly should “information” be understood, and how does that breadth affect what the person may need to supply in response to interview questions or other requests in the notice?
expected_answer: “Information” should be read expansively, so a written notice requiring a person to provide information can legitimately call for many different forms of content, not just formal documents. [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32] In practice, where the Investigator issues a written notice to the Person Under Investigation or any other person (even if not connected) requiring them to provide information, attend an interview and answer questions, or take other steps, the recipient should treat “information” as covering a wide range of material that can be supplied in response to those requirements. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] This broad scope includes, for example: knowledge communicated or received about a matter; knowledge gained through work or study; computer-processed data at any stage (input, output, storage, or transmission); explanations or statements; identification details about a person, matter, or thing; and direct responses to questions. [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32] Because the notice can also require attendance at an interview at a specified time and place to answer questions, the recipient should be prepared to provide “information” in the form of verbal answers and explanations, not only in written form. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] The key compliance takeaway is to map each notice requirement to this broad meaning so the response captures all requested knowledge, data, identifications, and statements. [#SRC:3846e7de-e3f3-42bd-af14-a0ec562dfc32] [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046]
