question: When evaluating interest rate risk arising from Non Trading Book activities, how must an Authorised Person determine which currencies are “material currencies” for purposes of measuring risk Exposures in each currency, and what quantitative threshold applies to Non Trading Book assets or liabilities?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must evaluate its Exposure to interest rate risk that arises from its Non Trading Book activities, and where it has balance sheet positions in different currencies it must measure its risk Exposures separately in each material currency. [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3] For purposes of identifying which currencies are “material currencies” in this context, the Authorised Person should treat as material each currency that represents 5% or more of its Non Trading Book assets or 5% or more of its Non Trading Book liabilities. [#SRC:fa74198b-0ce3-4a0c-a1a1-e2a3e719df28] Practically, this means the evaluation of interest rate risk must be supported by a currency-by-currency measurement approach whenever multiple currencies are present on the balance sheet, but the measurement obligation is focused on those currencies meeting the 5% materiality threshold based on Non Trading Book assets or liabilities. [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3] [#SRC:fa74198b-0ce3-4a0c-a1a1-e2a3e719df28] The threshold is applied by reference to the Authorised Person’s Non Trading Book positions (assets and liabilities), and the resulting set of material currencies defines the minimum set of currencies in which risk Exposures must be measured for the interest rate risk evaluation. [#SRC:fa74198b-0ce3-4a0c-a1a1-e2a3e719df28] [#TGT:9f5db2ba-19a5-4149-b8c0-f470ec9e54e3]

question: When a Third Party Provider reserves the right to stop or prevent a Third Party Transaction from being executed under the Governing Contract, what must the Third Party Provider do upon refusing a Third Party Transaction, and how must the contract frame the communication method for that refusal?
expected_answer: If a Third Party Provider refuses a Third Party Transaction (including where it has reserved a contractual right to stop or prevent execution), it must issue a refusal notification using the agreed manner specified for such notifications. [#SRC:a1d4e63c-99cf-4a22-a683-25f69663f575] The Governing Contract must therefore set out, unless otherwise agreed in writing between the Third Party Provider and their Customer, the means of communication the parties have agreed for transmitting information or notifications, including any relevant technical requirements for the Customer’s equipment and software. [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] In addition, because the contract must describe the conditions under which the Third Party Provider proposes to reserve the right to stop or prevent a Third Party Transaction from being executed, the refusal-notification process should operate within that stated contractual context (i.e., the refusal occurs when those conditions are met). [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49] Practically, compliance should ensure the refusal notification is delivered through the contractually agreed channel and in the agreed manner, and that the contract’s communication section and the “stop/prevent” conditions are consistent with how refusals will be communicated. [#SRC:a1d4e63c-99cf-4a22-a683-25f69663f575] [#TGT:c00769cc-c353-4c08-86ed-2b5baae1cc49]

question: When an Authorised Person is considering recognising a guarantee for credit risk mitigation where the guarantor is an MDB, how should the Authorised Person identify whether the guarantor is an eligible guarantor and, if the exposure is directly to that MDB, what risk weight must be applied to the CR Exposure?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person may treat a guarantee as eligible for credit risk mitigation when the guarantor is an MDB that falls within the MDBs referenced for guarantee eligibility, and the Authorised Person should determine this by checking whether the MDB is one of the qualifying MDBs listed for the MDB asset class. [#SRC:bedaa8b8-4488-4156-9886-a8e1e2edd6b8] [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4] Where the relevant MDB is among the qualifying MDBs (for example, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) or the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD)), the Authorised Person must apply a 0% risk weight to any CR Exposure to that MDB. [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4] In practical terms, this means the same MDB list used to determine which MDB exposures receive a 0% risk weight also provides the concrete set of MDB names that can be used to confirm the MDB is within the category of MDBs that may be recognised as guarantors for guarantee-based credit risk mitigation. [#SRC:bedaa8b8-4488-4156-9886-a8e1e2edd6b8] [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4] This linkage is limited to MDBs: other eligible guarantor categories (such as PSEs or certain international institutions) are separate from the MDB list and are not needed to determine the 0% risk weight for qualifying MDB exposures. [#SRC:bedaa8b8-4488-4156-9886-a8e1e2edd6b8]

debug_context.source_text: Credit Risk mitigation Guarantees. An Authorised Person may recognise guarantees provided by the following eligible guarantors: (a) the Bank for International Settlements, the International Monetary Fund, the European Central Bank, and the European Commission; (b) the MDBs referred to in Rule 4.12.8; (c) PSEs; and (d) other entities eligible for a CRW of 20% or better and with a lower risk weight than the Counterparty.

An Authorised Person must apply a 0% risk weight to any CR Exposure to the qualifying MDBs set out below: (a) The World Bank Group comprised of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD), the Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA), and the International Finance Corporation (IFC); (b) The Asian Development Bank (ADB); (c) The African Development Bank (AfDB); (d) The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD); (e) The Inter American Development Bank (IADB); (f) The European Investment Bank (EIB); (g) The European Investment Fund (EIF); (h) The Nordic Investment Bank (NIB); (i) The Caribbean Development Bank (CDB); (j) The Islamic Development Bank (IDB); and (k) The Council of Europe Development Bank (CEDB).

question: If an Authorised Person wants to count a guarantee from an MDB, which MDB names can they use to confirm it fits the MDB category, and what risk weight applies if the Authorised Person has a CR Exposure to that same MDB?
expected_answer: To use an MDB as a guarantor for credit risk mitigation, the Authorised Person needs the guarantor to fall within the MDB category that is permitted for recognised guarantees, and the practical way to confirm the MDB is to match it to the qualifying MDBs that are explicitly named for the MDB asset class. [#SRC:bedaa8b8-4488-4156-9886-a8e1e2edd6b8] [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4] The qualifying MDB names include, among others, the World Bank Group entities (IBRD, MIGA, and IFC), the African Development Bank (AfDB), and the Islamic Development Bank (IDB). [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4] If the Authorised Person’s position is a CR Exposure to one of these qualifying MDBs (i.e., the exposure is to the MDB itself), the Authorised Person must apply a 0% risk weight to that exposure. [#TGT:aed2a764-3ad1-4646-bf24-f6416556ffb4] This connects the guarantee-recognition concept (MDBs are an eligible guarantor type) with the exposure treatment concept (qualifying MDB exposures receive a 0% risk weight), using the same concrete list of MDB institutions to identify the relevant MDB. question: When seeking the Regulator’s approval to replace a Trustee, what specific submissions must the Fund Manager provide, and how should the Fund Manager assess whether the proposed replacement Trustee satisfies the independence standard (including the listed non-independence relationships) in addition to meeting the FSMR eligibility requirement referenced in the approval condition?
expected_answer: To obtain the Regulator’s approval to replace a Trustee, the Fund Manager must submit a written notice stating its intention to remove the Trustee and must support that notice either with a certification that the removal will not harm Unitholders’ interests and will not impair the Fund Manager’s ability to comply with the Trust Deed, Prospectus, these Rules and the FSMR, or with a Special Resolution of Unitholders approving both the removal and the replacement. [#SRC:731c9d3a-6611-49d3-9ef9-2ddab7f4f1f2] The application must also include the written consent of the person agreeing to act as the replacement Trustee, and the Fund Manager must ensure that person meets the requirements for a Trustee in Section 114(2) of the FSMR to be able to act in that role. [#SRC:731c9d3a-6611-49d3-9ef9-2ddab7f4f1f2] In parallel, because the Trustee of an Investment Trust must be independent of the Fund Manager, the Fund Manager should evaluate the proposed replacement Trustee against the specific circumstances that negate independence. [#TGT:f90dee9e-41b0-46ee-b8ad-8ec88ec8b05c] Independence is not present if there are cross-shareholdings or voting rights, a common holding company or ultimate holding company, overlapping Directors on the Governing Body, shared individuals performing Controlled Functions, or professional/material business dealings within the previous two years (other than acting as Fund Manager/Trustee for other funds). [#TGT:f90dee9e-41b0-46ee-b8ad-8ec88ec8b05c]

A Trustee will not be independent of a Fund Manager if— (a) the Fund Manager or the Trustee holds, or exercise voting rights in respect of, any Shares of the other; (b) the Fund Manager and the Trustee have a common holding company or a common ultimate holding company; (c) the Fund Manager or the Trustee have Directors on its Governing Body, who are also Directors of the other; (d) the Fund Manager or the Trustee has individuals performing Controlled Functions who are also individuals performing Controlled Functions for the other; or (e) the Fund Manager and the Trustee have been involved in the previous two years in any professional or material business dealings, other than acting as Fund Manager or Trustee respectively of any other Fund.

question: If a Fund Manager wants to remove a Trustee and appoint a new one, what paperwork must be sent to the Regulator, and what kinds of links between the Fund Manager and the new Trustee would mean the new Trustee is not independent?
expected_answer: The Fund Manager must give the Regulator a written notice saying it intends to remove the Trustee, and it must include either (i) a certification that the change will not negatively affect Unitholders’ interests and will not undermine the Fund Manager’s ability to comply with the Trust Deed, Prospectus, these Rules and the FSMR, or (ii) a Special Resolution of Unitholders approving the removal and the replacement with another Trustee. [#SRC:731c9d3a-6611-49d3-9ef9-2ddab7f4f1f2] The Fund Manager must also provide the written consent of the person who will be the replacement Trustee and confirm that person meets the requirements for a Trustee in Section 114(2) of the FSMR to be able to act as replacement Trustee. [#SRC:731c9d3a-6611-49d3-9ef9-2ddab7f4f1f2] Separately, the Trustee must be independent of the Fund Manager, so the Fund Manager should check that none of the listed relationships exist between it and the proposed replacement Trustee. [#TGT:f90dee9e-41b0-46ee-b8ad-8ec88ec8b05c] The new Trustee would not be independent if either party holds or votes Shares of the other, they share a common holding company (or ultimate holding company), they have Directors who sit on both Governing Bodies, they share individuals performing Controlled Functions, or they have had professional or material business dealings in the last two years (other than acting as Fund Manager/Trustee for other funds). question: When an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business intends to pay, or permit to be paid, Client Money to a Third-Party Agent, what specific Third-Party Agent documentation must be included in the Resolution Pack to evidence the required prior suitability assessment and related acknowledgement for Client Money?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person may only pay, or allow payment of, Client Money to a Third-Party Agent if it has first assessed that Third-Party Agent’s suitability and reached a reasonable conclusion that the agent is suitable to hold Client Money in a Client Account. [#TGT:7ec4ca22-df40-4fb5-ae3b-c48036500143] To evidence that prerequisite in the Resolution Pack, the Authorised Person conducting Investment Business must include the records specified for Third-Party Agents in relation to Client Money, namely the assessment of appropriateness of the Third-Party Agent and the Third-Party Agent’s acknowledgement in respect of Client Money. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] Practically, this means the Resolution Pack should contain documentation showing (i) the prior assessment performed before any payment/permitted payment of Client Money to the Third-Party Agent and (ii) the acknowledgement obtained from that Third-Party Agent regarding Client Money. [#TGT:7ec4ca22-df40-4fb5-ae3b-c48036500143] [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] This linkage is important because the payment permission is conditioned on a prior suitability conclusion, and the Resolution Pack requirement identifies the specific records that demonstrate the assessment and acknowledgement for Client Money. [#TGT:7ec4ca22-df40-4fb5-ae3b-c48036500143] [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]

question: If an Authorised Person wants to let Client Money be paid to a Third-Party Agent, what must they do first, and what related items have to be kept in the Resolution Pack to show they met that condition?
expected_answer: Before Client Money is paid (or allowed to be paid) to a Third-Party Agent, the Authorised Person must carry out a prior assessment of the Third-Party Agent’s suitability and, on reasonable grounds, decide the Third-Party Agent is suitable to hold Client Money in a Client Account. [#TGT:7ec4ca22-df40-4fb5-ae3b-c48036500143] To show that this condition has been met, the Resolution Pack for an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business must include the specific Third-Party Agent records for Client Money: the assessment of appropriateness of the Third-Party Agent and the Third-Party Agent’s acknowledgement in respect of Client Money. [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] In other words, the Resolution Pack should contain evidence of the assessment that was done before any payment/permitted payment, and it should also contain the acknowledgement obtained from the Third-Party Agent about Client Money. [#TGT:7ec4ca22-df40-4fb5-ae3b-c48036500143] [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] This ties the “prior assessment and reasonable conclusion” requirement for paying Client Money to a Third-Party Agent to the concrete Resolution Pack contents that document that assessment and acknowledgement. [#TGT:7ec4ca22-df40-4fb5-ae3b-c48036500143] [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]

debug_context.source_text: The following records must be included in the Resolution Pack of an Authorised Person conducting Investment Business: (a) Rules ‎2.7.1 and ‎3.7.1(d) (records of Client classification and Client agreements); (b) Rules 14.6.2 and ‎15.4.3 (master lists of all Client Accounts in relation to Client Money and Client investments); (c) Rule ‎15.4.4 and Rule ‎15.4.5 (adequate records and Client's written permission re use of Client Investments); (d) Rules 14.7.1 and 14.7.4 (assessment of appropriateness of Third-Party Agent and acknowledgement by Third-Party agent in respect of Client Money); and (e) Rule ‎15.5.1 and 15.6.1 (assessment of appropriateness of Third Party Agent and acknowledgement by Third-Party Agent in respect of Client Investments); and (f) Rule 14.11.1 and ‎15.9.1 (most recent reconciliations of Client Money and Client Investments).
debug_context.target_text: An Authorised Person may pay, or permit to be paid, Client Money to a Third-Party Agent only where it has undertaken a prior assessment of the suitability of that Third-Party Agent and concluded on reasonable grounds that the Third-Party Agent is suitable to hold Client Money in a Client Account.

question: Where an Exposure is partially guaranteed by an Authorised Person's Parent Financial Institution and only the guaranteed portion would attract a lower risk weight under Section 4.12, how should the Authorised Person apply the 25% of Tier 1 Large Exposures limit for its Non Trading Book (and, as applicable, Trading Book) after recognising eligible CRM—specifically, which portion is excluded from the Large Exposure limit and which portion remains subject to the limit?
expected_answer: The Authorised Person should apply the 25% of Tier 1 Large Exposures limit to the Exposure after recognising eligible CRM, but it may exclude only the portion of the Exposure that is covered by the parental guarantee (and that would receive the lower risk weight under Section 4.12). [#TGT:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f] The exemption is not an all-or-nothing treatment: if the Exposure is only partially guaranteed by an Authorised Person's Parent Financial Institution, only the guaranteed part is exempt from the Large Exposure limit in Rule 4.15.5, while the unguaranteed remainder continues to count toward the Large Exposures limit. [#SRC:81186429-473c-4428-ac22-2536fc6258c3] In practical terms, the Authorised Person should (i) identify the Exposure and determine the portion subject to the parental guarantee, (ii) confirm that the guaranteed portion is the part that would be assigned a lower risk weight under Section 4.12, and (iii) apply the Large Exposures limit to the remaining portion in the relevant book (Non Trading Book and, where applicable, Trading Book) after taking into account eligible CRM. [#SRC:81186429-473c-4428-ac22-2536fc6258c3] [#TGT:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f] The Authorised Person may also consider exemptions permitted under Rule 4.15.18 relating to parental guarantees when assessing this treatment. [#SRC:81186429-473c-4428-ac22-2536fc6258c3]

debug_context.source_text: Exempt Exposures. If an Exposure is partially guaranteed by an Authorised Person's Parent Financial Institution, and would be assigned a lower risk weight under Section 4.12, only that part of the Exposure subject to the guarantee is exempt from the Large Exposure limit in Rule 4.15.5. When considering the treatment of this Rule an Authorised Person may also consider the exemptions permitted under Rule 4.15.18 relating to parental guarantees.
debug_context.target_text: Large Exposures limits. Subject to IFR Rule 5.4.15, an Authorised Person must not incur any Large Exposures in its Non Trading Book and, subject to Rule 4.15.6, Trading Book after taking into account the effect of any eligible CRM, that exceeds 25% of its Tier 1.

question: If an Exposure is only partly covered by an Authorised Person's Parent Financial Institution guarantee, and the guaranteed part would get a lower risk weight under Section 4.12, does the 25% of Tier 1 Large Exposures cap apply to the whole Exposure or only to the part not covered by the guarantee (after eligible CRM and for the Non Trading Book/Trading Book as relevant)?
expected_answer: The 25% of Tier 1 Large Exposures cap applies to what remains of the Exposure once you have taken into account eligible CRM, but you can leave out only the part that is actually covered by the parental guarantee (and that would receive the lower risk weight under Section 4.12). [#TGT:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f] The rule on exempt exposures is limited to the guaranteed slice: when an Exposure is partially guaranteed by an Authorised Person's Parent Financial Institution, only the portion subject to that guarantee is exempt from the Large Exposure limit in Rule 4.15.5, and the rest of the Exposure is still counted for Large Exposures purposes. [#SRC:81186429-473c-4428-ac22-2536fc6258c3] This means you should separate the Exposure into guaranteed and unguaranteed parts, exclude only the guaranteed part from the Large Exposure limit, and then test the remaining part against the 25% of Tier 1 limit in the Non Trading Book (and, subject to the stated Trading Book condition, in the Trading Book). [#SRC:81186429-473c-4428-ac22-2536fc6258c3] [#TGT:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f] When doing this assessment, the Authorised Person may also consider exemptions permitted under Rule 4.15.18 relating to parental guarantees. [#SRC:81186429-473c-4428-ac22-2536fc6258c3]

If an Exposure is partially guaranteed by an Authorised Person's Parent Financial Institution, and would be assigned a lower risk weight under Section 4.12, only that part of the Exposure subject to the guarantee is exempt from the Large Exposure limit in Rule 4.15.5. When considering the treatment of this Rule an Authorised Person may also consider the exemptions permitted under Rule 4.15.18 relating to parental guarantees.

question: How must an Authorised Person operationalise the requirement that the sum of its Large Exposures does not exceed 800% of its Tier 1, including the specific identification, measurement, aggregation, monitoring, and breach-notification steps that must be performed to manage that cap?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must run a Large Exposures control framework that both calculates exposures relative to Tier 1 and keeps the total of Large Exposures within the 800% of Tier 1 ceiling. [#TGT:342299bc-1d26-4555-9104-cf3347054697] To do this, it must first identify its Exposures and the relevant Counterparties, including whether Counterparties are Closely Related to each other or Connected to the Authorised Person, because those relationships affect how exposures are grouped for control purposes. [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675] It must then measure the size and establish the value of its Exposures, and determine each Exposure’s size as a proportion of its Tier 1, so that the Tier 1-based limit can be assessed. [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675] It must also identify Exposures subject to Section 4.13 (CRM) and identify any Exposures exempt under Section A4.11 from the limits in Rules 4.15.4 to 4.15.7, while still ensuring the overall sum of Large Exposures remains within the 800% cap. [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675] Operationally, it must aggregate Exposures to the same Counterparty or to groups of Closely Related or Connected Counterparties, monitor and control Exposures daily within the Large Exposures limits, and immediately notify the Regulator of any breach and confirm the breach in writing. [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675]

debug_context.source_text: Applicability and limits. For the purposes of this Section an Authorised Person must: (a) identify its Exposures; (b) identify its Counterparties, including whether any are Closely Related to each other or Connected to the Authorised Person; (c) measure the size of its Exposures; (d) establish the value of its Exposures; (e) determine the size of its Exposures as a proportion of its Tier 1; (f) identify whether it has Exposures which are subject to the requirements of Section 4.13 (CRM); (g) identify which, if any, of its Exposures are exempt in accordance with Section A4.11 from the limits set out in Rules 4.15.4 to 4.15.7; (h) aggregate its Exposures to the same Counterparty or group of Closely Related Counterparties or group of Connected Counterparties; (i) monitor and control its Exposures on a daily basis within the Large Exposures limits; and (j) notify the Regulator immediately of any breach of the limits set out in this Section and confirm it in writing.
debug_context.target_text: Large Exposures limits. Subject to IFR Rule 5.4.16 an Authorised Person must ensure that the sum of its Large Exposures does not exceed 800% of its Tier 1.

question: If an Authorised Person is trying to stay under the rule that total Large Exposures must not be more than 800% of Tier 1, what day-to-day steps does it have to take (like grouping counterparties, calculating exposures vs Tier 1, and what to do if it goes over)?
expected_answer: To comply, an Authorised Person must ensure the combined total of its Large Exposures stays at or below 800% of its Tier 1. [#TGT:342299bc-1d26-4555-9104-cf3347054697] Doing that requires a set of daily controls that start with mapping what counts toward the limit: it must identify its Exposures and identify its Counterparties, including checking whether any Counterparties are Closely Related to each other or Connected to the Authorised Person, because those links drive how exposures are grouped. [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675] It must measure the size of its Exposures, establish their value, and calculate each Exposure as a proportion of Tier 1 so it can manage the Tier 1-based cap. [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675] It must aggregate Exposures to the same Counterparty and to groups of Closely Related or Connected Counterparties, then monitor and control Exposures on a daily basis within the Large Exposures limits so the total remains within 800% of Tier 1. [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675] It also has to identify whether any Exposures are subject to Section 4.13 (CRM) and which Exposures are exempt under Section A4.11 from the limits in Rules 4.15.4 to 4.15.7, while still managing the overall Large Exposures total. [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675] If the limits are breached, it must notify the Regulator immediately and then confirm the breach in writing. [#SRC:29db355c-0b9a-45bd-af0b-0e40adbf1675]

question: For an Authorised Person operating as a Domestic Firm, what capital-resources and liquidity obligations apply under the Rules, and how does the Section’s allocation of Rules by operating form determine that these obligations apply to a Domestic Firm rather than a Branch?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person operating as a Domestic Firm is subject to the Domestic Firm capital-resources requirements because this Section states that Rules 3.2.3 to 3.2.5 apply to an Authorised Person operating as a Domestic Firm (whereas Rule 3.2.2 applies to an Authorised Person operating as a Branch). [#SRC:125f72ef-4896-42ec-90ce-f01b83fa15b6] Within that Domestic Firm framework, the Authorised Person must have and maintain, at all times, Capital Resources of the types and amounts specified in, and calculated in accordance with, these Rules. [#TGT:afbb9f59-2c26-47f6-ac38-4c36ecd40d56] In addition, it must ensure it maintains capital and liquid assets beyond that baseline requirement that are adequate for the nature, size and complexity of its business, with the objective of avoiding any significant risk that it cannot meet liabilities as they fall due. [#TGT:afbb9f59-2c26-47f6-ac38-4c36ecd40d56] The practical implication of the Section’s allocation is that these “Domestic Firms – maintaining capital resources” obligations attach when the Authorised Person operates as a Domestic Firm, and the Branch allocation indicates a different rule set would apply in that operating form. [#SRC:125f72ef-4896-42ec-90ce-f01b83fa15b6]

debug_context.source_text: In this Section the Rules apply to an Authorised Person in any Category as follows: (a) Rule 3.2.2 applies to an Authorised Person operating as a Branch; and (b) Rules 3.2.3 to 3.2.5 apply to an Authorised Person operating as a Domestic Firm.
debug_context.target_text: Domestic Firms – maintaining capital resources. An Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm must: (a) have and maintain, at all times, Capital Resources of the types and amounts specified in, and calculated in accordance with, these Rules; (b) ensure that it maintains capital and liquid assets in addition to the requirement in (a) which are adequate in relation to the nature, size and complexity of its business to ensure that there is no significant risk that liabilities cannot be met as they fall due.

question: If an Authorised Person is a Domestic Firm (not a Branch), what does it have to do about capital resources and liquid assets, and why do these duties apply to it under this Section?
expected_answer: These duties apply because the Section says that Rules 3.2.3 to 3.2.5 apply to an Authorised Person operating as a Domestic Firm, while a different rule (Rule 3.2.2) applies to an Authorised Person operating as a Branch. [#SRC:125f72ef-4896-42ec-90ce-f01b83fa15b6] As a result, an Authorised Person that is a Domestic Firm must keep Capital Resources continuously: it must have and maintain, at all times, Capital Resources of the types and amounts specified in, and calculated in accordance with, these Rules. [#TGT:afbb9f59-2c26-47f6-ac38-4c36ecd40d56] It also has to go further than just meeting that baseline calculation by ensuring it holds additional capital and liquid assets that are adequate for the nature, size and complexity of its business. [#TGT:afbb9f59-2c26-47f6-ac38-4c36ecd40d56] The purpose of that extra buffer is to make sure there is no significant risk that the Domestic Firm cannot pay its liabilities when they become due. [#TGT:afbb9f59-2c26-47f6-ac38-4c36ecd40d56] This is tied to the operating form because the Section explicitly separates which rules apply to Domestic Firms versus Branches. [#SRC:125f72ef-4896-42ec-90ce-f01b83fa15b6]

question: When a Trading Halt is imposed pursuant to Rule 7.8.1, what is the maximum duration of that halt, and within what window may the Regulator impose a suspension in relation to that halt?
expected_answer: For a Trading Halt imposed pursuant to Rule 7.8.1, the halt is capped at two Business Days unless the Regulator agrees to a shorter period. [#TGT:88d53574-f94b-4da4-8a47-2afa2fd511db] In relation to that same Rule 7.8.1 Trading Halt, the Regulator has discretion to impose a suspension at any point while the Trading Halt is in effect, meaning the suspension can be imposed during the halt without waiting for the halt to run its full permitted duration. [#SRC:dd30220a-9ed3-4f7f-98aa-99f1bd8dd3da] Read together, this means the outer boundary for how long the Rule 7.8.1 Trading Halt itself may last is two Business Days (or less if the Regulator agrees), but the timing of a suspension decision is not limited to the end of that period and may occur at any time during the halt. [#TGT:88d53574-f94b-4da4-8a47-2afa2fd511db] [#SRC:dd30220a-9ed3-4f7f-98aa-99f1bd8dd3da] The key compliance implication is to treat the Rule 7.8.1 halt duration limit as a separate constraint from the Regulator’s ability to impose a suspension during that halt, because the suspension power operates throughout the halt window rather than only after it expires. [#SRC:dd30220a-9ed3-4f7f-98aa-99f1bd8dd3da] [#TGT:88d53574-f94b-4da4-8a47-2afa2fd511db]

debug_context.source_text: The Regulator may impose a suspension in accordance with Rule 2.6 upon completion of the duration of the Trading Halt established under Rule 7.8.2, or at any time during the Trading Halt established under Rule 7.8.1.
debug_context.target_text: A Trading Halt imposed pursuant to Rule 7.8.1 cannot exceed two Business Days or such shorter period as the Regulator agrees.

question: If there is a Trading Halt under Rule 7.8.1, how long can it last at most, and can the Regulator impose a suspension before the halt ends?
expected_answer: A Trading Halt that is imposed under Rule 7.8.1 is limited in length: it cannot run for more than two Business Days, unless the Regulator agrees to a shorter time period. [#TGT:88d53574-f94b-4da4-8a47-2afa2fd511db] Separately, during that same Rule 7.8.1 Trading Halt, the Regulator is allowed to impose a suspension at any time while the halt is ongoing, rather than having to wait until the halt finishes. [#SRC:dd30220a-9ed3-4f7f-98aa-99f1bd8dd3da] Putting these points together, you should understand the “two Business Days (or less)” limit as the maximum duration of the Trading Halt itself, while the suspension power can be exercised at any moment within that halt window. [#TGT:88d53574-f94b-4da4-8a47-2afa2fd511db] [#SRC:dd30220a-9ed3-4f7f-98aa-99f1bd8dd3da] This means that even if the Trading Halt is expected to last up to the maximum period, the Regulator can still decide to impose a suspension before the halt reaches its endpoint. [#SRC:dd30220a-9ed3-4f7f-98aa-99f1bd8dd3da] [#TGT:88d53574-f94b-4da4-8a47-2afa2fd511db]

debug_context.source_text: The Regulator may impose a suspension in accordance with Rule 2.6 upon completion of the duration of the Trading Halt established under Rule 7.8.2, or at any time during the Trading Halt established under Rule 7.8.1.
debug_context.target_text: A Trading Halt imposed pursuant to Rule 7.8.1 cannot exceed two Business Days or such shorter period as the Regulator agrees.

question: When calculating CET1 Capital, how should an Authorised Person treat (i) unrealised gains or losses on liabilities valued at fair value that arise from changes in its own credit quality, and (ii) any other unrealised gains or losses on assets or liabilities measured at fair value, given the general prohibition on making fair-value adjustments except for items referred to in Rule 3.10.5?
expected_answer: In calculating CET1 Capital, an Authorised Person is required to exclude all unrealised gains or losses on its liabilities that are valued at fair value when those gains or losses result from changes in the Authorised Person’s own credit quality, unless the gains or losses are offset by a change in the fair value of another Financial Instrument that is measured at fair value and that offset also results from changes in the Authorised Person’s own credit quality. [#TGT:6e1d64e5-60c2-4627-af1c-f05e612f92bc] Separately, as a general rule for CET1 adjustments, the Authorised Person must not make adjustments that remove unrealised gains or losses on assets or liabilities measured at fair value from its Capital Resources, except for the items referred to in Rule 3.10.5. [#SRC:977b51e8-a945-4729-87fb-0845f5319ed6] Read together, this means the CET1 calculation must implement the specific exclusion for own-credit-quality-driven fair-value movements on liabilities (subject to the stated offset exception), while otherwise avoiding discretionary “removal” adjustments for fair-value unrealised gains or losses unless the adjustment falls within the Rule 3.10.5 carve-out. [#TGT:6e1d64e5-60c2-4627-af1c-f05e612f92bc] [#SRC:977b51e8-a945-4729-87fb-0845f5319ed6]

debug_context.source_text: CET1 Adjustments. Except for the items referred to in Rule 3.10.5, an Authorised Person must not make any adjustments to remove from its Capital Resources unrealised gains or losses on its assets or liabilities measured at fair value.
debug_context.target_text: CET1 Adjustments. An Authorised Person must, in the calculation of CET1 Capital, exclude the following: (a) any increase in its equity under the International Financial Reporting Standards, including: (i) where such an increase is associated with future margin income that results in a gain on sale for the Authorised Person; and (ii) where the Authorised Person is the Originator of a securitisation, net gains that arise from the capitalisation of future income from the securitised assets that provide Credit Enhancement to positions in the securitisation; (b) the amount of cash flow hedge reserve related to gains or losses on cash flow hedges of Financial Instruments that are not valued at fair value, including projected cash flows; and (c) all unrealised gains or losses on liabilities of the Authorised Person that are valued at fair value, and which result from changes in the Authorised Person's own credit quality, except when such gains or losses are offset by a change in the fair value of another Financial Instrument which is measured at fair value and resulting from changes in the Authorised Person's own credit quality.

question: If an Authorised Person is working out CET1 Capital, what must it take out for (a) increases in equity under International Financial Reporting Standards tied to future margin income or securitisation future income, and how does that fit with the rule that it generally must not adjust away unrealised fair-value gains or losses (except for items in Rule 3.10.5)?
expected_answer: When calculating CET1 Capital, an Authorised Person must exclude certain increases in its equity that arise under the International Financial Reporting Standards, including increases linked to future margin income that produces a gain on sale for the Authorised Person and, where the Authorised Person is the Originator of a securitisation, net gains from capitalising future income from securitised assets that provide Credit Enhancement to positions in the securitisation. [#TGT:6e1d64e5-60c2-4627-af1c-f05e612f92bc] At the same time, the general CET1 adjustment principle is that (other than items referred to in Rule 3.10.5) the Authorised Person must not make adjustments that remove unrealised gains or losses on assets or liabilities measured at fair value from its Capital Resources. [#SRC:977b51e8-a945-4729-87fb-0845f5319ed6] Putting these together, the IFRS-related equity exclusions are mandatory components of the CET1 calculation, while the broader prohibition limits the Authorised Person from making additional fair-value “removal” adjustments beyond what is specifically permitted by the Rule 3.10.5 exception. [#TGT:6e1d64e5-60c2-4627-af1c-f05e612f92bc] [#SRC:977b51e8-a945-4729-87fb-0845f5319ed6]

An Authorised Person must, in the calculation of CET1 Capital, exclude the following: (a) any increase in its equity under the International Financial Reporting Standards, including: (i) where such an increase is associated with future margin income that results in a gain on sale for the Authorised Person; and (ii) where the Authorised Person is the Originator of a securitisation, net gains that arise from the capitalisation of future income from the securitised assets that provide Credit Enhancement to positions in the securitisation; (b) the amount of cash flow hedge reserve related to gains or losses on cash flow hedges of Financial Instruments that are not valued at fair value, including projected cash flows; and (c) all unrealised gains or losses on liabilities of the Authorised Person that are valued at fair value, and which result from changes in the Authorised Person's own credit quality, except when such gains or losses are offset by a change in the fair value of another Financial Instrument which is measured at fair value and resulting from changes in the Authorised Person's own credit quality.

question: When applying the Large Exposures limit for positions in the Non Trading Book (and, where relevant, the Trading Book), how must an Authorised Person reflect eligible CRM where a Client exposure is (i) secured by third‑party Collateral or (ii) guaranteed by a third party, including any condition about maturity mismatch?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person must apply the Large Exposures cap after recognising the effect of eligible credit risk mitigation (CRM), and it must ensure that the resulting Large Exposures in the Non Trading Book (and, subject to the stated Trading Book condition) do not exceed 25% of its Tier 1. [#TGT:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f] Where a Client exposure is supported by a third party, the Authorised Person may re-attribute only the supported portion to the third party—but only if the relevant Collateral or guarantee meets the Section 4.13 (CRM) requirements and would receive a lower risk weight under Section 4.12. [#SRC:e1516dcf-4781-4353-bc07-78b1e8ec2f4e] Specifically, the portion secured by third‑party Collateral must be treated as incurred to the third party providing the Collateral (not the Client) for purposes of considering the applicable limits, and the portion covered by a qualifying third‑party guarantee must likewise be treated as incurred to the guarantor (not the Client) for purposes of considering the applicable limits. [#SRC:e1516dcf-4781-4353-bc07-78b1e8ec2f4e] In addition, when relying on a guarantee for this treatment, there must be no maturity mismatch between the guarantee and the underlying exposure. [#SRC:e1516dcf-4781-4353-bc07-78b1e8ec2f4e]

debug_context.source_text: Exempt Exposures. Where Exposures to a Client are guaranteed by a third party, or secured by Collateral issued by a third party, an Authorised Person may: (a) provided the Collateral meets the requirements of Section 4.13 (CRM), and would be assigned a lower risk weight under Section 4.12, treat that portion of the Exposure which is secured by Collateral as an Exposure to the third party. An Authorised Person must treat the portion secured by Collateral as having being incurred to the third party providing the Collateral rather than to the Client for the purposes of considering the limits as set out at Rule 4.15.5; or (b) provided the guarantee meets the requirements of Section 4.13 (CRM), and would be assigned a lower risk weight under Section 4.12, treat that portion of the Exposure which is guaranteed as an Exposure to the third party. An Authorised Person must treat the portion guaranteed as having being incurred to the third party rather than to the Client for the purposes of considering the limits as set out at Rule 4.15.5. When considering the guarantee there must not be any Maturity Mismatch between the guarantee and the underlying Exposure.
debug_context.target_text: Large Exposures limits. Subject to IFR Rule 5.4.15, an Authorised Person must not incur any Large Exposures in its Non Trading Book and, subject to Rule 4.15.6, Trading Book after taking into account the effect of any eligible CRM, that exceeds 25% of its Tier 1.

question: If a Client exposure is partly covered by third‑party Collateral or a third‑party guarantee, how do you work out whether the firm stays under the 25% Tier 1 Large Exposures limit, and what extra check applies if you use a guarantee?
expected_answer: To stay within the Large Exposures limit, an Authorised Person must measure Large Exposures in its Non Trading Book (and, with the stated condition for the Trading Book) after factoring in the effect of any eligible CRM, and it must not exceed 25% of its Tier 1. [#TGT:e70c0e97-fb04-4f48-9b0f-9aa5f025cd7f] If the Client exposure is supported by a third party, the firm can treat only the supported portion as an exposure to that third party, but only where the Collateral or guarantee satisfies Section 4.13 (CRM) and would attract a lower risk weight under Section 4.12. [#SRC:e1516dcf-4781-4353-bc07-78b1e8ec2f4e] For Collateral, the secured portion must be treated as incurred to the third party providing the Collateral (rather than the Client) when considering the relevant limits. [#SRC:e1516dcf-4781-4353-bc07-78b1e8ec2f4e] For a guarantee, the guaranteed portion must be treated as incurred to the guarantor (rather than the Client) when considering the relevant limits, and the firm must also confirm there is no maturity mismatch between the guarantee and the underlying exposure. [#SRC:e1516dcf-4781-4353-bc07-78b1e8ec2f4e]

debug_context.source_text: Exempt Exposures. Where Exposures to a Client are guaranteed by a third party, or secured by Collateral issued by a third party, an Authorised Person may: (a) provided the Collateral meets the requirements of Section 4.13 (CRM), and would be assigned a lower risk weight under Section 4.12, treat that portion of the Exposure which is secured by Collateral as an Exposure to the third party. An Authorised Person must treat the portion secured by Collateral as having being incurred to the third party providing the Collateral rather than to the Client for the purposes of considering the limits as set out at Rule 4.15.5; or (b) provided the guarantee meets the requirements of Section 4.13 (CRM), and would be assigned a lower risk weight under Section 4.12, treat that portion of the Exposure which is guaranteed as an Exposure to the third party. An Authorised Person must treat the portion guaranteed as having being incurred to the third party rather than to the Client for the purposes of considering the limits as set out at Rule 4.15.5. When considering the guarantee there must not be any Maturity Mismatch between the guarantee and the underlying Exposure.

question: For a Listed Entity that qualifies for admission to the Official List under Rule 2.3.15 and has Restricted Securities, how do the Regulator’s discretion to disapply APP 7 restriction categories and the Controller’s need (or not) to be a party to the Rule 9.6.2 Restriction Agreement interact, including any remaining circumstances where the Controller still would not need to be a party?
expected_answer: If the Regulator does not decide otherwise, a Listed Entity that qualifies for admission to the Official List under Rule 2.3.15 is carved out from the application of restrictions in APP 7 categories 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8 and 9, so those category-based restrictions would not apply to that Listed Entity in the first place. [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac] Separately, where a Restriction Agreement under Rule 9.6.2 is relevant, a Controller is not required to be a party to that agreement if any of the specified conditions is met. [#SRC:afb239cd-ac67-4702-8e1d-e5293bccd010] In practice, even for a Listed Entity benefiting from the Regulator’s disapplication of the listed APP 7 categories, the Controller’s non-party status is still supported where (i) the Restricted Security’s value is below 10% of the total assets of the holder or an intermediate entity through which the Controller holds its interest, or (ii) the holder (or such intermediate entity) is itself a Listed Entity (or listed on an exchange that is a full member of the World Federation of Exchanges) or is a trustee, custodian or nominee. [#SRC:afb239cd-ac67-4702-8e1d-e5293bccd010] Additionally, if the holder’s Securities are Restricted Securities because category 2 or 4 applies, the Controller need not be a party—while noting that those categories may be among those the Regulator can disapply for the qualifying Listed Entity. [#SRC:afb239cd-ac67-4702-8e1d-e5293bccd010] [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac]

debug_context.source_text: Entry into Restriction Agreements and Application of Restriction. A Controller need not be a party to the Restriction Agreement referred to in Rule 9.6.2 if any of the following applies. (1) The value of the Restricted Security is less than 10% of the total value of the assets of: (a) the holder of the Restricted Securities; or (b) an intermediate entity through which the Controller has its interests. (2) The holder, or an intermediate entity through which the Controller has its interests, is: (a) a Listed Entity, or an entity listed on exchange that is a full member of the World Federation of Exchanges; or (b) a trustee, custodian or nominee. (3) The holder is a Person whose Securities are Restricted Securities due to the application of category 2, 4 or 6 of APP 7.
debug_context.target_text: Entry into Restriction Agreements and Application of Restriction. Unless the Regulator decides otherwise, the restrictions in categories 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8 and 9 of APP 7 do not apply in relation to a Listed Entity that: (1) qualifies for admission to the Official List pursuant to Rule 2.3.15; (2) has a track record of profitability or revenue acceptable to the Regulator; or (3) in the opinion of the Regulator, has tangible assets with a readily ascertainable value which constitute a substantial proportion of the total value of its assets.

question: If a Listed Entity qualifies for admission under Rule 2.3.15, when do APP 7 restriction categories stop applying, and in that same situation when can a Controller still avoid signing the Rule 9.6.2 Restriction Agreement because of the 10% asset-value test or because the holder is a trustee/custodian/nominee?
expected_answer: For a Listed Entity that qualifies for admission to the Official List under Rule 2.3.15, the restrictions in APP 7 categories 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8 and 9 are stated not to apply unless the Regulator decides otherwise. [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac] That category-based disapplication is separate from the rule on who must sign the Restriction Agreement referenced in Rule 9.6.2. [#SRC:afb239cd-ac67-4702-8e1d-e5293bccd010] Under the signing rule, a Controller does not have to be a party to the Restriction Agreement if any listed condition is met, including where the Restricted Security is worth less than 10% of the total asset value of the holder of the Restricted Securities (or of an intermediate entity through which the Controller has its interests). [#SRC:afb239cd-ac67-4702-8e1d-e5293bccd010] The Controller also does not need to sign if the holder (or that intermediate entity) is a trustee, custodian or nominee. [#SRC:afb239cd-ac67-4702-8e1d-e5293bccd010] So, even if the Regulator’s Rule 2.3.15-based carve-out means certain APP 7 restriction categories do not apply to the Listed Entity, the Controller’s ability to avoid being a party to the Rule 9.6.2 Restriction Agreement still depends on meeting one of the specific conditions such as the 10% test or the trustee/custodian/nominee status. [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac] [#SRC:afb239cd-ac67-4702-8e1d-e5293bccd010]

question: For an Applicant that is seeking to be treated as a Listed Entity, how should it align its constitutional arrangements so that it both operates in conformity with its constitution and also enables enforcement of Restriction Agreements?
expected_answer: An Applicant seeking to be treated as a Listed Entity should ensure its constitution both governs its operations and contains provisions that make Restriction Agreements enforceable. [#TGT:0011b198-f2c8-4274-b104-904e8a80b9d0] [#SRC:e54d518f-d9f5-40da-a031-b346bfca2a53] In practical terms, the Applicant’s constitutional framework must support two linked outcomes: (1) the Applicant operates in conformity with its constitution, and (2) the constitution includes the necessary provisions to allow enforcement of Restriction Agreements. [#TGT:0011b198-f2c8-4274-b104-904e8a80b9d0] [#SRC:e54d518f-d9f5-40da-a031-b346bfca2a53] This means the Applicant should review and, where needed, update its constitution so that the relevant constitutional provisions exist and can be applied in practice through the Applicant’s ongoing operations. [#SRC:e54d518f-d9f5-40da-a031-b346bfca2a53] [#TGT:0011b198-f2c8-4274-b104-904e8a80b9d0] The compliance linkage is that operating “in conformity with its constitution” is only meaningful for Restriction Agreements if the constitution itself contains provisions that permit their enforcement; otherwise, conformity would not deliver enforceability. [#TGT:0011b198-f2c8-4274-b104-904e8a80b9d0] [#SRC:e54d518f-d9f5-40da-a031-b346bfca2a53]

debug_context.source_text: Listed Entities are to ensure that provisions within their constitution (see Rule 2.3.1) allow for the enforcement of Restriction Agreements.
debug_context.target_text: Incorporation. An Applicant must be duly incorporated or otherwise validly established according to the relevant laws of its place of incorporation or establishment and be operating in conformity with its constitution.

question: If an Applicant is properly incorporated and must operate in line with its constitution, what does it need to make sure its constitution includes so that Restriction Agreements can actually be enforced once it is a Listed Entity?
expected_answer: It needs to ensure that its constitution contains provisions that allow Restriction Agreements to be enforced, and then operate in line with that constitution. [#SRC:e54d518f-d9f5-40da-a031-b346bfca2a53] [#TGT:0011b198-f2c8-4274-b104-904e8a80b9d0] The two requirements work together: the Applicant must be operating in conformity with its constitution, but that operational conformity will only support Restriction Agreements if the constitution has the right enforcement-enabling provisions in the first place. [#TGT:0011b198-f2c8-4274-b104-904e8a80b9d0] [#SRC:e54d518f-d9f5-40da-a031-b346bfca2a53] Accordingly, the Applicant should check its constitution for the necessary provisions and, if they are missing, amend the constitution so that enforcement of Restriction Agreements is possible, and then ensure its ongoing conduct follows the constitution as amended. [#SRC:e54d518f-d9f5-40da-a031-b346bfca2a53] [#TGT:0011b198-f2c8-4274-b104-904e8a80b9d0] This aligns the Applicant’s constitutional compliance obligation with the Listed Entity expectation that the constitution supports enforcement of Restriction Agreements. [#TGT:0011b198-f2c8-4274-b104-904e8a80b9d0] [#SRC:e54d518f-d9f5-40da-a031-b346bfca2a53]

question: For an Authorised Person in Category 1, 2 or 5 that is Managing a PSIA which is an Unrestricted PSIA, how do the applicable 25% exposure caps operate across (i) Financial Group Large Exposures (including the Financial Group's PSIAus) measured against the Group's Tier 1 and (ii) counterparty exposures measured against Capital Resources, including the financing-based 25%/40% thresholds?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person in Category 1, 2 or 5 must comply with a group-level ceiling on Financial Group Large Exposures and, if it is Managing an Unrestricted PSIA, must also comply with counterparty exposure limits that depend on how the exposure is financed. [#SRC:daaa6de1-3ef9-4148-ae13-789a1bb8a600] [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f] At the group level, the Authorised Person is prohibited from incurring any Financial Group Large Exposure (expressly including the Financial Group's PSIAus) above 25% of its Group's Tier 1, and this prohibition applies subject to IFR Rule 5.4.15. [#SRC:daaa6de1-3ef9-4148-ae13-789a1bb8a600] Separately, when Managing a PSIA that is an Unrestricted PSIA, the Authorised Person must ensure its Exposure to a Counterparty, Connected Counterparty, group of Closely Related Counterparties, or group of Connected Counterparties does not exceed specified percentages of its Capital Resources. [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f] The applicable percentage is 25% where the exposure is financed by its Capital Resources or Unrestricted PSIAs, and 40% where financed by an aggregate of its own Capital Resources and Unrestricted PSIAs. [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f] Accordingly, compliance requires monitoring both the Tier 1-based group cap (including PSIAus) and the Capital Resources-based counterparty caps (with financing determining whether 25% or 40% applies). [#SRC:daaa6de1-3ef9-4148-ae13-789a1bb8a600] [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f]

debug_context.source_text: Subject to IFR Rule 5.4.15, an Authorised Person in Category 1, 2 or 5 must not incur any Financial Group Large Exposure, including the Financial Group's PSIAus, that exceeds 25% of its Group's Tier 1.
debug_context.target_text: Exposure limits. An Authorised Person Managing a PSIA, which is an Unrestricted PSIA, must not have an Exposure to a Counterparty, Connected Counterparty, group of Closely Related Counterparties or to a group of Connected Counterparties that exceeds any one of the following percentages of its Capital Resources: (a) 25% if financed by its Capital Resources or Unrestricted PSIAs; or (b) 40% if financed by an aggregate of its own Capital Resources and Unrestricted PSIAs.

question: If an Authorised Person is in Category 1, 2 or 5 and it manages an Unrestricted PSIA, what are the two different “25%” limits it has to watch—one tied to the Group’s Tier 1 (including PSIAus) and one tied to Capital Resources for exposures to counterparties—and when can the counterparty limit be 40% instead?
expected_answer: In this situation, the Authorised Person has to track two separate limit frameworks that both include a 25% threshold but use different measurement bases and apply to different exposure types. [#SRC:daaa6de1-3ef9-4148-ae13-789a1bb8a600] [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f] First, because it is an Authorised Person in Category 1, 2 or 5, it must not incur any Financial Group Large Exposure above 25% of its Group’s Tier 1, and this group-level restriction explicitly includes the Financial Group’s PSIAus (and is stated to operate subject to IFR Rule 5.4.15). [#SRC:daaa6de1-3ef9-4148-ae13-789a1bb8a600] Second, because it is Managing a PSIA that is an Unrestricted PSIA, it must keep its Exposure to a Counterparty, Connected Counterparty, group of Closely Related Counterparties, or group of Connected Counterparties within limits expressed as percentages of its Capital Resources. [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f] Under that counterparty framework, the cap is 25% when the exposure is financed by its Capital Resources or Unrestricted PSIAs, but the cap can be 40% when the exposure is financed by an aggregate of its own Capital Resources and Unrestricted PSIAs. [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f] The practical takeaway is that the same firm may need to apply a Tier 1-based 25% group cap (including PSIAus) and, separately, a Capital Resources-based counterparty cap that is either 25% or 40% depending on financing. [#SRC:daaa6de1-3ef9-4148-ae13-789a1bb8a600] [#TGT:7521ffc6-250a-43ac-b7fd-68049d51519f]

question: In a Framework Contract, when the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, how may the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider contractually handle (i) charges for information requested by the Payment Service User and (ii) the applicability of the specific rule on “charges for information,” and what form must that agreement take?
expected_answer: The Payment Service Provider and the Payment Service User can contractually set charges for certain user-requested information, but they can also (if the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person) agree to disapply the specific “charges for information” rules, provided the agreement is in writing. [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] In particular, the parties may agree on charges for information supplied at the Payment Service User’s request when that information goes beyond what Section 19.2 requires, is delivered more often than Section 19.2 specifies, or is sent using a communication method different from what the Framework Contract specifies. [#TGT:18f42ca0-235a-47ac-9e8c-47bd6dd631d7] Separately, where the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider may agree in writing that Rules 19.2.16 and 19.2.17 (identified as covering charges for information) do not apply. [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] Read together, this means the parties can (a) price qualifying “additional/more frequent/alternative channel” information requests, and (b) if eligible, document in writing that the referenced “charges for information” rules are switched off for their relationship. [#TGT:18f42ca0-235a-47ac-9e8c-47bd6dd631d7] [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297]

debug_context.source_text: Where the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider may agree in writing the following Rules do not apply: (a) Rules 19.2.16 and 19.2.17 (charges for information); (b) Rule 19.10.1 (3) and (4) (withdrawal of consent); (c) Rule 19.18.1 (evidence on authentication and execution); (d) Rule 19.20.1 (Payer or Payee’s liability for unauthorised transactions); (e) Rules 19.17.1 and 19.17.2 (requests for refund); (f) Rule 19.14.3 (revocation of a Payment Order); (g) Rule 19.21.2 (defective execution of Payer-initiated transactions); (h) Rule 19.21.3 (defective execution of Payee-initiated transactions); (i) Rule 19.21.5 (liability for charges); and the parties may agree that a different time period applies concerning unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions for the purposes of Rule 19.17.1.
debug_context.target_text: The Payment Service Provider and the Payment Service User may agree on charges for any information which is provided at the request of the Payment Service User where such information is: (a) additional to the information required to be provided or made available by Section 19.2; (b) provided more frequently than is specified in Section 19.2; or (c) transmitted by means of communication other than those specified in the Framework Contract.

question: If the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, can the Payment Service Provider still charge for extra information the user asks for (like information beyond Section 19.2 or sent in a different way than the Framework Contract), and can the parties also switch off the “charges for information” rules—what must they do to make that happen?
expected_answer: Yes—there are two related contracting options, and the second one depends on the Payment Service User not being a Natural Person. [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] First, the Payment Service Provider and the Payment Service User may agree on charges for information that the Payment Service User requests when the information is extra compared with what Section 19.2 requires, is provided more often than Section 19.2 sets out, or is delivered using a communication method other than the one specified in the Framework Contract. [#TGT:18f42ca0-235a-47ac-9e8c-47bd6dd631d7] Second, if the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider may agree in writing that Rules 19.2.16 and 19.2.17 (the rules identified as dealing with charges for information) do not apply. [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] Putting these together, the parties can either (a) keep the information-charging approach and set the price for those qualifying requests, or (b) where eligible, formally document in writing that the specific “charges for information” rules are not applicable between them. [#TGT:18f42ca0-235a-47ac-9e8c-47bd6dd631d7] [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297]

question: When the FSRA expects a "substantial additional" regulatory burden or costs/effort in dealing with an application or ongoing supervision, what should the Applicant/Authorised Person do regarding fee implications, and how does this relate to the Regulator’s ability to require a supplementary fee (including in the example of migrating an MTF to become a conventional "Securities" Recognised Investment Exchange)?
expected_answer: Where a matter creates a “substantial additional” burden for the FSRA/Regulator, the fee outcome can extend beyond standard charges, and the Applicant/Authorised Person should proactively engage early on fee implications. [#SRC:43df6a6a-29a3-4dca-8203-57b209ce85cc] Specifically, the FSRA indicates it retains the ability to impose additional fees when a “substantial additional” regulatory burden is placed on it, and it highlights migration of an MTF into a conventional “Securities” Recognised Investment Exchange as an example of such a circumstance. [#SRC:43df6a6a-29a3-4dca-8203-57b209ce85cc] In parallel, the Regulator’s supplementary-fee power is framed around situations where it expects to incur substantial additional costs or to expend substantial additional effort in handling an application, authorisation, filing, or in conducting on-going supervision. [#TGT:64a0df5a-e946-4496-9fd3-244340c2a080] Taken together, the practical compliance step is that, when the Applicant/Authorised Person anticipates a scenario like an MTF migration (or any application/supervision activity likely to drive substantial additional effort), they should discuss fee implications with the FSRA as early as practicable, because the Regulator may respond by requiring a supplementary fee reflecting that additional cost/effort. [#SRC:43df6a6a-29a3-4dca-8203-57b209ce85cc] [#TGT:64a0df5a-e946-4496-9fd3-244340c2a080]

In such circumstances, including the migration of an MTF to become a conventional ‘Securities’ Recognised Investment Exchange, the FSRA recommends that the Applicant/Authorised Person discuss FEE implications with the FSRA as early as practicable.

question: If a Person’s application or ongoing supervision will take the Regulator a lot of extra work, what kind of extra fee can be charged, and what does the FSRA recommend the Applicant/Authorised Person do (for example, if an MTF is migrating to a conventional "Securities" Recognised Investment Exchange)?
expected_answer: If the Regulator expects that dealing with a matter will require substantial additional costs or substantial additional effort, it can require the Person to pay a supplementary fee. [#TGT:64a0df5a-e946-4496-9fd3-244340c2a080] The FSRA also signals that it keeps the right to impose additional fees when a “substantial additional” regulatory burden is imposed on it, and it gives the migration of an MTF to become a conventional “Securities” Recognised Investment Exchange as an example of a situation that can trigger this type of fee treatment. [#SRC:43df6a6a-29a3-4dca-8203-57b209ce85cc] Because these extra-fee tools are tied to the same practical driver—substantial additional burden/cost/effort—the FSRA recommends that the Applicant/Authorised Person raise and discuss fee implications with the FSRA as early as practicable when such a scenario is in view. [#SRC:43df6a6a-29a3-4dca-8203-57b209ce85cc] This early discussion is the stated action point for the Applicant/Authorised Person, while the supplementary-fee concept explains the type of charge the Regulator may require when the work involved in an application, authorisation, filing, or on-going supervision is materially higher than usual. question: When assessing whether a Digital Settlement Facility (DSF) has satisfactory arrangements to secure the timely discharge of rights and liabilities under MIR Rule 4.3.3, how should the FSRA treat a situation where a Recognised Clearing House is unable to arrange settlement for a specific transaction, and what DSF arrangements should still be evaluated in that context?
expected_answer: A single instance where a Recognised Clearing House cannot arrange settlement for a particular transaction should not, by itself, be treated as a compliance failure against the applicable recognition standard; that inability alone does not mean the Recognised Clearing House has failed to comply with the Recognition Requirement. [#TGT:a15123d3-b822-401d-9551-e8759dd9e84e] In parallel, when the FSRA is determining under MIR Rule 4.3.3 whether a DSF has satisfactory arrangements to secure the timely discharge of parties’ rights and liabilities, the FSRA should still evaluate the DSF’s own clearing-and-settlement framework and operational controls rather than relying solely on the outcome of one transaction. [#SRC:246aa96d-4111-4210-b1cd-e3e5022eea36] This evaluation can include the DSF’s rules and practices for clearing and settlement (including any arrangements with another Person to provide those services), trade-matching arrangements to ensure agreement on trade details, and (where relevant) delivery and payment arrangements across jurisdictions. [#SRC:246aa96d-4111-4210-b1cd-e3e5022eea36] The FSRA may also consider the DSF’s procedures to detect and address a Member’s (or participant’s) failure to settle, its arrangements to take action to settle when a Member (or participant) does not, and its monitoring of Members’ settlement performance, including Default Rules and default procedures where appropriate. [#SRC:246aa96d-4111-4210-b1cd-e3e5022eea36]

debug_context.source_text: DIGITAL SECURITIES SETTLEMENT Digital Settlement Facilities (DSFs) Pursuant to MIR Rule 4.3.3, in determining whether there are satisfactory arrangements for securing the timely discharge of the rights and liabilities of the parties to transactions, the FSRA may have regard to the DSF’s: a) rules and practices relating to clearing and settlement, including its arrangements with another Person for the provision of clearing and settlement services; b) arrangements for matching trades and ensuring that the parties are in agreement about trade details; c) where relevant, arrangements for making deliveries and payments, in all relevant jurisdictions; d) procedures to detect and deal with the failure of a Member (or participants) to settle in accordance with its rules; e) arrangements for taking action to settle a trade if a Member (or participant) does not settle in accordance with its rules; f) arrangements for monitoring its Members’ settlement performance; and g) where appropriate, Default Rules and default procedures.
debug_context.target_text: A Recognised Clearing House will not be regarded as failing to comply with the Recognition Requirement merely because it is unable to arrange for a specific transaction to be settled.

question: If a Recognised Clearing House can’t get one specific transaction settled, does that automatically mean it failed the Recognition Requirement, and what DSF features does the FSRA still look at under MIR Rule 4.3.3 to judge timely settlement arrangements?
expected_answer: No—being unable to arrange settlement for a particular transaction, on its own, does not mean a Recognised Clearing House is treated as failing to comply with the Recognition Requirement. [#TGT:a15123d3-b822-401d-9551-e8759dd9e84e] Even in that situation, the FSRA’s assessment of a DSF under MIR Rule 4.3.3 focuses on whether the DSF has satisfactory arrangements to secure the timely discharge of the rights and liabilities of transaction parties. [#SRC:246aa96d-4111-4210-b1cd-e3e5022eea36] To make that determination, the FSRA may look at practical elements of the DSF’s design and operations, including its clearing and settlement rules and practices and any arrangements it has with another Person to provide clearing and settlement services. [#SRC:246aa96d-4111-4210-b1cd-e3e5022eea36] The FSRA may also consider how the DSF matches trades and confirms the parties agree on trade details, and (where relevant) how it handles deliveries and payments in the jurisdictions involved. [#SRC:246aa96d-4111-4210-b1cd-e3e5022eea36] In addition, the FSRA can review the DSF’s tools for detecting and dealing with settlement failures by a Member (or participant), its arrangements to take action to settle when a Member (or participant) does not, and its monitoring of Members’ settlement performance, including Default Rules and default procedures where appropriate. [#SRC:246aa96d-4111-4210-b1cd-e3e5022eea36]

question: For an MTF (using Virtual Assets), which notification obligations drawn from the Recognised Body notification table must it treat as applicable under COBS Rule 17.7.4, and what timing and information must be provided if it proposes to appoint or elect a Person as a Key Individual?
expected_answer: An MTF (using Virtual Assets) must treat certain notification requirements that apply to Recognised Investment Exchanges under MIR Rules 5.1 and 5.3, and certain information requirements under MIR Rule 5.4.1, as additional requirements that also apply to the MTF. [#SRC:f1ec727b-52fd-409e-a8e4-bf9149a68fe8] Using the Recognised Body notification table as the operational detail for what a notification looks like in practice, if the MTF proposes to appoint or elect a Person as a Key Individual, the notification must be made at least 30 days before the appointment or election becomes effective, and it must include the Person’s name, date of birth, and a description of the responsibilities in the post. [#TGT:4089ddbd-ee76-45ed-a673-48384237c975] This linkage matters because COBS Rule 17.7.4 extends specified RIE/MIR notification and information requirements to MTFs using Virtual Assets, so the MTF should plan its governance changes (such as Key Individual appointments) to meet the advance-notice timing and content expectations reflected in the table. [#SRC:f1ec727b-52fd-409e-a8e4-bf9149a68fe8] In addition, the MTF must also comply with any other applicable notification requirements, including those referenced in paragraph 29 of the Guidance regarding the use of additional Accepted Virtual Assets. [#SRC:f1ec727b-52fd-409e-a8e4-bf9149a68fe8]

debug_context.source_text: MULTILATERAL TRADING FACILITIES AND VIRTUAL ASSETS Guidance in relation to Applicable Rules COBS Rule 17.7.4 specifies that certain notification requirements applicable to Recognised Investment Exchanges under MIR Rules 5.1, 5.3 and certain information requirements under MIR Rule 5.4.1 apply to MTFs (using Virtual Assets). These are additional requirements applicable to MTFs using Virtual Assets. MTFs using Virtual Assets will also need to comply with any other applicable notification requirements, including those set out in paragraph 29 of this Guidance in relation to the use of additional Accepted Virtual Assets.

question: If an MTF (using Virtual Assets) has a Key Individual who resigns, what does COBS Rule 17.7.4 imply about applying the Recognised Body notification approach, and what timing and information does the table require for that resignation notice?
expected_answer: COBS Rule 17.7.4 makes certain notification requirements that apply to Recognised Investment Exchanges under MIR Rules 5.1 and 5.3, and certain information requirements under MIR Rule 5.4.1, apply to MTFs (using Virtual Assets) as additional requirements. [#SRC:f1ec727b-52fd-409e-a8e4-bf9149a68fe8] Reading that extension together with the Recognised Body notification table, a resignation (or cessation) of a Key Individual is an event that must be notified as soon as practicable, and the information required for that notice is the Key Individual’s name. [#TGT:4089ddbd-ee76-45ed-a673-48384237c975] The practical compliance outcome is that an MTF using Virtual Assets should treat Key Individual departures as a notifiable governance event and be ready to send a prompt notice containing the required identifier, rather than waiting for periodic reporting. [#TGT:4089ddbd-ee76-45ed-a673-48384237c975] Separately, the MTF must also comply with any other applicable notification requirements, including those referenced in paragraph 29 of the Guidance concerning the use of additional Accepted Virtual Assets, so the MTF should check whether the resignation coincides with any other notifiable changes in its Virtual Asset arrangements. [#SRC:f1ec727b-52fd-409e-a8e4-bf9149a68fe8]

debug_context.source_text: MULTILATERAL TRADING FACILITIES AND VIRTUAL ASSETS Guidance in relation to Applicable Rules COBS Rule 17.7.4 specifies that certain notification requirements applicable to Recognised Investment Exchanges under MIR Rules 5.1, 5.3 and certain information requirements under MIR Rule 5.4.1 apply to MTFs (using Virtual Assets). These are additional requirements applicable to MTFs using Virtual Assets. MTFs using Virtual Assets will also need to comply with any other applicable notification requirements, including those set out in paragraph 29 of this Guidance in relation to the use of additional Accepted Virtual Assets.

question: For an ADGM Green Fund, when does the Fund Manager have to appoint a third party to attest compliance with the Green Fund Investment Requirement, and how does that obligation change if the Fund is a Qualified Investor Fund where the Fund Manager elects to self-attest, or if all Eligible Green Fund Assets held as Fund Property are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark?
expected_answer: The Fund Manager of an ADGM Green Fund must generally appoint a third party to attest, on an ongoing basis and at least annually, that it complies with the Green Fund Investment Requirement, but this obligation is limited in scope and can be displaced by specified alternatives. [#SRC:900d63ac-47c0-453a-91f1-79eaee1ab8f1] The third-party appointment requirement applies only to the portion of the Eligible Green Fund Property that is invested in assets aligned with an Acceptable Green Taxonomy (i.e., the taxonomy-aligned portion described in connection with Rule 20.2.3(a)). [#SRC:900d63ac-47c0-453a-91f1-79eaee1ab8f1] However, the Fund Manager is not required to appoint a third party if the Fund is a Qualified Investor Fund and the Fund Manager elects to provide the attestation itself, in which case the attestation function is performed by the Fund Manager rather than an external party. [#TGT:700ed6a6-3a4a-49b8-8bae-3980c9d36df0] Separately, if all Eligible Green Fund Assets held as Fund Property are included in or otherwise track an EU Paris Aligned Benchmark (as referenced with Rule 20.2.3(b)), then no attestation is required at all, removing both the third-party and self-attestation pathways for that scenario. [#TGT:700ed6a6-3a4a-49b8-8bae-3980c9d36df0]

question: When determining the Credit RWA of an Authorised Person as a sum of component RWAs, how should the Authorised Person delineate what is included in the RWA calculation for Credit Risk Exposures (CR Exposures) versus what is carved out because it is treated as securitisation or Trading Book exposure, including any Traditional Securitisation risk-transference recognition condition?
expected_answer: In calculating Credit RWA, an Authorised Person must aggregate three distinct RWA components: (i) RWA for all Credit Risk Exposures (CR Exposures), (ii) RWA for all securitisation Exposures (SE Exposures), and (iii) RWA for Counterparty Risk Exposures, each computed under the specified rule sets for those components. [#SRC:5e5b0814-b3c0-441d-b92e-c7fe290a8020] For the CR Exposure component specifically, the Authorised Person must include both on-balance sheet assets and off-balance sheet items in the CR Exposure RWA calculation. [#TGT:cb5e6ab2-3cae-450b-87c6-acb11128d3f0] However, to keep the CR Exposure component distinct from the other Credit RWA components, the Authorised Person must exclude from CR Exposure RWA: (a) any SE Exposure (which instead belongs in the securitisation RWA component of Credit RWA), (b) any securitised Exposure that qualifies for recognition of risk transference in a Traditional Securitisation under Section 4.14, and (c) any Exposure classified as a position or instrument in the Trading Book under Section A2.1. [#TGT:cb5e6ab2-3cae-450b-87c6-acb11128d3f0] This delineation ensures the CR Exposure RWA is calculated on the intended population while the excluded items are addressed through the separate securitisation and other relevant RWA calculations that together form Credit RWA. [#SRC:5e5b0814-b3c0-441d-b92e-c7fe290a8020]
