expected_answer: An Authorised Person’s Credit RWA is built by summing separate RWA amounts for (1) all Credit Risk Exposures (CR Exposures), (2) all securitisation Exposures (SE Exposures), and (3) Counterparty Risk Exposures, with each part calculated under the referenced rules and sections for that category. [#SRC:5e5b0814-b3c0-441d-b92e-c7fe290a8020] For the CR Exposures part, the Authorised Person must count both any on-balance sheet asset and any off-balance sheet item when calculating RWA for CR Exposures. [#TGT:cb5e6ab2-3cae-450b-87c6-acb11128d3f0] At the same time, the CR Exposures calculation must not include certain exposures because they are treated elsewhere within the overall Credit RWA framework: it must exclude any SE Exposure, and it must also exclude any securitised Exposure that meets the Section 4.14 requirements for recognising risk transference in a Traditional Securitisation. [#TGT:cb5e6ab2-3cae-450b-87c6-acb11128d3f0] In addition, any Exposure that is classified as a position or instrument in the Trading Book under Section A2.1 is excluded from the CR Exposures RWA calculation. [#TGT:cb5e6ab2-3cae-450b-87c6-acb11128d3f0] Those exclusions help keep the CR Exposures component aligned with the separate securitisation and other components that together make up Credit RWA. question: For an Authorised Person that falls within the categories covered by the Chapter, which specific categories are identified as having different treatment regarding use of the Simplified Approach under Section 4.7, and what is the nature of that differentiation?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person in Category 1, 2, 3A or 5 is within the scope of the Chapter. [#TGT:0e6645d8-2aef-402c-b9d3-94e8ac522d5d] Within that covered population, the differentiated treatment described applies specifically to Category 3A firms and Category 2 firms in relation to the Simplified Approach under Section 4.7. [#SRC:082e5005-d051-49ac-86ab-930ae5cfbe2f] The differentiation is that Category 3A firms are required to use the Simplified Approach under Section 4.7, whereas Category 2 firms are permitted (but not required) to use it. [#SRC:082e5005-d051-49ac-86ab-930ae5cfbe2f] By contrast, while Category 1 and Category 5 are included in the Chapter’s scope, the differentiated Simplified Approach rule described does not assign them a “must” or “may” position in the same way as it does for Categories 3A and 2. [#TGT:0e6645d8-2aef-402c-b9d3-94e8ac522d5d] Accordingly, when assessing whether the Simplified Approach under Section 4.7 is mandatory or optional, the key step is to confirm that the entity is an Authorised Person within the Chapter’s covered categories and then apply the specific Category 3A (mandatory) versus Category 2 (optional) treatment. [#TGT:0e6645d8-2aef-402c-b9d3-94e8ac522d5d] [#SRC:082e5005-d051-49ac-86ab-930ae5cfbe2f]

[#SRC:082e5005-d051-49ac-86ab-930ae5cfbe2f] The Chapter’s scope statement also includes Category 1 and Category 5, but the differentiated Simplified Approach rule described only specifies “must” for Category 3A and “may” for Category 2, so you should not treat Category 1 or Category 5 as automatically falling into either of those two positions based on these passages alone. question: When a Mining Reporting Entity discloses a Production Target in relation to its Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or a material Mining Project (including multiple Mining Projects that are material together), under what conditions may a subsequent disclosure omit the information otherwise required by Rule 11.8.3, and what additional proximate statements are required where the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources or is based in part on an Exploration Target?
expected_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity may disclose a Production Target in relation to its Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or a material Mining Project (including two or more Mining Projects that are material together), and if it has already made a disclosure under Rule 11.8.2, a later Production Target disclosure in that context can omit the information that Rule 11.8.3 would otherwise require, but only if specific conditions are met. [#TGT:9ecca3cb-1427-4279-b104-2bb3d2f1d7f6] [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] To rely on this omission pathway, the subsequent disclosure must (i) point back to the earlier disclosure that complied with Rule 11.8.3 and (ii) confirm that the material assumptions used for the original Production Target continue to apply and have not materially changed. [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] In addition, if the Production Target is wholly based on Inferred Mineral Resources, the subsequent disclosure must include an at least equally prominent and proximate statement about the Production Target that corresponds to the statement described in Rule 11.8.3(5)(d). [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] If the Production Target is based in part on an Exploration Target, it must likewise include an at least equally prominent and proximate statement corresponding to Rule 11.8.3(7)(b). [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef]

debug_context.source_text: If a Mining Reporting Entity made a disclosure under Rule 11.8.2, then any subsequent disclosure in relation to a Production Target need not include the information required to be disclosed by Rule 11.8.3 where the subsequent disclosure: (1) references the earlier disclosure that was in compliance with Rule 11.8.3; (2) contains a statement confirming that all the material assumptions in the initial disclosure, upon which the Production Target is based continue to apply and have not materially changed; (3) if the Production Target is wholly based upon Inferred Mineral Resources, includes an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement about the disclosed Production Target to the effect of the statement set out in Rule 11.8.3(5)(d); and (4) if the Production Target is based in part upon an Exploration Target, includes an at least equally prominent, and proximate, statement about the disclosed Production Target to the effect of the statement set out in Rule 11.8.3(7)(b).
debug_context.target_text: A Production Target may be disclosed by a Mining Reporting Entity in relation to: (1) the Mining Reporting Entity’s Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings; or (2) a material Mining Project of the Mining Reporting Entity (or two or more Mining Projects which, together, are material).

expected_answer: For a Production Target that is disclosed in relation to a Mining Reporting Entity’s Mineral Resources and Ore Reserves Holdings or a material Mining Project (including multiple Mining Projects that are material together), a later update does not have to repeat the information normally required by Rule 11.8.3 if the Mining Reporting Entity previously made a disclosure under Rule 11.8.2 and the later update satisfies the specified conditions. [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] If the Production Target is entirely based on Inferred Mineral Resources, the update must add a statement placed close to the Production Target and with at least equal prominence, matching the type of statement described in Rule 11.8.3(5)(d). [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef] If the Production Target is partly based on an Exploration Target, it must similarly include a proximate and equally prominent statement matching the one described in Rule 11.8.3(7)(b). [#SRC:9e79b83f-77f1-4597-a010-cd1013d0c6ef]

question: For a Low-Value Payment Instrument (as referred to under Rule 19.3.1) that is governed by a Framework Contract, what information must the Payment Service Provider give the Payer about the Payment Service, and how does that obligation apply given that such instruments can be used in relation to both Payment Accounts and Stored Value?
expected_answer: For a Low-Value Payment Instrument governed by a Framework Contract, the Payment Service Provider is not required to provide the broader general information otherwise compelled under Section 19.2 for Framework Contracts; instead, it must provide the Payer with information focused on the main characteristics of the Payment Service. [#TGT:419d782f-001f-4e45-bcc1-903132223a21] This streamlined disclosure approach applies in the Low-Value Payment Instrument context even though the instruments referred to under Rule 19.3.1 cover use in relation to both Payment Accounts and Stored Value, so the Payment Service Provider should frame the “main characteristics” information to match how the instrument is used in those contexts. [#SRC:9098e83a-9451-476e-8f4a-60bedc364e14] The required “main characteristics” information includes: how the Payment Instrument can be used; the Payer’s liability (as set out in Rule 19.20.1); charges levied; any other material information the Payer needs to make an informed decision; and where the general information specified in Rule 19.2.1 is made available in an easily accessible manner. [#TGT:419d782f-001f-4e45-bcc1-903132223a21] In practice, because the same Low-Value Payment Instrument category spans both Payment Accounts and Stored Value, the Payment Service Provider should ensure the usage description and any material decision-making information are presented in a way that is meaningful for the relevant mode of use. [#SRC:9098e83a-9451-476e-8f4a-60bedc364e14]

debug_context.source_text: Low-Value Payment Instruments referred to under Rule 19.3.1 encompass those used in relation to both Payment Accounts and Stored Value.
debug_context.target_text: In respect of Low-Value Payment Instruments governed by a Framework Contract: (a) Section 19.2 compelling disclosure under the terms of a Framework Contract of general information concerning the Payment Service Provider and the relevant Payment Service does not apply and the Payment Service Provider is only required to provide the Payer with information about the main characteristics of the Payment Service, including but not limited to: (i) the way in which the Payment Instrument can be used; (ii) the liability of the Payer, as set out in Rule 19.20.1; (iii) charges levied; (iv) any other material information the Payer might need to make an informed decision; and (v) an indication of where the general information concerning the Framework Contract specified in Rule 19.2.1 is made available in an easily accessible manner; (b) the parties may agree that information to be provided to a Payer or Payee concerning individual Payment Transactions as specified in Rules 19.2.13 and 19.2.14 do not apply and instead: (i) the Payment Service Provider must provide or make available a reference enabling the Payment Service User to identify the Payment Transaction, the amount of the Payment Transaction and any charges payable in respect of the Payment Transaction; (ii) in the case of several Payment Transactions of the same kind made to the same Payee, the Payment Service Provider must provide or make available to the Payment Service User information about the total amount of the Payment Transactions and any charges for those Payment Transactions; or (iii) where the Payment Instrument is used anonymously or the Payment Service Provider is not otherwise technically able to provide or make available the information specified in (i) or (ii), the Payment Service Provider must enable the Payer to verify the amount of Money stored.

question: Where the parties have agreed to disapply the individual Payment Transaction information requirements for a Low-Value Payment Instrument governed by a Framework Contract, what alternative transaction information must the Payment Service Provider provide or make available, and what is the fallback requirement when the instrument is used anonymously—particularly in light of the fact that Low-Value Payment Instruments under Rule 19.3.1 include instruments used for Stored Value?
expected_answer: If, for a Low-Value Payment Instrument governed by a Framework Contract, the parties agree that the usual information for individual Payment Transactions (as specified in Rules 19.2.13 and 19.2.14) will not apply, the Payment Service Provider must follow the alternative information approach set out for such instruments. [#TGT:419d782f-001f-4e45-bcc1-903132223a21] Under that alternative approach, the Payment Service Provider must provide or make available a reference that enables the Payment Service User to identify the Payment Transaction, the amount of the Payment Transaction, and any charges payable for that Payment Transaction. [#TGT:419d782f-001f-4e45-bcc1-903132223a21] If there are several Payment Transactions of the same kind made to the same Payee, the Payment Service Provider must instead provide or make available information about the total amount of those Payment Transactions and any charges for them. [#TGT:419d782f-001f-4e45-bcc1-903132223a21] Where the Payment Instrument is used anonymously, or the Payment Service Provider is not technically able to provide or make available the information described above, the Payment Service Provider must enable the Payer to verify the amount of Money stored. [#TGT:419d782f-001f-4e45-bcc1-903132223a21] This fallback is especially relevant because Low-Value Payment Instruments referred to under Rule 19.3.1 include instruments used in relation to Stored Value, making verification of stored Money a necessary substitute when transaction-level reporting cannot be delivered. [#SRC:9098e83a-9451-476e-8f4a-60bedc364e14]

question: When an Authorised Person prepares or publishes Investment Research while providing any Regulated Activities, what conflict-of-interest identification steps must it take under Principle 7 (Rule 2.2.7), and which categories of relationships must be considered in addition to maintaining adequate procedures and controls for the research output?
expected_answer: An Authorised Person preparing or publishing Investment Research must both maintain adequate procedures and controls for that research and take reasonable steps to identify actual or potential conflicts of interest, with the identification exercise aligned to Principle 7 as outlined in Rule 2.2.7. [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759] [#TGT:fce44023-cea8-42fb-9c0f-fee8b1ddf319] In practice, the conflict-identification duty applies to conflicts that arise or may arise in the course of the Authorised Person providing any Regulated Activities, so the Authorised Person should assess conflicts connected to those activities even where the immediate deliverable is Investment Research. [#TGT:fce44023-cea8-42fb-9c0f-fee8b1ddf319] The categories that must be considered when identifying conflicts include: (i) conflicts between the Authorised Person (including its managers, Employees and Clients, and any person directly or indirectly linked to them by control) and a Client; and (ii) conflicts between one Client and another Client. [#TGT:fce44023-cea8-42fb-9c0f-fee8b1ddf319] Separately, beyond identification, the Authorised Person is required to prevent or manage conflicts once identified, and this sits alongside the requirement to have adequate procedures and controls for Investment Research preparation or publication. [#SRC:078b569b-05f5-4aef-9be3-3789edcff759]

question: When assessing potential contravention of section 92(2) (Insider Dealing), how should a firm distinguish between (i) a person merely executing their own pre-formed intention to deal and (ii) dealing on the basis of “Inside Information” for Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, or Accepted Spot Commodities (including Related Instruments that are not Commodity Derivatives)?
expected_answer: A person’s execution of their own pre-formed intention to deal, by itself, is treated as not breaching section 92(2) (Insider Dealing); the compliance focus therefore shifts to whether the dealing is instead connected to “Inside Information” as defined for the relevant instruments. [#SRC:78dea780-e39f-407d-855f-5cb46c1b30d7] For Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, Accepted Spot Commodities, and Related Instruments that are not Commodity Derivatives, “Inside Information” is limited to information that is precise, not generally available, and that relates (directly or indirectly) to one or more Reporting Entities or Issuers or to the instruments themselves, and that would likely move the price significantly if it became generally available. [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977] In practical terms, the firm should (1) confirm the person formed an intention to deal before dealing and recognize that carrying out that intention alone is not the contravention trigger, [#SRC:78dea780-e39f-407d-855f-5cb46c1b30d7] and (2) separately test whether any information influencing the trade meets all elements of the “Inside Information” definition (precise, non-public, relevant to Reporting Entities/Issuers or the instruments, and price-significant). [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977] This linkage matters because the “own intention” concept addresses the act of dealing, while the “Inside Information” definition supplies the characteristics of information that could make dealing problematic under an insider dealing analysis. [#SRC:78dea780-e39f-407d-855f-5cb46c1b30d7] [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977]

question: If someone plans to trade a Financial Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset, or an Accepted Spot Commodity, when is simply following their own plan not enough to count as insider dealing, and what extra “Inside Information” features would you check for (including for Related Instruments that are not Commodity Derivatives)?
expected_answer: Following a person’s own plan to trade—where they formed the intention to deal before they traded—does not, by itself, amount to contravening section 92(2) (Insider Dealing). [#SRC:78dea780-e39f-407d-855f-5cb46c1b30d7] To decide whether there is a remaining insider dealing concern, you would then check whether the trade is connected to “Inside Information” as defined for Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, Accepted Spot Commodities, or Related Instruments that are not Commodity Derivatives. [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977] Under that definition, the information must be precise and not generally available, it must relate (directly or indirectly) to one or more Reporting Entities or Issuers or to the instruments themselves, and it must be the kind of information that would likely have a significant effect on price if it became generally available. [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977] So the combined approach is: treat “carrying out of own trading intention” as not automatically triggering the insider dealing contravention, [#SRC:78dea780-e39f-407d-855f-5cb46c1b30d7] but still evaluate whether any relevant non-public, precise, price-significant information about Reporting Entities/Issuers or the instruments is involved, because that is what qualifies as “Inside Information” for these products. [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977]

question: For a Payment Service User that is not a Natural Person, how does a written agreement with the Payment Service Provider to apply a different time period for unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions (for the purposes of Rule 19.17.1) interact with the Chapter condition that redress is available only if the Payment Service User notifies the Payment Service Provider without undue delay and no later than twelve months after the debit date?
expected_answer: A Payment Service User’s ability to obtain redress under the Chapter is conditioned on giving notice to its Payment Service Provider without undue delay and, at the latest, within twelve months of the debit date once it becomes aware of an unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transaction. [#TGT:9e69f77e-6b54-411e-bb70-41a02ee9e6cd] Separately, where the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider may, by written agreement, set a different time period concerning unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions for the purposes of Rule 19.17.1. [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] Read together, this means the Chapter’s redress entitlement hinges on timely notification (including the twelve‑month outer limit stated in the Chapter), while the parties also have an express ability—limited to the Rule 19.17.1 context—to contract for a different time period addressing unauthorised or incorrectly executed transactions when the user is not a Natural Person. [#TGT:9e69f77e-6b54-411e-bb70-41a02ee9e6cd] [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] In practice, the Payment Service User should (i) confirm it is not a Natural Person and that any variation is in writing, and (ii) ensure its notification to the Payment Service Provider satisfies the Chapter’s notice condition while also aligning with any agreed alternative time period applicable for Rule 19.17.1. [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] [#TGT:9e69f77e-6b54-411e-bb70-41a02ee9e6cd]

debug_context.source_text: Where the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider may agree in writing the following Rules do not apply: (a) Rules 19.2.16 and 19.2.17 (charges for information); (b) Rule 19.10.1 (3) and (4) (withdrawal of consent); (c) Rule 19.18.1 (evidence on authentication and execution); (d) Rule 19.20.1 (Payer or Payee’s liability for unauthorised transactions); (e) Rules 19.17.1 and 19.17.2 (requests for refund); (f) Rule 19.14.3 (revocation of a Payment Order); (g) Rule 19.21.2 (defective execution of Payer-initiated transactions); (h) Rule 19.21.3 (defective execution of Payee-initiated transactions); (i) Rule 19.21.5 (liability for charges); and the parties may agree that a different time period applies concerning unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions for the purposes of Rule 19.17.1.

question: If the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person and it has a written deal with the Payment Service Provider to use a different time limit for unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions (for Rule 19.17.1), what notice timing does the Payment Service User still need to meet to be entitled to redress under the Chapter?
